You underſtand it, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: So ſhall you anon maſter Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Your friend and Jonathan Buzzard kind gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What excellent luck had we, friend Buzzard, to
meet with thee, juſt as thy Maſter caſt thee off.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Juſt Sir, as I was going I know not whither:
And now I am arrived at juſt I know not where. Tis a
rich room, this. Is it not Goldſmiths hall.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: It is a Tavern man—And here comes the wine.
Fill boy—and her's to thee friend, a hearty draft to
chear thee—fill again boy—There, drink it off.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Off with it man—hang ſorrow, chear thy heart.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: And truly ti's the beſt chear that ere I taſted.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Come taſt it better, her's another to thee.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: —And truly this was better then the firſt.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Then try a third. That may be beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: —And truly, ſo it is—how many ſorts of wine
May a vintner bring in one pot together?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: By Bacchus Mr. Buzzard, that's a ſubtil queſtion.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Bacchus! whoſe that I pray?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: A great friend of the vintners, and maſter of their company indeed.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I was never in all my life ſo far in a tavern before.
What comforts have I loſt.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now he begins to talk.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: Nor ever was in all my two and twenty years under that Babilouian Tyrant Quicks ands, ſo far as a Vintners bar but thrice.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: But thrice in all that time?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: Truly but thrice Sir. And the firſt time was to fetch a jill of ſack for my Maſter, to make a friend of his drink, that joyned with him in a purchaſe of ſixteen thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: I, there was thriſt. More wine boy. A pottle and a beer bowl.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: The ſecond time was for a penny pot of Muſcadine, which he drank all himſelf with an egge upon his wedding morning.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: And to much purpoſe, it ſeem'd by his wives running away.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: The third and laſt time was for half a pint of ſack upon his wedding night, of later memory; and I ſhall nere forget it, that riotous wedding night: when Hell broke looſe, and all the devils danced at our houſe, which made my Maſter mad, whoſe raving made my miſtriſs run away, whoſe running away was the cauſe of my turning away. O me, poor maſterleſs wretch that I am.—O—

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Hang thy maſter, here's a full bowl to his confuſion.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I thank you. Let it come Sir, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Think no more of Maſters, friends are better then Maſters.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: And you are all my friends kind gentlemen, I found it before in your money when my Maſter (whoſe confuſion I have drunk) took your Mortgages; And now I find it in your wine. I thank you kind gentlemen ſtill. O how I love kind Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That ſhewes thou art of gentle blood thy ſelf, friend Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Yes friend—Shall I call you friend?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: By all means, all of us.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p:
Why then, all friends, I am a gentleman, though ſpoild i'che breeding. The Buzzards are all gentlemen,
We came in with the Conqueror. Our name (as the French has it) is Beau deſert; which ſignifies—Friends, what does it ſignifie?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: It ſignifies, that you deſerv'd fairly at your maſters hands, like a Gentleman, and a Buzzard as you were, and he turn'd you away moſt beaſtly like a ſwine, as he is. And now here is a health to him, that firſt finds his wife, and ſends her home with a bouncing boy in her belly for him to father.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Ile pledge that: and then Ile tell you a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Well ſaid friend; up with tha • , and then out with thy ſecret.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I will friend. And tother two friends, here's upon the ſame.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: I hope he will ſhew us a way, out of the bottom of his bowl to find his Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: This fellow was happily found.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: This was an excellent draught.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: But the ſeeret, friend, out with that, you muſt keep no ſecrets amongſt friends.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: It might prove a ſhrew'd matter againſt my miſchevious Maſter as it may be handled.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Hang him cullion, that would turn thee away.
Wee'l help thee to handle it, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Heark you then all friends. Shall I out with it?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: What elſe.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: Ile firſt take tother cup, and then out with't altogether—And now it comes—If my Miſtreſs do bring him home a baſtard, ſhe's but even with him.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He has one I warrant. Has he cadzooks?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: That he has by this moſt delicate drink. But it is the Arſivarſieſt Aufe that ever crept into the world. Sure ſome Goblin got it for him; or chang'd it in the neaſt, thats certain.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I vow thou uttereſt brave things. Is't a boy?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: It has gone for a boy in ſhort coats and long coats this ſeaven and twenty years.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: An Idiote is it.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: Yes: A very natural; and goes a thiſſen; and looks as old as I do too. And I think if my beard were off, I could be like him: I have taken great pains to practiſe his ſpeech and action to make my ſelf merry with him in the countrey.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Where is he kept, friend, where is he kept.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.p: In the further ſide of Norfolk, where you muſt never ſee him. Tis now a dozen years ſince his father ſaw him, and then he compounded for a ſum of mony with an old man, one Hulverhead, to keep him for his life time; and he never to hear of him. But I ſaw him within theſe three moneths. We hearken after him, as land-ſick heirs do after their fathers, in hope to hear of his end at laſt.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.p: But heark you, friend, if your beard were off, could you be like him think you? What if you cut it off, and to him for a father.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pray thee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: My beard, friend, no: My beard's my honour.
Hair is an ornament of honour upon man or woman.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.p: Come, come; I know what we will do with him. Mun, knock him down with the other cup. We'l lay him to ſleep; but yet watch and keep him betwixt hawk and buzzard as he is, till we make excellent ſport with him.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hey ho. I am very ſleepy.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: See he jooks already. Boy ſhew us a private room.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This way, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Down, Plumpton▪parke, &c.
sp.stage: They lead Buz. out, and he ſings.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Indeed you were unkind to turn away
M • maid (poor harmleſs maid) whoſe innocent mirth
Was the beſt chear your houſe afforded me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am ſorry ſiſter, truſt me, truly ſorry,
And knew I which way to recover her
With my beſt care I would. Yet, give me leave,
I ſaw her overbold; and overheard her
Say, ſhe foreſaw that Arthur my ſole enemy
Should be your husband. Ile marry you to death firſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Now you fly out again.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your pardon again your ſiſter,
And for your ſatisfaction I will ſtrive
To overſway my paſſion. How now Arnold,
Me thinks I read good newes upon thy face.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The beſt, Sir, I can tell is, the old Jew
Quicksands has loſt his wife.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She is not dead,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Tis not ſo well for him: for if ſhe were
He then might overtake her though ſhe were
Gone to the devil. But ſhe's run away:
But to what corner of the earth, or under
Whoſe bed to find her is not to be thought.
It has rais'd ſuch a laughter in the town
Among the Gallants—!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And do you laugh too?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes; and if you do not out-laugh all men
That hear the joyful newes, tis too good for you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am too merciful, I kill thee not.
Out of my doors, thou villain, reprobate.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hold, Pray Sir, hold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Never while I have power to lift a hand
Againſt thee, miſchievous Villain.

sp.speaker: Lucy
sp.l: Is not this paſſion, brother?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Forbear, ſiſter.
This is a cauſe turns patience into fury.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Arnold, forbear his ſight.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And my houſe too.
Or villain, look to die, oft as I ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Turn'd out o • doors! A dainty frantick humour
In a young Maſter! Good enough for me though;
Becauſe tis proper to old ſerving-men
To be ſo ſerv'd. What courſe now muſt I take?
I am too old to ſeek out a new Maſter.
I will not beg, becauſe Ile croſſe the proverb
That runs upon old ſerving creatures; ſtealing
I have no minde to: Tis a hanging matter.
Wit and invention help me with ſome ſhift
To help a caſt-off now at a dead lift.
Sweet fortune hear my ſuit.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Why how now, Arnold! What, at thy devotion?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ile tell you in your ear, ſir, I dare truſt you.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: Could earthly man have dreamt this Rafcal
Whoſe Letchery, to all our thinking, was
Nothing but greedy Avarice and coſonage,
Could have been all this while a conceal'd whoremaſter,
To have a Baſtard of ſo many years
Nurſled i'th' Countrey?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Note the puniſhments
That haunt the Miſcreant for his black miſdeeds;
That his baſe off-ſpring proves a natural Ideot;
Next that his wife, by whom he might had comfort
In progeny, though of ſome others getting,
Should with her light heels make him heavie-headed
By running of her Countrey! And laſtly that
The blinded wretch ſhould caſt his ſervant off,
Who was the cover of his villany,
To ſhew us (that can have no mercy on him)
The way to plague him.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: What do'ſt laugh at?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: To think how nimble the poor uzzard is
To be reveng'd on's Maſter; How he has Shap'd himſelf;
Cut off his beard, and practis'd all the poſtures
To act the Changeling baſtard.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Could we light
Upon ſome quaint old fellow now, could match him
To play the clown that brings him up to town,
Our company were full, and we were ready
To put our project into preſent action.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, we are fitted: take this man w'ye
He is the onely man I would have ſought,
To give our project life. I'le truſt thee Arnold,
And truſt thou me, thou ſhalt get pieces by't;
Beſides, Ile piece thee to thy Maſter again.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That clinches Sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Go follow your directions.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Come away then.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Sweet mirth thou art my Miſtreſs. I could ſerve thee.
And ſhake the thought off of all woman kind
But that old wonts are hardly leſt. A man
That's enter'd in his youth, and throughly ſalted
In documents of women, hardly leaves
While reins or brains will laſt him: Tis my caſe.
Yet mirth, when women fail, brings ſweet incounters
That tickle up a man above their ſphear:
They dull, but mirth revives a man: who's here,
The ſolitary muſing man, cal'd Arthur,
Poſſes'd with ſeriours vanity; Mirth to me!
The world is full: I cannot peep my head forth
But I meet mirth in every corner: Ha!
Sure ſome old runt with a ſplay-foot has croſt him!
Hold up thy head man; what doſt ſeek? thy grave?
I would ſcarſe truſt you with a piece of earth
You would chuſe to lye in though; if ſome plump Miſtriſs
Or a deft Laſs were ſet before your ſearch.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How vainly this man talks!

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Gid ye good den forſooth.
How vainly this man talks! ſpeak but truth now,
Does not thy thought now run upon a Wench?
I never look'd ſo but mine ſtood that way.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis all your glory that; and to make boaſt
Of the variety that ſerves your luſt:
Yet not to know what woman you love beſt.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Not I cadzooks, but all alike to me,
Since I put off my Wench I kept at Livory:
But of their uſe I think I have had my ſhare,
And have lov'd every one beſt of living women;
A dead one I nere coveted, that's my comfort:
But of all ages that are preſſable;
From ſixteen unto ſixty; and of all complections
From the white flaxen to the tawney-Moor;
And of all ſtatures between Dwarf and Giants;
Of all conditions, from the Doxie to the Dowſabel.
Of all opinions, I will not ſay Religious:
(For what make they with any?) and of all
Features and ſhapes, from the huckle-back'd Bum-creeper,
To the ſtreight ſpiny Shop-maid in St. Martins.
Briefly, all ſorts and ſizes I have taſted.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And thinkſt thou haſt done well in't!

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: As well as I could with the worſt of'em tho'l ſay't.
Few men come after me that mend my work.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But thou nere thinkſt of puniſhments to come;
Thou dream'ſt not of diſeaſes, poverty,
The loſs of ſenſe or member, or the croſs
(Common to ſuch looſe livers) an ill marriage;
A hell on earth to ſcourge thy conſcience.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Yes, when I marry, let me have a wife
To have no mercy on me; let the fate
Of a ſtale dovting Batchelor fall upon me;
Let me have Quicksands curſe, to take a Wife
Will run away next day, and proſtitute
Her ſelf to all the world before her Husband.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Nay, that will be too good: If I foreſee
Any thing in thy marriage deſtiny,
'Twil be to take a thing that has been common
To th'world before, and live with thee perforce
To thy perpetual torment.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cloſe that point.
I cannot marry. Will you be merry, Arthur?
I have ſuch things to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Pray thee come cloſer to me. What has croſt thee?
Is thy ſuppos'd ſlain father come again,
To diſpoſſeſs thee for another life time?
Or has thy valiant ſiſter beaten thee? Tell me.
It ſhall go no further.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let your valiant wit
And jocound humor be ſuppos'd no warrant
For you t'abuſe your friends by.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Why didſt tell me of marrying then? But I
Have done. And now pray ſpeak what troubles you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I care not if I do: For 'twill be Town talk.
My Siſter on a private diſcontent
Betwixt her ſelf and me hath left my houſe.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Gone quite away?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, And I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Beyond Sea ſure to ſight with th'Air, that took
Her fathers laſt breath into't. Went ſhe alone?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, No; My man's gone with her.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Who, the fellow
That brags on's back ſo; the ſtiff ſtrong chin'd Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Even he.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: The devil is in theſe young Tits,
And wildfire in their Cruppers.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let me charm you,
By all our friendſhip, you nor ſpeak nor hear
An ill conſtruction of her act in this,
I know her thoughts are noble; and my wo
Is ſwoln unto that fulneſs, that th' addition
But of word in ſcorn would blow me up
Into a cloud of wild diſtemper'd fury
Over the heads of all whoſe looſer breath
Dare raiſe a wind to break me. Then I fall
A ſodain ſtorm of ruin on you all.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I know not how to laugh at this: It comes
So near my pitty. But ile to my Griggs
Again; And there will find new mirth to ſtretch
And laugh, like tickled wenches, hand ore head.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How does my habit and my arms become me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Too well to be a woman, manly Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Wher's the piſtol you provided for me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Here Miſtreſs and a good one.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Tis too long.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: No Lady would wiſh a ſhorter. If it were
'T would bear no charge, or carry nothing hotne.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Ile try what I can do. Thou think'ſt me valiant.
I'm ſure I have often felt it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: All the virago's that are found in ſtory,
Pentheſilea and Symaramis
Were no ſuch handy ſtrikers as your ſelf:
But they had another ſtroke, could you but find it,
Then you were excellent. I could teach it you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I dare not underſtand thee yet. Be ſure
As you reſpect my honour, or your life
That you continue conſtant to my truſt,
And ſo thou canſt not know how much Ile love thee.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: There is a hope as good, now, as a promiſe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Here at this Inne abide, and wait my coming
Be careful of my guildings: Be not ſeen
Abroad for fear my brother may ſurpriſe you.
Ther's money for you; and ere that be ſpent
Tis like I ſhall return.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Beſt ſtars attend you,
Mars arm thee all the day; and Venus light
Thee home into theſe amorous arms at night.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Be chear'd my love; help to bear up the joy,
That I conceive by thy concealed Beauty,
Thy rich impriſon'd beauty, whoſe in • ranchiſement
Is now at hand, and ſhall ſhine forth again
In its admired glory. I am rapt
Above the ſphear of common joy and wonder
In the effects of this our quaint complot.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In the mean time, though you take pleaſure in't,
My name has dearly ſuffered.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: But thine honor
Shall, in the vindication of thy name,
When envy and detraction are ſtruck dumb
Gain an eternal memory with vertue;
When the diſcountenanc'd wits of all my jierers
Shall hang their heads, and fall like leaves in Autumn.
O how I laugh to hear the cozen'd people
As I paſs on the ſtreets abuſe themſelves
By idle queſtions and falſe reports.
As thus: good morrow Maſter Quicksands; pray
How fares your beauteous bedfellow? ſays another
I hear ſhe's not at home. A third ſayes no:
He ſaw her yeſterday at the ſtill-yard
With ſuch a Gallant, ſowſing their dry'd tongues
In Rhemiſh, Deal, and Back-rag: Then a fourth
Sayes he knowes all her haunts and Meetings
At Bridgfoot, Bear, the Tunnes, the Cats, the Squirels;
Where, when, and in what company to find her,
But that he ſcornes to do poor me the favour:
Becauſe a light piece is too good for me.
While a fifth youth with counterfeit ſhew of pity,
Meets, and bewails my caſe, and ſaies he knowes
A Lord that muſt be nameleſs keeps my wife
In an inchanted Caſtle two miles Weſt
Upon the River ſide: but all conclude—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: That you are a monſtrous cuckold, and deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Knowing my ſafety, then, and their foul errors,
Have I not cauſe to laugh? Yes, in abundance.
Now note my plot, the height of my invention
I have already given out to ſome,
That I have certain knowledge you are dead,
And have had private burial in the countrey;
At which my ſhame, not grief, forbad my preſence:
Yet ſome way to make known unto the world
A husbands duty, I reſolve to make
A certain kind of feaſt, which ſhall advance
My joy above the reach of ſpight or chance.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: May I partake, Sir, of your rich conceit?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: To morrow night expires your limited moneth
Of vow'd virginity; It ſhall be ſuch a night;
In which I mean thy beauty ſhall break forth
And dazle with amazement even to death
Thoſe my malicious enemies, that rejoyc'd
In thy ſuppos'd eſcape, and my vexation.
I will envite 'hem all to ſuch a feaſt
As ſhall fetch bluſhes from the boldeſt gueſt;
I have the firſt courſe ready—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: And if I
Fail in the ſecond, blame my houſwifery.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Away, ſome body comes; I gueſs of them
That have jeer'd me, whom I muſt jeer again.
Gallants y'are welcom. I was ſending for ye.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: To give us that we come for?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: What may that be?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Trifles you have o • ours.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Of yours, my Maſters?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, you have in mortgage
Three-ſcore pound Land of mine inheritance.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And my Annuity of a hundred Marks.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: And Jewels, Watches, Plate, and cloaths of mine,
Pawn'd for four hundred pound. Will you reſtore all?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You know all theſe were forfeited long ſince,
Yet I'le come roundly to you, Gentlemen.
Ha'you brought my moneys, and my intereſt?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: No ſurely. But we'le come as roundly to you
As moneyleſs Gentlemen can. You know
Good Offices are ready money Sir.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: But have you Offices to ſell, good Sirs.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: We mean to do you Offices worth your money.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: As how, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Marry, Sir, as thus;
We'le help you to a man that has a friend—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: That knows a party, that can go to the houſe—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Where a Gentleman dwelt, that knew a Scholar

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That was exceeding wel acquainted with a Traveler

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.l: That made report of a great Magician beyond the Seas.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: That might ha'been as likely as any man in all the world.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: To have helpt you to your wife again.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You are the merrieſt mates that ere I cop'd withal.
But to be ſerious Gentlemen, I am ſatisfied
Concerning my loſt Wife. She has made even
With me and all the World.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What is ſhe dead?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Dead, Dead: And therefore as men uſe to mourn
For kind and loving wives, and call their friends
Their choiceſt friends unto a ſolemn banquet
Serv'd out with ſighs and ſadneſs, while the widowers
Blubber, and bath in tears (which they do ſeem
To wring out of their fingers ends and noſes)
And after all the demure ceremony.
Are ſubject to be thought diſſemblers, I
(To avoid the ſcandal of Hypocreſie,
Becauſe 'tis plain ſhe lov'd me not) invite
You and your like that lov'd her and not me,
To ſee me in the pride of my rejoycings,
You ſhall find entertainment worth your company,
And that let me intreat to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: You ſhall ha'mine.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: To morrow night ſay you.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Yes gallants: fail not, as you wiſh to view
Your mortgages and pawns again. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: We came to jear the Jew, and he jears us.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: How glad the raſchal is for his Wives death.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: An honeſt man could not have had ſuch luck.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: He has ſome further end in't, could we gueſs it,
Then a meer merriment for his dead wives niddance.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Perhaps he has got a new Wife, and intends
To make a funeral and a Marriage feaſt
In one to hedge in charges.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: He'il be hang'd rather then marry again.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Zooks would he had ſome deviliſh jealous hilding,
'Twould be a rare addition to his mirth,
For us to bring our antick in betwixt'em
Of his changling Baſtard.

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: How ere we'll grace his feaſt with our preſentment.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: When's the Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: We left him with his foſter father, Arnold,
B • ſy at rehearſal practiſing their parts.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: They ſhall be perfect by to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If not unto our profit, our delight.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Brother be comforted.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let not the name
Or empty ſound of comfort mix with th'air
That muſt invade theſe ears: They are not capable,
Or, if they be, they dare not, for themſelves,
Give the conveyance of a ſillable
Into my heart, that ſpeak not grief or ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Be griev'd then, Ile grieve with you: For each ſigh
You waſte for Millicents untimely death
Ile ſpend a tear for your as fruitleſs ſorrow.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That's moſt unſutable; y'are no company
For me to grieve with if you grieve for me;
Take the ſame cauſe with me; you are no friend
Or ſiſter elſe of mine. It is enough
To ſet the world a weeping!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: So it is;
All but the ſtony part of't.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Now you are right. Her husband's of that part;
He cannot weep by nature: But Ile find
A way by art in Chymiſtry to melt him.
At leaſt extract ſome drops. But do you weep
Indeed for Millicent? What, all theſe tears?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: All for your love.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She is my love indeed; and was my wife.
But for the empty name of marriage onely,
But now ſhe's yours for ever. You enjoy her.
In her fair bleſſed memory; in her goodneſs,
And all that has prepar'd her way for glory.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee ſiſter. How I reverence
Any fair honour that is done to her,
Now thou ſhalt weep no more: Thou haſt given me comfort
In ſhewing me how ſhe's mine. And tears indeed
Are all too weak a ſacrifice for her
But ſuch as the heart weeps.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sit down brother.
Sing boy the mornful ſong I bad you practiſe.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Call you this mournful. Tis a wanton air.
Go y'are a naughty child indeed, Ile whip you
If you give voice unto ſuch notes,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know not brother how you like the air,
But in my mind the words are ſad, Pray read'em.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They are ſad indeed▪ How now my boy, doſt weep?
I am not angry now.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I do not weep,
Sir, for my ſelf. But ther's a youth without
(A handſome youth) whoſe ſorrow works in me:
He ſayes he wants a ſervice, and ſeeks yours.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Doſt thou not know him▪

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No: but I pity him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: O, good boy, that canſt weep for a ſtrangers miſery!
The ſweetneſs of thy dear compaſſion
Even melts me too. What does he ſay he is.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Tis that Sir, that will grieve you when you hear it.
He is a poor kinſman to the gentlewoman
Lately deceaſ'd that you ſo lov'd and mourn for.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And doſt thou let him ſtay without ſo long?
Mercileſs Villain! run and fetch him quickly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: O brother—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Siſter, can I be too zealous
In ſuch a cauſe as this? For heark you, ſiſter,

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: There was no way like this to get within'em,
Now courage keep true touch with me. Ile vex
Your cunning and unnatural purpoſe, brother,
If I do nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sir, here's the youth?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A lovely one he is, and wondrous like her,
O let me run and claſp him; hang about him,
And yoak him to me with a thouſand kiſſes!
I ſhall be troubleſome and heavy to thee,
With the pleaſ'd waight of my inceſſant love.
Youth of a happy kindred, which foreruns
A happy fortune ever. Pray thee, ſiſter,
Is he not very like her?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: If I durſt
I would now ſay, this were the better beauty,
For it reſembles Arthurs.

sp.speaker: The,
sp.l: I'st not her face? you do not mind me ſiſter:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hers was a good one once, and this is now.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why ſiſter, you were wont to take delight
In any comfort that belong'd to me;
And help to carry my joyes ſweetly: now
You keep no conſtant courſe with me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This man
Melts me—alas, Sir, I am a poor boy.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What, and allied to her? impoſſible!
Where ere thou liv'ſt her name's a fortune to thee.
Her memory amongſt good men ſets thee up;
It is a word that commands all in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This ſnare was not well laid. I fear my ſelf.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Live my companion; my eſpecial ſweet one,
My brother and my bedfellow thou ſhalt be.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: By lakin but I muſt not, though I find
But weak matter againſt it.—This my courage!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She took from earth, how kind is heaven, how good
To ſend me yet, a joy ſo near in blood!
Good noble youth, if there be any more
Diſtres'd of you, that claims aliance with her
Though a far off; deal freely; let me know it,
Give me their ſad names; Ile ſeek'em out,
And like a good great man, in memory humble
Nere ceaſe until I plant'em all in fortunes,
And ſee'em grow about me.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I hear of none, my ſelf excepted, Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have all my care then, all my love.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What make I here? I ſhall undo my ſelf.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yet note him ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I ther's the mark my malice chiefly aims at;
But then, he ſtands ſo near, I wound him too.
I feel that muſt not be. Art muſt be ſhewen here.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come, you ſhall kiſs him for me, and bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You are moſt welcome, Sir, and were her name
To which you are allied, a ſtranger here,
Yet, Sir, believe me, you in thoſe fair eyes
Bring your own welcome with you.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Never came Malice 'mong ſo ſweet a people.
It knowes not how to look, nor I on them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Let not your gentle modeſty make you ſeem
Ungentle to us, by turning ſo away.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That's well ſaid ſiſter, but he will and ſhall
Be bolder with us, ere we part.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I ſhall too much I fear.—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Come gentle blesſing,
Let not a miſery be thought on here,
(If ever any were ſo rude to touch thee)
Between us we'll divide the comfort of thee.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I have heard thy ſtory often, and with pitty
As often thought upon't, and that the father,
Of my beſt lov'd Theophilus, together with
His, then, friend Maſter Meanwell (who have ſince
Become each others deathſman astis thought)
By ſuits in Law wrought the ſad overthrow
Of thy poor Fathers fortune; by which means,
Poor Gentleman he was enforc'd to leave
His native Country to ſeek forrain meanes
To maintain life.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Or rather to meet death.
For ſince his traval, which is now ſix years,
I never heard of him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Much pittiful!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So is your ſtory, Miſtreſs unto me.
But let us dry our eyes; and know we muſt not
Stick in the mire of pitty; but with labour
Work our delivery: yours is now at hand
If you ſet will and brain to't. But my honor
(If a poor wench may ſpeak ſo) is ſo crack'd
Within the ring, as 'twill be hardly ſolder'd
By any art. If on that wicked fellow,
That ſtruck me into ſuch a deſperate hazard.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: He will be here to night, and all the crew
And this muſt be the night of my delivery,
I am prevented elſe for ever, wench.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Be ſure, among the gueſts, that you make choiſe
Of the moſt civil one to be your convoy,
And then let me alone to act your Mores part.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Peace, he comes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ile to my ſhift then.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Wher's my hidden beauty?
That ſhall this night be glorious.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I but wait the good hour
For my deliverance out of this obſcurity.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Tis at hand.
So are my gueſts. See ſome of'em are enter'd.
O my blith friend, Maſter Nathaniel, welcome.
And Maſter Arthur Meanwell as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, a Gentleman late poſſes'd with ſadnes,
Whom I had much a do to draw along
To be partaker more of your mirth then chear.
You ſay here ſhall be mirth. How now, what's that?
Ha'vou a black coney berry in your houſe?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Stay Catelina. Nay, ſhe may be ſeen.
For know, Sirs, I am mortified to beauty
Since my wives death. I will not keep a face
Better then this under my roof I ha'ſworn.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You were too raſh, Sir, in that oath, if I
Mav be allowed to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Tis done and paſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If I be not taken with yon'd funeral face,
And her two eyes the ſcutcheons, would I were whipt now.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Suppoſe your friends ſhould wiſh you to a match
Proſperous in wealth and honour.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Ile hear of none, nor you if you ſpeak ſo.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Sir, I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: It is the handſom'ſt Rogue
I have ere ſeen yet of a deed of darkneſs;
Tawney and ruſſet faces I have dealt with,
But never came ſo deep in blackneſs yet.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Come hither Catelyna. You ſhall ſee, Sir,
What a brave wench ſhe ſhall be made anon
And when ſhe dances how you ſhall admire her.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Will you have dancing here to night.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Yes I have borrowed other Moors of Merchants
That trade in Barbary, whence I had mine own here,
And you ſhall ſee their way and skill in dancing.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He keeps this Rie-loaf for his own white white tooth
With confidence none will cheat him of a bit;
Ile have a ſliver though I looſe my whittle.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Here take this key, twill lead thee to thoſe ornaments
That deck'd thy miſtreſs lately. Uſe her casket,
And with the ſparklingſt of her jewels ſhine;
Flame like a midnight beacon with that face,
Or a pitch'd ſhip a fire; the ſtreamers glowing
And the keel mourning, (how I ſhall rejoyce
At theſe prepoſtrous ſplendours) get thee glorious;
Be like a running fire-work in my houſe.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: He ſets me more a fire at her. Well old ſtick breech
If I do chance to clap your Barbary buttock
In all her bravery, and get a ſnatch
In an odd corner, or the dark to night
To mend your chear, and you hereafter hear on't,
Say there are as good ſtomacks as your own,
Hiſt, Negro, hiſt.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: No fee, O no, I darea notta.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Why, why—piſh—pox I love thee,

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: O no de fine white Zentilmanna
Cannot a love a the black a thing a.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cadzooks the beſt of all wench.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: O take—a heed—a my maſtra ſee—a.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: When we are alone, then wilt thou.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then I ſhall ſpeak a more a.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: And Ile not loſe the Moor-a for more then I
Will ſpeak-a.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: I muſe the reſt of my invited Gallants
Come not away.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Zooks the old angry juſtice.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: How comes it Sir, to paſs, that ſuch a newes
Is ſpread about the town? is my Neece dead,
And you prepar'd to mirth Sir, hah?
Is this the entertainment I muſt find
To welcome me to town?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: She is not dead, Sir. But take you no notice
You ſhall have inſtantly an entertainment, that
Shall fill you all with wonder.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Sure he is mad;
Or do you underſtand his meaning ſirs?
Or how or where his wife died?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I know nothing;
But give me leave to fear, by his wild humor,
He's guilty of her death; therefore I hope
Hee'l hang himſelf anon before us all
To raiſe the mirth he ſpeaks of.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Fie upon you.
Yet truſt me, ſir, there have been large conſtructions,
And ſtrong preſumptions, that the ill made match
Betwixt her youthful beauty and his covetous age;
Between her ſweetneſs and his frowardneſs
Was the unhappy means of her deſtruction;
And you that gave ſtrength to that ill tied knot
Do ſuffer ſharply in the worlds opinion,
While ſhe, ſweet virgin, has its general pity.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Pray what have you been to her? I nere found you
Appear a ſuiter to her.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: I nere ſaw her,
Nor ever ſhould have ſought her, Sir; For ſhe
Was onely love to my ſworne enemy,
On whom yet (were ſhe living and in my gift
Rather a thouſand times I would beſtow her
Then on that man that had, and could not know her.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: I have done ill; and wiſh I could redeem
This act with half my eſtate.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: This Devels bird,
This Moor runs more and more ſtill in my mind.
O are you come? And ha'you brought your ſcene
Of Mirth along with you?

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: Yes, and our actors
Are here at hand: But we perceive much buſineſs
Firſt to be ſet a foot. Here's Revels towards.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A daunce of furies or of Blackamores
Is practiſing within;

sp.speaker: Ʋin.
sp.l: But firſt there is to be ſome odd collation
In ſtead of ſupper.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cheap enough I warrant,
But ſaw you not a Moor-hen there amongſt'em.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: A pretty little Rogue, moſt richly deck'd
With pearls, chains and jewels. She is queen
Of the Nights triumph.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: If you • h • nce to ſpy me
Take her aſide, ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thou wilt filch
Some of her jewels perhaps.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Ile draw a lot
For the beſt jewel ſhe wears. But mum my Maſters.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Enter the houſe pray Gentlemen: I am ready
Now with your entertainment.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Wee'l follow you.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: N • w for ſix penny cuſtards, a pipkin of bak'd
Pears, three ſawcers of ſtew'd prunes, a groats worth
Of ſtrong ale, and two peniworth of Gingerbread.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: If ſhe does live (as he bears me in hand
She is not dead) Ile tell you briefly, Sir,
If all the law bodily and ghoſtly,
And all the conſcience too, that I can purchaſe
With all the wealth I have can take her from him,
I will recover her, and then beſtow her
(If you refuſe her) on your ſo you ſpeak of,
(whoſe right ſhe is indeed) rather then he
Shall hold her longer. Now mine eyes are open'd.
Will you walk in.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I pray excuſe me, Sir,
sp.stage: Exi • , Enter Mili. white. fac'd & in her ovvn habit.
sp.l: I cannot fit my ſelf to mirth.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Your pleaſure.
Mil. Have I with patience waited for this • ou • ,
And does fear check me now? I'le break through all,
And truſt my ſelf with yon'd mildeGentleman.
He cannot but be noble.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: A goodly creature!
The Rooms illumin'd with her; yet her look
Sad, and cheek pale, as if a ſorrow ſuck'd it.
Hovv came ſhe in? What is ſhe? I am fear▪ſtruck.
Tis ſome unreſting ſhaddow. Or, if not,
What makes a thing ſo glorious in this houſe,
The maſter being an enemy to beauty?
She modeſtly makes to me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Noble Sir,—

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Speaks too.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: If ever you durſt own a goodneſs,
Now crown it by an act of honour and mercy.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Speak quickly; loſe no time then: ſay, what are you?
You look like one that ſhould not be delai'd.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I am th'unfortunate woman of this houſe,
To all mens thoughts at reſt. This is the face
On which the Hell of jealouſie abus'd
The hand of Heaven, to fright the world withall.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Were you the ſeeming Moor was here?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: The ſame;
And onely to your ſecreſie and pitty
I have ventur'd to appear my ſelf again.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What's to be done? Pray ſpeak, and tis perform'd.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In truſt and Manhood Sir, I would commit
A great charge to you, even my life and honor
To free me from this den of miſery.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: A bleſſed taſque! But when you are freed Lady—

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I would deſire Sir, then to be convei'd.—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whither? to whom? ſpeak quickly: why do you ſtoop?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Pray let that reſt. I will relieve your trouble
When I am freed from hence, and uſe ſome others.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Nay, that were cruelty. As you love goodneſs tell me.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Why dare you bear me Sir, to one you hate.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: What's that, if you love? Tis your peace I wait on.
I look upon your ſervice, not mine own.
Were he the mortall'ſt enemy fleſh bred up
To you I muſt be noble.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You profeſs—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: By all that's good and gracious, I will die
Ere I forſake you, and not ſet you ſafe
Within thoſe walls you ſeek.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Then, as we paſs
Ile tell you where they ſtand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You ſhall grace me.

div.head: ACT 4. SCENE 5.
div.stage: Quick ſands. Testy. Nath. Vincent. Edmond.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Now to our Revels. Sit ye, ſit ye gallants
Whilſt, Uncle, you ſhall ſee how I'le requite
The maſque they lent me on my wedding night.
Twas but lent Gentlemen, your maſque of horns,
And all the private jears and publick ſcorns
Y'have caſt upon me ſince. Now you ſhall ſee
How Ile return them; and remarried be.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I hope he'l marry his Moor to anger us.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Ile give her ſomething with her, if I catch her,
And't be but in the cole-houſe.
sp.stage: Floriſh enter Inductor like a Moor leading Phillis (black and) gorgeouſly deck't with jewels.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Attend Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: The Queen of Ethiop dreampt upon a night
Her black womb ſhould bring forth a virgin white.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: She told her king; he told thereof his Peeres.
Till this white dream fil'd their black heads with fears:

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: A whorſon blockheads.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: Blackheads I ſai'd. Ile come to you anon

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: He puts the blockheads on'hem groſly.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Brave impudent rogue. He made the ſpeeches laſt year
Before my Lord Marqueſs of Fleet Conduit.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: Till this white dream fil'd their blackheads with fear,
For tis no better then a Prodegy
To have white children in a black countrey.
So 'twas decreed that if the child prov'd white,
It ſhould be made away. O cruel ſpight!
The Queen cry'd out, and was delivered
Of child black as you ſee: Yet Wizards ſed
That if this damſel liv'd married to be
To a white man, ſhe ſhould be white as he.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The moral is, If Quicksands marry her,
Her face ſhall be white as his conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: The careful Queen, concluſion for to try,
Sent her to merry England charily
(The faireſt Nation man yet ever ſaw)
To take a husband; ſuch as I ſhall draw,
Being an Aegyptian Prophet.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Draw me, and ile hang thee.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: Now I come to you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Now mark my Jeeres.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: You muſt not have her: For I find by your hand
You have forfeited the mortgage of your land.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Pox o'your Palmiſtrie.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now me.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: Nor you: For here I plainly ſee
You have ſold and ſpent your lifes Annuity.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The devil take him, made thee a ſoothſayer.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I find from whence your skill comes. Yet take me
For thy little Princeſs of darkneſſe, and if
I rub her not as white as another can
Let me be hung up with her for a new
Sign of the labour in vain.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: Nor you, ſir: For
T • e onely ſute you wear ſmels of the cheſt
That holds in Limbo Lavender all your reſt.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Would his brains were in thy belly that keeps the key on't.

sp.speaker: Ind.
sp.l: This is the worthy man, whoſe wealth and wit,
To make a white one, muſt the black mark hit.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Your jeers are anſwer'd, gallants. Now your dance.
sp.stage: Enter the reſt of the Moors. They Dance an Antique in which they uſe action of Mockery and deriſion to the three Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: We applaud your deviſe, and you'l give me leave
To take your black bride here, forth in a daunce.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: With all my heart, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Muſick, play a Galliard,
You know what you promiſed me, Bullis.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But howa can ita be donea.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: How I am taken with the elevation of her noſtrils.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Play a little quicker—Heark you—if I lead you
A dance to a couch or a bed ſide, will you follow me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I will doa my beſta.
sp.stage: Nat. daunces vily. Quicks. & Teſ. laughs & looks off.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: So, ſo; quick Muſick, quick.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O ougly! call you this dauncing; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Do you laugh at me.
sp.stage: Enter Arnold like a Countrey man, and Buz. like a changling, and as they enter, exit Nat. with Phil. the Muſick ſtill playing.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: By your leave Gentlefolks.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: O brave, o brave.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: How now.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: What are theſe?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hack ye there, hack ye there,
O brave pipes. Hack ye there.
sp.stage: He ſings and dances and ſpins with a Rock & ſpindle.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: What are you men or devils?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You are advis'd enough: Sir, if you pleaſe
But to be ſhort, I'le ſhew you I am a Norfolk man,
And my name is John Hulverhead.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: Hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: You cannot hear o'chat ſide it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I know thee not, not I.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But you know my brother Matthew Hulverhead
Deceas'd, with whom you plac'd this ſimple child of yours.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I plac't no childe in Norfolk nor Suffolk nor any
Folk I—ſay thou miſtookſt me: Ile reward thee. Go.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I cannot hear o'that ear neither, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What's the matter, Mr. Quicksands?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Ha'you any more jeeres to put upon us? what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Get you out of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I may not till I be righted. I come for right, and
I will have right, or the beſt of the Citie ſhall
Hear on't.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: I ſwear the Raſcals act it handſomly.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: What art thou fellow? What doſt thou ſeek?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Tell that Gentleman: He is an upright Majeſtrate
And will ſee thee righted.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: I am a poor Norfolk man, ſir. And I come to eaſe myſelf of a charge, by putting off a childe nat'ral to the natu • al father here.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.l: My child! Am I his father? Darſt thou ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Be not aſham'd on't, ſir: You are not the firſt grave and wiſe Citizen that has got an ideot.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Here's good ſtuff towards.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—with a Hay toodle loodle loodle loo.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: How ſhould I get him. I was never married till this moneth.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: How does other bawdy Batchelors get children?

sp.speaker: Buz
sp.l: With a hay toodle loodle loodle loo, &c.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Have you been a baſtard-getter and marry my Neece.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: I • e teach you to get a baſtard, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: He needs none o'your skill it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Well, Gentlemen, to take your wonder off,
I will lay truth before you.
For a poor ſervant that I had, I undertook and paid
For keeping of an ideot.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Who, your man Buzzard?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Even he.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: 'Tis like this is the child. But for a certain ſum
Which I did pay, 'twas articled, that I ſhould nere be
Troubled with it more.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Now what ſay you to that Sir?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: 'Tis not denyed Sir, There was ſuch agreement,
But now he is another kind of charge.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why, he gets ſomething towards his living me thinks.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, he has learn'd to thrip among the Mothers;
But Sir, withal, to do more harm then good by't,
And that's the charge I ſpeak of: we are not bound
To keep your child, and your childes children too.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Sir, by his cunning at the Rock,
And twirling of his ſpindle on the Thrip-skins,
He has fetch'd up the bellies of ſixteen
Of his Thrip-ſiſters.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle, loodle, loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Is't poſſible.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: So well he takes after his father here it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Take heed o'that friend: you heard him ſay it was his mans child.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: He ſha'not fright me with that, though it be
A great mans part to turn over his baſtards
To his ſervants. I am none of his hirelings, nor
His Tenants I. But I know what I ſay; and I know
What I come about; and not without adviſe; And you
May know, that Norfolk is not without as knaviſh
Councel, as another County may be. Let his man Buz.
Be brought forth, and ſee what he will ſay to't.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Wretch that I was to put away that fellow!
But ſtay! where is my wife? my wife, my wife—

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: What ſay you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: My Moor I would ſay. Which way went my Moor?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Your Ethiopian Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: is gone to dance with her in private, becauſe you laught him out of countenance here.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Miſchief on miſchief! worſe and worſe I fear.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: What do you fear, why ſtare you? Are you frantick?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I muſt have wits and fits, my fancies and fegaries.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Your jeers upon poor Gallants.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: How do you feel your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Ask your father bleſſing Timſy.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Upon your knees man.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Upon all my knees. A—ah. Hay toodle loodle.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What was't to you, you ſlaves?
sp.stage: Enter Nat. & Phillis pul'd in by the Moors.
sp.l: Muſt you be peeping.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What was't to you, ye Raſcals?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: It is to us Sir, We were hir'd to dance and to ſpeak ſpeeches; and to do the Gentleman true ſervice in his houſe: And we will not ſee his houſe made a baudy houſe, and make no ſpeech o'that.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: What is the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Marry Sir a naughty buſineſs. This Gentleman has committed a deed of darkneſs with your Moor, Sir; We all ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: What deed of darkneſs? ſpeak it plainly.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Darkneſs or lightneſs; call it which you will.
They have lyen together; made this ſame a baudy houſe;
How will you have it?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Undone, moſt wretched. O, I am confounded.
I ſee no art can keep a woman honeſt.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I love her, and will juſtifie my Act.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And I the beſt of any man on earth.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Thou ſpeakeſt good Engliſh now.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O Ruine, ruine, ruine—

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Why take you on ſo, for an ougly feind?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: She is my wife, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How Sir, your wife.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: In conceit you mean.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I ſay my lawful wife; your Neece; and ſo diſguis'd
By me on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: I ſaid he was mad before, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Now I applaud my act, 'twas ſweet and brave.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I'le be divorc'd before a Court in publique.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Now will I uſe Authority and skill.
Friends, guard the doors. None ſhall depart the houſe.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Mun. Vin. Content, content.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Shall I, Sir, and my charge ſtay too?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Oh—

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Marry Sir, ſhall you.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I fear we ſhall be ſmoak'd then.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No, no, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: You know your Chamber huſwife. I'le wait o'your Maſter
To night. We will not part until to morrow day,
Juſtice and Law lights every one his way.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is this your merry night, Sir?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Oh—oh—oh—o—

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Why roar you ſo?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: It is the Cuckolds howle. A common cry about the City.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Oh o—Buz. Hay toodle loodle, &c.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Now my good Hoſt, ſince you have been our friend
And onely councel keeper in our abſence,
To you, before we viſit our own houſes
We'le render a relation of our journey,
And what the motive was that drew us forth.
'Tis true, we did pretend a deadly quarrel
At a great bowling match upon Black-heath;
Went off; took horſe; and ſeveral wayes, forecaſt
To meet at Dover, where we met good friends,
And in one Barque paſt over into France:
Here 'twas ſuppos'd to fight, like faſhion followers
That thither flie, as if no ſand but theirs
Could dry up Engliſh blood.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Now, by the way,
Suppoſe that ſuppoſition had been true,
And the ſuppoſed deaths of you, and you
Had mov'd your ſons to combate in earneſt,
And both been kil'd indeed, as you in jeſt,
Where had been then your witty ſubtilty,
My noble Meanwell, and my brave Raſhly?
Ha! have I twight ye there?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Thou keepſt thy humor ſtill my running Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: My humor was, nor is, nor muſt be loſt:
But, to the queſtion, was it wiſely done,
When each of you might ſo have loſt a ſon?

lg.l: We had no fear of that Sir, by the Rule,
The common Rule o'th'world. Where do you find
Sons that have lives and Lands, will venture both
For their dead Fathers that are gone and car'd for?
Nor was it onely to make tryal of
What husbands they would be; how ſpend, or ſave;
How mannage, or deſtroy; how one or both
Might play the Tyrants over their poor Tenants,
Yet fall by Prodigality into th'Compters:
And then the dead by pulling off a Beard,
After a little chiding and ſome whyning,
To ſet the living on their legs again,
And take 'em into favour; piſh, old play-plots.
No Sir, our buſineſs runs another courſe;
Know you this Gentleman yet?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Nor yet, nor yet;
Beſt wits may have bad memories; I forget.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: It is my part to ſpeak. Mine Hoſt, y'have known me,
My name is Winloſs; a poor Gentleman,
Yet richer, by my liberty, then I was
For ſix years ſpace, till theſe good Gentlemen
In charity redeem'd me.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Maſter Winloſs!
I thought I could as ſoon forgot my Chriſs-Croſs,
Yet (pardon me) you have been ſix years gone,
And all of them in priſon ſaving one,
In Dunkerk as I weene.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: It is moſt true;
And that from thence theſe Gentlemen redeem'd me
At their own charge, by paying five hundred pound,
Which was my Ranſom.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: 'Tis a rare example.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Worthy braſs tables, and a pen of ſteel.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: No more good neighbour Winloſs. What we did
Was to diſcharge our conſcience of a burden
Got (and 'twas all we got) by your undoing,
In a ſad ſuit at Law.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I do remember;
And, without ruine I'le tell you, That ſad cauſe,
In which you join'd againſt him, overthrew him
And all his Family: But this worthy act
Of yours in his enlargement, crowns your piety,
And puts him in a way of better Fortune,
Then his firſt tottering eſtate could promiſe.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Shut up that point. You have heard no ill, you ſay,
Among our ſons and daughters in our abſence.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Not any Sir at all. But, Mr. Winloſs,
You that have paſt ſo many ſorrows, can
(I make no doubt) here one with manly patience.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Tis of my daughter Phillis! Is ſhe dead?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Tis well and't be no worſe with her: I fear
She's gone the tother way of all fleſh, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Why doſt thou tell him this?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: To have him right
His daughters wrong upon that wicked beaſt
That has ſeduc'd her.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Who is't? canſt thou tell?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Even the Ran • k-rider of the town, Sir, one
Maſter Nathaniel Banelaſſe, if you know him.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: He has my ſons acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: And mine's too.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: You may be proud on' • , if they ſcape his doctrine.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: But does he keep my daughter to his luſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: No, Sir, tis worſe then ſo. He has caſt her off
To the common, as tis fear'd.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Owretchedneſs!

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: How cam'ſt thou by this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Sir, Ile tell you.
I have, i'th'houſe, a gueſt, was once your man,
And ſerv'd your ſon, ſince you went ore I'm ſure on'c,
Though now he has got a young ſpark to his Maſter,
That has a brace of gueldings in my ſtable;
And luſty ones they are. That's by the way.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: But to the point, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Sir, the young gallant is abroad, the man
Scults cloſs i'th' • ouſe here, and has done theſe two dayes
Spending his time with me in drink and talk.
Moſt of his talk runs upon wenches mainly;
And who loves who, and who keeps home, and ſo forth;
And he told me the tale that I tell you
Twixt Banelaſſe and your done and undone daughter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Mine hoſt—cry mercy Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Nay, nay, come on.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I told you he was very ſhy to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My old maſter alive again? and he that he kil'd too?

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Whom do you ſerve? was I ſo ill a maſter,
That, in my abſence, you forſook my children?
Or how have they miſus'd you? Why doſt look
So like an apprehended thief? I fear
Thou ſerv'ſt ſome robber, or ſome murderer,
Or art become thy ſelf one. If the Devil
Have ſo poſſeſs'd thee, ſtrive to turn him out:
He add my prayers to help thee. Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O honor'd maſter! Ile keep nothing from you.
There is an act of horror now on foot,
Upon revenge of your ſuppoſed murder,
Of which to ſtand and tell the circumſtance,
Would waſt the time and hinder the prevention
Of your ſons murder, and your daughters ruin.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O fearful!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Let not your amazement drown
Your reaſon in delay; your ſudden haſt
Was never ſo requir'd as now. Stay not
To ask my why, or whither. As ye go
I ſhall inform ye.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Go, we follow thee.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCENE 2.
div.stage: Dionyſia as before in mans habit, ſword and pistol.
div.l: What a fierce conflict twixt revenge and love,
Like an unnatural civil war, now rages
In my perplexed breaſt. There, fight it out;
To it Pel-mel my thoughts. The battel's hot.
Now for the day! revenge begins to ſtagger,
And her deſtracted Army at an inſtant
R • uted and put to flight. All conquering love,
Thou haſt got the victory; and now I ſue
(Like a rent kingdom by ſelf-oppoſite thoughts)
Unto thy ſoveraignty, to be the liege-right.
Take me to thy protection, kingly love,
And having captivated my revenge,
O, play not now the Tyrant. A firm hope
Perſwades me no: But when I ſhall
Reveal my ſelf I ſhall obtain Theophilus love.
Which now is ten times ſweeter in my thought
Then my revenge was, when 'twas firſt begot.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What, ſtill alone? we have been ſeeking thee.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O 'tis the ſervice that I ow you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Indeed you are too penſive: two whole dayes
And nights among us, and no more familiar?
sp.stage: Ent. Ar. in his falſe beard, • eading in Mil. veil'd. Pages they ſtand aloofe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: May I crave your name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That's to little purpoſe,
My buſineſs is the thing—yonder's the ſtar!
What young Gentleman is that your Miſtris arm
Appears ſo courteous too?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: One ſhe thinks well on Sir,
No matter for his name, as you ſaid, neither.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He ſeems ſome well grac'd ſuitor. 'Tis my fear,
If he ſhould now—I muſt be juſt however.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sir, a Gentleman deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Doſt thou not know his name?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: He will not tell it Sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You treacherous boy, do you bring you know not whom?
O 'tis the Gentleman I was ſo bound to, Siſter:
The welcom'ſt man alive; Thanks my good boy.
What's ſhe he brings in veil'd, and this way leads?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir, though I am ſtill a ſtranger in my viſit,
To works of gentleneſs, I am partly known.
There (if you chance t'enquire of me hereafter
(When I ſhall more deſerve your inquiſition)
I may be found, if not exact in ſervice,
A leaſt a poor pretender in my wiſhes:
And ſo preſenting this white gift, (more modeſt
Then the moſt ſecret duty of mans friendſhip
Can ever be) I take my leave—

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This man
Would breed, at every time ht's ſeen, a wonder!
Sir, leave me not thus loſt: let me once know you,
And what this myſtery means? This bears a ſhape
I may not entertain: I have ſet my vow
Againſt all woman kinde, ſince Heaven was married
To my firſt love; and muſt not willingly
Diſcover a temptation with mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How ſhie and nice we are to meet our happineſſe!
Like dying wretches, ' • raid to go to reſt.
Becauſe you ſhall be guilty of no breach
I'le ope the Casket for you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Bleſſe me, it is—
Warm, ſo Love cheriſh me and comfortable.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O death, my hopes are blaſted.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How is it with you, ſir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Might a man credit his own ſences now
This were my Millicent. How think you, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Indeed I am ſo, my Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: She lives, and he is loſt to me for ever,
I ſhall be ſtraight diſcover'd too. Falſe Love
Thou haſt dealt looſely with me; And Revenge
I re-invoke thy nobler ſpirit: Now
Poſſeſſe me wholly; let it not be thought
I came and went off idly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sir, ſomething troubles you. See your kinſwoman
My brother ſtands intranc'd too; Brother, brother▪
Noble Lady, ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I was in my diſcovery too ſudden.
Strong rapture of his joy tranſmutes him—Sir,
Be not ſo wonder-ſtruck; or, if you be,
Let me conjure you by the love you bore me,
R • turn unto your ſelf again. Let not
A wandring thought fly from you, to examine
From whence, or how I came: If I be welcome
I am your own and Millicent.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And in that
So bleſt a treaſure, that the wealth and ſtrength
Of all the world ſhall never purchace from me.
Heaven may be pleas'd again to take thee, but
Ile hold ſo faſt, that wee'll go hand in hand;
Beſides, I hope his mercy will not part us.
But where's the man now more deſir'd then ever
That brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: You ask in vain for him.
I can reſolve you all; but for the preſent
He will be known to none.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is a cruel goodneſs: To put thankfulneſs
Out of all action. Sirah, how went he?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I know not, Sir, he vaniſh'd ſodainly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Vaniſh'd! good Lucy help to hold her faſt
She may not vaniſh too. Spirits are ſubtle.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: This was my fear. Will you have patience,
And fit but in this chair while I relate my ſtory.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ile be as calm in my extreameſt deeps
As is the couch where a ſweet conſcience ſleeps.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Tis now determinate as fate; and ſo
At the whole cluſter of'em. Bleſs me ha!
sp.stage: As Dioniſia preſents her piſtol. Enter. Raſh. Mean. Win. Rafe. Arthur.
sp.l: My father living! Then the cauſe is dead
Of my revenge.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: What is he kill'd out right.
Or els but hurt? Theophilus! my boy!
Dead, paſt recovery. Stay the murdreſs there.
Look you, Sir, to her. I ſuſpect your ſon too
Is not without a hand in't by the haſt
We met him in.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He is not hurt at all
My honour'd father, as I deſire your bleſſing,
But ſtricken with an extaſie of joy.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Look up my boy. How doſt?here's none but friends.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Sure, ſure w'are all then in Eliſium
Where all are friends and fill'd with equal joy.
Earth can have no felicity like this.
If thisbe any thing.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Thou canſt not ſee nothing,
Look well about thee man.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I ſee, I feel, I hear and know ye all:
But who knowes what he knowes, ſees, feels, or hears?
Tis not an age for man to know himſelf in.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: He is not mad I know by that.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If I know any thing, you are my father—

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Thou art a wiſe child.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And I beſeech your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Thou haſt it. Millicont, I have heard your ſtory,
And Lucy, you betwixt you ſooth his fancy,
He will be well anon. Keep'em company Arthur,
And Lucy, bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: More then life, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: You Dionyſia would be chid a little;
But, Sir, let me intreat her parden •

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Dry your eyes: you have it.
Go inſtantly reſume your ſexes habit,
And with the reſt be ready, if we call ye
To Quicſands houſe. The rumour of our coming
Already calls us thither to be aſſiſtant
To juſtice Teſty in a pondrous difference.

sp.speaker: Kaſh.
sp.l: How does he now?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: He's fallen into a ſlumber.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: In with him all I pray.

sp.speaker: Ar. &c.
sp.l: He ſhall have all our cares.
sp.stage: Exit with The. in the chair.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Come my friend Meanwell. Now to Quick-ſands cauſe,
To keep it out of wrangling lawyers jawes.
The face of danger is almoſt made clean
And may conclude all in a comick ſcene.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Come, we will hear this cauſe try'd.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: See the Judges
Have tane their ſeats, while we ſtand here for evidence.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: My worthy friends, y'are come unto a cauſe
As rare, as was your unexpected coming
From the ſuppoſed grave—

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: To th' point I pray.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: How quick you are! Good Mr. Raſhly, know
(Though I crav'd your aſſiſtance) onely I
Supply the chief place in Authority.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: And much good do'c you. I have other buſineſs—
Your Neece Sir was too good for my poor ſon.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Nay Gentlemen, we came to end
A buſineſs: Pray begin no new one firſt.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Well Sir, I ha'done.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Pray Sir fall to the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.l: Bring in the parties.
The firſt branch of the queſtion riſes here
If Quicksands wife, my Neece, be dead or living
Speak Gentlemen. What can you ſay to this?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Quicksands affirm'd to us, that ſhe was dead.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Though, ſince in a deſtracted paſſion
He ſayes ſhe lives.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: She lives, and is that ſtrumpet,
From whom I ſue to be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: That Moor, there?
Did you wed her ſince your fair wives deceaſe?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Tha • ſame is ſhe, and all the wives I had
That black is but an artificial tincture
Laid by my jealouſie upon her face.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: This is moſt ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Braver and braver ſtill,
I aim'd but at a cloud and claſp'd a June,
Will you be onely mine?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have ſworn it ever.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Then I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Teſt.
sp.l: Remove her, and let inſtant tryal be made
To take the blackneſs off.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Then if her ſhame,
And my firm truth appear not, puniſh me.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: However, your conſent to be divorc'd
From Millicent is irrecoverable.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Before you all, Ile forfeit my eſtate
If ere I re-accept her.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Then ſhe's free.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Now Mr. Banelaſs—

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Now for the honour of Wenchers.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Your fact is manifeſted and confeſt.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: In feweſt words it is.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Are you content
To take this woman now in queſtion,
If ſhe be found no Moor to be your Wife,
In holy marriage to reſtore her honour?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Or elſe, before you all, let me be torn
To pieces; having firſt thoſe deareſt members,
In which I have moſt delighted, daub'd with honey▪

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: This proteſtation
Is clear, without reſpect of portion, now,
Or that ſhe is my Neece: For you muſt know
She is no Neece of mine that could tranſgreſs
In that leane kind: Nor muſt ſhe ever look
For favour at my hands.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I am content, to take her as ſhe is,
Not as your Neece, but as his counterfeit ſervant,
Hoping he'le give me with her all about her.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: My chains, and Jewels, worth a thouſand pounds,
I'le pay it for my folly.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: 'Twil be twice
The price of my pawn'd goods. I'le put the reſt
Up for your jeers paſt on my friends and me.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: You are agreed.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: To take her with all faults.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Hah—

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Hell and her changes.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Lead by the hope of juſtice, I am bold
To fix here faſt, here to repair my ruins.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: The devil looks ten times worſe with a white face,
Give me it black again.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Are we not one, you know from the beginning?

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Get thee from me.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Sirrah you have your ſuit and your deſert,
'Tis your beſt part to paſs it patiently.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: 'Tis Winloſs daughter; we have found the error.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I am confounded here. Where is my Wife?

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: I, that's the point muſt now be urg'd. The Law
Asks her at your hands. Anſwer me, where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I am at my joys end, and my wits together.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: You have brought her fame in queſtion: Tis reveng'd
Now you are in both for her life and honour.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: S • eak villain, Murderer, where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I have ſnar'd my ſelf exceeding cunningly;
That quean there knows.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Take heed, Sir, what you ſay,
If ſhe muſt be my wife. Hands off I pray,
Theſe are my goods ſhe wears. Give me'em, Phil.
For fear he ſnatch, Ile put'em in my pockets.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sweet heart, my own will hold'em.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Sweet heart already! we are ſoon familiar.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You know we are no ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Well Mr. Quickſands: becauſe you cannot anſwer
(To put you by the fear of halter-ſtretching)
Since y'have ingag'd your word and whole eſtate
To be divorc'd: And you good Mr. Teſty,
I • you'l be willing yet that my poor ſon
To wed your Neece, as I ſhall find it lawful,
Ile undertake her ſafe recovery.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: I have in heart given her your ſon already.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: And he has her already.
sp.stage: Ent. The. Mil. Ar. Lu. Dio. Winloſs.
sp.l: As for example, ſee Sir.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: See, ſee, the heaven that I am juſtly fallen from,
O may I yet find favour.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Never here.
Hadſt thou not given thy faith to a divorce,
On forfeiture of thine eſtate, which thou
Doſt hold more precious; or couldſt now redeem
That great ingagement; and then multiply
Thy paſt eſtate into a tenfold ſum.
Make me inheritrix of all; and laſt aſſure me
To die within a week, Ile not re-marry thee:
Adulterate beaſt, that brok'ſt thy former wedlock
In thy baſe luſt with that thy ſervant there.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: What a pox no, I tro—My wife that muſt be?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Twas your own doing, to put me to my ſhifts.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: The devil ſhift you, then you will be ſure
Of change enough.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O ſhame unto my blood.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: I will henceforward councel all my friends
To wed their whores at firſt, before they go
Out o'their hands.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: How can you anſwer this?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I utterly deny't upon my oath.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: So do I, and ſafely for any act.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: That's well agen.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: It was but in attempt, I told my Miſtriſs,
Had it been done, ſure I ſhould nere have ſpoke on't.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Thoſe are the councels women can onely keep.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Nothing in act I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: In him 'twas foul enough though.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: O hateful vice in age.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: 'Tis an old vice grown in him from his youth,
Of which bring forth for proof his baſtard there.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: I fear we ſhall be whipt for counterfeits;
My long coats have a grudging of the laſh.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: I ſee my old Maſters face again, and I will
Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: Then Ile bear up again—
Hay diddy daddy, come play with the Baby
Dindle dandle on thy knee, and give him a penny,
And a new coat, o ho—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: My grief and ſhame is endleſs.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Let not grief maſter you, Mr. Quicksands.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: We are your friends, and pitty your afflictions.
What will you give us now and we'le releaſe you
For ever of this changling charge of yours?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: And prove he's not your baſtard. Speak now roundly.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I'le cancel both your mortgages.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: A match. Now look you Sir, your quandam ſervant,
All but the beard he wore; for loſs of which
We'le recompence him.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: O Buzzard, Buzzard, Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: O Maſter, Maſter, Maſter. Your ſervant and no baſtard,
Nor father of your Ideot in Norfolk,
He's there, and well Sir, I heard lately of him.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: How couldſt thou uſe me thus?

sp.speaker: Buz.
sp.l: How could you turn me away ſo?

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Come hither Buzzard. Thou ſhalt not want a M • ſter.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Nor I, I hope, while my old Maſter lives. Y'are welcome home Sir.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: And thou to me my good old ſervant Arnold.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Well fare a miſery of a mans own ſeeking;
A tough one too will hold him tack to's end,
Would doating fools were all ſerv'd ſo for me.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: To ſhut up all: Theophilus, take my Neece,
We'll ſhortly find a Lawfull courſe to marry ye.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: I will take care for't. Arthur, take my daught • r well beſtow'd.
With a glad fathers bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: And mine with it, wiſhing my daughter were as

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Sir take no thought for me, till my ſtrict life
(By making man, and the world meer ſtrangers to me,
In expiation of my late tranſgreſſion
Gainſt maiden modeſty) ſhall render me
Some way deſerving th'honour of a husband.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.l: Spoke like a good new woman.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: How now! do you look ſquemiſh on your fortune,
Sir her's a Gentleman ſhall maintain her blood
As worthy as your own till you defile it,
Tis beſt you cleanſe it again.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Cadzooks I will—
Forgiv'me for ſwearing, and turn Preciſian, a • d pray
I'che noſe that all my brethren whoremaſters ſpend no worſe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My father—

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: O my child.

sp.speaker: Nat.
sp.l: Though Mr. Quicksſands made a Mock-marriage with his Engliſh Moor,
Ile not mock thee.

sp.speaker: Teſ.
sp.l: Enough, euough. I hope all pleas'd at laſt
But Maſter Quick-ſands here.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I yeeld to fortune with an humble knee,
If you be pleas'd, your pleaſure ſhall pleaſe me.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: Now let me be a modoſt undertaker
For us the players, the play and the play-maker:
If we have faild in ſpeech or Action, we
Muſt crave a pardon; If the Commedy
Either in mirth, or matter be not right,
As 'twas intended unto your delight,
The Poet in hope of favour doth ſubmit
Ʋnto your cenſure both himſelf and it,
Wiſhing that as y'are judges in the cauſe
You judge but by the antient Comick Lawes.
Not by their courſe who in this latter age
Have ſown ſuch pleaſing errors on the ſtage,
Which he no more will chuſe to imitate
Then they to fly from truth, and run the State.
But whether I avail, you have ſeen the play,
And all that in defence the Poet can ſay
Is, that he cannot mend it by a jeſt
I'th Epilogue exceeding all the reſt;
To ſend you off upon a champing bit,
More then the ſcenes afforded of his wit:
Nor ſtudies he the Art to have it ſaid
He ſculks behind the hangings as affraid
Of a hard cenſure, or pretend to brag
Here's all your money again brought in i'th bag
If you applaud not, when before the word
'Twas parcel'd out upon the ſhearing-board.
Such are fine helps; but are not practiſed yet
By our plain Poet who cannot forget
His wonted modesty, and humble way
For him and us, and his yet doubtful play,
Which, if receiv'd or but allow'd by you,
We and the play are yours, the Poet too.

div.p: THE Love-ſick Court OR THE Ambitious Politique.
A COMEDY
Written by Richard Brome:

p.hi: Nil mea, ceu mos eſt, commendes carmina curo

div.p: LONDON, Printed by J. T. for A. C. and are to be ſold by Henry Broom, at the Gun in Ivie-lane, 1658.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: A little wit, leſſe learning, no Poetry
This Play-maker dares boaſt: Tis his modeſty.
For though his labours have not found leaſt grace,
It puffs not him up or in minde or face,
Which makes him rather in the Art diſclame
Bold Licenſe, then to arrogate a Name;
Yet to the wit, the ſcholler, and the Poet,
Such as the Play is, we muſt dare to ſhow it
Our judgements to but too: And without fear
Of giving leaſt offence to any ear.
If you finde pleaſure in't, we boaſting none,
Nor you nor we loſe by' expectation.
Sometimes at poor mens boards the curious finde
'Mongſt homely fare, ſome unexpected diſh,
Which at great Tables they may want and wiſh:
If in this ſlight Collation you will binde
Ʋs to believe you' have pleasd your pallats here,
Pray bring your friends w'you next, you know your cheor.

div.head: Drammatis Perſonae.

list.item: King of Theſſaly.
Philargus, the Prince, ſuppoſed Son of the late ſlain General.
Stratocles a Politician.
Philocles, A young Nobleman ſon of the late General, and twin with Philargus.
Euphalus, A Gentleman belonging to the King.
Geron, A curious Coxcomb and a Schollar.
Matho, A villain, ſervant to Stratocles.
Terſulus, A Taylor, ſervant to Philargus.
Ʋarillus, A Barbar, ſervant to Philocles.
Eudina, The Princeſſe.
Themile, Philocles Mother.
Placilla, Her Daughter.
Garula, An old Midwife.
Doris, Themilis Waiting-woman.
4. Rusticks.

div.p: The Scene THESSALY.

sp.speaker: DIſ.
sp.l: Good morrow my good Lord. How fares the King?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: More ſick in mind then body, by th'opinion,
(Not onely of the skilful Doctors, but) of all
That come about him.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I that have not ſeen him
Since he was ſick, can gueſs, then at the cauſe
Of his diſtemper. He is ſick o'th'ſubject;
Th'unquiet Commons fill his head and breaſt
With their impertinent diſcontents and ſtrife.
The peace that his good care has kept'hem in
For many years, ſtill feeding them with plenty,
Hath, like ore pampered ſteeds that throw their Maſters,
Set them at war with him. O miſery of kings!
His vertue breeds their vices; and his goodneſs
Pulls all their ills upon him. He has been
Too long too lenetive: A thouſand heads
(Or ſay a hundred, or but ten) cut off
Of the moſt groſs ones, the prime, leading heads
Of theirs a moneth ſince, had preſerv'd him better
Then all his doctors pills can purge him now.

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: You are too ſharp Diſanius. There's a means,
As milde as other of the Kings clear Acts,
In agitation now, ſhall reconcile
All to a common peace no doubt.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What's that Juſtinius?

sp.speaker: Jus.
sp.l: Stay: Here comes Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I fear, in that
Ambitious pate lies the combuſtable ſtuff
Of all this late commotion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why is man
Preſcrib'd on earth to imitate the Gods,
But to come neareſt them in power and action?
