sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Die villane, die. And were thy maſter in thee,
The thirſt of whoſe ambition ſought our bloods;
His fleſh with thine ſhould here become a prey
Unto the Ravens.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: O, be pitiful
And ſpare my life, my Lords, and I'le reveal
Matters of weight and wonder; which, conceal'd,
Will yet coſt both your lives, and make the Princeſs,
If ſhe not anſwer my Lords fierce deſires,
Subject to rape and murder.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: How can ſhe
So fall into his power.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: We ſhall abuſe
The truſt the Gods have put into our hands
If we neglect to execute juſtice on thee.

sp.speaker: Math
sp.l: Let me but warn ye of Eudina's danger,
Whereby her virgin Innocence may not ſuffer,
And then inflict your furies on me.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: That charms our ready hands and ſteel. Speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: This very hour ſhe's to be ſurpriz'd
By my Lord Stratocles, here, on Tempe plains,
Where ſhe is come to walk, ſlenderly guarded
To take the air. He with a ſtrength will ſeiſe her
And hurry her hence unto his Manſion houſe,
To yield to his deſire, or death, if ſuddenly
Prevention be not made.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Tis worth our care.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Preſerve me from his vengeance, and I'le bring you
Unto his enterprize.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: We muſt not truſt him,
He may have laid an Ambuſcado for us.

sp.speaker: Philar
sp.l: See brother, ſtand upon our guard.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Help, help, aid me good people, help.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: What means the villan now.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: What's the complaint?

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: What is your grievance, ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I am a ſervant to Lord Stratocles
Who has preſerv'd your Countey and your lives.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: We are the more beholding to him; on.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: 'Twas more his gentlenes then our deſerving; on.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Theſe two are his malignant enemies;
And finding that my Lord is in theſe parts
Together with the Princeſs, fair Eudina
(Who has made him her choice) they lie in wait
To murder him, as they had me, had not
The Gods ſent you to reſcue me.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: 'Twas more their Gentleneſs, then your deſerving, on.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I have no more to ſay, but that you take'em
On your allegiance to ſafe cuſtody,
And let me paſs.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Un'ch, That would be more
Our gentleneſs then your deſerving too. on, on.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Dear friends—

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Good, interrupt us not we'll hear ye in order.
On you, Sir, ere you go; and come not back
For any thing unſpoke you left behind.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir, I had like to ha'leſt my ſword deſerving,
Behind, which they diſarm'd me of.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: That was their Gentleneſs more then your
(They having three ſwords, and you none to guard you)
They kill'd you not indeed, yet on again.
W •• t further do you charge'em with.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No more, nor you, leſs you detain me longer.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Now you grow bold, and ſaucy I muſt tell you.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: Now y'are a knave, a villane and a Traytor,
Leſt you no more behind you but a ſword?
I ſaw a ſcabberd on your face of late,
A falſe one: Seek it out.

sp.speaker: 3. Ruſ.
sp.l: O here it is.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Put it him on again. On with it, on.
Reſiſt and we will hang thee. Now my Lords,
My Princeſs I may ſay: For one of you
Muſt be our King. We know you though you know
Not us; you may perhaps hereafter know us
More by your Gentleneſs then our deſerving.

sp.speaker: Phil. Phil.
sp.l: O worthy Countrey men.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: We are the heads of Tempe; and the chief
Swain heads of Theſſaly (the King has known us)
And here we came to lay our heads together
For good of common wealth. Here at the verge
Of this adjoyning Thicket is our Bower
Of conſultation; and from thence (regardful
Ever with eye and ear for common good)
We ſaw a beard pull'd off; and heard that mouth,
(Which now is dumb) open a plot, unlike
The pittiful compl • int he made to us.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: But ſaw you not ſome paſſages before?
Of his attempt upon our lives?

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Good Gods.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: No we came in but then. Thoſe are enough
To hang the man, and turn his Lord out of
Our Countrey favour: If we find he has
That plot upon the body of the Princeſs
Of Rape and Murder. He can be no King
For us: for, ſirrah, we have wives and daughters.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Stand cloſe. See who comes here.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: So, now go back my friends. There's ſome reward.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Thanks to the noble bounteous Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Srat.
sp.l: Lady your tears are bootleſs.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Help ye Gods.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your cries as unavailable. The Gods
(To whom your friendly fooliſh lovers
Have ſacrific'd each other) have given you up
To me the onely worthy of you.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: No they are both ſublim'd into one ſtar,
Yet of a double influence, that ſhall
Strike death into thy purpoſes, and give
Me light by which t'aſcend with them to live
After my preſent death.
sp.stage: She offers to kill her ſelf with a knife, he holds her.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Your haſt to death ſhall not prevent my luſt.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: She muſt outlive thy Luſt and the falſe Traytor

sp.speaker: Ruſ.
sp.l: Hold, hold, diſarm, but kill him not.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: Wee'll keep him tame.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You have ods o'me.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I am in heaven already.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Live wonder of the heavens, a ſtar on earth
Out ſhining theirs.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: What a ſhort journey 'tis
For heavenly minds to reach unto the Gods!

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: B • tray'd!

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: No not betray'd. Y'are but well meet my Lord,
But that's our Gentlen eſs more then your deſerving.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Am I become the ſhame and ſcorn of peſants.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Or if you'l ha't betray'd, then blame your own
Overmuch policy and want of Beaſts
To carry it to Market. We nere lay
More burthen on a Aſſe, then he can bear
Here in the countrey: what is done at court
We know not. Here perhaps is one can tell,
Know you this bearded Satyre?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Coward, ſlave,
Thy faintneſs hath betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No, 'twas ods,
Such as men meet that ſight againſt the Gods.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: The fellow has ſome Grace; he weeps: But come
Princeſs and Princes, what is now your pleaſure
We do unto theſe men?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: For me, I have learn'd
By mine own ſufferings in my afflictions
To be compaſſionate. I wiſh their pardon.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That mercy wounds me deeper with remorſe
Then all my loſt deſigns, and their deriſion
Have done with indignation.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: There is ſome hope theſe yet may prove new men.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Lord Stratocles,
Thoſe wounds that pierce the heart with true contrition
Do bring the precious balm in'em that cures it.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: We wiſh yours may be ſuch.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: And that this ſhame
May guard you innocent of future blame.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: Here's ſweetneſs upon ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Now it remains, that we adviſe our ſelves,
Brethren of Tempe, that ſince theſe delinquents
Are fallen into our hands, that we diſcharge
Our Countrey loyalty with diſcretion,
And not releaſe him from our power, but by
The power above us. (that's the kings) wee'l wait
On you to court. On you for your new loves,
And you for old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I'le acquaint my father with your care,
He ſhall be witneſs of our bringing in
The ambitious Politick trapt in his own gin.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bereft of all my joyes and hopes at once!
Is there no com • ort, nor no counſel left me?
Why ſtand you gazing thus with ſealed lips?
Where is your counſell now, which you are wont
In trifling matters to pour out in plenty?
Now, in the peril of my life and ſtate
I cannot get a word. Give me my daughter,
Or take my Kingdom too. Where is ſhe? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: All we can ſay or hear is, ſhe was taken
Out of her private walks by violent hands,
Onely we gueſſe the maſter of the plot
Was Stratocles, who now is miſſing in the Court.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: He ask'd my leave to leave the Court, and had it.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Twas a fit gloſſe for his fowl treachery.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But what ha' you ſaid for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: We have diſpatch't a hundred ſeveral poſts
To every coaſt and angle of your Kingdom:
No way of finding her is left unſought.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Could we finde Stratocles, ſhe might be found.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Stil upon him? Where's Philocles? where's Philargus?
They are miſſing too.

sp.speaker: Diſ▪
sp.l: Hell has not in't a thought
That can detract their honours.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: Yet a Rumor
Is ſpread about the Court; they are gone to fight.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: 'Gainſt whom?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: Againſt themſelves. Nay more, that they
Have fought, and both are ſlain.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: You may as ſoon
Believe the Artick and Antartick poles
Can meet it oppoſition, amidſt
The firmament, and jointly in a fall
Extinguiſh both their lights in Neptunes boſom.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Whence ſprings this Rumor.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Stratocles is the head
We may be confident; and his men the pipes
That have diſpers't it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Stil you judge Stratocles.
What purpoſe can he have in't.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O my ſiſter
Has heard the news too. Weep not tender ſiſter,
Your ſons are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yes they are with the Gods.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And, had they tane Eudina with them too,
My doubts and fears were over, well as yours.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Here's one that makes a face, an ugly one,
And would weep too, had ſhe but moiſture in her.
How now! Whoſe Mare's dead, Garrula? Take thy bottle
And turn that into tears. Or doſt thou wring
Thy face becauſe that's dry? Gi'mee't, I'le fill it.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My ſon, oh, oh my ſon is at deaths door.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: And is death ſo unkind to keep it ſhut
Againſt him? Out upon him churle.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: My liege
And Madam (it ſhall out) you might have ſav'd
My ſons life in your ſervants love, whoſe ſcorn
Will be his death, except the King divert it,
And I ſhall tell him what you know I know—

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: O me undone.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: And open ſuch a ſecret
Unto his majeſty—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet forbear me now.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Do you ſlight me in the care of my ſons life?
Do you ſcorn my ſecret too, that may be worth
More then your kingdom to you?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Away old fool.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Now you ſhall never know't.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: For thy good wil
The king would thank thee, in offering at ſome mirth
To cool his grief, but that it is too hot
Yet to be touch'd.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: Indeed you do not well
To move the King, or to perplex the Lady
Now in their ſorrows fulneſs.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: What's their ſorrow
To mine? My ſons a dying.

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: Her ſons are dead,
And the Kings daughter loſt.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: But I pray, ſay,
Is my Lord Philocles and Philargus dead?

sp.speaker: Juſ.
sp.l: 'Tis ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Then I ſay my ſon ſhall live.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: And ſo wilt thou while thou canſt lift thy bottle
To that old Mazer.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Hem! A hem! a ha!

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Do you rejoyce, and ſhew the rotten half tooth
You have left that they are dead.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: No I rejoyce
That the advancement that the giglet gap'd for
In one of their fine followers is loſt,
In hope of which ſhe ſcorn'd my ſon. But now
He ſhall ſcorn her and live.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Out envious trot

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Ile comfort him with the newes.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: away you Hag,
Here comes one merry look.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Joy to the king.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Well ſaid, ſpeak up and home good

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Your daughter's ſafe return'd ſo is your ſon, Madam,
For which you are to thank the Gods: This is
Their true relation.
sp.stage: He gives the King a paper.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Where is Stratocles?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Caught in the ſnares of his foul treachery.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Bravely and honeſtly ſpoken Eupathus.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: And by their hands whoſe voices he had once
For his election.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What his country heads?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: They all turn head upon him now.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Brave heads
Obſerve my judgement now, my king: Thoſe heads
I will ſo ſouſe in our beſt Greekiſh Wines,
That they ſhall be ſuch heads! O heads, heads, heads!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do approve your judgment good Diſanius,
But wiſh you not inſult ore mans dejection.
We find that Stracocles is much Penetent
And troubled at his treſpaſs.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: A halter ſtill him
For an ambitious hypocritical Traytor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The time for my Eudina's match draws near,
And I no longer will attend on fortune,
I have decreed it paſt recal, regardleſs
Whether againſt the oracle, or with it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet am I conſident in your aſſertion
You prieſts of Delphos.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Hee'l beſtow her yet
On Stratocles, if ſhe ſtand longer doubtful
In a fair choiſe.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: Fear not my Lord. That doubt
Your Countrey heads will clear. He has loſt them
For ever.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O brave heads! I will ſo ring
Their ears with jewels of praiſes and preferment
That they ſhall glare like direful comets at him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: One ſhe ſhall chuſe of them: If not, I'le put
A third upon her.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: With your pardon Sir,
Why are you (for I find it is ſo) ſtronger
For Philocles?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No reaſon urges me;
And yet I find an inclination in me
That pleads for him. I can perceive you too,
Are partial towards Philargus. Can you yield
A reaſon for't?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, he is my eldeſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas, But not an hour. Well, I'le remit
My power propounding, and accept
Her choice of either, made within the time.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I, there my hopes do anchor; elſe they were
Certain of Ship-wrack: yet the perillous waves
My veſſel rides on ſeems ſo many graves.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Brother, and friend, I'm deaf to all deſwaſion.
I charge you by Eudina's love, our friendſhip,
And (if there be) ought that you hold more ſacred,
Move not to alter my fix'd reſolution.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: That reſolution's mine; And I conjure you
By the ſelf-ſame reſpects, and all that are
Or may be hollowed, to let me depart.
I will remove but for ſome few daies journey
Whence you ſhall duly hear from me. But rather
I'le travail to th' Antipodes, then here
Linger the vain impediment of your joyes
In your Eudina.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Travel's my deſign.
Eudina muſt be yours. She is a bliſs
Which heaven created for you.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Can a bliſs
Be purchas'd with your abſence? No: 'Twil torture
Equally in fruition as in want.
Were it a Kingdom onely, we could part it
Without the quarrel of the Thebean brothers;
Or, were it heaven it ſelf, Caſtor and Pollux
Should have our imitation. But Eudina
Is onely indiviſible.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Add to it this,
Their ſentence is erroneous, that deny
Partition to the ſoul: For ours do witneſs,
Friendſhip can give her a diviſion,
And make reciprocal community
Of all her faculties. But ſtill Eudyna
Is indiviſible. Why name I her,
Whom to forget muſt be my onely taſque?
Brother adieu.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: 'Tis I that muſt take leave.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Is it even ſo?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I fear we are prevented.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Nephews, why left you ſo the preſence? I
May juſtly fear you were ill advis'd in it.
The King expects your quick return, and will not
Let paſs this peremptory day, ſet down
For matching of his daughter; to preſerve
Life, State, or Kingdom. Have you a purpoſe,
Firſt having beg'd that villain Stratocles pardon,
To give him up your intereſt in the Princeſs?
The Kingdom too, to boot? will you compel
The King to give him all?

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Not ſo good Uncle.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What do you leſs in flying from the preſence,
When that affair is now in agitation?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Uncle, you ſaw withal the great deſtraction
We left the Princeſs in. How when ſhe look'd
Upon Philargus, ſhe inclin'd to him;
And when on me to me; when on us both
How extaſied ſhe fell!

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: A ſtrong neceſſity
There is that one of us abſent.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Therefore
You both flie off to travel ſeveral wayes!
Come, let me tell you your courteſie is fooliſh,
And you unworthy to have ſuch a fortune
Hang like a pregnant cloud over your heads
Ready to be diſſolv'd in ſhowres upon you,
While your own madneſs conjures up a wind
To blow't away.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Uncle, you are unjuſt,
I would remove to let that golden ſhowre
Light upon Philocles.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I upon Philargus.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I could even ſwadle'em both for a brace of Babyes.
Your folly makes me mad: will you return
Yet to the preſence, both of you?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Uncle, you know
To be both there, is neither to be there,
But to breed more perplexity in Eudyna.
Pray take Philargus.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Nephew, come, be wiſe:
It is a crown that Courts you; and the name
Of friend, or Brother ought to ſtand aloof,
And know a diſtance, where ſuch dignity
Is tendred. Take your opportunity,
I find you coming, come.

sp.speaker: Philarg.
sp.l: I pray take Philocles.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I'le take him for the wiſer man then. Nephew,
Come, and embrace your fortune, and forget not
To thank the Gods your Brother has no more wit.
A Kingdom and a beauteous bed▪fellow
(There Nephew, there!) Do not thoſe bare a ſound
'Bove friend and Brother, ha?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: not in mine ears.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What froſt has ceiz'd their blood, & brains, which neither
Beauty nor dignity can thaw? Go travel.
What ſtay you for? young Gentlemen ſometimes
Wait for a gale of gold to blow'em out
O'th'harbour; Stratocles will furniſh you,
And thank you more then for his forfeit life.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Stratocles can gain nothing by my abſcence,
While her Philargus ſtayes.

sp.speaker: Philarg.
sp.l: No, nor by mine,
While Philocles remains.

sp.speaker: Diſ
sp.l: Shall I make a motion,
Will one of you remain?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: One muſt and ſhall.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Then yield to take your lots for't. (I will make'em)
As you reſpect my love; your mothers life;
The kingdoms good; Eudynas love and life,
Let it be ſo. Pauſe not upon't, but do't.
See, here's ink and paper. I am inſpir'd,
Apollo, with thy wiſdom. Love.—and friendſhip.
See, here's a paſs for one, and a plantation
For tother. Love and friendſhip Gentlemen.
Love ſhall abide at home, and friendſhip walk,
According to the cuſtom of the world.
Let it be ſo. ▪Come ſtudy not, but draw,
I'le draw upon ye both elſe.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Friendſhip for me then.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: See here I have it brother. And yours is love.
My love be proſperous to you. My horſe, my horſe.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: All's ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: In the firſt place then bring
A parting cup, that by the grapes Elizar
As Jove by Acheron, I may proteſt
My conſtancy and zeal unto my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: And now's my time to act thy purpoſe, Doris.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Kick not your heels againſt the Gods, Philargus,
It is moſt evidently their decree
That you abide and Philocles remove.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I do obey my Lot. And nobleſt brother.
Be you as free in love, as I from envy.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: But how can you forgo that equal intereſt
You have with me in Theſſaly, and Eudina?

sp.speaker: Diſs.
sp.l: Why ſhould that trouble you? you ſee he does
Forgo't; and is a going. Would he were gone once.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Can love allow't?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Variety of objects
Like Nails abandon one a nother. So
May I, by novelties of Travail, loſe
The thought of Love; and chearfully return
Both hers and yours in a more juſt relation.
sp.stage: Enter Varillus with a bowl of wine.
sp.l: Give me the bowl. Now brother to that love
You owe the fair Eudina, unto which
I give th'addition of mine own, and all
The joves that ere I wiſh'd my ſelf and her,
And to that friendſhip, which nor Time, nor abſence
Shall ever end or alter.
sp.stage: He drinks and gives Varillus the bowl.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Now the ſervice that may redeem my faults
Is to be done.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Give it me full, Varillus.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I'le give you more then you expect by this.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: You have the victory in friendſhip, brother,
Who, by your reſolute abſence will inforce
And drive me to a happineſs; wherein
I muſt not ceaſe, in all the ſtrength of prayers
Of ſacrifice, and vowes; in all my goods
Of fortune, mind and body to be yours:
Which that you may return to repoſſeſs
With the more ſpeed, this health to auſpicate
And expedite your travails.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: They are done
Already if my Pothecaries skill fail not.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: With this embrace my brother, and my laſt
Of preſent ceremony, I now wiſh you
In th'arms of your Eudina—
And may my better part of ſoul, which now
I leave in truſt with you, by you be breath'd
Into her breaſt; that ſhe may lively find
She has my love in yours; and that in you
She has us both.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: So, ſo, enough. Ha'ye done yet?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: How is it with you brother?

sp.speaker: Philarg.
sp.l: As it is
With ſouls that leave the world in peace.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: For ſhame
Leave womaniſh ceremony. Will you part
Before it be too late?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Too ſoon I fear.
Philargus! Brother! Friend! Ye Gods, how comes this?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What is he dead? I ſee then how it comes.
You or your man, or both ha'poyſon'd him.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: No, 'twas my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Thou wilt not go out o'th'world
With a lie i'thy mouth? Speak yet again,

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: He has ſaid well for me already,

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Gone, paſt recovery, but he ſhall not paſs
Without my company.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Wilt thou die mad too?
sp.stage: He offers to kill himſelf. Diſ. ſnatcheth his ſword away.
sp.l: Come, Sir, let go your whiblin. He has yet
Some breath. Run for Phyſitians—No, Sir, ſtay.
I will not quit you ſo. I can read guilty lines
Palpably on this villans viſnomy.
Is there no more i'th'houſe? ſome help here! ho!
Nephew forbear. As you will have me think
sp.stage: Philocles offers again to kill himſelf.
sp.l: You guiltleſs of your brothers blood, forbear.
How am I tortur'd! Ho! Philargus; rub him,
Rub him, he may live yet.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: O that the world
Might be ſo happy!

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: So, well ſaid: A box
Or two in kindneſs will not do amiſs.
Stir not you ſirrah. O, Sir, you lay hold
On that ſame traytor.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: I'le not ſtir my Lord.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I'le hold you to your word, Sir, run, Sir, you
And fetch Phyſitians.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: O my Lord, fallen dead!

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Stay but to look upon him, and I'le ſwear
Thou art his murderer. Fetch the Kings Phyſitians,
If not to cure him; yet to rip the cauſe
Out of his ſodain death. I gueſs they'l finde
Your handy-work in's maw.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: You heard him ſay
It was himſelf that did it. I am clear'd.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: My Lord, the King, impatient of your ſtay,
Has ſent • .

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What has he ſent. Has he ſent means
To call this man from death, or that from falling
After him into th'grave?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: O heavy ſpectacle!

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: But, come I will not cry tho'. Pray aſſiſt me,
In with this body, Charity commands
When griev'd neceſſity intreats your hands.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My Ruſtici amici, your Councel and
Your vertue have reſtor'd me. And tis true
As Wholom ſaid the good Antiſthenes
Vertue is armour 'gainſt the very fates.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: We told you for your good, good Mr. Geron,
Fond love became you not.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: It ſat upon your coat like burs or bryars
Stuck in the hindlocks of our fleecy ſheep;
Who ſhake their heads; figgle, and writh their tayls,
And bleat for woe; ſprinkle the ground behind'em
Sometimes I wiſſe: Twould make one laugh and pitty'em
And all at once, but all remedileſs.
Til we with helping wit and hands releaſe'em

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: A wiſe man then in love is like a ſheep
l'th' bryars. As Whilome ſaid

sp.speaker: 3. Ruſ.
sp.l: But (by the way)
What was that Whilome, Sir, you ſpeak much of him,
But what was he pray.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: An ancient Britain, whom I have affected
As idly as my love. But I'le forget it
And uſe that word no more. The clowns have found me.

sp.speaker: 4. Ruſ.
sp.l: But will you now proceed upon your plot
For th'honour of Tempe plains, and Tempe ſwains.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You can all dance.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: After our countrey guiſe.

sp.speaker: 3. Ruſ.
sp.l: Like ſo many light horſes.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: So can our wives
Who have follow'd us up to Court we thank'em
Pray Juno we get them honeſtly home again.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: There is no doubt. However fear you nothing
As why—Tis hard to leave off an old cuſtom.

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: The why was out, but lome ſtuck in your teeth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis well it did ſo. You can dance you ſay.
A dance I have projected for the Princeſs
Who ever marries her it ſhall ſerve. As why—

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Again 'twas eene a comming.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You are as quick as why—

sp.speaker: 2. Ruſ.
sp.l: And there again.

sp.speaker: 1. Ruſ.
sp.l: Nay we are heads, I tell you Maſter Geron,
And ſhould have wit; and ſhew't we can i' th'countrey,
In the head vein, though hear at Court, like courtiers
We'll ſhew it in our heels. Pray therefore on.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: On, let us then to practiſe. King and court
Shall ſee, to crown their joyes, ſome countrey ſport.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No anſwer, no return? Muſt I intreat,
Yet have my undeſerved favours ſlighted?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Yet, Sir, your Kingly patience.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stupid folly
'Twere longer to attend. My vow is paſt
And regiſter'd in heaven; the minute is
Athand, that calls down thonder on me, which
No tear, or prayers can mollifie or aver' • ,
If I upon ſo long deliheration
Shall falſifie. So, call in Stratocles.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: O my dread father. Yet one hours patience
Till Eupathus or Diſanius return.
One ſhort, ſhort hour: I may not live ſo long.
His wife you nam'd; though you may force me take him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I'le leave that to the Gods.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: They will forgive. Give them your imitation
In mercy, as in power on earth. I know Diſanius
Went not in vain to call'em to your preſence.
And him that he brings firſt into this room
O Philocles or Philargus I will take,
Though he precede the other but one foot,
I have it by inſpiration from the Gods.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You are full of dreams.

sp.speaker: Thym.
sp.l: This cannot, Sir, be long
In tryal. King Yet I am not bound to wait
On thoſe ingrateful men. O Stratocles,
You have from your late Errors, which your then
Head-ſtrong ambition hurried and caſt you in
With that humility purg'd your ſelf, that I
Conceive you now a temperate Man; and am
Inſtructed by the clemency of the Gods
To cheriſh and reward your vertue. Therefore
From their divine appointment, as my hands—

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: (O mighty, Sir—

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dare not to diſobey me)
Receive Eudina.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Royal King and Maſter,
Miſtake not ſo the pleaſure of the Gods.
My forfeit life you have forgiven me:
Your Kingly power and grace might do it. You
Have given it freely: but I took't with caution,
By future ſervice to make good your gift:
But for my forfeit love to fair Eudina,
And my loſt honor to the twin-born brothers,
There can be no redemption, if I add
By acceptation of your bounteous offer
A ſecond treſpaſs, greater then the former.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Do you refuſe her then.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: In hope ſhee'l plead
My pardon to your grace.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: The Gods have wrought
Effectually for me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Strangely, unexpected
Are you become a ſuppliant Placilla?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: In the behalf, Sir, of your loyal ſubjects,
The Swains of Tempe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I expected, rather,
News from your unkind brothers. See Juſtinius,
The Commons, rather then I ſhall beſtow
My daughter upon Stratocles, do beſeech me
To take a further time.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Y'are happy, Sir,
In his refuſal and in their requeſt.
They are fair predictions of enſuing joyes
To you, your daughter, and the Kingdom, If
I may be worthy to divine ſo much.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How ere thy divination proves, thy wiſh
Is worth our thanks. And we may have
Glad tidings preſently. Now Eupathus
Where is Diſanius, Philocles, and Philargus?
Why come they not?

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: They are all at hand my liege.
This paper may excuſe their ſtay.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O do
They plead excuſe then?

sp.speaker: Thym.
sp.l: I am full of fears.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: And I of ſodain joy.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.l: Pray all be well.
The King has ſtruck his breaſt, and ſeems perplext.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Justinius, Stratocles, read here this Paper.
Go Eupathus, and let them enter. Stay.
Yet go, bring them in their preſcribed manner.
I'le ſend the woman off, whoſe ſodain grief
May be a bar to our proceedings. Madam—

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I fear that Garrula has detected me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I muſt intreat a while your abſence, Lady.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: May I preſume to ask your reaſon, Sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My will has been above your queſtion. Pray,
Let me requeſt you go.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I know obedience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And go Placilla, ſend old Garrula to me.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Now tis moſt evident. O mighty, Sir,
Conceive not worſe of me then Garrula.
Let us appear together.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You may be pleas'd to hear me firſt.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Pray pull not
More weight upon your breaſt then you can bear,
By your impertinent ſtay. Go I command you.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I muſt obey. However tis too late
To change the reſolution of my fate.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I have not known her thus. I fear deſtraction
Fore-runs the voice of grief, as to prevent it.
Heaven knowes I call'd for Garrula, but to ſend her
With beſt directions to prepare and arm
Her tender ſoul againſt the ſting of ſorrow
Before it ſhould approach her. But Eudina
You muſt be valliant; and not let the ſight
Of death in others ſhake your confidence.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: How means your majeſty?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Suppoſe that both
Your fatal lovers, Philocles and Philargus
Slept in the caves of death.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I ſhould not live then;

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Suppoſe his deſteny had cut off one,
And, in him, all the impediments, that croſt
You in th' enjoying of the other, ſay
Which could you wiſh ſurviver? But you have
Declar'd your conſtant purpoſe to poſſeſs
The firſt Diſanius brings into this preſence.
Come; one is dead. There is a ſtrict neceſſity
You know it. Now collect your Reaſon: For 'tis not
Your paſſion for the dead; nor your diſlike
Of Stratocles; no though my ſubjects yeeld you
A longer time, ſhall make me tempt the Gods
sp.stage: Recorders. Ent. Diſanius before a herſe. Philocles after. Varillus manacled and led by Terſu • us. Euputhus ſupports Philocles, as ready to ſink with grief.
sp.l: By breaking of my vow. Be ſtedfaſt then,
As you reſpect a father; and take courage.
See Philocles lives.

sp.speaker: Eud
sp.l: Philargus then
And unto him the firſt to be brought in
My faith was vow'd; and he is now my choice.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What being dead? Could you affect'em ſo
Equally, both alive, that you forbore
To chuſe, becauſe you could not have'em both;
And now ſeek onely him cannot be had?
sp.stage: The herſe ſet down. Eudinae kneels to it. Philo. kneels
sp.l: What Love, what madneſs call you this? good Gods,
Throw not your wrath upon me in deſtruction on the other

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Nor let your paſſion Maſter you great, ſir, ſide,
As ſodain grief does her. But give a little
Scope to her ſorrow. Shee will ſoon return
And meet her Reaſon in obedience
To your deſires.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thank thee good Juſtinius.
sp.stage: During which Diſanius &c. diſcourſe with the King. Diſanius ſeems to acquaint the King with the manner of Philargus death, pointing at Varillus. The King ſeems much troubled; but at the end of the ſong, (as by the Kings appointment Diſanius raiſeth Philocles, and Juſtinius raiſeth Eudina, and bring them to the King while Eupathus with the Attendants go forth with the herſe, the Recorders playing. which done,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your virgin tears and vowes ore your loſt love
I did attend with pardon, my Eudina,
I • hope you are now compliant to my will.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Grieve not your father Madam.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: I ha'done;
And as the Gods direct him to command me,
I muſt and will obey.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: So that's well ſaid.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Gods have pleas'd Eudina to determine
Your doubtful choice, reſerving Philocles
Unto your love without competitor:
Therefore it now remains that he be taken
Into your liking; whom I have decreed
My ſucceſſor.

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: His merits are above
Me and this land; In which what intereſt
My birth hath given me I reſign to him.
Onely let me beſeech a further reſpite.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For what? the celebration? I conſent;
But for the contract, this imediate hour
Shall ſee it knit beyond all diſſolution.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I that I thirſt to ſee.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give me your hands.
Yours Philocles.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Why give you not your hand,
Dare you not truſt the King with't? ſhould he now
Shew a jades trick and flie back.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I beſeech
Under your highneſs Pardon, yet, a reſpite.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: More reſpits yet? Was ever hopeful match
Driven ſo round about?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why this delay?

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: My brothers blood cries in me for your juſtice
Which muſt be executed on his murderer
Before I ſafely can, or dare poſſeſs
His intereſt in the faith of fair Eudina.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O, is that all? that may be ſoon diſpatch'd.
Come forwards Poyſoner. Good your Majeſty,
For expedition, make me his judge,
And hangman too (I care not) rather then
Suffer this match hang o'the tenters thus.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Has he confes'd the fact?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Yes, yes to me.
I beat it out of him. Quickly good King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Your patience good Diſanius Sirrah ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: It was my act. But may your mercy look
Upon my love in it unto my Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Your Lord ſhall be your j • dge then.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: I adjudge him
To ſharp but lingring tortures (for his death
Alone can yeeld no ſatisfaction)
Tortures that may draw in, by his confeſſion,
As acceſſaries with him, all the homicides
That are i'th' Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: A hard matter that.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Nor can I think his onely brain and hands
Compos'd the poyſon.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Hang him, hee's a Barber,
And uſes Aqua fortis, oyl of Vitriol,
Mercury, and ſuch like, to cleanſe his Raſors.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: 'Tis good that you Varillus clear your conſcience
And, if you had confederates in the fact,
Give up their names.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Varillus, I ſuſpect
Doris joyn'd hand with you in my Lords death.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What's that you mutter?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: It ſhall out my Lord;
The handmaid Doris put him on't; I know't
By what ſhe ſaid to us both we being her lovers.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: The Taylor proves an honeſt man: becauſe
He cannot have the wench himſelf, he'll hang her.

sp.speaker: Var.
sp.l: Of her I had the poyſon, tis confeſt.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O that whore. King. Find her and drag her hither.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Where's my Philargus? Give me yet his body,
That with a mothers tears I may imbalm it.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: You have heard the woſul newes then; but my ſiſter
Could grief recal Philargus, we would weep
A ſecond deluge for his reparation;
Renew his breath by ſighing, and awake him,
With grones out of his Sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Already
Have you inter'd him then? you made ſtrange haſt.
Was it your ſubtlety to ſend me hence,
Fearing my cries might have reviv'd him, king?
And ſo again delay'd your daughters marriage?
I have enough to croſs it yet Philargus

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Deſtraction ſure.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My fear foreſaw't.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd, for from my depth of ſo • row,
Through this thick film o • tears, I can perceive
You are about to joyn the hands and faiths
Of Philocles and Eudina,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is not that
Enough to dry your tears, and ſhew, you that
The Gods were rather merciful in leaving
This ſon, then rigorous in taking • other?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Or would you now, cauſe you have loſt Philargus,
Kill Philocles too by croſſing of this contract?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: It is the pleaſure of the Gods I croſs it.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Of devils it is. What can ſhe mean? Go ſleep.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: King by your leave.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: What ſayes old ſuckbottle now?

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Nay I am here before you Garrula,
And now will tell the long hid ſecret for you.
And if I erre in it, diſprove me.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: Tell't then.
My faltring tongue will fail me. I can hear tho'.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This contract muſt not be.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You then muſt yeeld
More reaſon then I find you have.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your ſelf
Can never make it. You will ſooner joyn
The Wolfe and Lamb. Falcon and Dove together.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: No trifling I command you Thymele.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: If you be ſerious, Mother, hold us not
In this ſuſpence.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Let not the royal blood
Of Theſſaly be ſtain'd with an inceſtuous match.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: She ſayes right. They are both your lawful children
By your own vertuous Queen now in—Eliſium.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What dreams are theſe of your diſtemperd heads,

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: This is no dream or fable. But unfain'd
As truth it ſelf: Which with your gracious leave
I ſhall demonſtrate, humbly craving pardon
For my ſo long concealment, as I'le yeeld
Due reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Freely ſpeak, you have it.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: You may remember in your civil wars,
(Thoſe cruel warres, as I may juſtly ſtile' em)
In which my husband fell—

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: O my brave brother!

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: When open Rebels and domeſtick Traytors
Purſu'd your Crown and life; your gracious Queen
To have been brought to bed; and was beleev'd
To have miſcarried by an abortive birth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: True: In her flight ſhe was conſtrain'd to take
A neighbouring cottage; and uſe the help
Of the Swains wife.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.l: That ſwain-eſs was my ſelf,
Though my deſerts have glorified me ſince:
And by my help (and ſomewhat of the Gods)
She then made you the Father of that Prince.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Take up thy bottle—Siſter, ſpeak you on.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Th'affrighted queen (yet wiſe in that extremity)
Suſpecting that the innocence of her babe
Born to a Kingdom, could not be ſecur'd
In thoſe combuſtions from apparent danger,
Sent him to me in private, then in travel
Of my Philargus—Charging me to fain
A ſecond labour, with the Midwifes aid,
For Philocles: I did, and was reputed
Mother of both.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I cannot think our Queen
Would keep us ignorant of ſo good a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: I mov'd her oft to tell you. But ſhe anſwer'd,
All is not ſound, There's danger, yet; And when
After Eudyna's birth ſhe felt her ſelf
At point of death, ſhe ſtrictly did enjoyn
Me and this woman, onely conſcious with her,
By oath of which ſhe had prepar'd this copy
In her own hand, to keep it ſilent, till
Philocles ſhould be able to ſecure
Himſelf from treachery; or that your terme
Of life expiring, or ſome accident
Of no leſſe conſequence requir'd detection.
For further proof—

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My joy forbids more queſtioning
Give me my • leſh and blood into my boſome.
Thrice happy Fathers if your Children were
Borne to you thus of perfect Age. But where
Is now a Match for my Eudina. I
Have here a ſucceſſor.
sp.stage: A ſhout within and crying Philargus, Philargus. &c.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hah! Voyces i'th Ayre that cry Philargus?

sp.speaker: Eud.
sp.l: Voyces that do tell me, I muſt follow him
Up to the heavens, and there be married to him.

sp.speaker: Deſ.
sp.l: Here's the She-Devil now.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You need not pull me
For that mans love, I laid thy Lord to ſleep:
Had I lov'd thee beſt, then his Lord had ſlept.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: How does he ſleep? ſpeak impudent baggage, how?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How? With a powder, Sir, which my own father
A skilful pothecary prepar'd; who, if
Philargus dye, ſhall hang with us for Company.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Your father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Yes, But now the perils paſt.
See, if he ſleep, tis walking.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Ha! Philargus.
Or but the ſhade; the ſpirit of my friend.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Be not amaz'd, as at an apparition.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Doth my ſon live? O then I have enough.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Come hither. come hither you three. I will diſcharge
The ſcene of you▪ Thy love unto thy Lord
(Though ſomewhat unadviſedly imploy'd)
Deſerves reward; Ile ſee it given thee,
Thy Lord and King ſhall thank thee: take thy wench,
She has love in her wit, and wit in her anger.
I like the luck of things; that ill intents
Should bring forth good events. Thy faithfulneſs
To thy Lord too was happy. Go, I▪le ſee you
All royally rewarded. How now Geron?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: My Lord I ſee here's joy towards, as why—

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: 'Slife, ſtand not Whiloming now man:but be brief.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Cry mercy. I had left it. But my Lord
To celebrate the flowing joyes in Court,
I and my Countrey heads have fram'd a Maſque,
Rather an antick dance, rather a countrey toy,
Rather a Ruſtick round; rather a—

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Hoy day!
Thy Rather's worſe then thy Whilom. Doſt know
What time o'day 'tis.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Tis a rural thing
To be preſented at the Princeſs wedding
And, if you think it meet, I will induce
The practiſe of it preſently. As why—

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Go fetch the heads and heels, I'le ſtay the King,
To ſee and laugh at'em. That's grace enough.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Philargus you have much to know; the which
We will Eudina tell you, now ſhee's yours.
Receive her and our bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Were I dead
(As I was thought to be) your name pronounc'd
Over my grave, beyond all Necromancy,
Would call freſh blood into my veins again;
Strengthen my nerves, to break the Iron gates
Of death; and force my joyful ſpirit from
Th' Eliſian Paradiſe to live with you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: You ſhall not be a looſer Thymele:
Philocles ſhall be yours, and in exchange
Placilla mine.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: To me my beauteous ſpouſe
Thou art as Juno to her Jupiter,
Siſter and wife.

sp.speaker: Thy.
sp.l: Your highneſs may be pleas'd
Now at ſo happy leaſure to perpend
The Oracle; which truly hath effected
Each word of the prediction.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Who can repeat the anſwer, I ha'loſt it.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: I have it.
Contend not for the jewel, which
Ere long ſhall both of you inrich.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: Eudina does ſo: me in a dear ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Philar.
sp.l: Me in a Peerleſs wife.

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Purſue your fortune: for 'tis ſhe
Shall make ye what you ſeem to be.

sp.speaker: Philoc.
sp.l: She has done that too: For now indeed w'are brothers

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Apollo thou haſt fill'd us all with joy,
But has our joy already fill'd our Court
With Muſick?

sp.speaker: Diſ.
sp.l: Will your Majeſty yet ſit
And ſee the practiſe of a preſentation,
Againſt the Marriages by your Swains of Tempe
With thanks; and give it all the grace we may?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: From Tempe plains, the Tempe Swains
sp.stage: Enter Geron and the Swains and Nymphs for the dance.

l.hi: With Dance and Song do hither throng

sp.speaker: Gar.

l.hi: O there, look there, Madam my Son, and all

sp.l: My old Temperian Neighbours.

l.hi: We cannot hope in all our ſcope,
To gain much praiſe for skill,
But it ſhall be enough, if ye

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My thanks to all.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Heaven bleſs your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks to Apollo. Let his temple be
The place of our ſolemnity. His Altars
Let them be laden with Arabian ſpices;
Let his Prieſts lead, in a devout proceſſion,
The horned Sacrifice, mantled with Ghirlonds
And we (our Temples crown'd with Laurel) follow
With Muſick, ſounding Hymen and Apollo.

div.head: EPILOGƲE.
div.l: Tis not the Poets art, nor all that we
By life of Action can preſent unt'ye
Can juſtly make us to preſume a Play
Is good till you approv't: which that you may
It cannot miſ-become us, ſince our gains
Come by your favour more then all our pains.
Thus to ſubmit us unto your commands
And humbly ask that favour at your hands.

div.p: THE WEEDING OF THE COVENT-GARDEN.
Or the Middleſex-JƲSTICE OF Peace.
A POSTHUME of RICHARD BROME, An Ingenious Servant, and Imitator of his Maſter, that famouſly Renowned Poet Ben. Johnſon.

p.hi:
Aut prodeſſe ſolent, aut delectare Poetae.
Dramatis Perſonae.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Andrew Crook, and are to be ſold at the Green Dragon in St. Pauls Church-yard: And Henry Broom at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

div.head: Upon AGLAƲRA printed in Folio.
div.l: Br this large Margent did the Poet mean
To have a Comment writ upon his Scene?
Or is it that the Ladies, who ne're look
On any but a Poeme or Play-book,
May, in each page, have ſpace to ſcribble down
When ſuch a Lord, or Faſhion comes to Town.
As Swaines in Almanacks account do keep,
When their Cow calv'd, and when they bought their ſheep?
Ink is the life of Paper: 'tis meet then,
That this which ſcap'd the Preſs ſhould feel the Pen.
A Room with one ſide furniſh'd, or a face
Painted half-way, is but a faire diſgrace.
This great voluminous Pamphlet may be ſaid
To be like one that hath more haire then head;
More excrement then body. Trees, which ſprout
With broadest leaves, have ſtill the ſmallest fruit.
When I ſaw ſo much white, I did begin
To think Aglaura either did lie in,
Or elſe took Pennance. Never did I ſee
(unleſſe in Bills daſht In the Chancerie).
So little in ſo much; as if the feet
Of Poetry, like Law, were ſold by th'ſheet.
If this new faſhion ſhould but laſt one yeare,
Poets, as Clerks, would make our paper dear.
Doth not the Artiſt erre, and blast his fame
That ſets out pictures leſſer then the frame?
Was ever Chamberlaine ſo mad, to dare
To lodge a childe in the great Bed at Ware?
Aglaura wo • ld pleaſe better, did ſhe lie
I'th' narrow bounds of an Epitomie.
Pieces that are weav'd of the finest twiſt,
(As Silk and Pluſh) have ſtill more ſtuffe then liſt.
She, that in Perſian habit made great brags,
Degenerates in this exceſſe of rags;
Who, by her Giant-bulk this only gaines,
Perchance in Libraries to hang in chaines.
Tis not in Book, as Cloth; we never ſay
Make London-meaſure, when we buy a Play:
But rather have them pair'd: Thoſe leaves be faire
To the judicious, which more ſpotted are.
Give me the ſociable Pocket-books.
Theſe empty Folio's only pleaſe the Cooks.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: A Way with all grief and give us more ſack.
'Tis that which we love, let love have no lack.
Nor ſorrow, nor care can croſſe our delights,
Nor witches, nor goblins, nor Buttery ſprights,
Tho' the candles burne dimme while we can do thus,
We'll ſcorn to flie them: but we'll make them flie us.
Old Sack, and old Songs, and a merry old crew
Will fright away Sprights, when the ground looks blew.

div.head: A PROLOGUE.
div.l: HE that could never boaſt, nor ſeek the way,
To prepare friends to magnifie his Play,
Nor raile at's Auditory for unjuſt,
If they not lik't it nor was ſo miſtrust.
Ful ever in himſelf, that he beſought
Preapprobation though they lik't it not.
Nor ever had the luck to have his name
Clap't up above this merit. Nor the ſhame
To be cried down below it. He this night
Your faire and free Attention does invite.
Only he prays no prejudice be brought
By any that before-hand wiſh it nought.
And that ye all be pleaſ'd to heare and ſee,
With Candor ſuiting his Integritie.
That for the Writer. Something we muſt ſay,
Now in defence of us, and of the Play
We ſhall preſent no Scandal or Abuſe,
To vertue or to honour. Nor traduce
Perſon of worth. Nor point at the diſgrace
Of any one reſiding in the Place,
On which our Scene is laid, nor any Action ſhew,
Of thing has there been done, for ought we know.
Though it be probable that ſuch have been.
But if ſome vicious perſons be brought in.
As no new Buildings, nor the ſtrongeſt hold
Can keep ou • Rats and Vermine bad and bold.
Let not the ſight of ſuch be ill endur'd;
All ſores are ſeen and ſearch't before th' are cur'd.
As Ruffian, Bawd, and the licentious crew,
Too apt to peſter Scituations new.

div.head: Another Prologue.
div.l: 'Tis not amiſſe ere we begin our Play,
T' intreat you, that you take the ſame ſurveigh
Into your fancie, as our Poet took,
Of Covent-Garden, when he wrote his Book.
Some ten years ſince, when it was grown with weeds.
Not ſet, as now it is, with Noble Seeds.
Which make the Garden glorious. And much
Our Poet craves and hopes you will not grutch
It him, that ſince ſo happily his Pen
Foretold its faire emprovement, and that men
Of worth and honour ſhould renown the place.
The Play may ſtill retain its former grace.

div.head: To my LORD of Newcaſtle, on his PLAY called THE VARIETY. He having commanded to give him my true opinion of it.
div.l: I Could not think theſe ſeven yeares, but that I
In part a Poet was, and ſo might lie,
By the Poetick Licence. But I finde
Now I am none, and strictly am confin'd
To truth, if therefore I ſubpaena'd were
Before the Court of Chancerie to ſwear.
Or if from thence I ſhould be higher ſent,
And on my life unto a Parliament
Of wit and judgement, there to certifie
What I could ſay of your VARIETY:
I would depoſe each Scene appear'd to me
An Act of wit, each Act a Comedy,
And all was ſuch, to all that underſtood,
As knowing Johnſon, ſwore By God 'twas good.

list.item: Rooksbill, a great Builder in Covent-Garden.
Croſſewill, a Countrey Gentleman, Lodger in his Buildings.
Cockbrain, a Juſtice of Peace, the Weeder of the Garden.
Mun Clotpoll, a fooliſh Gull.
Driblow, Captain of the Philoblathici.
Belt, Croſſewills Servant.
Ralph, Dorcas Servant.
Pig, Damaris Servant.

list.head: Women Actors.
list.item: Lucie, Rooksbills daughter.
Katharine, Croſſewills daughter.
Dorcas, alias Damaris, Croſwills Neece.
Margerie Howlet, a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I Marry Sir! This is ſomething like! Theſe appear like Buildings! Here's Architecture expreſt indeed! It is a moſt ſightly ſcituation, and fit for Gentry and Nobility.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: When it is all finiſhed, doubtleſſe it will be handſome.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
It will be glorious: and yond magnificent Peece, the Piazzo, will excel that at Venice, by hearſay, (I ne're travell'd). A hearty bleſſing on their braines, honours, and wealths, that are Projectors, Furtherers, and Performers of ſuch great works. And now I come to you Mr. Rookesbill: I like your Rowe of houſes moſt incomparably. Your money never
ſhone ſo on your Counting-boards, as in thoſe Structures.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I have pil'd up a Leaſh of thouſand pounds in walls and windows there.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It will all come again with large encreaſe.

And better is your money thus let out on red and white, then upon black and white, I ſay. You cannot think how I am taken with that Rowe! How even and ſtraight they are! And ſo are all indeed. The Surveyor (what e're he was) has manifeſted himſelf the Maſter of his great Art. How he has wedded ſtrength to beauty; ſtate to uniformity; commodiouſneſſe with perſpicuity! All, all as't ſhould be!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: If all were as well tenanted and inhabited by worthy perſons.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Phew; that will follow. What new Plantation was ever peopled with the better ſort at firſt; nay, commonly, the lewdeſt blades, and naughtypacks are either neceſſitated to 'hem, or elſe do prove the moſt forward venturers. Is not lime and hair the firſt in all your foundations? do we not ſoile or dung our lands, before we ſowe or plant any thing that's good in 'hem? And do not weeds creep up firſt in all Gardens? and why not then in this? which never was a Garden until now; and which will be the Garden of Gardens, I foreſee't. And for the weeds in it, let me alone for the weeding of them out. And ſo as my Reverend Anceſtor Juſtice Adam Overdoe, was wont to ſay, In Heavens name and the Kings, and for the good of the Common-wealth I will go about it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p:
I would a few more of the Worſhipful hereabouts, (whether they be in Commiſſion or not) were as well minded that way as you are Sir; we ſhould
then have all ſweet and clean, and that quickly too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have thought upon a way for't, Mr. Rooksbill: and I will purſue it, viz. to finde out all the enormities, yet be my ſelfe unſpied: whereby I will tread out the ſpark of impiety, whileſt it is yet a ſpark and not a flame; and break the egge of a miſchief, whileſt it is yet an egge and not a Cockatrice. Then doubt not of worthy tenants for your houſes Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, your beſt furtherance.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I had a letter bur laſt night from a worthy friend, a Weſt-countrey Gentleman, that is, now coming up with his family to live in Town here; and deſire is to inhabit in theſe buildings. He was to lie at Hammerſmith laſt night, and requeſted an early meeting of me this morning here, to aſſiſt him in the taking of a houſe. It is my buſineſſe hither; for he could never do't himſelfe. He has the oldeſt touchy, wrangling humour.—But in a harmleſſe way; for he hurts no body, and pleaſes himſelf in it. His children have all the trouble of it, that do anger him in obeying him ſometimes. You will know him anon. I mean, he ſhall be your Tenant. And luckily he comes.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It is not enough you tell me of obedience. Or that you are obedient. But I will be obeyed in my own way. Do you ſee—

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My noble friend Mr. Croſwill, right happily met.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Your troubleſome friend Mr. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
No trouble at all, Sir, though I have prevented
yours in finding a fit houſe for you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You ha' not ha' you, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Actum eſt Mr. Croſwill. But Civility pardon me, Is not this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: All the Shee-things I have: and would I were well rid of her too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Katherine, Welcome—Mr. Gabriel, I take it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel Croſwill is my name.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But where's your younger ſonne Mihill? There's a ſpark!

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: A Spark! A dunce I fear by this time like his brother Sheepſhead there.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel is my proper name.

sp.speaker: Groſ.
sp.p: I have not ſeen him this Twelve-moneth, ſince I chamber'd him a Student here in Town.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: In town, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: He knows not yet of my coming neither, nor ſhall not, till I ſteal upon him; and if I finde him mopiſh like his brother, I know what I will doe.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Have you not heard from him lately?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes, often by his letters, leſſe I could reade more comfort in 'hem. I fear he's turn'd Preciſian, for all his Epiſtles end with Amen; and the-matter of 'hem is ſuch as if he could teach me to ask him bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: A comfortable hearing of a young man.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Is it ſo Sir? but I'le new mould him if it be ſo.—I'le tell you Mr. Cockbrayne; never was ſuch a father ſo croſt in his children. They will not obey me in my way. I grant, they do things that other fathers would rejoyce at. But I will be obeyed in my own way, dee ſee. Here's my eldeſt ſonne. Mark how he ſtands, as if he had learn't a poſture at Knights-bridge
ſpittle as we came aloug while-eare. He was not only borne without wit, but with an obſtinate reſolution, never to have any. I mean, ſuch wit as might become a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Was that reſolution borne in him think you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It could never grow up in him ſtill as it does elſe. When I would have him take his horſe, and follow the dogs, and aſſociate Gentlemen, in hawking, hunting, or ſuch like exerciſes, he'l run you a foot five mile another way, to meet the brethren of the ſeparation, at ſuch exerciſes as I never ſent him to (I am ſure) on worky dayes. And whereas moſt Gentlemen run into other mens books, in hands that they care not who reades, he has a book of his own Short-writing in his pocket, of ſuch ſtuffe as is fit for no mans reading indeed but his own.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely Sir.—

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Sure you are an Aſſe. Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You are my father.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What comfort ſhould I have, were my ſon ſuch.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: And he has nothing but hang'd the head, as you ſee now, ever ſince Holiday ſports were cried up in the Countrey. And but for that, and to talk with ſome of the ſilenc'd Paſtors here in town about it, I ſhould not have drawn him up.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I would I could change a ſonne w' you Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What kinde of thing is thy ſonne? ha! doſt thou look like one that could have a ſonne fit for me to father, ha? And yet the beſt take both, and t' pleaſe you at all adventures, ha?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I am ſure there cannot be a worſe, or more debauch'd reprobate then mine is living.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
And is the devil too good a Maſter for
him, think'ſt thou, ha? Wherein can I deſerve ſo ill at thy hands, fellow, whate're thou art, that thou ſhould'ſt wiſh me comber'd with a worſe burden, when thou heareſt me complain of this, ha? What is this fellow that you dare know him, Friend Cockbrayn? I will not dwell within three pariſhes of him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My tenant! Bleſſe me from him. I had rather all my Rents were Bawdy houſes.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Think nothing of his words, he'll forget all inſtantly. The beſt natur'd man living.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Doſt thou ſtand like a ſon now that hears his father abuſ'd, ha?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am praying for the converſion of the young man he ſpeaks of.

sp.speaker: Coek.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But by the way, where's your ſonne Anthony? have you not heard of him yet?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Never ſince he forſook me, on the diſcontent he took, in that he might not marry your daughret there. And where he lives, or whether he lives or not, I know not. I hope your davghter is a comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes, in keeping her chamber whole weeks together, fullenning upon her Samplery breech-work, when I was in hope ſhe would have made me a Grandfather ere now. But ſhe has a humour, forſooth, ſince we put your ſon by her, to make me a match-broker, her marriage-Maker; when I tell you friend, there has been ſo many untoward matches of Parents making, that I have ſworn ſhe ſhall make her own choice, though it be of one I hate. Make me her match-maker! Muſt I obey her, or ſhe me, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I wiſh, with teares, my ſonne had had her now.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Wherein Sir, (under correction do I diſobey you?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: In that very word, under correction, thou diſobey'ſt me. Are you to be under correction at theſe yeares? ha! If I ha' not already taught you manners beyond the help of correction, go, ſeek a wiſer father to mend 'hem.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave, dear Sir, in my excuſe.—

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Leave out correction then.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: If I were forward as many Maidens are,
To wiſh a husband, muſt I not be ſought?
I never was a Gadder: and my Mother,
Before ſhe dy'd, adjur'd me to be none.
I hope you'll give me leave to keep your houſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: La there again! How ſubtly ſhe ſeeks dominion over me! No, huſwife, No; you keep no houſe of mine. I'll neſtle you no longer under my wing. Are you not fledge; I'll have you fly out I, as other mens daughters do; and keep a houſe of your own if you can find it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: We had a kinſwoman flew out too lately, I take it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What tell'ſt thou me of her; wiſe-acres? Can they not flie out a little, but they muſt turne arrant vvhores, ha? Tell me of your kinſwoman? 'Tis true, ſhe was my Neece; ſhe vvent to't a little afore her time? ſome tvvo years ſince, and ſo fled from Religion; and is turn'd Turk, vve fear. And vvhat of that in your preciſiancial vviſdom? I have ſuch children as no man has. But (as I vvas ſaying,) vvould ye top me husvvife, ha! Look you, novv I chide her, ſhe ſayes nothing. Is this obedience, ha?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Perhaps, I might unfortunately caſt my affection on a man that vvould refuſe me.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: That man I vvould deſire to knovv; ſhevv me that man; ſee if I ſvvinge him not dares ſlight my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Still the old humour, ſelf-vvill'd, croſſe, and touchie; but ſuddainly reconcil'd. Come, Mr. Croſwil, to the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Oh, you told me of a houſe you had found for me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes Sir. And here's the Landlord.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Does he look, or go like one could let a houſe vvorthy of me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sir, vve have able Builders here, that vvill not carry leaſt ſhevv of their buildings on their backs. This is a rich ſufficient man, I aſſure you, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I cry him heartily mercy, and embrace him. And novv I note you better, you look like Thrift it ſelf.
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas above upon a Bellconie. Gabriel gazes at her. Dorcas is habited like a Curtizan of Venice.
sp.p: I cannot think you vvill throvv avvay your houſes at a caſt. You have a ſonne, perhaps, that may, by the commendations you gave of him. Lets ſee your houſe.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Come avvay Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Come Sir, vvhat do you gape a • d ſhake the head at there? I'll lay my life he has ſpied the little Croſſe upon the nevv Church yond, and is at defiance vvith it. Sirrah, I vvill make you honour the firſt ſyllable of my name. My name is Will. Croſwill, and I vvill have my humour. Let thoſe that talk of me for it, ſpeak their pleaſure, I vvill do mine.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I ſhall obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Novv you are in the right. You ſhall indeed. I'll make your heart ake elſe, dee ſee.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
But truly I vvas looking at that Image; that
painted idolatrous image yonder, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O hereſie! It is ſome Lady, or Gentlewoman ſtanding upon her Bellconey.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Her Bellconey? Where is it? I can ſpy from her foot to her face, yet I can ſee no Bellconey ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What a Knave's this: That's the Bellconey ſhe ſtands on, that which jets out ſo on the forepart of the houſe; every houſe here has one of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: 'Tis very good; I like the jetting out of the forepart very well; it is a gallant faſhion indeed.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I gueſs what ſhe is, what ere I have ſaid. O Juſtice look to thine office.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Come now to this houſe, and then to my ſon Mihil, the Spark you ſpoke of. And if I find him croſs too, I'le croſs him: Let him look to't▪ Dee ſee.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'le ſee you hous'd; and then about my project, which is for weeding of this hopeful Garden. Ex. omnes.
sp.stage: Gabriel ſtayes last looking up at her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Why ſhould not we in England uſe that freedome
The famous Curtezans have in Italy:
We have the art, and know the Theory
To allure and catch the wandring eyes of Lovers;
Yea, and their hearts too: but our ſtricter Lawes
Forbids the publique practiſe, our deſires
Are high as theirs; our wills as apt and forward;
Our wits as ripe, our beauties more attractive;
Or Travellers are ſhrewd lyars. Where's the let?
Only in baſhful coward cuſtome, that
Stoops i'the ſhoulders, and ſubmits the neck
To bondage of Authority; to theſe Lawes,
That men of feeble age and weaker eye-ſight
Have fram'd to bar their ſons from youthful pleaſures.
Poſſets and Cawdels on their queaſie ſtomacks,
Whilſt I fly out in brave rebellion;
And offer, at the leaſt, to break theſe ſhackles
That holds our legs together: And begin
A faſhion, which purſu'd by Cyprian Dames,
May perſwade Juſtice to allow our Games.
Who knows? I'le try. Franciſca bring my Lute.
sp.stage: while ſhe is tuning her Lute: Enter Nich. Rookesbill, Anthony in a falſe beard, Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Troth I have a great mind to be one of the Philoblathici, a Brother of the Blade and Battoon, as you tranſlate it; now ye have beat it into my head: But I fear I ſhall never come on and off handſomely. I have mettal enough methinks, but I know not how methinks to put it out.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: We'l help you out with it, and ſet it flying for you never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Obotts, you mean my money mettal, I mean my valour mettal I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace, heark.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: T'other flyes faſt enough already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pox on ye peace.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O moſt melodious.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Moſt odious, Did you ſay? It is methinks moſt odoriferous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What new deviſe can this be? Look!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She is vaniſht. Is't not the Mountebanks Wife that was here; and now come again to play ſome new merry tricks by herſelf.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A botts on't, I never ſaw that Mountebank; they ſay, he brought the firſt reſort into this new plantation, and ſow'd ſo much ſeed of Knavery and Cozenage here, that 'tis fear'd 'twill never out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay but this creature: What can ſhe be?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And then again, he drew ſuch flocks of idle people to him, that the Players, they ſay, curſt him abhominably.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.p: Thou ever talk'ſt of the wrong matter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Cry mercy Brothers of the Blade and Battoune: Do you think if I give my endeavour to it, I ſhall ever learn to roar and carry it as you do, that have it naturally, as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, as we'll beat it into you. But this woman, this muſical woman, that ſet her ſelf out to ſhow ſo, I would be ſatisfied in her.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And ſhe be as able as ſhe ſeems, ſhe has in her to ſatisfie you, and you were a Brother of ten Blades, and ten Battounes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow—Peace. I'le battoune thy teeth into thy tongue elſe; ſhe bears a ſtately preſence. Thou never ſaw'ſt her before: Didſt thou Toney?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No; but I heard an inkling at the Paris Tavern laſt night of a She-Gallant-that had travelled France and Italy; and that ſhe would—

sp.speaker: (Clot.
sp.p: Battoun thy teeth into thy tongue.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Plant ſome of her forraign collections, the fruits of her travels, in this Garden here, to try how they would grow or thrive on Engliſh earth.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Young Pig was ſpeaking of ſuch a one to me, and that ſhe was a Mumper.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: What's that a Siſter of the Scabberd, brother of the Blade?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come, come; we'l in, we'l in; 'tis one of our fathers buildings; I'le ſee the Inhabitants. Some money Clot. furniſh I ſay, and quickly.—I vow—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You ſhall, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Vow twice before you have it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow, and I vow again, I'le coyn thy brains.—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take your powl money; I thought I would have my will; and the word I look-for, I'le coyn thy brains.—

I do not love to give my money for nothing, I have a volume of words here, the worſt of 'hem is as good as a blow; and then I ſave my Crown whole half a dozen times a day, by half a crown a time, there's half in half ſav'd by that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come let's appear civil, till we have our entrance, and then as occaſion ſerves—
Who would you ſpeak withal?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs, little one.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but I would know her, that's the buſineſs: I mean the muſical Gentlewoman that was fidling, and ſo many in the What-doe-call't een now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What-doe-call her Sir, I pray?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What-doe-call her; 'tis not come to that yet, prethee let me ſee and ſpeak with her firſt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are diſpos'd I think.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What ſhould we do here elſe?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You wont thruſt in upon a body whether one will or no.

sp.speaker: Ant. Nic.
sp.p: Away you Monkey.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O me, What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O my brave Philoblathici.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What's the matter the Girl cryes out ſo?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I know not: I fear ſome rude company, ſome of the wild crew are broke into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Within. Whether would you go, you wont rob the houſe will ye?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Will ye be quiet Whiskin?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O me 'tis ſo: Hell's broke looſe; this comes of your new fingle-fangle faſhion, your prepoſtrous Italian way forſooth: would I could have kept my old way of pots and pipes, and my Strong-water courſe for cuſtomers: The very firſt twang of your fiddle guts has broke all, and conjur'd a legion of devils among us.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Nay, there's but a Leaſh of us. How now?
Who have we here? Are theſe the far travel'd Ladies?
O thou party perpale, or rather parboild Bawd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? Dam. Out alaſs; ſure they are devils indeed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Art thou travel'd croſs the Seas from the Bankſide hither, old Counteſs of Codpiece-row?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Party perpale and parboild Bawd.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And is this the Damſel that has been in France and Italy? Clot. Codpiece-row.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Peace ye roaring Scabs: I'le beſworn ſhe ſupt at Paris Tavern laſt night, and lay not long ago at the Venice by Whitefryers Dock.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Prethee what is ſhe Madge?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A civil Gentlewoman you ſee ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She has none of the beſt faces: but is ſhe warrantable; I have not had a civil night theſe three moneths.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Nor none are like to have here, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Madge how I do long thy thing to ding didle ding.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O Nick, I am not in the humour, no more is ſhe to be o'the merry pin now; I am ſure her caſe is too lamentable. But if you will all ſit down, I'le give you a bottle of wine, and we'l relate her ſtory to you, ſo you will be civil. Nic. Well for once, I care not if we be.
sp.stage: A Table bottle, light, and Tobacco ſtales.
sp.p: Let us ſet to't then; ſit down brother Toney, ſit down Gentlewoman, we ſhall know your name anon, I hope it will fall in your ſtory; ſit down Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You will call me brother Clotpoll too when I have taken my oath, and paid my entrance into the faternity of the Blade and the Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis like we ſhall. Now Lady of the Stygian Lake, thou black infernal Madge, begin the diſmal ſtory, whilſt I begin the bottle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman whoſe name is Damyris.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Damyris ſtay. Her nick-name then is Dammy, ſo we may call her when we grow familiar: and to begin that familiarity, Dammy here's to you.—drink.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And what's your nick-name I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nick: only Nick, Madge there knows it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then I believe your name is Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow-witty. Yes Dammy, and my Sirname is Rookesbill, and ſo is my Fathers too: and what do you make o'that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Nothing not I Sir: ſure this is he.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And I would he were nothing, ſo I had all he has: I muſt have tother glaſs to waſh him out of my mouth, he furs it worſe then Mondongas Tobacco. Here old Madge, and to all the birds that ſhall wonder at thy howletſhip, when thou rid'ſt in an Ivy-buſh, call'd a Cart.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well mad Nick, I'le pledge thee in hope to ſee as many flutter about the tree, that thou ſhalt clime backwards.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A pox thou wilt be ſtifled with Offal and Carret leaves before that day.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, what talk's this? 'tis he I am conſident.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Theſe are our ordinary complements, we wiſh no harm.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No Dammy I vow, not I to any breathing.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But your Father Nick.—Is he that Rookeſbill.—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But my Fathet; Pox rot ye, why do ye put me in mind of him again, he ſticks i'my throat, now I'le waſh him a little further.—Here Brother Toney

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gramercy Brother Nick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the brothers that are, and are to be of the Blade and the Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There ſaid you well Clotpoll: Here 'tis—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I would but have asked you whether your Father were that Rookesbill that is call'd the great Builder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Yes marry is it he forſooth; he has built I know not how many houſes hereabout, though he goes Dammy as if he were not worth a groat; and all his cloaths I vow are not worth this hilt, except thoſe he wears, and prayes for fair weather in, on my Lord Mayors Day; and you are his Tenant, though perhaps you know it not, and may be mine; therefore uſe me well: for this houſe and the reſt I hope will be mine, as well as I can hope he is mortal, of which I muſt confeſs I have been in ſome doubt, though now I hope again, he will be the firſt ſhall lay his bones i'the new Church, though the Church-yard be too good
for him before 'tis conſecrated. So give me the to-the cup, for now he offends my ſtomack. Here's to thee now Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the Siſters of the Scabberd Brother in Election. Dee hear, Pray talk of his father no more, for the next brings him to the belly-work, and then he'll drink him quite through him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And ſo we ſhall have a foul houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No he ſhall ſtick there. Now to the ſtory Gentlewoman, 'twas that we ſate for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I to the ſtory, I vow I had almoſt forgot it; and I am the worſt at Sack in a morning: Dear Dammy to the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Good Sir my heart's too full to utter't.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Troth and my head's too full to hear it: But I'le go out and quarrel with ſome body to ſettle my brains, then go down to Mich. Croſſewill to put him in mind of our meeting to day; then if you will meet me at the Goat at Dinner, wee'll have it all at large.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you be there indeed Sir, I would ſpeak with you ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Dammy if I be not, may my father out live me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We both here promiſe you he ſhall be there by noon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Lady, 'tis ſworn by Blade and by Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This will be the braveſt diſcovery for Mihill, the new Italian Bona Roba Catſoe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why ſo ſad on the ſuddain Niece.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But do you think hee'll come as he has promis'd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: He never breaks a promiſe with any of us' though he fail all the honeſt part o'the world: But I truſt you are not taken with the Ruffian, you'll nere get penny by him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I prethee peace, I care not.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But Myſtris, rhere is a Gallant now below, a Gingle boy indeed, that has his pockets full of, crowns that chide for vent. Shall I call him up to you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will ſee no man.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: How's that? I hope you jeſt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Indeed, I hope you jeſt.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You will not hinder the houſe, I hope. Marry heigh. This were a humour and 'twould laſt. Go fetch him up.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'le flie then out at window. Nay, by this ſteel 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's the matter? have I got a mad woman into the houſe. What do you go about to break me the firſt day of your coming, before you have hanſell'd a Couch or a Bedſide in't. Were you but now all o'th heigh to ſet your ſelf out for a ſigne with your fiddle cum twang, and promiſe ſuch wonders, forſooth, and will not now be ſeen. Pray what's the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll tell thee all anon. Prithie excuſe me. I know thy ſhare of his ſins bounty would not come to thus much, take it, I give it thee. And prithee let me be honeſt till I have a mince to be otherwiſe, and I'le hinder thee nothing.

sp.speaker: M • d.
sp.p: Well, I'le diſmiſſe the Gallant, and ſend you, Sirrah, for another wench. I'le have Beſſe Bufflehead again. This kickſy wincy Giddibrain will ſpoil all I'le no more Italian tricks.—
sp.l: Thus ſome have by the phrenſie of deſpair
Fumouſly run into the ſea to throw
Their wretched bodies, but when come near
They ſaw the billows riſe, heard Boreas blow,
And horrid death appearing on the Maine,
A ſudden fear hath ſent them back again.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: NAy, but honeſt Shoomaker; thy honeſt price.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I tell you intruth, Sir, 'tis as good a boot as ever you pull'd on in your life.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A little too ſtreight, I doubt. What do you think o' my boots honeſt Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: They do exceeding handſomely, never truſt me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Never fear it Tailor, you ſhall truſt me, and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: You are pleaſant Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
