sp.p: And what do you think of my ſuite Shoomaker? can you ſay as much for the Tailor as he for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A very neat ſuite, Sir, and becomes you excellent.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Honeſt men both, and hold together; one would little think you were ſo near neighbours. Well, you, have fitted me both, I muſt confeſſe. But how I ſhall fit you, now there's the point.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: There's but one way for than and pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: With paying us our money Sit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Still both in a tale, I can not but commend your neighbourhood, I muſe my Laundreſſe ſtayes,
I ſent her three or foure wayes for moneys. But do not you ſtay for that. I have wayes enough to pay you. I have ploughes a going that you dream not of.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, we dream of nothing but ready money, ſleeping or waking.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I ſhall be rich enough ne're fear't. I have a venter in the new ſoap buſineſſe man.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: We are but ſervants, Sir. And our Maſters themſelves have no faith, in flippery projects.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Beſides, the women begin to grumble againſt that ſlippery project ſhrewdly, and, 'tis feard, will mutinie ſho tly.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Burlakin, and they may prove more troubleſome then a commotion of Sailors.
O welcome, Laundreſſe, where's the money.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Not a penny of money, Sir, can I get. But here's one come to town has brought you enough, and you can have grace to finger it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Who's that I prithee.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your father, your father Sir. I met his man by great chance, who told me his Maſter meanes to ſteal upon you preſently, and take you as he findes you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Is he come up with his croſſe tricks. I hea • d he was to come. And that he meanes to live here altogether. He has had an aime theſe dozen years to live in town here, but never was fully bent on't until the Proclamation of reſtraint ſpurr'd him up. 'Tis ſuch a Croſſewill. Well, he is my father, and I am utterly undone if thou help'ſt me not now at a pinch, at a pinch, dear Laundreſſe. Go borrow me a Gown,
and ſome foure or five Law-books? for, I proteſt, mine are in Duck-lane. Nay, trudge, ſweet Laundreſſe, trudge.— Ex. Laun. Honeſt Tailor and Shoemaker convey your ſelves away quietly, and I'll pay you to morrow, as I am a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: As I am a Shoemaker, and that's a kinde of a Centleman, you know, I'll not ſtirre till I have my money, I am not an Aſſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No body ſayes thou art.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: I have had too many ſuch tricks put upon me i' my dayes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A trick! as I hope for money it is no trick.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Well Sir, trick or no trick. I muſt have my money or my boots, and that's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A pox o'th' boots, ſo my legs were out of 'hem. Would they were i'thy throat, ſpurres and all, you will not out.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: No marry will we not.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well-ſaid Shoomaker, I commend thee, thou haſt a better heart then I, though my ſtomack's good.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: O well ſaid, my good Laundreſſe. How am I bound to thee; yet all this wo'not do't Laundreſſe. Thou muſt beſtir thy ſtumps a little further, and borrow me a couple of Gownes more for theſe Raſcals here that will not away.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: How! wo'not away? And they were well ſerv'd, they would be thruſt out of doors for ſaucie companions. Your Maſters would not put a Gentleman to his trumps thus.

sp.speaker: M;.
sp.p:
Nay, ſvveet Laundreſſe, reſtrain thy tongue, and ſtretch thy feet. A couple of Govvns, good
Laundreſſe, and forget not caps. Ex. If I do novv furniſh you like Civil Lavvyers, and you do not keep your countenances; if ever you do but peep in at the Hall-door at Chriſtmas to ſee the revels, I'le have you ſet i'th' ſtocks for this beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If you do, Sir, I may hap be even vvith you before the year comes about, and ſet you in our ſtocks for't.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: But will you make Lawyers of us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you a minde to have your money you unbelieving Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Shoc.
sp.p: I ſee your drift, and hope you'll prove an honeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſome hope, though no faith nor truſt in any man.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, our Maſters ſit at grear rents, and keep great families.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, they are remov'd into the nevv plantation here, where, they ſay, are a tribe of Infidel-tradeſmen, that have made a Law vvithin your ſelves to put no truſt in Gentlemen. But beare your ſelves handſomely here you vvere beſt. I am acquainted vvith a crevv that haunts about your habitations, vvith whom I will joyne, and ſo batter your windows one of theſe nights elſe.—O welcom, Laundreſſe, how doeſt thou toile for me.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your fathers talking, as I am a woman, below.—As thou art a woman below, well-ſaid. Come on with theſe Gownes, and lets ſee how yow'll look. If we had time, the Shoomaker ſhould waſh his face; but ſeeing there is no remedy; pull the cap in your eyes, and good enongh. Now Laundreſſe, ſet us ſtooles, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: I hear him coming up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Now let him come, we are ready for him. Shoomaker, keep your hand underneath the
book, that the pitch do not diſcover you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And Taylor, be ſure you have no Needle on your ſleeve, nor thread about your neck.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I warrant you too for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: He's enrred.
sp.stage: Enter Croſwill, Belt, and ſtand aſide.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Remitter, I ſay, is where a man hath two titles, that is to ſay, one of an elder, the other of a later. And he cometh to the land by the later title; yet the Law adjudgeth him to be in by the force of the elder title. If the tenant in the taile diſcontinee the taile, and after he diſeaſeth his diſcontinue, and ſo dieth ſeiſed, whereby the tenants deſcend to their iſſue, as to his Couſin inheritable by force of the taile. In this caſe the tenants deſcend, who have right by force of the taile, a Remitter in the taile taken for that in the Law, ſhall put and adjudge him to be in by force of deſcent. Pox on ye, ſpeak ſomething good or bad, ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The Remitter, you ſay, is ſeiſed i'th' tail.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Excellent Shoomaker, I ſay ſo, and again, I ſay, that if the tenant in the taile in feoffe his ſon, or his Couſin, inheritable by force of the taile, the which ſonne or couſin at the time of the feoffment is within age, and after the tenant in the taile dierh, this is a Remitter to the heire in the taile to whom the feoffment is made, now Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Think you ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Look either Fitzherbert, Perkins, or Dier, and you ſhall finde it in the ſecond part of Richard Cordelyon. So much for Remitter. Novv I'll put a plain home-ſpun caſe, as a man may ſay, vvhich vve call a moot-caſe.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I pray do Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Some father might take joy of ſuch a ſonne novv. This takes not me. No, this is not my vvay.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: The caſe is this
pull up your grounds cloſer and behang'd, you are a Tailor, and you: a Shoomaker.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you owe us money.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I put the caſe, I do, to you for a ſuit of clothes.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And to you for a paire of boots.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have broke my day with you both. Suppoſe ſo.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Very well, we do.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You clap a Sergeant o' my back. I put in bail, remove it, and carry it up into the upper Court, with habeas-Corpus; bring it down again into the lower Court with procedendo; then take it from thence, and bring it into the Chancery with a Certiorari; I; and if you look not to • t, bring it out of the Chancery again, and thus will I keep you from your money till your ſuite and your boots be worne out before you recover penny of me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: S • ly'd but you ſhall not, your father ſhall know all firſt.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: S'foot Shoomaker wilt thou be an Aſſe. I do but put a caſe, Have you not feen it tried.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p:
Away with books. Away with Law. Away with madneſſe. I, God bleſſe thee, and make thee his ſervant, and defend thee from Law, I ſay. Take up theſe books, ſarrah, and carry them preſently into Pauls Church-yard dee ſee, and change them all for Hiſtories, as pleaſant as profitable; Arthur of Britain,
Primalion of Greece, Amadis of Gaul, and ſuch like de ſee.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope he do's but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Croſs.
sp.p: And do you heare, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Get Bells work, and you can, into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Which Bell, Sir? Adam Bell, with Clim • 'th' Clough, and William of Cloudeſley.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Adam Bell you Aſſe? Valiant Bell that kill'd the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You mean St. George.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Sir Jolthead, do I not. I'le teach you to chop logick, vvith me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot, how ſhall I anſwer my borrow'd books? Stay Belt. Pray Sir, do not change my books.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, I will change them and you too: Did I leave thee here to learn faſhions and manners, that thou mightſt carry thy ſelf like a Gentleman, and doſt thou waſt thy brains in learning a language that I underſtand not a word of? ha! I had been as good have brought thee up among the wild Iriſh.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Why alaſs Sir, Had I not better keep my ſelf within my Chamber, at my Studie, then be rioting abroad, waſting both money and time, which is more precious then money? if you did know the inconvenience of company, you would rather incourage and commend my retir'd life, then any wayes dehort me from it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why Sir did not I keep companie think you when I was young? Ha!

sp.speaker: Ml.
sp.p: Yes Sir; but the times are much alter'd, and youth more corrupted now, they did not drink and wench in thoſe dayes, but nay, o 'tis abominable in theſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Why this is that I fear'd, the boyes turning
meacock too, after his elder brother, 'twas time to look to him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why Croſwill Mich. What, not up yet and behang'd. Or ha ye a wench a bed wye. Is this keeping your home. Mihil runs to the door and holds it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot the Rogue Rooksbil and his crew, I fear'd as much.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Break open the door, let me come to't.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Forbear, or behang'd, you will undo me, my father's here. I'll meet you anon as I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your father's a Clowterdepouch. Nay, I will come then, what Madamoiſelle do you call father.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You would not believe me. Pray be civil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, we will Cry mercy, you are buſie, we will not moote to day then?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope you may excuſe me, I'le be w'ye anon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come to the Goat Capricorne. We have the braveſt new diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: How now! what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: They are Gentlemen of my ſtanding, Sir, that have a little over-ſtudied themſelves, and are ſomewhat—.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Mad; are they not? And ſo will you be ſhortly, if you follow theſe courſes. Mooting do they call it? you ſhall moote nor mute here no longer. Therefore on with your cloak and ſword, follow me to the Tavern and leave me ſuch long-tail'd company as theſe are, for I do not like them.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No more do I, Sir, if I knew how to be rid of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I think thou haſt ne're a ſword, haſt thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Where is it, Sir, let me ſe't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Tis here, under mybed, Sir.—Reach it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why there's a Lawyers trick right, make his weapon companion with his Piſſe-pot. Fie, fie, here's a tool indeed. There's money, Sir, buy you a good one, one with the Mathematical hilt as they terme it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It would do better in Mathematical books▪ Sir, offer me no money, pray Sir, but for books.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Go to, you are a peeviſh Jack, do not provoke me: do not you owe me obedience? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: 'Tis good you do. Well, take that money; and put your ſelfe into cloathes befitting your rank, Do ſo. And let me ſee you, ſquirting about without a weapon, like an Attorneys Clerk in Tearm-time, and I'l weapon you, What, ſhall I have a Noddie of you. This frets him to the liver. Go to, never hang the head for the matter. For I tell thee I will have it ſo, and herein be knowen what I am.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are known ſufficiently for your croſſe humour already; in which I'll try you if I can make you double this money, for this will not ſerve my turne.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What have you told it after me, you had beſt weigh it too.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No Sir, but I have computed that for my preſent uſe, here is too much by halfe, pray Sir, take halfe back.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Bodie o' me, what a perverſe knave is this, to croſſe me thus! Is there too much, ſay you? ha •

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes truly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Let me ſee't. Go thy wayes, take thy muſty books, and rhy ruſtie whittle here again. And take your fooliſh plodding dunci-coxcomely courſe, till I look after you again. Come away ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot, who's the Gull now? Taylor, Shoomaker, you may go pawn your Gownes for any money I am like to have.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: We have all played the Lavvyers to pretty purpoſe, in pleading all this while for nothing. Well ſir, to avoid further trouble, I am content to withdravv my action, that is, pull off your boots again, and be jogging.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And for my part, ſir, I can do no leſſe then take you by default and non-ſuit you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Very good Lavvyers both, Is my father quite gone Belt?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Gone in a tempeſt of high diſpleaſure, ſir: And has ſent you here all the money he had about him; and bids you refuſe it if you dare, 'tis above tvvice the ſumme he offered you before; but good ſir, do not refuſe it. He ſvvears he vvill try vvhether you or he ſhall have his vvill. Take heed you croſſe him not too much.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well at thy requeſt, becauſe thou ſhalt not have anger for carrying it back again, I vvill accept.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. Conſider, he's your father, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
I do moſt Reverend Belt. and vvould be loth to croſſe him, although I may as much in taking his money as refuſing it, for ought I knovv, for thou knovv'ſt 'tis his cuſtome to croſſe me, and the reſt
of his children in all we do, to try and urge his obedience; 'tis an odde way: therefore to help my ſelf I ſeem to covet the things that I hate, and he pulls them from me; and makes ſhew of loathing the things I covet, and he hurles them doubly at me, as now in this money.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Are you ſo crafty?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes, but do thou put it in his head, and I'le pick out thy braines.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You never knew an old Serving-man treacherous to his young Maſter: what? to the hopes o'th' houſe; you will be heire, that's queſtionleſſe: for to your comfort, your elder brother growes every day more fool then the other. But now the reſt of the meſſage is, that you make haſte, and come to my Maſter to the Goat in Covent-Garden, where he dines with his new Landlord to day.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He has taken a houſe then.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O, a moſt delicate one, vvith a curious Belconee and all belonging to't moſt ſtately.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: At the Goat does he dine, ſayeſt thou.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My crevv are gone thither too. Pray Mars vve fall not foule of one another. Well, go thy vvay, preſent my duty to him, I'le follovv preſentlie. Tell him I took his money vvith much unvvillingneſſe.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: As Lavvyers do their fees. Let me alone ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well Tailor and Shoomaker; you have put me to't, but here's your money.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: 'Twas for that we did put you to't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Let's ſee your biil Tailor

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Here 'tis, ſir, as ready as a Watchmans.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Then good vvords vvill paſſe it, 7 li. 4. ſh. tell your money; yours is 14 ſh. boots and Galloſhes.
There 'tis and 12. d. to drink.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: I thank your vvorſhip.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Are you right Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Yes and pleaſe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There's a ſhilling for you too, to ſpend in bread.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: He knows both our diets. We'll make bold to take leave of your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Not ſo bold as I'm glad I'm too well rid of you, moſt courteous Gentlemen.

To ſee what money can do; that can change mens manners, alter their conditions: how tempeſtuous the ſlaves were without it. O thou powerful metal! what authority is in thee! Thou art the Key to all mens mouthes. With thee a man may lock up the jawes of an informer, and without thee he cannot the lips of a Lawyer.

div.head: Scoen. II.
div.stage: Enter Croſſewill, Rookesbill, Gabriel, Katherine, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Down boy, and bid the Cook haſten dinner.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: What will you pleaſe to drink in the mean time, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I will not drink in the mean time, ſir, Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A fine old humorous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Hold up your head, Sirrah, and leave your preciſe folly. I'll leave you to the wilde world elſe, dee ſee. Is the name of a Tavern ſo odious to you? Ha. Your brother has vext me ſufficiently alreadie, and perhaps he'll refuſe to come too! If he dares let him. Welcome Mr. Rooksbil, welcom Landlord, and your faire daughter, welcome pretty one. Truſt
me a pretty one indeed, pray be acquainted with my daughter there. In your Maiden-company, I hope ſhe will not think the Tavern ſuch a bugs neaſt as ſhe did. I had much ado to draw my rebellious children to the Tavern after me.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And truly, ſir, 'tis the firſt to my knowledge that e're my daughter came into.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: All in good time, ſhe may encreaſe in vertue. But if it be a fault, (as i' my conſcience in his thought it is a great tranſgreſſion) my unſetledneſſe, and unprovidedneſſe elſe, where or how to entertain a friend, or feed my ſelfe, may well excuſe us all, dee ſee.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O Sir, I cannot enough admire that vertue in your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It is a vice, as much a vice or more, as is your ſonnes, your caſt-aways as you call him, that ſucks no other ai • e, then that of Tavernes, Taphouſes, Brothels, and ſuch like. I would their extream qualities could meet each other at half-way, and ſo mingle their ſuperfluities of humour unto a mean betwixt 'hem. It might render them both allowable ſubjects, where now the one's a firedrake in the aire, and t'other a mandrake in the earth, both miſchievous, ſee how he ſtands like a mole-catcher. What dirty dogged humour vvas I in vvhen I got him troe?

sp.speaker: Rookeſ.
sp.p: Hovve're his carriage ſeems diſtaſteful unto you, I could afford (vvith your allovvance, to make conditions of eſtate agreeable) to give all that is mine to him vvith my daughter.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
What a mechanick ſlave is this, to thank a ſonne of mine, hovve're I under-rate him, a fit mate to mingle blood vvith his moore-ditch breed. True, his eſtate is great, I underſtand it, but of all foule I love not Moor-hens. Such another motion
vvould ſtir me to roare him dovvn the tavernſtairs.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: What do you think on't ſirs.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Will you conſider of it Maſter Croſſewill.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I was never ſo put to't. I wiſh we had a ſtickler. I muſe that Maſter Cockbrayne ſtayes thus.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: You do not mind my motion ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Uds precious I minde nothing, I am ſo croſt in mind thar I can minde nothing, nor I will minde nothing, dee ſee. Why comes not Mr. Cockbrayue, Ha!

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Yet you minde him it ſeems. But he, ſir, cannot come, and deſires you to hold him excuſ'd. He's gone about ſome ſpecial undertaking, for the good of the Common-wealth, he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Fart for his undertaking; all the world is bent to croſſe me. What is my young Maſter come? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: My young Maſter Mr. Mihil will be here preſently, he ſaid he would follow me at heeles, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: And why not come before you, ſir. Does he not think that I have waited long enough, ſir? ſure I'll croſſe ſome body under that knaves pate of yours, d'y'fee.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Thus when any body angers him, I am ſure to hear on't.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: So now my ſpleen is a little palliated, let me ſpeak with you Mr. Rooksbill. Get you down, Sirrah; and bring me word, dinner is not ready, and I'll give you as much more, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: That's his way to his ſtomach.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And is your brother that your father ſayes is ſo ungracious, ſo well acquainted with my brother Mihil, ſay you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh all in all, he's not ſo familiar with any man, if Mihil Croſwill be your brother, as 'tis manifeſt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I would not that my father knew it, for all I can expect from him but his bleſſing, but does your father know it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, I would not he ſhould miſtruſt it for all he has, bleſſing and all; and now that I have found you love your brother fo well, I will make over my reaſon and my counſel in truſt with you, hoping you will not wrong that truſt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I do, may the due price of treachery be my reward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love your brother, Lady, and he loves me. The only good act that ever my brother did, was to bring us acquainted, and is indeed all that he has to live on. For I do ſuccour him with many a ſtolne peece for the felicitie he brought me in your brothers love. Now, my father, whoſe irreconcileable hate has for ever diſcarded my brother, ſhould he but dream of their acquaintance, would poiſon all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But let me ask you, is there an hope betwixt you and my brother ever to come together?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, and a way he has for • t, which I underſtand not yet.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truſt me, I pity you both, your caſe is very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Love's above all adventures, the more hard the atchievement is, the ſweeter the reward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I like her ſpirit well.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You Sir, come hither, what is hammering in your head now?
Is't not ſome Synodical queſtion to put unto the brethren, concerning Whitſonales and Maygames? ha!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely ſir, I was premeditating a fit thankſgiving to be rendred before meat in. Tavernes, according to the preſent occaſion which the time and place adminiſtreth, and that as the ſpirit ſhall enable me, ſhall be delivered before you in due ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I am glad I know your minde; for that trick, my zealous ſonne, you ſhall come in at half-dinner, like a Chafing-diſh of coales, when the ſawce is cold, to make uſe of the heat of your ſpirit; d ye ſee. I love not meat twice dreſt.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good ſir, put the Propoſition to him, that I made my affection to him, urges it more and more, I never was ſo taken with a man.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But what's that to your daughter? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: The ſame affection governes her, ſhe is not mine elſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ
sp.p: Well, hold your peace, and was that your ſpiritual meditation?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, verily.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Come Sir, at this Gentlemans requeſt I will now put a queſtion to you concerning the fleſh. What, think you of yond Virgin there his daughter? can you affect her ſo well as to wiſh her to be your wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You mean, elpouſed in holy Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes, I mean ſo.

p.hi: hum hum hum Pſalm tune. How happy.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But do thou ſay, yes verily to that, and as I hope to have peace in my grave. I'll break the Kings peace on thy pate preſently.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is a weighty queſtion, and requires due premeditation in a religious anſwer, pray give me leave to take advice—

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What ſayes he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: He ſayes he will talk with a cunning man about her.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Sure you miſtake him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Will. Harry, Zachary.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Zachary is a good name.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Where are you? he (rings the bell) ſhew up into the Phoenix. Is the Checque empty?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Hoyday, here's a din.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A pottle of Canarie to the Dolphin, ſcore.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Y' are welcome, Gentlemen, take up the lillie-pot.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Half a dozen of clean pipes and a candle for the Elcphant. They take their own Tobaccho.

sp.speaker: Vint,
sp.p: Whoſe room do they foul Sirrah, Harry, Harry?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do Elephants take Tobaccho?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Carry up a Jordan for the Maidenhead, and a quart of white muskadine for the blew Bore.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Now me thinks, the muskadine for tht Maidenhead, and the Jordan for the Bore were better.
Knock aboue, and a pot thrown. Why boyes, drawer, rogues, take up, (below) By and by, by and by, (above) Wine, Tobaccho.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What variety of noiſes is here? and all excellent ill ſounds. (Above) Call up the Fidlers, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such cries as theſe went forth before the deſolation of the great City.
O prophane tinkling the cymbals of Satan; that tickle the care with vanity, to lift up the mind to lewdneſſe. Mine eares ſhall be that of the Adder againſt the Song of the Serpent.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O rare, in a young man!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will roare out aloud to drown your Incantations. Yea, I will ſet out a throat even as the beaſt that belloweth.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Moſt happy youth!

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Sirrah, or I'le make you bellow for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot-back, Nick to your own room. Thy father's here too, as I breath.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My Lucie too, as I live. How the devil got they acquainted? Sure he's his Landlord 'Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Dare you come, ſir, you ſhould have ſtayed now till you had been ſent for.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Verily, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Are you at your Verilies too? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But for di • pleaſing you, I had rather have graz'd on Littletons Commons, or ha' faſted this fourtnight, then come for my repaſt into this Wilderneſſe; but you will ha' it ſo

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You are in the right Sir, I'le have it ſo indeed, I'le know why I ſhall not elſe. What do you know no bodie here?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I crie them mercie, my good brother,—and my loving ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: But what vertuous men has this man to his ſons, and how they thrive in grace againſt his will, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman is this of your acquaintance, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis well diſſembled brother, but I know your cunning.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you betray'd me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mum Mr. Mihil, mum.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: By and by.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What devil art thou that roareſt in mine eare ſo.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Hold, I beſeech you, I come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What, with a By and by, that ſtrikes into my head as ſharp as a Stellatto.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I come to tell you, ſir, that your table's covered in a fairer Room, and more private, your meat is ready to go up, and all in a readineſſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Now thou art an honeſt fellow, there's a couple of ſhillings for thee. Have us out of thy windmil here, I prithee, and thy By and by's.

div.head: Scoen 1.
div.stage: Enter Captain Driblow, Clotpoll, Nick, Anthony, Drawer, A Table, Pot and Glaſſes.
div.p: GO Sirrah, make your reckoning for our dinner. Leave us this wine, and come when we call you. We have buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I ſhall, ſir, by and by.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, ſir, you will be of both you ſay, the Blade and the Battoon?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Of both, ſir, by all meanes, both Philoblathicus and Philobatticus, I. I'le now have all that belongs to your order, or all my money again, that's for a certain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your money again? loe you there. You bring me a fit man, Gentlemen to be ſworn, do you not? that talks of money again, when 'tis a main Article in the Oath, never to look for money again, once disfinger'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You will not ſpoil all now 'tis come ſo far? will you?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Well ſir, when I have my Oath, and that I am ſworn one of you. I'le do as you do, and care as little for money as he that has leaſt.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, to the Oath then, for both the Bſade and the Battoon you ſay?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I by all meanes, Captain, for both. S'lid the Battoon may ſtick to me, when the Blade may flie out o'th' Hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, to the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lay your hands on theſe Hilts, ſir. The Articles that you depoſe unto are theſe, To be true and faithful unto the whole Fraternity of the Blade and the Battoon, and to every member thereof.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: As ever faithful member was.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That at no time, wittingly or ignorantly, drunk or ſober, you reveal or make diſcovery of the Brother, or a member of the Brotherhood, of his lodging, haunts, or by-walks, to any Creditor, Officer, Sutler, or ſuch like dangerous or ſuſpitious perſon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I defie them all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That if any of the Brotherhood be in reſtraint or diſtreſſe by impriſonment, ſickneſſe, or whatſoever engagement, you make his caſe your own, and your purſe and your travel his; and that if a brother die or finiſh his dayes, by end timely or untimelie, by Surfet, Sword, or Law. You wear the ſable order of the Riband in remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A convenient cheap way of mourning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
That your purſe and weapon to the utmoſt
of your ſtrength, be on all occaſions drawn to the aſſiſtance or defence of a Brother or Brothers friend, be it he, be it ſhe.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I underſtand you, and ſhall be as forward to fight for a She-friend, as ever the beſt man in the mirrour of Knighthood was for an honeſt woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That you be ever at deadly defiance with all ſuch people, as Protections are directed to in Parliament, and that you watch all occaſions to prevent or reſcue Gentlemen from the gripes of the Law briſſons. That you may thereby endear your ſelfe into noble ſociety, and drink the juice of the Varlets labours for your officious intruſions.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And that will go down bravely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You muſt rank your ſelf ſo much the better man, by how much the more drink you are able to purchaſe at others coſts.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cupt.
sp.p: You are to let no man take wall of you, but ſuch as you ſuppoſe will either beat you or lend you money.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Better and better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The reſt of your duties for brevity ſake you ſhall finde ſpecified in that copy of your Order. Kiſs the book.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I'le ſwear to them whatſoever they be.
So, now I am a Blade, and of a better Rowe then thoſe of Tytere tu, or Oatmeal hoe, and ſo an health to our Fraternity, and in chief to our Noble Captain Driblow.

sp.speaker: Nick. Ant.
sp.p: Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now are you to practiſe or exerciſe your quality on the next you meet that is not of the Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Are you one of the Brotherhood ſir, of the Philoblathici.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I had elſe loſt much ſir, I have paid all dues belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So have I as I hope to gain honour by't 40 li. thick at leaſt; yet I have this left, pleaſe you command the half ſir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Another time, your reckoning is not yet paid perhaps.
sp.stage: [Clot. puts his money in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis the firſt money of mine that was refuſ'd ſince my coming to Town. I ſhall ſave infinitely.
I ſee now that I am ſworn. How would I ſwear to get by it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Take heed of that, Come hither ſon.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: How have you ſcrewed this youth up into this humour, that was ſuch a dry miſerable Clown but two dayes ſince.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The old way, by watching of him, and keeping him high-flown a mattet of fourty eight houres together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Men are apt to beleeve ſtrange fancies in their liquour, and to entertain new opinions.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have faſtned three or foure cups upon my preciſe brother. I would 'twere as many pottles, ſo it would convert him into the right way of good fellowſhip.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vvould vve could ſee him, to try vvhat good vve could do upon him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Perhaps vve might convert him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's above ſtill vvith the old men. I ſtole from him, but to ſee if your Italick Myſtreſſe vvere come yet. Your Madam.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, ſhe comes anon; but is my affliction above ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thy father? yes

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Ptithee do not call him my father leſs he took better courſes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And ſo is thy Siſter; the little Rogue looks ſo ſqueamiſhly on me, and I on her, as we had never ſeen before; but the fooliſh Ape out of a preſent affection ſhe has taken to my Siſter, has diſcovered to her the whole diſcourſe of our love, and my familiarity with thee, which were enough to ſpoile all, if it were diſcovered to the old folkes, befote my cards were play'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, remember Mr. Mihil, you have promiſed me half, if the old dogged fellow give her all, and you marry her.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou canſt not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: You know I can ſpoile all when I liſt, but to ſhew my countenance in your cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Such is your vertue, Sir. Well, I'le up to 'em again before I be miſt; and when they part, I am for you again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have given you all the rudimenrs, and my moſt fatherly advices withal.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the laſt is that I ſhould not ſwear, how make you that good? I thought now I was ſworne into this Brotherhood, I might have ſworne what, and as much as I would.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's moſt unneceſſary, for look you ſon, the beſt, and even the leudeſt of my ſons do forbear it, not out of conſcience, but for very good ends; and in ſtead of an Oath furniſh the mouth with ſome affected Proteſtation. As I am honeſt, it is ſo. I am no honeſt man if it be not. Ud take me, if I lie to you. Nev'rgo, nev'rſtirre, l vow, and ſuch like.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or never credit me or let me never be truſted.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: O take heed of that, that may be ſpoken in ſo ill an houre, that you may run out of reputation, and never be truſted indeed; the other will gaine you credit, and bring you into good and civil eſtimation with your Hoſteſſes; and make 'em terme you a faire conditioned Gentleman if he had it; and truly I never heard worſe word come out of his mouth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Nev'r-go, nev'r-ſtir, I vow. l'le have, I vow then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow, but you ſhall not, that's mine.

sp.speaker: Clot
sp.p: Cann't you lend it me now and then brother? I'le have, I ſwear then, and come as nigh ſwearing as I can.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſwear but you muſt not, that's mine you know.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt then, I'le have I proteſt, that's a City-word, and beſt to cozen with.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Come boyes, fall to ſome practice, Let me ſee about at the new French balls, ſprung out of the old Engliſh vapours

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt come on. I'le make a third man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whoſe man are you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Whoſe man is not to be asked, nor ſcarce whoſe ſubject, now he is of our Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, by your favour he may ask.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ask no favour, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: That may be granted.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You can grant nothing in this kinde.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow he may grant any thing of any kinde.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſwear, I neither can, nor will grant that.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: That, I proteſt, may bear exception indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Exceptions amongſt us? nay, then I vow.—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I proteſt—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Part faire my boyes; 'tis very well perform'd; now drink a round to qualifie this bout.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Look upon me ye Common-wealths men now, like a State-Surgeon, while I ſearch and try
sp.l: The ulcerous coare of foule enormitie.
Theſe are a parcel of thoſe venomous weeds,
That ranklie peſter this faire Garden-plot.
Whoſe boiſterous growth is ſuch, that I muſt uſe
More policie then ſtrength to reach their root,
And hoiſt them up at once.
This is my way to get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, 'tis gone round.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I muſe theſe Mumpers come not.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Beſt ſend a boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Drawer, ha! where be thoſe Raſcalls? (Within) By and by.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are you one of 'em, ſir?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I am one that has the favour of the houſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To intrude into Gentlemens privacies? ha!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: To ſeek a poor living and 't pleaſe you, by picking up the crums of your liberalitie, for the uſe of my rare qualities.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And what's your qualitie?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It is to ſpeak or ſing ex tempore upon any Theame, that your fancie or the preſent occaſion ſhall adminiſter.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can you drink before you lay your lips to't

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O my weak eye-ſight.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or can you eate a cruſt without chawing, made of the Flower of Battoon.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen, forbear, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The flower of Battoon. I proteſt a good jeſt, and 'twas mine own before I was aware, for he had the Maidenhead or firſt-blow of my Battoon. Nay, it ſhall down.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will not yet deſiſt; but ſuffer private affliction with a Romane reſolution for the publike welfare, with full aſſurance that my fortitude ſhall at laſt get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are not ſatisfied, i • ſeems, you Raſcal, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Phew! beat not the poor fellow ſo.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Let me come to him again, and fleſh my ſelf upon him. I will not only fleſh my ſelf, but tire upon him.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Enough, enough, good Gentlemen, you have beaten me enough of conſcience. Was ever good Patriot ſo rudely handled? but the end crowns all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Forbear him ſons. What canſt thou be, that canſt not be ſatisfied with beating? ſpeak, art a man or a Ghoſt?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have been, Sir, a man, and of my hands, howe're misfortune humbles me under your manhoods. But I have ſeen the face of warre, and ſerv'd in the Low-countreys, though I ſay't, on both ſides.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Then 'tis impoſſible this fellow can be beat out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Mick.
sp.p: We'll leave him in his qualiry for that conſtant vertue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sure, 'tis Fenner or his Ghoſt. He was a riming ſouldier. Look, do his eyes ſtand right?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: They had a diſh e'ne now, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Of ſack, 'tis true here, take another, and waſh the inſide of your Throat. And let us hear your pipes in their right tune.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Give me a Theam Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The praiſe of ſack. Sing the praiſe of ſack.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let it be of the Blade.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the Battoon, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I will have ſack.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: T'other quart of Canarie? you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are your eares ſo quick? I vow, I'le dull 'em.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſay, a ſong of Sack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I, let it be of Sack.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now you pump, do you?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, ſir, but think of a tune.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: If he can pump us up a ſpring of Sack, we'll keep him, and break half the Vintners in Town.
sp.stage: (Song. Now B. and Clot. askes Gabriel, Are you a b • other. They fall in the burthen.)

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, well-ſaid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſwear, 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt the beſt that I have heard in this kind. I wonder at his ability. I prithee, art not acquainted with my two Poetical Drury-lane Writers? the Cobler and the Tapſter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No ſir, not I, I work not their way. What I do is ex tempore after the Theme given.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But they run quite before you. Their Works are in print ſometimes▪ and ready to be ſung about ſtreets, of men that are hang'd before they come to the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But did not Mihil ſay he would come again.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I marvel at his ſtay.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I, and the Mumpers, when come they? I long to ſee the Siſters, now I am a brother ſworn and entred.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O here comes news. How now pig?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: You muſt all preſentlie to the Paris Tavern.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Muſt? at whoſe ſuit!

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Mr. Mihil bade me tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he gone from hence?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: He is, and all his gone and diſperſed.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Then the old Jew my father's gone.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Only there's one delicate demure Gentleman with Mr. Mihil. travell'd along with him towards Paris. I believe he meanes to make a mouth of him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, 'tis his preciſe brother. But vvhere's thy Myſtreſſe, and Madama Damaris? that they come not.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: They deſire to meet you there too, 'tis more private.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Avvay vve'll follovv thee.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Pig, hovv does thy father Hog, the Turkie Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: I am in haſte, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Turkie Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Becauſe he trades in nothing but Turkie commodities; Egges and Concubines; 'tvvere vvell to geld him, and ſend him to the Grand Seignior, to vvait in his Seraglio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſuch a vvit in this Clotpoll of thine. The Reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir; here's your bill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let ſee the ſumme. What is't Drawer? 40. ſh. and 3. d. Si, your dinner, and what you had ſince, in all, ſir.

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: 'Tis very reaſonable, Commend me to thy Maſter. Son Clotpoll pay't. It is your duty.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, for my Brotherſhip.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Boyes, I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: 40. ſh. for foure mens dinners, note that, yet he ſayes 'tis reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Good Captain, He was ever the faireſt Reckoner, though he has never the luck to pay any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fare you well, father.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: When we have further occaſion, we'll repair to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: At Bloomesbury. Father, I know.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Bloomsbury? good, I note it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sirrah, look to the ſecond Article of your Oath.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Againſt diſcovery of lodgings, haunts, or by-walks, I am warn'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Look that you be ſo.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 40. ſh. and 3. d. you'l bate the 3. d. will you not?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We'll not much ſtand for that Sir, though our Maſter ſits at deare rent.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Give me your two peeces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee the bill before you pay it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, I can hold it then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bread and beer, 1. ſh. 4. d. I do not think we four could eat 3. d. of bread, and for my part, I drank but two glaſſes of beer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And I but one, Ivow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And my father and I but one betwixt us, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Ha' you no men below?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Below the earth doeſt mean? I am ſure we have none above-ground.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I know not, Gentlemen, there's ſo much reckon'd at the bar, and you pleaſe you may ſee it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, an't be at the bar, it ſtands for Law. Well, wine 5 ſh. 9. d. I think we had no leſſe. A Shoulder of Mutton ſtuff't with Oyſters 8. ſh. that coſt your Maſter very near ten groats, a brace of Partridge 5. ſh. a couple of Cocks 4. ſh. 6. d. a dozen of Larks 20. d. Anchovis 6. ſh. I ſwear but a Sawcer full.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le be ſworne they are ſo much reckon'd in the Kitch • n.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's law, I tell you, all's law in Tavernes. But I hope there will be a law for you one o'theſe dayes. Then is their Fruit and Cheeſe, Tobaccho, Fire, and I know not what, is't right caſt.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There is more hope of that young man, then of all the reſt, indeed it is a ſore abuſe, another verie weed in the city. I do note that alſo.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sirrah, before you have your money, fetch me a glaſſe of Beere. But canſt thou ſing this upon any ſubject.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Any ſir, any, an't be till midnight.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But you have ſtrange helps to your invention. I did note the rolling o' th' eye, and rubbing your Brows ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So did I, I proteſt, and therefore, I tell you what. If he can ſing ſuch another Song, and look ſtedfaſtly the while upon any thing, and hold his hands behind him. I'le give him half a crown; if not, he ſhall ha' nothing for tother.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Agreed Gentlemen, give me your Theme.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall give it him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And withal, watch him if he ſtir hand or eye, eſpecially the eye.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I will I proteſt, and ſet mine eye againſt his, that he ſhall not twink, but I'le perceive it, and lay him o're the pare.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well Sir, your Theme.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: In praiſe of the Battoon, and if you miſſe it you ſhall be ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: You'll help me with the burthen, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, for the more grace of the Song.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take you no care for that. Set your eyes and begin.

lg.l: To prove the Battoon the moſt noble to be.
Of all other weapons obſerve his degree,
In Field to be Leader of all other Armes,
To conqueſt and honour, through hazard and harms.
The Gallant and Peaſant, the Lord and the Lowne.
Muſt move by the motion of the Leaders Battoon.
O give me the Battoon.
The Pike and the Halbert are ſubject to it.
The Enſigne, the Partizan, all muſt ſubmit,
To advance, or retire, fall back, or come on.
As they are directed by the Leaders Battoon.
Then it is to the Souldier the greateſt Renown,
To purchaſe by ſervice to bear the Battoon.
O give me the Battoon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Marry, and take it Sir, why do you ſtare about? though you have broke Covenant, I have not.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Where be the Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Ha! they are not gone, I hope, where be my brothers Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gone ſir, and have ſent me to you for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt you jeſt, do you not? I gave 'em the full ſumme, and all the money I had, I proteſt, I ſwear, I vow, now they are not here, I may make bold with their words. They have my money, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: If you have no money, pray leave a pawne, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take him there, put him in a cage, and let him ſing it out.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We know him not, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clat.
sp.p: No? he ſaid he had the favour of the houſe to ſing to Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I feare I ſhall be diſcovered, ſir, I can give your worſhip credit for a peece till you come to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Proteſt, thou art generous; nay, I know where to finde'em; and thou ſhalt go with me to 'em, we will not part now, wee'll ſhoune 'em. I vow, (the words out) here, I'le leave my ſword for t'other peece.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your ſword will not ſerve, ſir, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take my coat too, a friend and a Battoon is better then a coat and a ſword at all times.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I am glad my feare is over. And after all my ſufferings, if at laſt
Cock braine crow not theſe roaring Lions down,
Let him be balladed about the Town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me now bid you welcome to my fathers houſe, where till your own be fitted, though my father keep too private a family to expreſſe large entertainment, yet I hope at worſt you ſhall ha' convenient lodging.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Indeed, I am glad that my father yielded to your fathers friendly requeſt in it; and the more, in regard he is ſo hard to be entreated to any thing; but eſpecially for your ſocieties ſake, ſweet Siſter. Indeed I'le call you Siſter alwayes, and I hope you ſhall be ſhortly in my brother Mihils right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have laid open my heart to you, which indeed is his, but your father, I feare, will never be wonne.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Why you would not have him too, Siſter, would you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His conſent I would, and my fathers, I hope, would eaſily be wrought. You ſaw he was willing your other brother ſhould have me at the firſt ſight, meerly for his reſervedneſſe, and Mihil methought carried himſelf as civil to day as he; I mean, as civilly for a Gentleman, that ſhould not look like one fathers of the Dutch Church at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: He was put to't to day. The noiſe of the Tavern had almoſt wrought his zeale in • o fury, it is ſcarce out of my head yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you were about to tell me how he firſt fell into this veine, this vanity indeed.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I'le tell you now, and in that ſomething worth your obſervation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will obſerve you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My father has an humour, not to like any thing at firſt, nor accept beſt courteſies of friends,
though preſently he findes 'em moſt commodious to him; things that he knows not how to be without, and oftentimes deſires with the ſame breath the things he viliſied, and ſcorn'd them the laſt ſyllable he ſpake before. You ſaw when your father offered him the uſe of his houſe here, till his own be furniſhed, he cried, hah • are all the houſes in the Town yours Sir; and yet preſently entreated for't, and thanked him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That ſhews the beſt nature, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But that is ſeldome attended by the beſt fortune. Nay, in us, I mean, his children, he will like nothing, no, not thoſe actions which he himſelf cannot deny are vertuous; he will croſſe us in all we do, as if there were no other way to ſhew his power over our obedience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange fatherly care.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now, note the puniſhment that followes it. There's not a chil • e he has, • hough we all know what we do, that make any conſcience of croſſing him, we have ſo much of his good nature in us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that's as odde a duty in children.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe it is a ſtubbornneſſe.

Yet for the moſt part we do nothing, but that which moſt Parents would allow in their children: and now for my brother Gabriel, with whom I muſt bring in the ſtory of another Kinſwoman of ours, my father had at home with us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Nay, mark, I pray you, as I would entreat an Auditorie, if I now were a Poet to mark the Plot, and ſeveral points of my play, that they might not ſay when 'tis done, they underſtood not this or that, or how ſuch a part came in or went out, becauſe they did not obſerve the paſſages.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well on, I pray.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My brother Gabriel, when he was a boy, nay,
till within theſe two yeares, vvas the wildeſt untamed thing that the countrey could poſſibly hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he is ſtill for ought I know, for I think no man of his Religion in his wits.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mean in outvvard converſation, he vvas the Ring-leader of all the youthful Frie, to Faires, to Wakes, to May-games, footbal-matches, any thing that had but noiſe and tumult in it; then he was Captain of the young train-band, and exerciſed the youth of tvventy pariſhes in martial diſcipline. O he did love to imitate a ſouldier the beſt,—and ſo in every thing, that there vvas not an handſom maid in an whole County could be quiet for him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He may be good at that ſport ſtill, for there is almoſt none of his ſect holds any other game lavvful.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet did he bear the civilleſt aud the beſt ordered affection to our Kinſvvoman I ſpake of.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, I remember.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: So loving to her perſon, ſo tender of her honour that nothing but too near affinity of blood could have kept them aſunder.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ſhe did love him as vvell!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O dearly, vertuouſly vvell; but my father fearing vvhat youth in heat of blood might do, removes my brother Gabriel from home into the ſervice of a Reverend Biſhop to follovv good examples.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But he learned not to be a Puritane there I hope.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
You ſhall hear, Siſter, ſoon after came a Gallant into the countrey from London here, and as vve after found, a Citizens ſonne, though he ſhevved like a Lord there. Briefly, he grevv acquainted vvith my brother Mihil. Then vvoo'd and vvonne my
Couſin ſo ſecretly, my father never ſuſpected, nor he nor I e're knevv vvhoſe ſon he vvas, nor of vvhat occupation my old lord his father vvas; but he promiſ'd her marriage, clap't her, you may gueſſe vvhere, and ſo like the ſlippery Trojan left her.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: O divelliſh Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And fooliſh creature, ſhe vvho ſoon repented it, and vvith her ſhame is fled to vvhat part of the vvorld vve knovv not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth 'tis pitiful, that villain vvould be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Novv upon this, my poor brother that lov'd her ſo, fell into diſcontent, forſook his lord, and vvould have left the Land, but that he vvas prevented and brought home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ever ſince he has been thus religious.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Thus obſtinate, for I think verily he does it but to croſſe my father, for ſending him out of the vvay vvhen the miſchief vvas done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I vvill not then beleeve 'tis Religion in any of the gang of 'em, but meer vvilful affectation. But vvhy, or vvherein do you or Mihil. croſſe your father.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I tell you Siſter vve muſt. He is ſo croſſe himſelf, that vve ſhall never get any thing of him that we deſire, but by deſiring the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then do you deſire him to get you an husband?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Becauſe he ſhould get me none. O Siſter, both he and Mr. Cockbrayne, can vviſh novv that I had had his ſon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There's another youth novv gone on love's pilgrimage, e're ſince your father croſthim in your love not to be heard of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Huſh! the old men.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: In good truth ſir, I am taken with your converſation. I like it now exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I'm glad it pleaſes you.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: 'Tis very faire and friendly, I finde we ſhall accord.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I am glad I have it for you Sir, I pray, make bold with it.

sp.speaker: Ro • k.
sp.p: Then pray ſir, let me urge my motion a little further to you.

sp.speaker: Croſ,
sp.p: What is't? you cannot utter it ſo eaſily as I ſhall grant it, out with it man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That you will be pleaſed to accept my daughter for either of your ſons, your youngeſt if you pleaſe, now I have ſeen him, I'le give him with her preſently, either in hand a thouſand pound, and five hundred pound a childe as faſt as he can get 'em. And all I ſhall die ſeiz'd of.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What a Dogbolt is this to think that I ſhould get a childe for him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope you do think well on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray love he does. I hope ſo too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mark his Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could finde in my heart to ask his good-will my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And that were a ſure way to go without it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: How ſay you, ſir, is't a match?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I will not ſtay a minute in thy houſe, though I lie in the ſtreet for • t.
Huswife, I'le ſort you with f • tter companions, Come, follow me quickly.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: H • aven bleſſe me and my childe too from matching with ſuch a diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truly, ſir, I long'd to be out o th' houſe before.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Before you came in it did you not? ha!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Theſe new walls do ſo ſtink of the lime methinks.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Marry fough, Gooddie Foyſt.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: There can be no healthie dwelling in 'em this twelve-moneth yet.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Are you ſo tender bodied?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Even pleaſe your ſelves then where you can like better, and you ſhall pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why you will not thruſt me out of your houſe, will you? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: There's no ſuch haſte, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Indeed there is not, nor will I out for all your haſte neither. I'le have look to my bargain.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: With all my heart, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But no more of your idle motions, if you love your eaſe in your houſe, your •• n here.
Here's a letter, ſir, from Mr. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Is the earer paid, or give him that an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Some body has anger'd him, and I muſt ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I ſent you to ſeek my ſons, good ſir, have you found 'em? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I cannot finde 'em ſir. They went out of the Tavern together, they ſay, and I have been at Mr. Mihils chamber, and there they are not. I went to the Tavern again, and there they were not. • hen I beat all the reſt o'th' buſhes, in this four eſt of foo es and mad men, and cannot finde em I, where e're they be.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
Sirrah, go finde em me where e're they be, any where, or no where, finde 'em, and finde 'em
quickly; I'le finde 'em in your Cockſcombe elſe, d' ye ſee! and bring my ſons Sanctity home before it be dark, leſt he take up his lodging in a Church-porch; and charge Mr. Mihil that he come not to me till I ſend for him. Here's danger i'th' houſe. There was a match-motion indeed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good ſir, either like my houſe well, or be pleaſ'd to pleaſe your ſelf with ſome better.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be quiet in your houſe, leſt I ſend you out of it to ſeek another. Let me ſee my chamber.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: He muſt have his way, I ſee.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Bettie, Frank, with ſwords drawn make faſt the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: NAy, you perpetual Puſſe, I'le fetch him out of the very bowels of thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He never came ſo deep himſelf yet with all that he could do, and I ſcorne the threatning of a She Marmaſet.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why Bettie, Frank, you mankinde Carions you. I vow, open the door, will you both kill one another, and cozen the Hangman of his fees?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Thou hadſt been better have bit off the dugs of thy Damme, thou pin-buttock Jade thou, than have ſnapt a bit of mine from me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here's that ſhall ſtay your ſtomack better then the bit you ſnarle for. Thou greedy Brach thou.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why wenches, are ye wild? break open the doores.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That I could ſplit that divelliſh tongue of thine!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have as good a ſpight at as ill a member about thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hold, what's the devil in ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are ye ſo ſharp-ſet ye Amazonian Trulls?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Let me but make one paſſe at her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray let me go, and let her come.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can no blunter tooles then theſe ſerve to take down your furies?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Let me come but within nailes reach of het.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me but try the ſtrength of my teeth upon her.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: As Hector 'twixt the hoſts of Greece and Troy,
When Paris and the Spartane King ſhould end
Their nine yeares warres, held up his brazen lance.
In ſignal, that both Armies ſhould ſurceaſe,
And hear him ſpeak. So let me crave your audience.
Dear Bettie be adviſ'd, and Frank, forbear
Thy thirſt of Siſters blood. Whileſt I rip up
The folly of your ſtrife. Your caſes both
Have been laid open to me. You contend
For love of a lewd Citizen, that ſleights,
Nay more, diſdaines, nay more, deſies you both.
Tony can tell, Mun Clotpoll alſo knows
The words he ſpake, that you were both poor whores,
Not poor alone, but foule infectious harlots.
And that he wears your mark with pain and ſorrow,
Hopeleſſe to claw them off. With conſtant purpoſe
Never to ſee you more, unleſſe to greet.
Your bumpin buttocks with revengeful feet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Did he ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And muſt we two fall out for ſuch a ſlanderous Villain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, agree, agree.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Buſſe and be friends. Buſſe, or I'le baſte ye both, I vow.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come Siſter we'll be in for ever now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For my part, Siſter, ſure I was not out with you.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But did he ſay he would kick us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lo here, the man that dares it not deny.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: But do ye hear, Gentlemen. I hope you will uſe me kindlier then ſo.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Than how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Then to win all my money, and leave me at ſtake for the reckoning. Pray do you pay the Drawer for me, though I pay it you again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is it Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentlewomen and he had 14. ſh. in before you came.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Tis a plain caſe, your cloak muſt anſwer it at the bar, Sir. Drawer, away with it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Nay, but Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do but look after it, till we be gone, and theſe ſhall claw thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well ſir, I hope this quarter will not be alwayes lawleſſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you grumble? Mr. C • ffeleſſe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow you ſhall have cu •• es.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, that you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cuts and ſlaſhes too before we part, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You will not murder me, will you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Damoſels forbear; and you, forbear your noiſe. I vow, I'le ſlit your wiſtle elſe. You ſhall give him due correction civilly, and we will make him take it civilly. Sit you down Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, mum.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O, are ye here! was it a brotherly trick do ye think, to leave me to pay one reckoning twice? or did I think never to be made a mouth more, after I had paid my ſwearing dinner, and am I now a greater mouth then e're I was?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mum, hold your tongue ſtill in your mouth, leſt I halifax it with your teeth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Halifax my tongue. And liſten to a buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Do yon know this man?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, the City mouth we had tother night.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Theſe are the Siſters that his laviſh tongue ſo lewdly did deprave.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I cry them heartily mercy Are you of the ſweet Siſterhood? I hope to know you all, all the pretty Mumpers in the berrie here, before I have done. 'Tis true, I proteſt, he ſpake words of you, that ſuch fleſh and blood could not bear. He could not have ſpoken worſe of mutton of a groat a quarter.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And were we ſo fond to fight for him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But now we'll both be revenged upon the fleſh of him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray let me ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, they ſhall beat you firſt. And mark me well. Do thou but ſtir an hand or foot, or raiſe a voice that may be heard to the next room, well cut thy weaſand. Now wenches take your courſe.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, you ſlave, we'll mark you for a Sheepbiter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll teach you how to ſcandalize.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Have I given you that you cannot claw off, you Mungrel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Rare, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There, there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll claw thine eares off rather.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O brave.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O out-rage, moſt inſufferable, all this goes into my black book.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To him Bettie, at him Frank; there whores, there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, fie, forbear, enough, too much in conſcience.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: That young man has ſome pity yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ſwear you ſhall no more.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Alas, good Gentlemen, it is enough.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do you prate? you ſhall have as much. Come, take the Chaire, Sir, the breeches ſhall bait him too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, they ſhall. To him and claw him, I'le clapperclaw your ſides elſe

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O me! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Heyday! his beard comes off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And his head too What rotten ſcab is this?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I proteſt, they have pulled my pieced brother in pieces here.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, ſome diſguiz'd villain, and but for doing the State ſo good ſervice, we would hang him preſently without examination.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know him. And you ſhall not touch him. Beſt is, he knows nor me. Good Heaven, what Braintrick has poſſeſt him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, what canſt thou be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, 'tis an honeſt fellow, that is only aſham'd to run ſo baſe a courſe for his living in his own face. Poor man, I warrant his feare threatens his breeches ſhrewdly. But let's away, and quickly, our ſtay is dangerous. Come, we forgot Mich. Croſwil and the wenches.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come all away then, Sirrah, thank this Gentleman, and pray for him at the end of your Songs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Farewel, friend Peece. I'le know you better now, before you have't again.
sp.stage: Ex. omnes but Cock. and Cit.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What monſters in mankinde? what hell-hounds are they? only as Ovid feign'd among the Getes. A friend at need, I with a friend was bleſt, Whom I may gratifie, and plague the reſt. How is it with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O, I am very ſore.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Indeed you are ſorely handled. This may warne you out of ſuch caterwaling company. You look like one more civil. And in hope you will be ſo, I'le bring you to a Barber.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Alas, my Cloke.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'le help you to that too, ſo you with me, Will in an honeſt plot Aſſiſtant be.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O Sir, in any thing, and thank you too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A Paris ill ya ben veni- Here's no buſh at this door, but good wine rides poſt upon't, I mean, the ſign-poſt. Boy, get you down, and if Nick Rooksbill, or any of his company ask for me, bring 'em up, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will, I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are welcome to Paris brother Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is nevertheleſſe a Tavern, brother Mihil, and you promiſed and covenanted with me at the laſt houſe of noiſe and noiſomneſſe, that you would not lead me to any more Tavernes.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Lead you brother? men uſe to be led from Tavernes ſometimes. You ſaw I did not lead you nor bring you to any that was more a Tavern then the laſt, nor ſo much neither; for here is no Buſh you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Twas that betrayed and entrapped me: but let us yet forſake it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray let us drink firſt brother. By your leave here's to you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: One glaſſe-full more is the moſt that I can bear. My head is very full, and laboureth with that I have had already.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There Sir, I'le undertake one good fellow, that has but juſt as much Religion as will ſerve an honeſt mans turne, will bear more wine then ten of theſe giddy-braind Puritanes, their heads are ſo full of whimſeys.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Tis mighty headie, mighty headie, and truly I cannot but think that the over much abuſe of theſe out-landiſh liquors, have bred ſo many errours in the Romiſh Church.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Indeed brother, there is too much abuſe made of ſuch good creatures. Wine in it ſelf is good, you will grant, though the exceſſe be nought; and Tavernes are not contemptible, ſo the company be good.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is moſt true, we finde that holy men have gone to Tavernes, and made good uſe of 'em upon their Peregrinations.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
And cannot men be content to take now and
then a cup, and diſcourſe of good things by the way. As thus. Brother, here's a remembrance (if ſhe be living, and have not loſt her honour) to our Couſin Dore as.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O that kinſwoman of ours. She was the deareſt loſſe that e're fell from our houſe.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Pledge her, good brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I do—

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope 'twill maudlenize him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: But have you never ſeen that miſcreant that wrong'd her, ſince he did that ſame, they ſay you knew him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Alas, ſuppoſe I had, what could be done? ſhe's loſt we ſee. What good could ſhe receive by any courſe againſt him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It had been good to have humbled him, though into the knowledge of his Tranſ • reſſion. And of himſelf for his ſoules good, either by courſe of Law, or elſe in caſe of neceſſity, where the Law promiſeth no releefe, by your own right hand you might have ſmote him, ſmote him with great force, yea, ſmote him unto the earth, until he had prayed that the evil might be taken from him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This is their way of loving enemies, to bear 'em into goodneſſe. Well, brother, I may meet with him again, and then I know what to do. If he knew him as I do now, what a religious combate were here like to be at Nicks coming.
Sir, here's a Gentlewoman asks for Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The travell'd Gallant, is't not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and the old black party, her Land lady with her. But they ask for no body but him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say he is here by all meanes, and bring 'em up.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Women! pray brother lets avoid the place, let us flie it. What ſhould we do with women in a Tavern?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: No harme aſſure your ſelfe, cannot we govern ourſelves?
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas and Madge, and ſtart back.

sp.speaker: Nay,
sp.p: Lady, ſtay, he will be here preſently, that you look for.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will not glance an eye toward temptation.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I am amaz'd ſure, I have ſeen this face, howe're your habit and the courſe of time may give't another ſeeming.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Good Angels, help my thoughts and memory. It is my Kinſman Mihil. What's the other that hides his face, ſo?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Do you turn away?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: It is my Couſin Gabriel, ſtrangely altered.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Come hither you. I • le make a little bold with you. Thou that haſt been a concealer of more ſins in womens actions, then thou haſt grizled hairs.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sure I will ſpeak to him, he alwayes lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Reveale a truth to me on my demand, now inſtanrly, without premeditation. I'le cut thy tongue out elſe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's here to do? do you think I am a devil? that you make ſuch conjurations over me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I think thou art as true a ſervant of his as any Bawd can be. But he now if thou dareſt. How long have you known that Gentlewoman? and what do you know by her?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Here's a ſtirre about nothing. I know nothing by her, not • . Nor whether ſhe has any thing or nothing, that a woman ſhould have by the report of knowledge of man, woman or beaſt, not I. She came to me but this morning, with a purpoſe to ſet me up in my new houſe as I hoped. But ſhe has taken a courſe to make it honeſtly ſpoken of already, to my utter undoing, but ſhe never comes within my doors again, as I hope to thrive by my Trade hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Pray look upon me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Was ſhe ſo reſolutely bent, and ſo ſoon altered?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Upon the very firſt fight of the very firſt man that came into my houſe, the very firſt houre of my ſetting up in it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What man was that?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A ſhame take him, your roaring friend, Nick. I think ſhe is enamoured of him, or of ſomething ſhe gueſſes he has; and would faine play the honeſt woman with him, that never played honeſt man with woman in his life.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe, and 'tis moſt wonderful.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: If you knew who I were, you would not be ſo ſtrange to me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And here ſhe comes me a hunting after him, like a fondling, whileſt halfe a dozen peeces might ha' been gotten at home by this time, aud ſhe have had the halfes of it in her purſe by this time; if ſhe would have done, as I thought, ſhe would have done by this time.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Alas, poor Howlet.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I ſent whooping after the beſt gueſt that haunt my houſe, to have taken the firſt fruits of her converſation, and ſhe would not ſee a man of 'em, to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well leave thy hooting, Madge, and hold thy peace. thou ſhalt get by it.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall get a good name ſhortly, and this geare hold, and turn begger, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray ſir, but one word.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Speak to her, brother, 'tis our Couſin Dorcas.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Will you abuſe me too? is ſhe not loſt?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And will not you give her leave to be found again? his wine and her ſudden apprehenſion works on him at once. Couſin, I'le ſpeak to you, though I confeſſe the miracle of our meeting thus amazes me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O Couſins both. As ye are Gentlemen, and of that noble ſtock, whoſe meer remembrance, when he was given up, and at the brink of deſperate folly, ſtroke that reverend fear into my ſoul, that hath preſerv'd my honour from further falling. Lend me now your aide, to vindicate that honour by that man, that threw me in the way of loſſe and ruine.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All ſhall be well, good Couſin, you ſhall have both hands and hearts to re-eſtate you in him. So that in fact you have not wrong'd that honour, ſince he forſook you.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: On my ſoule I have not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Infants then ſhall be pardoned. Brother ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You were wont ſtill to be my loving'ſt Couſin.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What a ſtrange dream has wine wrought in my head.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I hope it will work out his ſuperfluous zeale.
And render him civil Chriſtian again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is no dream, good Couſin, you are awake,
And I, that Dorcas, for whom you have wiſh't

Affinity of blood might be diſpen • 'd with. And you
to be my choice. So well you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And will above my life affect you ſtill. But you muſt leave theſe gauds and prophane dreſſings.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Bawds did he ſay? how comes he to know me troe?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.l: How came my Couſin Gabriel thus tranſlated.
Out of gay cloathes long haire, and lofty ſpirit,
Stout and brave action, manly carriage;
Into ſo ſtrict a Reformation?
Where is the martial humour he was wont ſo to affect.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: His purity and your diſgrace fell on you both about a time, I faith.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do you ſwear by your FAITH?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's falling back again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Some more wine. You will drink with our
Couſin, brother, will you not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What wine is't, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, in a cup of ſincere love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What other wine you pleaſe, Gentlemen, we have none ſuch i • th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Of the ſame we had, ſir.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Call not for wine for us, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Aſſuredly, we are no prophane wine-bibbers, not we.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Modeſt, and well-ſpoken verily, ſhe ſhould be a Siſter or a Matron.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we'll all drink for the good o'th' houſe.
'Tis upon putting down, they ſay, and more o'th neighbours. But Couſin, he knew you not to day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, nor dreams of me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And the old one knowes nothing, does ſhe.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: No, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: She can bewray nothing then. My brother knows not him. I only do for his faire Siſters fake, of which you may hear more hereafter; in the mean, bear your ſelfe faire and free, as if you knew him not, and I'le work him to your end, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You are a noble Spokeſman.
sp.stage: [Bawd and Gabriel confer devoutly the while.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Truly, you ſpeak moſt edifyingly.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well-ſaid, give it to my brother. Drink to our Couſin, Brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
