sp.p: I will, and to that vertuous Matron, whoſe care of her, I hope, tends unto good edification.—Truly the wine is good, and I was ſomething thirſty.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Beſt drink again then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will follow your motherly advice.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill work, anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And you have travell'd Couſin. I may ſuppoſe you brought this well-diſpoſed Gentlewoman from Amſterdam with you. And this unto your welcome, hoping I ſhall be informed by you how the two zealous brethren thrive there? that broke in St. Hellens.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Of that or any thing ſir, pray drink again, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You Jade you, hold your tongue.
sp.stage: Enter Nick, Anthony, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, are ye here Gallants! I made all the haſte I co ••• , but was ſtayed, I vow, by the braveſt ſport, baiting of a fellow or two with our Puſſe-cats here. I could e'ne ſind in my heart to marry 'em both for their valours.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Thoſe words are daggers.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I pray diſſemble your paſſion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What? are you acquainted already?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee ſhe was a brave Madona?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: How long have you had acquaintance with her, Nick?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Never ſaw her before this morning, I, ſtanding upon her Belconee.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly Couſin, I think 'twas you that I ſaw to day too, ſtanding upon a Bellconee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: You ſpell very modeſtly, ſir. Your brother
I take it. But did you call her Couſin, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes ſir, ſhe is my Couſin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill out too ſoon. Why Nick, thou knoweſt theſe kinde of creatures call and are called Couſins commonly.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, in their tribe. But I thought he had been too holy for them. But Dammy—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O fearfully prophane!

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You ſaid you had a ſtorie to relate, of dire misfortune. and of unquoth hearing. I come to hear your ſtory, what ſtop you your eares at? ſir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I dare not ſpeak it but in thy reproof. Thou ſweareſt Gee o Dee, Dee a • m thee, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thou lieſt, I call'd her Dammy, becauſe her name is Damyris,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I ſay thou lieſt, her name is Dorcas, which was the name of an holy woman.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Shall we have things and things? I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This vvill ſpoil all. Brother, I pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I may not forbear, I am moved for to ſmite him; yea, vvith often ſtripes to ſmite him; my zealous wrath is kindled, and he ſhall flie before me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Bet. Frank.
sp.p: What furie's this?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Great Damboys ſhrink, and give a little ground.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will purſue him in mine indignation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And beat him into Potſheards.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Now he has bang'd the Pitcher, he may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray, brother, be perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A brother to be ſo controuled?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You ſir, put up your Steel-ſtick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I deſire but to know firſt, if he be a brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes marry is he, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſatisfied. So let him live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to ask you, do theſe men take part with the brethren?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and are brothers a little diſguiz'd, but for ſome ends.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Some State-occaſions.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Meer Intelligencers, to collect up ſuch and ſuch obſervations, for a great Separatiſt that is now writing a book againſt playing at Barlibreak, moulding of Cocklebread, and ſuch like prophane exerciſes.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly ſuch exerciſes are prophane exerciſes, that bear the denomination of good things ordained for mans uſe, as Barley, Cockles, and Bread are ſuch things to be made ſports and play-games? I pray you let me ſee theſe brethren again, to make my atonement with them. And are thoſe Siſters too, that were wi • h them?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
O, moſt notorious ones, and are as equally diſguiz'd to be as rank Spies as the other. S'lid man, and they ſhould be taken for ſuch as they are, they would be cut off preſently. They came in this
mad humour to be merry with you for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray let 'em come again, I ſhall not be well until I have rendred ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You muſt do as they do then, or they will think you are a Spie upon them.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will be as merry as they, let wine be given unto us.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: More wine, Boy, and bid 'em all come in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, Couſin, let him drink no more.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Couſin, it ſhall be for his good and yours, as I will order it.
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Anthonie, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank, Drawer with wine

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All welcome, not any repetition, but begin a new

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will begin it, two glaſſes: it ſhall be a faithful Salutation to all the Brothers and Siſters of—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Blade and the Scabberd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It ſhall go round.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le ſwear you do not well to let him drink ſo.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well ſaid civil Roarer.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Let it go round, go to, you are a wag. I know what you mean by the Blade and the Scabberd.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Who could have thought this had been ſuch a brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Nay, who could have thought you had been of the brethren.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brethren ſir, we are the Brothers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yea, the diſguiz'd ones.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: How? diſguiz'd ones?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Do not croſſe him again. If thou doeſt, and I do not maul thee. Yes, brother, theſe are vertuous
men howe're they ſeeeme.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I have ſo much vertue as to rebuke thee for lying. But we are brethren, ſir, and as factious as you, though we differ in the Grounds; for you, ſir, defie Orders, and ſo do we; you of the Church, we of the Civil Magiſtrate; many of us ſpeak i'th' noſe, as you do; you out of humility of ſpirit, we by the wantonneſſe of the fleſh; now in devotion we go beyond you, for you will not kneel to a ghoſtly father, and we do to a carnal Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le ſtop your mouth, you ſaid you came to be merry.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, and brought Fidlers along, but they muſt play i'th' next room, for here's one breaks all the Fiddles that come in his reach. Come fir, will you drink, dance, and do as we do?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'le drink, I'le dance, I'le kiſſe, or do any thing, any living thing with any of you that is Brother or Siſter. Sweet-heart let me feel thy Coney.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I now he's in. Play Fidlers. Dance.
All bravely performed, admirably well done, &c.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, thou art a brother after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.p: We cannot commend you enough, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This done in civil fort among our ſelves, I hope, will prove no ſcandal to a brother.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Twill prove an honour to our faction.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I thirſt to do it honour.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Give him ſome wine, he thirſts.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Thou little dapper thing, thou, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou ſeeſt he can ſcarce ſtand.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, my religious brethren, no more wine.
Enough's a feaſt, and little doth ſuffice.
sp.p:
I thirſt to do ſome honour to our cauſe. To lead
forth legions to fight a battel 'gainſt our. malignant adverſaries.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brave.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such an employment now would make me famous, for my ſufficiency of Att in Armes.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, this man has hidden things in him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He has as brave a warlike ſpirit, man, before his preciſe humour tainted it, as ever breath'd in Hector.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow then, a good orderly diet of nothing but ſack for a week together, would revive it in him, and bring it to good again.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I hope, 'tis done already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How do you, ſit?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I feare ſome Jeſuitical fumes have invaded my Brain pan. All me thinks goes whirley, whirley, whirley.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Beſt lie down upon a bed. Drawer!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Souldiers muſt not be curious. A Bench or any thing.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentleman may have a bed here, an't pleaſe you. But ſir, there's an old angry Gentleman below, that asks for you, and by all deſcription for that mortified Gentleman. And will by all meanes preſſe into your room here.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is my father.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O me! What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: M • d. Bet. Fran.
sp.p: We ſhall be all clap't up.

sp.speaker: M • .
sp.p: Fear nothing, veile your face a little; Who is with him?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: No body but his old Servingman, that it ſeems diſcover'd you. You may put this Gentleman into this inner room, and keep the Key your ſelfe. I know not what charge he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Admirable honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: And you may tell your father he is gone, for he is gone you ſee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow. a wit.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Now if you'll be civil, I may bring him up to you, if not, becauſe he is your father, we'll thruſt him out of doors, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Notable raſcal, well ſir, let him up. I know how to fit him.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: But this delays my buſineſſe, Couſin, and will, I fear, fruſtrate my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor hinder any thing, I'le warrant thee, he's thine. Play Fidlers, t'other dance.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Will you! proteſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not wilde?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come Wenches, if he venture in his fathers ſight, ſhame take us and we bluſh.

sp.speaker: Croſſ. Belt.
sp.p: And I had not ſold all my land to live upon my money in Town here, out of danger or the Statute, I would give thee a Copihold for this diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank your worſhip, and truly 'tis a goodly ſight, me thinks, an't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I'm glad it likes you. Heigh, excellent good again. Heigh, Heigh, what an happineſſe may fathers boaſt, that can bring their children up to this. (Dance ended) I cry ye mercy, Gentlemen all. Ha! I am ſory I interrupted your ſerious private occaſions.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Would you ſpeak with any here, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It is my father, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Tny father? hold thy peace; dar'ſt thou uſe thy father thus? to ſpend thy time thus! ha! Is this place fit for the ſon of a Geatleman of quality? ha! why doeſt not anſwer me, does this company ſort with thy reputation? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, the company.—

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, I ſay, or are theſe exerciſes allowable for a Gentleman, that ever ſaid or heard Grace at his fathers Table? anſwer me that.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: An't pleaſe you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Hold thy peace when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The company, ſir, offends not you, I hope; you ſee the worſt of us.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: In good time, ſir, you are the diſtracted Gentlemen, I take it, that ask't him if he would moot to night? Is this your mooting? do you put caſes to your VVenches, or they to you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thy father talkes too much.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Which are the better Lawyers? ha!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But that you are his father, ſit, and an old man, and he an honeſt young Gentleman, and our friend, we would tell you.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I thank you for him, yes truly, heartily; and for your good opinion of him, heartily. Pray keep him amongſt you while ye have him, for I' • e ha • no more to ſay to him, I. Is your Invectives againſt drinking, wenching, and the abomination of the times come to this? is this your ſpending of time more pretious then money? is it you that knows not what to do with money but to buy books; and were drawn with ſuch unwillingneſſe to a Tavern? ha! you ſhall graze upon Littletons Commons, or eat nothing but books, an't pleaſe you, for any exhibition thou ever get'ſt from me—And in that faith thou haſt loſt a father. Come ſir, you have brought me to a goodly ſight here; would any Villain but thy ſelfe have ſhewed his Maſter light to ſee ſo much woe! Thy Coxſcombe ſhall yet pay fot't.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O ſir, O.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: This was your trim ſight, was it?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: But well remembred. Pray where's your brother? my ſon I would ſay; for I know no brother or father thou haſt. Where is Gabriel?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He is not here, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Did you not tell me, Sirrah, he was here?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I told you then too much. I feel it here.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: He was here, ſir, but he is gone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: So, ſo, he's loſt. He muſt be cried, or we ſhall never finde him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, I'le find him yet to night, ſir. Pray Gentlemen pay you the Reckoning, I'le wait upon my father home.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Was that ſpoke like a ſon of mine? muſt others pay your reckoning, and I in place; take that, and do not make me mad. And why ſhould you home with me? I pray, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Becauſe ſir, it grows dark, and 'tis the worſt way as it is about the town; ſo many odde holes a man may ſlip into; pray take me with you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Pray take no care for me, ſir, and let the way be as it is. Do not think me worſe at it in the dark then your ſelf, I beſeech you. But you talk't of the Reckoning, pray let not the want of money for that hinder the ſearch of your brother. There's towards your paines for that; and ſo for a farewel to you and your friends here, till I hear thou keepeſt better company, let me hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There was no way to get this money, and be rid of him, but to offer him my ſervice He would have driven me out before him elſe. But come, let's ſee my brother that went to ſleep in ſo warlike a Paſſion. I hope he'll wake in a better.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mun Clotpoll, thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No, I proteſt, but ſtruck with admiration at the old Blades humour.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come, Dammy and the reſt, be merry. I vow, we'll ſup together, and ſo at laſt hear all thy diſmal ſtory.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I mean he ſhall, and ſuch an Audit make,
As ſhall reſtore her honour from the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p:
WHat has this Coxſcombe Cockbrayne writ me here? That he deſires his abſence be excuſ'd. What have I to do with him? when I ſend for him, let him come to me. That he is upon a point of diſcovery in a moſt excellent project for the weeding of this Garden? what Garden? what project? A project he ſays here for the good of the Republike, Repudding. This fellow has in ſtead of braines, a Cob-web in his Noddle, with little ſtrawes, feathers, and wings of dead Butterflies hanging in it, that having motion by his aery fancie, there dance and keep a Racket; 'tis to teach women ſilence, or ſome ſuch fooliſh impoſſibility. He is ambitious to be call'd into authority by notice taken of ſome ſpecial ſervice he is able to do the tate aforehand. But what great ſervice he is able to do it, or which way to undertake it, falls not in the reach of my imagination. But good Mr. Croſwill, by your favour now, what reaſon have you to ſlight or wrangle at this man? this honeſt Cockbrayne? that has alwayes been a conſtant friend to you, and officious in many good wayes, and is a Gentleman, not only of good deſcent and eſtate, but of a good diſpoſition. And you two, Mr. Croſſewill, by your leave, have alwayes agreed like
neighbours children. I, the divel was in't, and now he vexes me again; we agreed in one point ſo well, that we have undone a couple of our children by it, and hindred the getting of I know not how many more. His ſon and my daughter ſhould have married. And on a ſndden he and I both conſented to a diſlike of the match and broke it, and have both repented it an hundred times ſince. We agree very wel in that point; and now is his ſon irrecoverably loſt, and my daughter reſolutely bent to be an Ape-leader in Limbo. But whats all this to the affliction I ſuffer in my ſons now? that one of them from a riotous boy. ſhould grow into a Puritanical Woodcock; and the tother from a civil well-qualified fellow, turn'd abſolute Ruffian. There, there, I there's the devil in't. I could beat my ſelfe for getting ſuch children.
See, ſee, my Maſter for want of other company fallen out with himſelf, and it pleaſe you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: It does not pleaſe me, nor thou pleaſeſt me, nor any thing pleaſes me. The world's bent to croſſe me, and thou ſhalt feel it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O good ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Is it not ſo, ſir, was not that dunce Gabriel, a moſt notorious wilde thing

Before he ſteer'd a Religious courſe? but then he run ſo full a ſaile, that he paſſ'd and was beyond the line of Religion before he was aware; and as he paſſed it under the torrid Zone of Zeale, the Calenture took him o'the pate, that he is mad with it, and as far beyond Religion now as it is to it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Sir, there's hope that he may he fetch't halfe way back again, by your fatherly advicement, and become a ſound man.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: And then was not Mihil ſo civil, that he made me even ſick to ſee him. And now is he flowen out as far into rior t'other way.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: But he, ſir, will appear a preſent comfort to you, he is reclaim'd already; you ſhall never ſee ſuch a Reformation in a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What's this you tell me? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: He has caſt off his long-curl'd haire and all.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.l: He had been better have cut his head off.
Where is he!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Below ſir, and a Gentlewoman with him, but very much afraid to appear to you. I never ſaw a man ſo timourſome.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Do you think it fit I ſhould go down to him, or he come up to me, fir, ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I'le fetch him, here's a life!

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I charg'd he ſhould not come at this houſe too, for feare he might be catch'd with this mechanick fellows daughter, though her portion be around one. And let him take heed he look not at her.
Bleſſe me! what changeling is this? he's in his Brothers cut.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir,—Sir.—

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Would you ſpeak with any here, ſir, do you know me. I know not you, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The ſenſe of your late diſpleaſure, ſir, has ſo humbled me into the knowledge of my ſelf, that on the wings of true obedience, I flew after you to make a childes ſubmiſſion at your feet, to crave your pardon for my riotous tranſgreſſion, and to ask your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
A delicate ſpeech, pray take it for faſhion-ſake.
But if I know how to look towards thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray ſir, beſtow it really upon me.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: God bleſſe thee, I ſay, and ſo much many honeſt men beſtow daily on ſons that are none of their own, if thou beeſt mine, how cameſt thou thus like a fellow that had narrowly ſcap't the Pillorie, and brag'd in the publication of his eares? not an hair left to hide them.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: To ſhew my readineſſe to reform my life, ſir. And yet a willingneſſe withal to live, as well, as civilly, in which I am in all humility to preferre a ſuit to you. You know, ſir, I am but a younger brother.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Here is a widow, ſir, a Gentlewoman of great eſtate, and of a well-known life. Antient ſhe is, and has had husbands. How many?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Foure truly, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Foure ſir, I would not lie. Of which the worſt ſpoke well of her on's death-bed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's that to me or thee? come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I have all wo'd and wonne her, ſir, and crave but your good-will to marry her. I have brought a Church-man and a Kinſman to give her.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Why ſo, what needs two words then? do you think I can deny you?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: If he does grant it, 'tis the firſt requeſt that e're he granted in his life. Sure the old Match-maker the devil thinks I am in earneſt to marry this beaſt. And puts a readineſſe in his hand to forward it.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Widow, you are welcome. Why call you not your Prieſt? or tarry ſir, let me queſtion you but a little, Do you think ſeriouſly you love this widow?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Better then many men love their wives, I am perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, what children have you widow?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Never had any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Very well ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor ever like to have any, fir, thats the comfort. We ſhall live at the leſſe charge.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Thou art a covetous and a prepoſterous Knave. Wouldeſt thou bury up thy youth in barren ground? doeſt ſeek after wealth, and not after iſſue? doeſt love to feed on other mens leavings? or travel only in a beaten path? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A man goes certaineſt on his journey ſo, ſir, and leſſe trouble it is you know to go in at a great gate, then a narrow wicket.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: You have ſaid enough, ſir, and delight to croſſe me; but I'le croſſe you for once, and lay a croſſe upon you, ſhall perhaps carry you to your grave. Go, fetch your Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le face it as far as I dare. I hope I ſhall have the grace to pull my hand from the book when it comes ſo far.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Widow, you are reſolv'd to have him too.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Before all men i'th' world by your fair leave, 1.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: You ſhall not have him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Without your free conſent, I will not.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd I'le do't. And 'twill be the beſt croſſe trick that e're I did in my life. Pray let me ſpeak in ſome more private wirh you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: If I but 'ſcape Bridewell, I care not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Now Tonie, ſhe's thine own, Now Siſter Kate;
he's thine. The Prieſt has pronounc't it. I ſay, Amen to't. And heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now you have done the beſt brotherly office that ever made a Siſter happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And the friendlieſt to a friend. We have been caſting for it, Sweet, this Twelve-moneth, and Heaven pardon me. I vow'd never to take acquaintance of my Father, till 'twere effected. Although I know of late he has been willing.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And ſo is mine, I know, but yet he ſwore, that I ſhould match my ſelf before he knew't, or I ſhould never marry.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You'll finde him of another minde towards me, and force me into wedlock preſently.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: You have ta'ne the likelieſt courſe that could be. But what is your diſguiz'd woman, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What you ſhall never know, Siſter, I hope.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Come ſir, I have broken off the match with your widow; and ſhe's content to leave you as ſhe found you. And now take me this pretty, ſimpring, plump-lip't, ruddie-cheek't, white-neck't, long-finger'd Virgin in hand, or I will ſwindge you, Sirrah, look to't. If you cannot live civilly with a young wife, you cannot but be mad with an old, I think. Beſides, ſhe's a friends daughter of mine, and prepar'd by her diſcreet father here to love you. Come, and kiſſe her, quickly, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I cannot do't for all the wealth in the world.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Kiſſe a Maid I never ſaw above twice in my life.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: He will have me think him a baſtard, do I what I can. Canſt thou ſee a Maid twice, and not kiſſe her?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, twenty times, ſir, and not kiſſe her, or if once, not above, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: But you ſhall kiſſe her above and below, ſir, and in every room o'th' houſe, ſir, before you part. Stand faire pretty one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not how to do't.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You were not beſt let me inſtruct you. I can be angry too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His back ſide's towards me.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Turne your ſelf, Sirrah, or I'le turne you. Go to, bend your body a little and be hang'd. So, now come your way, and ſay after your little Sir John here, I Mihil take thee, Lucie, &c. As learning ſhall enable him to proceed without book.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Pray let'em do it in the next chamber, they are too baſhful afore us. There are witneſſes enough. Go all in, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Widow, will you give me leave to obey my father?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: With all my heart, and ſay Amen to the marriage.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I think I ſhall have my will at laſt upon one of my rebellious off-ſpring.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And now, pray give me leave ſir, to let you know how happy I do hold my ſelfe in this marriage. I did like this Son better then the other before. And now I like him better then I did at my former view of him, by ſome Reformation that I do obſerve in him. And I do not a little rejoyce in the honour I may have to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p:
That very word brother out of his mouth, has turn'd my ſtomack. I muſt pull all in pieces again. And yet let me ſee theſe young bloods when they
are ſet on't; if they do not marry, they will do worſe. Let em e'ne go on now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You may eaſily conceive, ſir, what a comfort it will be unto me, that I now growing old, and having (I give praiſe for't,) wealth enough, and no childe that I make account of but this one daughter, may, before I die, ſee Grandchildren that I may have by her ſufficiently provided for, be they more or leſſe in number, they may have enough.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: There he is again, he calls my Grand-children that ſhall be, his Grand-children. Am I a Gentleman, and can hear this? if it be not too late, I'le ſpoile the getting of your Grand-children.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven give you joy. Heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: Parſ.
sp.p: I do pronounce them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mad. Kat. And we are witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Croſſe.
sp.p: What remedy?

sp.speaker: Mih. Luc.
sp.p: We are, and crave your bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Croſſ. Rook.
sp.p: All bleſſings be upon you, (all ſalute).

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: But you, ſir, Mr. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le only gratifie the Miniſter.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Do ſo, and pay him well, it is, perhaps, for the deareſt fault that e're thou didſt.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There's for your paines, ſir. Madge, there's for you. Enough to purchaſe thee a Licence to ſell Ale, Tobaccho, and Strong-water again in Godpiece-Rowe, for here will be no dwelling for thee, I ſee that.

Now, brother Anthonie, go you all back to the company we left, and ſee that my Inſtructions be followed
concerning my brother Gabriel, Nick, and his Dammie,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Shall he go from me?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, but you ſhall follow him preſently, truſt to me Siſter. Go, take no leave of 'em. I'le bring 'em upon you preſently.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Are you at leiſure now, ſir, to tell me of your brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, to my grief, ſir, praying you may have patience.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: To your grief, ſir, he is not dead then? Younger brothers ſeldome grieve for their Elders death.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray bear it as you may, ſir I left him in an heavy plight. And let me ſpeak it with ſorrow, he lay ſpeechleſſe.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Alack-a day, good Gentleman, my ſon in-law, perhaps, is heire already.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: And haſt thou been here all this while fooling or wiving (all's a matter) & left thy brother in danger? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He's well attended, ſir, and look't unto. Nor would I wiſh you ſee his weak eſtate.
It can but grieve you, ſir, my wife and ſiſter, together with my ſelf, will go. Or if
It pleaſe my father Rooksbill here, becauſe his power in this quarter is available.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Co, ſhew the way. I'le go in perſon, I. My ſon's my ſon.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Nay, pray ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Yes, 'cauſe you have a wife, you ſhall controul me. Will you go on, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well, I'le bring you to him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was your widow, ſir, ſhe ſtunk of Aquavitae, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le tell thee as we go. Kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What a drunken ſot was I, that knew thee not all this while? I vow, thy ſtory pities me. I'le marry thee, and turne thee to thy friends, for I am ſure I have none that will keep thee for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: I ask no further ſatisfaction of you, then to be honeſted by marriage. I'le work for a poor living.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee Mun ſeek me a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I have no acquaintance in their function, I.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: My Couſin Mihil ſaid he would bring or ſend one.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There's no ſtarting, that Mihil has a fiſt over me. I vow, and thou wert not his Kinſwoman, thou ſhould to the Common yet.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Father, how come you hither?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did not the company ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, not we.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The City-mouth, that peck't us at my lodging laſt night, came to me with an abominable ſcratch't face, and warn'd me on a buſineſſe hither.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I ſmell ſome trick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Some treacherie upon the brotherhood, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Timorous thing! what in our own Quarter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: If you doubt any thing, 'tis beſt remove.
The fellow was ſorely handled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would but ſee the carcaſs of authority prance in our Quarter, and we not cut his legs off. Welcome Tonie, what haſt thou brought the word here to paſſe for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, you muſt make a wedding-night on't Nick, Mihil will go no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: My Vow is paſſ'd, and before you, ſir, I confirm it. This is my wife. Anon, you ſhall perform the holy Ceremony,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis well, pray ſir, retire your ſelf to the next room there a while, and ſtay you with him, Lady.
But what do you with Gabriel? Is it not time to wake him yet?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis now upon the point, h'as ſlept two houres.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Father, you'll ſee a brave experiment upon a Gentleman that has been a youth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And of the Philoblathici, as we are now.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And ſince was grown one of the reformed, and we are now in practice to retrive, and bring him back to his firſt condition.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you followed all Mihils directions?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hitherto we have. Firſt, you ſaw he was laid defunct in Sack, next in his ſleep, we have accoutred him in martial ab liments, and now we mean to wake him with alarmes ſhall affright the ſilly humour out of him, and render him his warlike faculty, or our Art failes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where be the Wenches?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Siſters of the Scabberd, there's the ſport on't. They have their parts to play upon him too. But for his drink now when he wakes, you ſaid you would have a bottle of the womans what do you call't yonder? the Medea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What? the charm'd liquor that Medea brew'd to make old father Aeſon young again?
Muſt that renew his youthful ſpirit in him?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, Sack will do bette • . When he wakes he will be very dry, then a quart-draught of good Canarie will ſo ſcrew him up. 'Tis time 'twere now in practice. So, ſoftly, ſoftly. We muſt but halfe wake him at firſt.
sp.stage: A Bed put forth, Gabriel on it, Bettie and Frank.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O ſome ſmall drink.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here, drink it off, ſir, (Drinks) D • um and Trumpet. An Alarm.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surpriz'd by th' enemie, whileſt we have plaid the Sluggard in our Tents.

sp.speaker: Capt. Nick. Clot.
sp.p: Hold Captain, hold, we are your ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Y'are Mutineers, and have diſturb'd my reſt. And I'le do Martial Juſtice on you all.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, hold, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Know you not diſcipline? or are you growen rebellious in the Camp. I'le teach you warfare.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have conjur'd a fury into him to beat us into fitters.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: My pate bleeds for't; I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'le make you know command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble Commander, hold thy furious hand, and heare thy ſouldiers ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What have we women for our Martial Muſick?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: None but the She-Trumpet, a neighbour here, and her Siſter, that was Drum-ma • or to my Countrey-Amazons, that pull'd up the Incloſures to lie all in Common.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is the enemy i'th' field?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Upon their march, Captain, and we your officers: But rowſ'd you up to be in readineſſe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
You are my Lieutenant, you my Ancient, and you two my Sergeants; and you muſt know the Commander
you ſerve under, to be none of thoſe Letter-carriers that know not ſo much as the termes of diſcipline, what a Flanker is, Nor a Raveling is. Nor a Petarre is. Nor a Curtain is. Nor a Bulwark is. Nor a Baſtile is. Nor a Counterſcarp is. Nor a Caſemate is. A Gabion is: Nor any left word of fortification. How can ſuch freſh-water Captains command?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Right noble Colonel. He ſhall be our Colonel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: One ſouldier made up of Sack, is worth as many as would drink a freſh water river dry.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I knew, men of abilities ſhould at laſt be put in action.
sp.l: Valiant men and wiſe,
Are only fit for weighty enterpriſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O noble Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What would an upſtart Militaſter now, That knew no rudiments of diſcipline, nor Art of warre, do in a ſudden ſervice? or ſay, when I know how to have my Ordnance planted here, my Cavalrie mounted here, my Battery-diſcove • er on ſuch a point, my Trenches cut thus, my Mine carried thus, my Gabions raiſ'd thus. Here my Parapet, there my Palliſadoe o'th'top of that. The enemie made ſaltable ſix hundred paces there. And I draw out my Musketeers to flank 'em in their Trenches here, while my Pikes and Targeteers advance to the breach there. What would Captain, my Lords man, or Sergeant-major, my Ladies Kinſman, ſent in by honourable favour, do or ſay in ſuch an expedition?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Braver and braver ſtill.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: This goes beyond the Blade and the Battoon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
Or how would their braines lie in their breeches, when the able Captain leads up his men in the Head of a Troop bravely, charges with his ſhot,
makes a ſtand with his Pikes, does execution with his Sword, the Cannon playing, the Drum beating, the Shot thumping, the Enſignes waving, the Armes claſhing, the Aire rending, Duſt and Smoke clouding, Blood raining. And then to bring up ſuch a Diviſion to fight, make good ſuch a Ground, relieve ſuch a Squadron, fetch off ſuch a loſſe, r'enforce the Ranks that are broken. March on, Come off. Beat the Beſſognes that lie hid in the Carriages. O the renowned life of a worthy Commander.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sound Drum and Trumpet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Colonel, a Colonel.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Whither haſt thou brought me? does thy brother lie ſpeechleſſe in this houſe? ha! what in the name of tumult can theſe be?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray ſit, attend, you will be pleaſed anon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: A ſtill march now. So, I have loſt a great many of my men. But courage yet, you poor remainder of my ſcatter'd Troops. Stand. Qni vala. An Ambuſcado of the enemy. Alarme. Lieutenant, charge in with your Shot. Now Gentlemen, for the honour of Covent-Garden, make a ſtand with your Pikes; in to the ſhort ſword; well fought, take Priſoners. Sound a Retreat now. Faire, faire i'th' coming off. So, 'twas bravely perform'd.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Muſt we not fall to rifling now, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Part faire on all ſides, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What's this, a viſion, ſure I do aile ſomething.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Is't poſſible it is thou? art thou run mad as far as hell the tother way now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.l: My wicked, caitiffe, reprobate ſon is here too.
Pray let me flee, I am but a dead man elſe.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You ſhall receive no harm, ſir Lay by your Armes my Maſters. I bring none but friends.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I hou canſt not make that good, my father's there.

sp.speaker: Mih
sp.p: I'le make him friends with thee. Go and di patch within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le ſee it done, and take our new made Brides with us for witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Rook
sp.p: Has his ſhame yet taught him to ſhunne my ſight.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And ſhall returne him inſtantly your comfort.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Unpoſſible, unpoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Attend the event.

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: I rather thought I ſhould have found you, ſir, diſputing with the Paſtors, and the Elders; yet to ſay truth, this is the better madneſſe. What can this mean? how came he thus tranſlated? what Charmes, or what Inchantments are upon him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What Babel was a building in my braines?
But now it turnes, and I can recollect
The knowledge of a father, brother, Siſter.
And that a thouſand vain imaginations,
Like ſcatterings of light things upon the earth,
Ruſhes, looſe leaves, ſprigs, ſtraws, and duſt
Contracted by a whirlwinde, were blowen up,
And lodg'd in the rich Seat of Contemplation,
Uſurping there the room of vertuous thoughts.
Honour awake me from this Lethargie.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What can thoſe women that appear like furies be in this action?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They were but uſ'd as properties to give new motion to his mortified condition.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p:
I know not what to ſay to any thing; there
is ſome Spell upon me too. My anger has forſook me. What are thoſe men that bear a countenance. As if they ſtood indifferently affected to Bedlam and Bride-well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Meaning by us, ſir. If our ſight offend you,
Know we are men that dare forbear the place.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I ſon, let's go, our ſtay is dangerous.
They look like Peace-maintainers, we • ll fall off.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: O tarry, Gentlemen, we are all undone elſe. If you make not your peace before you ſtir, both you and I muſt ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: The Magiſtrates and Officers with their Bill-men have ta'ne us by ſurpriſe. They are i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O me! the blew Gown Colledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wheels and whips. I feel what we muſt go to. Did not I ſay our ſtay was dangerous?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Did not I ſay there was ſome ſubtile practice upon the Philoblatici? and that we were betrayed hither?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: There's no eſcaping forth. And Gentlemen, It will but breed more ſcandal on my houſe, and the whole plantation here, if now you make rebellious uproar. Yield your weapons, and welcome Juſtice but like ſubjects new, and peace will follow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: But where's Nick? where's Tonie?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They ſhall yield up their weapons. So do you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes yes, 'tis beſt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Shall we, ſir, ſhall we?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes ſir, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
So, ſir, I will then, not the Blade alone. But
for your more ſecurity, the Battoon, There ſee my Armes forth coming.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say they ſhall have faire welcom, What are they married?
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Dorcas, Ant. Kat. Luc.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, as faſt as troth and holy words can binde 'em.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: 'Tis well. Now ſir, let me entreat your favour.
'Tis my firſt ſuit to you ſince I was your ſon,
That before others entrances diſtract our troubled
Scoene, theſe may be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Even unto the earth, ſir, and humbled with as true a penitence, as ſon can be for wronging of a father, I beg your pardon and bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Give it him, Brother Rooksbill, I dare ſay 'twill make him a good man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven make him ſo. My bleſſing and my prayers ſhall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What? my Neece Dorcas made an honeſt woman?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Was that the man that wrong'd my Couſin Dorcas?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and has now made ample recompence.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Here they are altogether, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
Lay hands on all. Firſt, on that old Ruffian, the Incendiarie, that ſets the youthful bloods on fire here with his Infernal diſcipline. Next, take his ſons, there's one, that young Blade there, Have I now got within ye, Gentlemen? will you have Songs ex temporc? know ye me now? a ha! I'le be can'd the
Weeder of this Garden. Take up thoſe She weeds there. I have the rank one here. I took her ſtragling in my Round e'ne now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My Tenant, I take it, Mrs. Margerie Howlet.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Your widow ſir, I think.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: But for a ſhift ſir, now you know my aim.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O good your worſhip, as you came of a woman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Peace Circes, ceaſe thy charmes. What cluſter have we here now. O here's another of the ſons of noiſe.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That's my ſon now, ſir, by your leave, and I'le baile him.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What Mr. Rooksbil, are you here? what woman's this?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: My Neece, ſir, his ſons wife. And I'le baile her.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What Mr. Croſwill, you among this Ginge too?
How will you 'ſcape commitment?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Cockbrayne? how his braines crow now?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Who's here? your daughters too? but what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I hope they'l prove my ſons, and be indifferent men in time, ſir, by that time their haire may grow, or be reduc't to an indifferent length.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: That's done on me already, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Now he looks as like a Rogue as e're he did again.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And ſir, for me, now that my Couſin is reſtored, and the wilde fury of my wine abated.
I do you the obedience of a ſon, acknowledging my former formal habit was more of ſtubbornneſſe then true devotion. For which I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: There's more deceit under theſe half Footballs, then in whole Pudding-bags. Well boyes, be you indifferent ſons, neither too hot nor too cold. I have found a fault in myſelf, I confeſſe. I will reform it, and be an indifferent father.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O here's the man I ſought, whom, I confeſs, I am half ſorry to commit with the reſt, becauſe I found him civiller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hoping you will not ſtake that good opinion, I'le now come nearer to you. And ſince here is ſuch a convention of love and joy. I hope my offering of a ſons true duty may ſinde I dulgencie.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What? my ſon Antonie?

sp.speaker: Croſſ.
sp.p: How? how? your ſon that ſhould have had my daughter? Come hither Kate, now if thou lov'ſt him, take him. Are you content, friend Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O ſir, moſt happily.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Why run you not together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is too late, or needleſſe now for me to marry her.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Is't come to that? and if I do not ſwindge him—.Are you too good, ſir, for my daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not ſay ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Huswife, do you like him?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No more then he does me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Get you together, or I'le ſwaddle you both into one, you perverſe fooles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, we are married already.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, indeed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Heyday! who am I trow? how durſt you do it vvithout my conſent?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I had your conſent, ſir, you commanded me to take my choice in vvhom I pleaſ'd, before you vvould take notice.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I cannot abide this vvrangling. Give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Joy and my bleſſing on you. Why I knovv not vvhom to commit novv.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You have done the Common-wealth a ſpecial piece of ſervice the vvhile vvith your State-braines. But let us make a night of this, I pray.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, the parties have given me ſatisfaction, and I am content they be releaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: There's an honeſt fellovv novv, and looks like one that vvould be beaten every day for ready money. Go novv, vvhile ye are vvell, and be ſeen no more in this Precinct.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Never and't pleaſe your vvorſhips, never.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.l: 'Tvvas built for no ſuch vermine. Hence avvay.
And may the place be purg'd ſo every day.
'Tis no unvvorthy member may be found,
To peſter or to vilifie this ground.
That as it vvas intended, it may be
A Scoene for Vertue and Nobilitie.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: TIs not the Poets Art, nor all that we
By life of Action can preſent on't, ye
Can or ought make us to preſume a Play
Is good, 'tis you approve't. Which that you may
It cannot misbecome us, ſince our gaines
Come by your favour, more then all our paines.
Thus to ſubmit us unto your commands.
And humbly ask the favour at your hands.

div.head: Another.
div.l: 'Tis done. And now that Poets can divine,
Obſerve with what Nobility doth ſhine
Faire Covent-Garden. And as that improves,
May we finde like Improvement in your Loves.

div.p: THE NEW ACADEMY, Or, the NEW Exchange.
By RICHARD BROME.

LONDON, Printed or Andrew Crook, at the Green Dragon in Saint
• auls Church-yard: And Henry Brome at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: Sir Swithin Whimlby, a melancholy Widower. Suitor to the Lady Neſtlecock.
Old Matchil, a Merchant that married his Maid. Gabrialla's Guardian.
Young Matchil his ſonne.
Old Lafoy a French Gentleman, Guardian to young Matchil.
Young F. Lafoy his ſonne.
Mr. Hardyman, Captain Valentines Father-in-law. Hannah's father.
Strigood, half brother to Matchil.
Valentine Askal, ſon-in-law to Hardiman. Hannah's half-brother.
Eraſmus a young Gentleman, his Companion and Friend.
Caſh, Matchils Prentice.
Nehemiah Neſtlecock, a fooliſh Gentleman, the Ladies ſonne.
Ephraim, the Lady Neſtlecocks Servant.
Rafe Camelion an uxorious Citizen.

list.head: VVomen.
list.item: Ladie Neſtlecock, a fond Mother.
Mrs. Blithe Tripſhort, Sir Swithin Whimlbies Neece.
Hannah, Camelions wife, Captain Hardimans daughter.
Maudlin, Matchils Maid and Wife.

div.head: THE NEW ACADEMY, OR, THE NEW EXCHANGE.
Act. I.
div.p: IS this the entertainment you promiſ'd me in the Jovial Merchants houſe? Is this the great intereſt you have in his huge hoſpitality? when by half an hours attendance and intreats, we cannot obtain the ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I wonder at it; Sure ſome ſtrange diſaſter has ſuddenly befallen him. He was, laſt night the merrieſt man alive, drank healthes; told tales; ſung Catches; Trowle the Bowle; Toſſe the Cannykin; and what not! and all for joy, that his ſonne, he ſaid, was upon his returne, whom he has not ſeen theſe dozen years, ſince he ſent him a little Lad into France, to be bred there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I heard he did ſo; and that in lieu, by way of
Exchange, he brings up the daughter of the Pariſien that breeds his ſonne.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But is that daughter ſo exquiſite a creature, as is this Merchant Matchills own whom you ſo much extoll?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: They are both ſo equally handſome, and vertuous, that, be their dowries ſo, and their conſents alike, I'll take my choice of croſſe and pile for either, with ſuch a friend as thou art.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Troth, and that's friendly ſpoken, Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: It is ſo Val. yet not with ſome policie do I wiſh thee a fortune: for, inſooth. young Gentleman, though I like your perſon, and ſome of your qualities, yet by reaſon of your wants, I finde you ſomething heavy on my purſe-ſtrings; and my ſelfe ſcarce able to ſupply you. And, if we faile of good matches, I muſt even turne you over ſhortly to the hopes you hoaſt of in your City-Myſtreſſes and Tradeſmens wives—.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, prythee hold thy peace.
Friend Caſh! Is your Maſter, Mr. Matchill yet at leiſure 〈◊〉 be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.p: He much deſires, ſir, to be held excuſ'd. 'Tis true that he invited you. His dinner's ready; and his heart welcomes you. But he has met with an unhappy newes to day.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I feard ſome ill. What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: His only ſonne, whom he of late expected home out of France, we hear, is dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: His daughter will prove a bouncing match then.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: That's the impreſſion the heavy newes makes in you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, although my Maſters ſudden ſadneſſe ſhuts him from you. His meat and wine are ready. There are ſome good company in his Parlour too, Pray ſtay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are his faire daughter, and the French-borne
Damſel there to be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: Both. Pray be pleaſ'd to enter.
I hope his paſſionate fit e're you have din'd will be paſt over. He is not wont to ſuffer long under the hand of ſorrow.
sp.l: 'Tis like that you ſhall ſee him ere you go.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: In that faire hope we'll enter and fall to.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: 'Tis like you ſhall fall ſhort though of your aim
At my young Myſtreſſe, who by this black newes,
Becomes my Maſters heire, and ſo the white
That all the gallant ſuiters of the City
And Court will level their keen ſhafts at. Where
Are mine own hopes then, that ſtood as faire
In competition for her, love as any,
When the great noiſe of her inheritance,
Shall drown each Lovers tongue, that cannot ſay,
It is a Lords at leaſt, I rather wiſh
The young man had not did.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where's my Boykin? my Friskoe? my Delight? my Caſh? by what better name can I call thee?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: O me! Maſter Strigood, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I come to comfort my brother in his ſorrow.
His ſonne is dead, they ſay. Ha! Is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And he is almoſt dead with ſorrow: Back ſir.
The ſight of you, that are his ſole vexation, will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That is my way to cure him.
Madneſſe drowns grief in any man.—Probatum.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Good Mr. Strigood depart.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Good Mr. Caſh, and Mr. Matchils man.
I'll ſee your Maſter. What! deny his brother?
His nowne natural brother? By the ſurer ſide too
We tumbled in one Pannier; though we had
Two Rippiers, Sweet ſir, I am the elder too
Strigood was in my mother before Matchill
Therefore, becauſe I have ſpent an eſtate
And he has got-one, muſt not I maintain
My ſelf the better man?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Yes: if you had the wherewithal.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, you had been as good ha' held your tongue.
Lend me ſome money Caſh.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I have no money, ſir, but what's my Maſters.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Whoſe money, ſir, was that you played laſt night.
Among the Knights and Braveries at the ordinary?
Gold by the handfuls, Caſh! Lend me two pieces.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Speak lower, ſir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me three pieces, Caſh.
Before I ſpeak too loud, whoſe money's that
You uſe to weare abroad at Feaſts and Revels
In ſilver lace and ſatten; though you wait
At home in ſimple Serge, or broad-cloth, ſir.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Be not ſo loud, I pray.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me five pieces.
I ſhall grow louder elſe. Who payes your Barber?
I mean not for your Prentice pig-hair'd cut
Your weare at home here; but your Periwigs;
Your locks and Lady-ware that dangle in 'em,
Like ſtraws in the buſh natural of a Bedlem?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: What mean you Mr. Strygood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I mean ten pieces now; I'll go no leſſe. Do not I know your haunts?—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You may; you train'd one to 'em

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Do not I know your our leaps, and vagaries?
Your tiring houſes, where you ſhift your ſelf,
Your privy lodgings, for your trunks and punks?
Your midnight walks and meetings? Come, the money.
And, heark thee, though thou modeſt my brother by't.
I'll keep thy councel: thou ſhalt finde me yertuous.
I want, he gives me nothing; and thou canſt not
Do him better ſervice, then relieve his brother.

sp.speaker: Caſh:
sp.l: I am in; and muſt, to hide my old faults, do
Like an ill Painter, lawbe 'em o're with new.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Quickly. I ſhall grow loud again elſe Caſh.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Sir, I am in your hands, here are ten pieces.

I hope you will not think my Maſter for▪
•• .

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: No; no for all he has that comes through thy hands.
My nimble Caſh; and from his I am ſure,
Though I were ſtarving, I ſhould finger nothing.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Will you go now?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'll ſee him e're I go,
And dine, if there be meat i'th' houſe. What eate's
Are there within • 'll draw a knife amon • 'em.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: This deſperate old Ruſſian, would undo me,
But he hopes to waſte his brother by me.
He has ſpent himſelf to beggery; and would fall ſo,
But that he has pernicious fire in's brain,
That raging ſpreads to ruine others with him.
I muſt beware of him,
Is ſhe come too?
Then 'tis deereed, my Maſter muſt, from ſorrow, ſuffer in madneſſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go home Ephraim.
And have a care you ſuffer not my boy
To Straggle forth 'mong his unhappy play-mates,
For fear of miſchief.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: It ſhall be my care.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What do you lock up my brother, ha?—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: H' has lock't himſelf up, Madam; and will ſuffer
None to come at him, till his ſorrowful fit
Be ſomewhat over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not's own Siſter, ha?—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Nor his half brother neither: yet he's here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is he here, ha? That Strygood? Is he here?
Hang him old reprobate. And beſhrew thy heart,
For a young varlet, to call him our brother.
It is no marvel, if my brother Matchil
Lock up himſelf, and ſuch a wickedneſſe
Be in his houſe, as is that Strygood, ha—
Let him take heed, he comes not in my Nayl reach,
And call me Siſter, or my Brother, brother,
Like a debauſh'd old Villain, as he is.
O that my husband Neſtlecock were alive,
But for three minutes, to ſend him to
Newgate, if he preſume to call me Siſter
But I command you in my husbands name,
Who was a Juſtice, when he liv'd, to thruſt him
Out of your Maſters doors, my brothers houſe.
Leſt I be ſick with the loath'd ſight of him.
You will not diſobey this, will you, ha?—
If not, why ſtir you not? ha.—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I muſt remove
This fit of hers. There's but one way to do it;
And thats to talk of her white boy, ſhe's fond on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you not ſend him packing, ha?—

sp.speaker: Caſh,
sp.l: Firſt, Madam.
(By your good Ladiſhips leave) how does your ſonne
Sweet Maſter Nehemiah Neſtlecock?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you courteous friend. In truth, laſt night,
One of my Coach-gueldings fell lame, and I,
By that conſtrain'd to come afoot,
Was forc'd to leave my boy at home; or elſe
He had come with me, to have been a comfort
To his ſad Uncle: But I would not now
For twice my Gueldings price, my childe were here;
And that foule fiend i'th' houſe, whoſe very looks
Would fright him into ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: O good Lady!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I can't ſo ſoon forget the fright he took
At ſeeing the roguiſh Jugler once eat tow,
And blow it out of's mouth in fire and ſmoke,
He lay a fourtnight by't.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: That's two yeares ſince.
And he was then but young, he's now a man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alack a childe; but going in's nineteenth year.
Where's my Neece Joyce?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Within there Madam; ſo is Gabriella
The French young Gentlewoman to attend you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll ſtay with them till I may ſee my brother.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I hope old Strygood, who now on the ſudden
Hath ſlipt her memory, meets her by the eares firſt.
sp.stage: Enter Matchil, an opeu letter in his hands.
sp.l: But the good minute's come, before I look't for't.
My Maſter now appears. He looks moſt ſourely
Expreſſing more of anger then of grief.
I feare, old Strygood was ſo loud with me,
That he hath over-heard us, and I ſhall break
Before I am a Freeman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sorrow be gone
And puleing grief away, whileſt I take in
A nobler and more manly Paſſion;
Anger, that may inſtruct me to revenge.
My childe is loſt by treacherous neglect
In that falſe Frenchman, to whoſe ſeeming care
I truſted the chief comfort of my life;
My boy. Nay, read again. 'Tis written, here,
He was grown man:

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: His man, I think, he ſaid.
sp.stage: Caſh liſtens to Matchil, and ſpeaks aſide.
sp.l: Does your man trouble you. I do not like that

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And here he writes that in his youthful ſpring
And heat of ſpirit, he began to grow
Intemperate and wilde—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Wilde! Are you there?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Which drew him on to riotous expence—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And there again, to riotous expence!
'Tis I directly that he's troubled with.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And ſometimes into quarrels. What o' that?
In all this he was ſtill mine own. Oboy—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Some ſlave has writ ſome fearful information.
Againſt me, and he hugs and kiſſes it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And had his Guardian had a feeling care
(Hang his French friendſhip) over my dear childe,
As I had over his, theſe youthful follies
Might have been temper'd into manly vertues.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I hear not that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I fall back agen
From my revenge to grief. Away; I will not.
Here's the death-doing point. Theſe ſlight diſorders.
In my young forward ſonne (I finde it here)
Were, by his churliſh and perfidious Guardian,
Interpreted no leſſe then Reptobation,
And, by his ignorant cruelty, ſo puniſh'd.
For, here he ſhuts his eare and door againſt him:
When ſuddenly the looſe licentious world
Soothes on his youthful, in judicious courage
To imminent deſtruction; ſo being engag'd
In a raſh quarrel, he in duel fell.
Th' Opponents ſword was inſtrument; yet I inferre.
Lafoy, his Guarcian was his murderer.
Farewel, my boy; and this is the laſt teare
Thou ſhalt wring from me. Something I'll do,
Shall ſhew a fathers love, and valour too.
I'm young enough to draw a ſword in France, yet.
But firſt—Come hither, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Now it comes.

sp.speaker: Mrt.
sp.l: I purpoſe ſtreight to order my eſtate
Look that you forthwith perfect my Accompts;
And bring me all my books of debtor and creditor,
Receipts and payments, what you have in wares,
And what in caſh, let me inform my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: 'Tis as I fear'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll ſet all right and ſtreight,
All ſtatutes, bonds, bills, and ſeal'd inſtruments
That do concern me, I have in my Cloſet
Or at my Councels, or my Scriveners.
I'll call in them my ſelfe. Why doeſt thou look ſo amaz'dly?
Would'ſt have me yield a reaſon? why, I'll tell thee
I mean to make a voyage; and, perhaps,
To ſettle and proportion out my eſtate
By Will, before I go. Do you as I command you.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Whatever he pretends, I know his drift:
And, e'te I'll be diſcover'd by my ſtay;
Being run out, I'll chooſe to run away.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My daughter in the firſt place muſt be car'd for.
I'll make her a good match. My next in blood then,
My Knave-half-brother, and my whole fool-Siſter.
But the beſt is, her Ladiſhip has enough;
And all I have, in Strygoods hands, were nothing.
Therefore I'll purpoſe nothing to him. Oh.
The Joy and Torment of my life, at once
Appear to me. I muſt divide them, thus.
Hence hated iſſue of my mortal foe
VVhom I have foſter'd with a Parents Piety
As carefully and dearly as mine own.
VVhile the inhumane cruelty of thy Sire
Has to untimely death expoſ'd my ſonne.
Thank me I kill not thee; ſo leave my houſe.
There's French enough in town, that may befriend you.
To pack you o're to Paris; what's your own
Take w'ye, and go. VVhy cleave you to her ſo?
Forſake her, caſt her off. Are not my words
Of force, but I muſt uſe my hands to part ye?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Deare, honour'd father, I beſeech you hear me.
In parting us you ſeparate life from me,
And therein act a real crueltie
On me your only childe, ſharper then that,
Which you can but pretend done by her father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Durſt thou ſpeak ſo?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I cannot live from her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O monſtrous. Pray, your reaſon. Why not live?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You know, Sir, from our Infancie we have been,
Bred up together, by your tender care
As we had been twin-borne, and equally
Your own; and by a ſelf-ſame education,
We have grown hitherto, in one affection,
We are hoth but one body, and one mind,
What Gabriella was, I was, what I, was ſhe.
And, till this hapleſſe houre, you have enjoyn'd me,
Nay, charg'd me on your bleſſing, not to arrogate
More of your love unto my ſelf, then her,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That was, 'cauſe I preſum'd her father lov'd,
Or ſhould have lov'd my ſonne, your brother.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I never knew brother, or ſiſter, I;
Nor my poor ſelf, but in my Gabrella.
Then blame me not to love her, I beſeech you
—Upon me knees.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Th' art knee-deep in rebellion.
Unnatural Gipſie, ſince thou prov'ſt my torment
In being the ſame with her; and haſt declar'd
Thy ſelf no more my childe, then ſhe, whom now
I do abhorre, avoid, with her, my ſight.
Riſe, and be gone, leſt thou pull curfes on thee
Shall ſink thee into earth.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O rather, Sir.
Let me, 'gainſt whom your fury firſt was bent
Suffer alone the ſharpneſſe of your vengeance:
And let it not be ſaid, 'cauſe you ſurmiſe,
My father loſt your ſon, that, therefore, you
Have caſt away your daughter. Hurl me, rather,
Into the ruthleſs waves to ſeek my way;
Or do but take her, hold her in the armes
Of your paternal love, and I'll take flight
To weane her to you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: She cannot, may not leave me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Out of my doors then, with her.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What's the matter? ha—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Such as you cannot mend, deare Lady Siſter.
What come you hither with your Ha—for? Ha—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To comfort you, dear brother, if you'll heare me.
Your ſonne is dead, they ſay; and here I finde
Your daughter is rebellious 'gainſt; our will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You ſpeak much comfort, do you not, think you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But is it ſo Joyce? ha!—I thought you, Joyce,
Would have rejoyc'd your father in obedience, Joyce;
And not afflict him with your ſtubbornneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O this impertinent woman!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But my brother,
Let me adviſe you, rather then ſuffer her
To be an eye-ſore to you, put her out,
Where ſhe may learne more duty. If you pleaſe
I'll take her home, and ſhew her how it ſhould be

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes, as you have ſhewen your Neſtlecock, your ſonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I, there's a childe! Brother, you'l pardon me,
If I aſpire in hope, that he ſhallbe
Your heire, if Joyce miſcarry in rebellion.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And therefore you would breed her. How the devil
Works in a covetous woman! Though a foole too.
Your ſonne's an Aſſe; an Ideot; and your ſelf
No better, that have bred him ſo. Do you tell me
Of your ſweet ſugar-chop't Neſtle cockſcombe?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He's fit t' inherit nothing but a place
I'th' Spittle-houſe, Fools Colledge, yond, at Knightsbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And did I come to bring thee conſolation?
Now let me tell thee, I rejoyce in thy
Juſt puniſhment, thy ſcourge of croſſes. Thou,
That for theſe ſix years ſpace▪ until this day,
Haſt kept continual feaſt and jollitie
For thy wives death, who was too good for thee.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Right, for ſhe was my Maſter, a perpe ••• l
Vexation to me, while ſhe was above-ground
Your Ladiſhip could not have ſpoke more comfort to me
Then the remembrance of that ſhook-off Shackle,
Which now, in my affliction makes me ſmile,
And were I on her grave, I could cut capers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A further puniſhment, I pr •• hecie
Grows in the neck of thy leud inſolence

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I could e'ne finde in heart to marry again,
In ſpight, now, of thy witchcraft, my ſon dead!
My daughter diſobedient! and your childe
A very chilblaine. What have I to do
But marry again: all women are not devil • ,
I may yet get an heire unto my minde.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Art thou here too—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stay, you forget your brother, Mr. Matchil.
You have match'd ill once already; and take heed
You match not worſe, your children, though untoward.
And taking of the devilliſh Shrew, their mother,
Were likely of your own begetting; Yet
Your ſecond wife may bring you a ſupply
Of heires, but who muſt get them, firſt is doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thy impudence amazes me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'm ſick at ſight of the leud Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Dee caſt about for heirs; and have beſides
Your daughter here, a brother and a ſiſter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Call not thy ſelf our brother. He appears
U ••• nde to me, but thou inſufferable,
I loath to look upon thee.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He has ſpoke
sp.p: Againſt her Aunt, her Moon-calf ſonne. I'll make her love me beſt, and preſently.
sp.l: Brother, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot look upon thee.
Provoke me not to •• eech, I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Give me leave to ſpeak; Hold you your peace;
Hear but my brotherly advice; and when
Give your conſent in ſilence.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hear him not.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Nor you neither, hum—hum—hum.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am not angry with you now; and therefore
I charge you, hear him not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: My advice is thus, that for your daughters good.
For mine own good, and for your Siſters good.
And for her ſonne, your Nephew's good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How's that? ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And chiefly for your own good, and the credit
A wiſe man would deſire to hold i'th' world,
Think not of marrying, nor of buying hornes
At the whole value of your whole eſtate,
But match your daughter while you have the meanes
In your own hands; give her a good round portion,
Here are deſerving Gentlemen i'th' houſe.
Next, think of me your brother, that has ſpent
In down-right fellowſhip (heaven knows what
All fraudulent purpoſes to make any man
A miſer or a gainer by't) a faire eſtate.
And now do want a brotherly ſupply.
A hundred a year or ſo: but above all
Faſten your land unto yout Siſters ſonne.
That hopeful Gentleman, ſweet Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now brother you may hear him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: What though it ſtraggle from the name of Matchil.
Remember yet he is your mothers Grandchilde.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why dee not hear him, brother?—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As I hope
To be a landed man my ſelf,
Had I a thouſand yearly, I would leav't him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Trulie, I thank you. Now I'll call you brother.
Y'are a good natur'd Gentleman if you had it.
Come home, and ſee my ſonne.—VVill you not hear him? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I need not, nor your ſelfe. I ſee you gape
Like monſters that would ſwallow me alive.
I know your mindes; and I will do mine own.
And, thus it is. Stay, let me ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Look you how wilde he looks.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He's falling mad.
Stark ſtaring mad,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would he had a wife then,
For nothing elſe can tame him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So it ſhall be.
Firſt, I'll be Maſter of mine own eſtate.
Next—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Take a wife to maſter that, and you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Next, you Madamoiſelle, (on whom with patience
I cannot look) forſake my houſe, and ſuddenly;
Linger not for a man to wait upon you,
But let your black bag guard you, 'tis a faſhion
Begun amongſt us here by your own Nation.
And if I longer muſt call you my daughter,
Forſake you her.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: VVhat mine own heart? dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: At your own choice. I can force her departure,
Though not perſwade your ſtay, determine quickly
Either to leave her, and enjoy a father,
Or never more expect a fathers bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Dear, mine own heart, leave me, obey your father.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: It muſt be to my death then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll be ſudden.
Therefore be you as brief in your reſolve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, poor hearts. Juſt ſo loth
To part was I and my ſonne Nehemiah
Today when I came forth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Neece Joyce, let me
Adviſe you.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, none of your advices.
Let her adviſe her ſelf; whileſt I impart
To you my next intention; which is thus.
To end your ſtrife for ſhares in mine eſtate
I'll venter on a wife: indeed I'll marry

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you ſo? ha!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes indeed La,—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: If then
You'l eſtate nothing on me for my life
Give me a ſee to help you to a wife,
I can, a good one.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll none, Sir, of your good ones.
Beſides, Sir, I'm provided.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are not, are you? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let it ſuffice, I ſay't, ſo quit my houſe.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Shall I expect then nothing?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray ſir, do.
'Tis all I can afford you. You have wit,
Yes, you can daunce, tread money out of ruſhes,
Slight and activity to live upon.
A nimble braine, quick hands and airie heels
To get a living.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Hah.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray fall to practice.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I may, ſir, to your coſt, if you put off
Your daughter with her Sweet-heart, her Mon Coeur
There, as ſhe calls her. Dear, my Lady Siſter;
You ſee how churliſhly this Merchant uſes us.
He has forgot, ſure, he was borne a Gentleman.
Will you be pleaſ'd, I ſpeak to you in your eare.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Any way, brother Strigood, Hang him, Nabal,
To warn me out o's houſe; and not alone,
To turne a ſtranger from within his gates,
But offer to caſt out his childe too, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis about that I'd ſpeak, pray Madam heark you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Matchil, though we are your meat
Before we ſaw you you will give us leave
To take our leaves, and thank you ere we part.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: W'have heard your cauſe of ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I have over-paſt it. Heark ye Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Eraſ.
sp.l: You'l give us leave firſt to ſalute the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, if you love me, heare me firſt.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Your will, Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Neece, you ſhall no way diſobey your father
In being rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, ſo, it takes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You and your ſecond ſelfe ſhall home with me
Until his furious humour be blown over.
To which the firſt meanes is to 〈◊〉 his fight,
And then let me alone to make your peace.

sp.speaker: Joy. Gab.
sp.l: We thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So let us ſlip.
Home to my houſe together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hiſt brother, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As glad as ever Fox was of his prey
sp.stage: Exit. • om. Pet. Mat. Er. Vab.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis even ſo, Gentlemen, ſorrow findes no lodging.
In my light heart ſometimes ſhe knocks at door,
And takes a drink, but here ſhe muſt not ſit by't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y' are happy Sir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet I have heard you ſay
You never taſted joy for divers yeares
Till your wife died: ſince when, a King of mirth,
And now to marry agen is ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes ſir, tis ſuch a thing that I will marry
That I fore know can never diſobey me
And I'll defie the devil to diſhoneſt her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo ougly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, he means ſo vertuous.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-ſaid, ſir, you ſhall drink before me. Rachel, Mawdlin.
sp.l: 'Proteſt you ſhall though't be in my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now he reſumes his humour.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ratchel I ſay,
Bring me a kan o' ſack.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But how can you
Preſume before the dangerous marriage-trial
That ſhe whom y'have choſen will be obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: D' ye think he has not tried her? There's a queſtion

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-ſaid agen. I was about to ſay ſo.
Rachel, ſome ſack, I ſay. Yes, I have tried her, ſir,
Tri'd her, and tri'd her again; all over and over
Theſe five yeares day and night; and ſtill obedient.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Then you are ſure to her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I never uſ'd
A marriage-queſtion, not a woing word,
But do all by command, ſhe is ſo obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And yet ſhe's chaſte and vertuous withal.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-ſaid again, ſir, ſo I was a ſaying.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But we have talk't away the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No matter, let'hem go. Would they were far enough.
sp.stage: Enter Rachel, ſilver Kan and Napkin.
sp.p: Come, the ſack, the ſack.—Who taught you that courteſie maid.
sp.l: Pray try a better to the Gentleman.
Proteſt you ſhall begin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your own houſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: • 'll rather g' ye my houſe, then break my word in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Y' are Lord here, and may command me, ſir. And ſo my ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll do you reaſon, ſir.
Be ready with your Napkin, and a lower douke maid.
I'll hang dead weight at your buttocks elſe. So.
Is not this obedience, Gentlemen, Mr. Eraſmus?
Mus, I will call thee Mus, I love to be
Familiar, where I love; and Godamercy
For your friend here; you both ſhall ſee my daughter.
But my French Damoſel and I are parted
I hope by this time. So here's to you Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: To me, to me, to me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha boy, art there? diſpatch
Your court'ſie quickly, and go cal my daughter.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: She is gone forth, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Forth, ha? when? whither?
La ye, ſhe thinks I'm angry, and the finger
Is in the eye already. Is not this
Feare and obedience, Gentlemen? who went with her.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: She went with my Lady Neſtlecock, to bring Gabriella on her way they ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would
They were all in France together.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She comes again, I doubt not. Dry your eyes.
And drink that ſack, without a court'ſie, drink it.
You do not know my meaning, Gentlemen.
Stay: now gi' me't agen.—Now go and dry
Your face within—without a court'ſie? ha!
Now is not this obedience, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But this is not the rare obedient peece
That you will marry?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You do not hear me ſay ſo.
But I preſume, as much obedience
In her I have made choice of.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Marrie a maid.
And we will be her Hench-boyes, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I'll have no ſuch blades 'bout my wives hanches.
But come, to end this tedious Scene, in which
I ha' paſt the Purgatorie of my Paſſions
Of ſorrow, anger, feare, and hope at laſt.
I am refin'd, ſublim'd, exalted, fixt
In my true Sphere of mirth; where love's my object.
And bloodie thought of black revenge caſt by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could your faire breaſt harbour a bloody thought?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: For ſome few minutes, in which extaſie
I meant t' ha' gone, as other Gallants do.
To fight in France, forſooth, and charg'd my man
To draw up his Accompts, call in my moneys,
Thought to have made my Will—.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I ſaw your Caſhier
Go forth e'ne now with a ſttong luſty Porter
Loaden with money: I will not ſay my teeth
Water'd at it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But 'twas enough to make
A very true mans fingers itch.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot
Think he is run away; but yet I like not
His carrying forth, when I ſay, fetch in money.
But this is from my purpoſe. Love ye mirth?
Let's in, and drink, and talk. That gives it birth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I prithee now, I prithee, prithie now
Urge me no more in this caſe; for I cannot,
Nor I wo' not ſo I wo' not, I be jealous
Oſ mine own wife, mine own deat fleſh and blood?
That's ſuch a thing! I pidee ſpeak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You ſhew you love Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So I hope I do Nan.
My cock, my pity nittle nanſie cockſie,
Do I not ſhew my love when I deny thee
Vnreaſonable requeſts? I never heard
Of woman that deſir'd a loving husband
To be a jealous Maſter over her.
Eſpecially a City-Shopkeeper.
The beſt part of whoſe trade runs through the hands
Of his faire wife too! 'Tis unreaſonable.
And thou the ſirſt that e're take up the humour.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you the ſirſt that e're I knew beſotted
Into a wilful confidence, which renders
Me to a vile conſtruction; and your ſelfe
By leaving me to all aſſaults and hazards
Have got the reputation of a Wittal.
Or one that ſeems contented to become ſo.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Cock, my Nanſie Cock, my Cockſie Nanſie,
Kiſſe me, and uſe thine own conſcience: I ſcorn
The yellow ſickneſſe, I, let 'hem all ſay what they will.
D'einty, come thou to me. I will not loſe
An haires bredth o' my humour, nor retain
An ill thought o' my Cocks honeſtie
For all the wealth i' the Exchange, not I

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I not deſire you ſhould, but only that
You will not ſeem ſo careleſſe of my credit,
Expoſing me to all temptations
Of the wilde Gallantry of the wanton time.
By whom (although my chaſtity remaines
Untouch't) my name and your diſcretion ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh, Honi ſoit again: Cock, I defie
Calumniation and detraction I.
When I am jealous, let the horne-curſe take me;
And let me be with hornets ſtung to death.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Still you flie from the point, I would not have
You vex your ſelf with cauſeleſſe jealouſie
