Over my conſtant love; but only ſeem
A little watchful o're my reputation.
Whereby you may decline mens leud attempts.
And not to throw me upon opportunities
To draw them on; as if I were a thing
S •• out, as in your ſhop, for common ſale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, Thou ſhalt never tie me to't: not I.
I muſt not loſe my harmleſſe recreations
Abroad to ſnook over my wife at home.
Thought'ſt ha' me like the hair-brain'd Point-tagger,
That uſ'd to hammer his fingers at one end
O'th' ſhop, while's wife was bargaining at the other?
Not I; ſweet Cock, pidee lets heare no more on't.
Now friend! Is your buſineſſe to me or my wife?

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: This Superſcription will inform you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To my deare daughter Mrs. Hannah Camelion, at her ſhop or houſe in or near the New Exchange.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Take it quickly, what a Knave art thou to put a letter in my hands, that is directed to my wife. Sbobs I would not ha' open'd it for fonrty pound.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: If all husbands in the City were of his minde, it were a Forreſt of fooles indeed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I muſt leave thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Pray ſtay a little. This letter's from my father.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I hope the good Captaine's well.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, very well, pray read his Letter here.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, you ſhall pardon me. Not I.
I have a match to play at the ducking-pond.
Prithee fore-ſlow not my occaſions, Cock,
As I forbear to pry into thy ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Here's nothing but what I would have you ſee.
There's for your poſtage, friend. It needs no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: I thank you, Myſtris.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But if you will not ſtay to reade this Letter.
You ſhall not deny me one thing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What is it, quickly? my ſweet Nanny Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here, take this pen: write here a word or ſentence.
What you pleaſe. But keep it well in minde,
And look that you be ſure to know't agen
When I ſhall ſhew't you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis done, there: I defie, and dare the devil and all his Clerks to counterfeit my hand. So, my ſweet Cock, a kiſſe and adieu.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well Rafe, remember that you won't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, Sbobs yonder comes one of the Blades,
That thou would'ſt have me have an eye to; He
That lives by his wits, and yet is ſeldom ſober:
That goes ſo gallantly, and has no credit,
Nor ever buyes with ready money; But
Barters commodity for commodity.
(Such as it is) with Tradeſmens wives, they ſay.
What call you him, oh Askal; there's another
Comes with him too. Into thy ſhop, good Cock.
I wo' not ſtay, not I. So, farewel Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And farewel Coxſcombe, ſome wife would ſay now.
I am much troubled at his ſillineſſe.
And would to right me, ſtraine a womans wit,
Knew I with modeſty how to anſwer it.
Something I'le do.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch a humour in a man, as this mad
Merchant Matchil is poſſeſt with.
To marry ſo, to ſpight his childe and kindred.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has made his daughter by't a match worth nothing.
And there your hope is gone.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And yours in me.
For as I ſaid before, good Valentine.
I muſt returne you to your City wives.
By the old trade to pick your maintenance
Out of em, as you boaſt you can.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well, ſir.
And now to let you know that I can live
Without the helps of ſuch cool friends as you.
I'le ſhew you a preſent probability.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doeſt ſee yond pretty mumping peece i'th' ſhop there?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, is that one—?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: One o'th' fourty, boy,
That renders tribute in to my Exchecquer.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Didſt ever lie with her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How plain you are. Not I, not I.
That▪s her fool-husbands word.
Let it ſuſſice that I have ſeen her thrice.
And that I lay with, drink, and weare her money.
O 'tis the ſweeteſt Rogue.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: How got you acquainted.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le tell you that, walking by chance as now,
Before her ſhop, where a young Gentleman
Was bargaining, he call'd me by my name,

sp.speaker: Val Askall.
sp.l: Inſtantly her eye was fixt,
And ſtreight ran over my delineaments,
Which I ſet to her view; and took occaſion
To ask her how the object pleaſ'd her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Bold-face.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I never loſt by that.
She then demands, Is your name Askall, ſir?
I anſwer, Yes. Pray of what countrey, ſir?
I told her; when a ſudden flaming bluſh
Did in her face betray the fire of love,
That was at th' inſtant raging in her breaſt,
She look't me through and through. Sigh'd, turn'd away.
Then look't again under her hat-brims thus.
And thus I nimbly catch't her with mine eye.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I, thou haſt a devilliſh catch i'that ſame eye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, what I have, I have. I gave a leere
With that ſame eye that made her turne her whitesup.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But to the point.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why do you think a woman's ſo quickly brought to th' point?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: VVhat follow'd then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſaw ſhe was ſtruck, and thus I gave her line
To play withal. I whiſper'd in her eare,
The way to finde my lodging and my ſervice.
Next morning early comes a meſſage to me,
Inviting me to dinner: Chear and welcome
Plenteouſly flowed; and ſir, before we parted
Upon ſome private conference, twenty pieces
Were clutch't into this hand, but with a caution
To be diſcreet and thrifty of her purſe,
And keep a friend in ſtore. I have been modeſt,
And have not ſtruck her ſince, but for ten more.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And that's your laſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I le hold you ten o that
See ſhe has ſpied me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: VVhat lack ye, Gentlemen; faire cut-work bands, boot-hooſe, or boot-hooſe tops, ſhirts, waſt-coats, night-caps, what will you buy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I come not now to buy.
But in plain termes to borrow. Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not on theſe termes.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sure thou miſtak'ſt the woman.
This is not ſhe, thou talk'ſt fo freely on Bounce.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She's cautious before thee. Walk off a little.
Now you may hear me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Give me leave
A little, firſt to wonder at your raſhneſſe,
To talk ſo openly before a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My intimate friend: I'le truſt him with my life.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What's that to my unblemiſh't reputation?
'Tis not your life can ſalve that, being wounded.
But thus it is, when women out of goodneſſe
Hazard their fortunes to relieve the wants
Of ſuch as you, that carry no reſpect,
But to your own licentious Appetites.
And think no favour's ſweet, unleſſe you may
Have priviledge to boaſt 'hem to our ſhame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do not boaſt of yours.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Pray, boaſt no more
Then you have found, and much good may they do you.
'Tis not poor thirty pieces can undo me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, nor ten more I hope; and that's the ſumme
I would entreat: all makes but fourty pound.
I'll pay thee like a Gentleman, as I am one,
Either in money; or doeſt hear me, Rogue,
In what ſhall pleaſe thee better. Come, be wiſe,
Thy husband's a dull ducking Gameſter. And
Kennels his water-dog in Turnbull-ſtreet.
We'll anſwer his delights with better ſport.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: There's your preſumption.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, 'tis my ambition.
When ſhall we walk to Totnam? or croſſe o're
The water, or take Coach to Kengington
Or Padington; or to ſome one or other
O'th' City out-leaps for an afternoon,
And hear the Cuckow ſing to th' purpoſe? when?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.l: A woman were a wiſe one that would truſt
Her ſelfe in ſuch wilde hands as yours; to have
Her name made Tavern-talk among your blade,
And thruſt i'th 'liſt of your looſe-hilted Myſtreſſes:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no; fie no: you cannot think how cloſe
And careful I will be. Heark in thine eare.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cannot blame this fellow now ſo much
For uſing of his wits to get his living,
Though in an idle way; as for traducing
People of worth and vertue, as this woman
Who I am credibly inform'd is vertuous
And too diſcreet for him to ſhark upon.
Therefore to grace himſelf, he ſlanders her.
I have alwayes lik't his company till now,
And ſhall hereafter be more wary of him.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well ſir, upon pour faithful proteſtation,
And vow of ſecreſie, liere's ten pieces more.
You have found a tender-hearted woman of me
Over your wants; and all the ſatisfaction
That I deſire, is, that I may not ſuffer
Under a laviſh tongue; 'tis eaſie payment.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, but I'le pay thee better. Therefore tell me, when we ſhall meet and have a ſpirtabroad.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Your friend ſtayes for you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, let him ſtay.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: You ſlight him now, but he knows all your Councels.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By this good tongue, no more then the unbegotten Hans that I mean to clap into thy Kelder.
sp.l: Nor ever ſhall: doeſt think I am ſo fooliſh
To talk away my hopes? No, thou art my Faery,
Pinch me to death when I diſcover thee.

sp.speaker: Han,
sp.l: Go to, avoid ſuſpition then, beſides
I have occaſions that do call me hence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Your ſtay was ſomewhat long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet 'twas to purpoſe.
As here you may behold, but I muſt make no words on't.
She has enjoyn'd me that. O'tis a cunning Gypſie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So't ſeems, by truſting thee that haſt no power to keep a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, to tell you true.
My conſcience will not beare't, I cannot be
So ungrateful to receive a courteſie,
But to acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet thou haſt the conſcience
To work a mans eſtate out of his hands
By his wives frailty, even to break his back.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis rather to be fear'd ſhe may break mine.
She's a tight ſtrong dock't Tit.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O Tradeſmen, why do you marry?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why? to make Tradeſwomen.
For Gentlemen that want money and commodity.
You know the thing that I call father in 〈◊〉 ,
That had my mothers whole eſtate, and butied her,
Allowes me nothing.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thank your own ſweet courſes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My courſes are ſweet courſes, they ſerve me to live upon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But I ſhall put you off
O'one of your ſweet courſes, or at leaſt
I'le ſtrain a point of friendſhip to be ſatisfied
Touching this woman, 'twill be worth diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But why theſe cloudy looks? do not you like my courſes? ha▪

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy, Val.
I was upon our former ſubject Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I there's a haſty match clap't up. You ask't
Why Tradeſmen marry, there's a marriage now!
A humorous Coxſcombe that could never laugh
In all his laſt wives dayes; and ſince her death
Could ne're be ſad. For him to marry his Malkin
For poor and courſe obedience. Well. I hope
To take my courſe in his houſe yet for all.
Her boaſted chaſtity and obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wouldeſt thou touch ſuch a thing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, not for money?
She can pay well and her uglineſſe cannot fright me
I can do that work winking.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She can be no ſuch woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tell not me
What any woman can or cannot be,
You'll give me leave to try my fortune with her,

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, and walk with you towards it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No newes, no tidings of 'em, Ephraim, ha!
Was even ſucg a ſcape?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Not ſince the Rape
Of H • llon • I'm perſwaded. I have ſearch't
With narrow eyes (as I may ſay) with care,
And diligence in moſt ſecret places.
And can no way inform my ſelf, what is
Betide of the young Damoſels, or old Squire.
Your Neece, and the French Virgin, and the man
Unworthy to be call'd your brother Strigood.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O hang him Villain.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Doubtleſſe 'twas his plot
To work upon your Ladiſhips good nature
To harbour them, that he might take th' advantage
Of ſtealing them away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What to do, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: To do? much may be done by his ſeducements,
On two ſuch tender Virgins, though he ſhould
But plant them in our ſuburbs: but my feare
Is that he has tranſported them beyond ſeas
Into ſome Nunnery. Your Ladiſhip
Knows he is adverſe in Religion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know he is of none.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Satan will work.
The ſtronger in him, then to their ſubverſion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How ſhall I anſwer now my brother Matchil?
But he is juſtly ſerv'd to marry ſo.
The thought of it torments me. Where's my comfort?
Where's Nehemiah, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: He's buſie, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What, at his book? or at his muſick, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: That is, his Ballet, or his Jewes Trump. No,
Madam. He is buſie at his exerciſe of Armes
With a new Caſting top, a Cat and Catſtick,
I bought and brought him home.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you for 'hem,
My careful diſcreet Ephraim. I like
His harmleſſe exerciſes well.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I hope,
Your Ladiſhip can ſay ſince I have had
The Government of him under your Ladiſhip,
I have been careful of the Gentleman,
And have his love withal ſo much, that I
Dare ſay (I hope you'll pardon the compariſon)
That had you married me (which was as likely
As that your brother would have ta'ne his Maid.
I think that Mr. Nehemiah would not
Have run away in hatred of our Match,
As Mrs. Joyce. it ſeems, hath done of theirs.
I hope your Ladiſhips pardon, I underſtand
My duty.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And you ſpeak but reaſon Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I have given her there a touch of my affection.
Who knowes how it may work?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go call him in.
I would not have him over heat himſelf.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: 'Tis a good care. And Madam, by the way,
Let me adviſe, that ſince his riper yeares
Require, and that faire Propoſitions
Of marriage are tender'd for him, that
We gently by degrees, do take him off
From childiſh exerciſe, indeed plaine boyes play.
More manly would become him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You would have him
Do worſe then, would you? and be nought, you varlet?
What! would you have him play at Mans-game, ha?
Fore he be married, ha! what, what! how now!
Is it but up and ride w'ye, ha!

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I humbly
Beſeech your Ladiſhips pardon, I will call
Sweet Mr. Nehemiah to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go, th'art an honeſt man. I know thou lov'ſt him.
Indeed he's all my comfort and my care
And I muſt naturally reſpect all thoſe
That do partake with me my care of him.
sp.stage: Enter Nehemiah, looking down and eating.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: my boy Negh, Sonne Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: F'ſooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That's my good Lamb. Hold up thy head; and thou.
Shalt have a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But mother f ſooth, when I have her,
Will ſhe play with me at peg-top?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: At any thing, my boy.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And ſhe ha' not good box and ſteel, I ſhall ſo grull her.
And then at Mumbledepeg I will ſo firk her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But when y'are married, you • ll finde other paſtime.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Whate're I ſay, I have a meaning though.
But yet, I doubt, I ſhall not forſake all
My old fagaries in a yeare or two.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know thy will is good to leave thy wag-tricks.
And I commend your underſtanding in it.
It ſhewes you man, and ready for a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, f'ſooth, I think ſo; I Amardla.
For I did beat a boy as high as my ſelfe
Yeſterday, with one hand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where was thy tother.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: The boy had but one hand f'ſooth. I uſ'd both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well th'art too witty to live long, I feare.
But as I was ſaying, ſonne, I do expect
Sir Swithen Whimtby to bring his Neece.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Who f • ſooth, the crying Knight, he that has wept
E're ſince his Lady di'd; and mournes in colours;
Speaks nothing but in verſe, and gives me Ballats;
The old Knight Powel, that pronounces what dee call 'hem?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Odes childe and Elegies. He has been inſpir'd.
With the infection of Poetry,
E're ſince his wives departure: and 'tis thought
Nothing can put him out, or cure him of it
But a new wife to kill the furious itch of't,

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But is not his Neece too big for me? I would be loth
To be over-match'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O witty, witry, ſtill.
But when ſhe comes Nehemiah, What'll you ſay to her?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: I'll give her the time of the day or the night
I warrant her, come at what houre ſhe will.
Why if I eat not all before ſhe come.
(And ſhe muſt try her, if I do'nt) I'll ask her
If ſhe can ſpeak with plums in her mouth; and then
I'll offer her a long one and two round ones,
And nod at her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You will not, will you, ha?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, I know both what to ſay and do
I truſt I am not to be taught to wooe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Too witty ſtill, I ſay, to be long-liv'd.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But heark you mother f'ſooth; I am told that you
Beare a moneths minde to that Sir Whimlby,
And a croſſe match is talk't on betwixt you
And the old Knight, and me and his young Neece.
O ho—is't ſo?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is no crafty childe.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Let me but ſee how you will handle him now
And mark how I'le come over her with ſmall Jerks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O th'art a witty wag. A bleſſing on it.
sp.stage: Enter Ephraim, uſhering Whimlby and Blith.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, Sir Swithen Whimlby and his Neece,
Mrs. Blith Tripſhort.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They are very welcome,
Noble Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Noble Mrs. Blith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sweet Knight, y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Welcome, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Still weeping.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: O good Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Still weeping for a husband.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, ſhe puts me on't,
She laughes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Laugh with her then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, ſo I will, and if you laugh
At me, I'll laugh at you again, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Are you there with me? I'le be here with you then.
Will you eat any Sugar-plums? no, I'le eat 'em for you.
There's ha, ha, ha, ha, for you now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do you note, Sir Swithin, what a wag it is.
Walk into the next room Nehemiah. Did you note him?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Madam, to tell you true.
My love to you
Springs from the joy,
I take in your ſweet boy
sp.stage: —Eph. And that's the way to win her.
sp.l: I can take no delight
But in his ſight,
Nor any pride
Since my dear Griſſel di'd,
In all, I ſee on earth or finde in books,
But that which overcomes me in his lookes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O ſweet Sir Swithen, you have all woo'd and won me.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Then all my hopes are fruſtrate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My ſonne ſhall have your Neece, and for mine own part.
You loving him ſo well, of what's in me.
I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Gentle Madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: She offers up her ſelfe; now may the proverb
Of proffer'd ſervice light upon her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay, Sir Swithen.
Let me entreat you to leave weeping now.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: When my dear Griſſel did.

l.hi: And when your Ladiſhip appears in ſight.
(Pardon) I cannot chuſe but cry out-right.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, good Knight. He weeps pure Helicon.
He has not wherewithal to quench his love,
But his own teares. A wife would cool him better.
Why ſir, does ſight of me renew your grief?

sp.speaker: Whi.

l.hi: And till, to eaſe my paine,

sp.l: That in my Griſſel di'd.

l.hi: So oft as ſhe in you to me appears
My numbers cannot ceaſe to flow in tears.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good ſir, collect your ſelf, and be aſſur'd
I am your own, ſo Neh. may have your Neece,
With her full Dowry of foure thouſand pounds.
My perſonal eſtate is full as much.
That and my ſelf are yours on the croſſe marriage,
You making me an anſwerable Joincture.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Is't come ſo near; I'le croſſe it, or my ſtar▪
Drop croſſes on my head. O vain, vain woman,
To doat on Poetry in an old man.
Ladies may love it in the young and bold,
And when they are ſick give gally-pots of gold,
For cordial Electuaries to chear
Their crop-ſick Muſes; but to an old and ſere
Man that out-lives his labours, who can be
So vain to give her ſelf away but ſhe.
I had been ſitter for her, and I'le watch
Occaſion yet, perhaps, to croſſe the match,
I can tu • n Poet too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dry now your eyes, and anſwer me in proſe,
Are you content to yield to thoſe conditions
I have propounded, ha!

sp.speaker: VVhim.
sp.l: I am content.
And now for joy could weep,
Finding my Griſſel in your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I hope the young ones do accord as well.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Proteſt, I cannot abide you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Nor I you.
Amardla, that I cannot.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: They'r agreed.
Madam, it ſeems they both are of one minde.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: I do not like it. What's the matter Nehemiah?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: She is no wife for me, ſhe has broke my Jewes-trump; look you here elſe. And almoſt broke my head with one of my bounding ſtones.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bleſſe my boy; ſhe has not, has ſhe, ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And yet after all that, and for all I offered to teach her to ſhoot in my Trunk and my Stone-bowe, do you think ſhe would play with me at Trou, Madam? no, nor at any thing elſe. I'll none of her.
And yet I'le have her too. If ſhe will promiſe to do as I would have her hereafter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There, do you note him there, Sir Swithen?
This childe has no childiſh meaning in't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: No Madam, no, I know him inwardly
He is my joy, and ſhe ſhall be conformable,
Or fare the worſe.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: She will, I know ſhe will.
Will you not have my ſon, ſweet Mrs. Blith?

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Sweet Madam, what to do? ha, ha, I ſhall be quickly weary with laughing at him. His fooling will ſoon be ſtale and • edious; and then to beat him would be as toilſome to me; and laſtly, to be tied to nothing but to cuckold him, is ſuch a common Town-trick, that I ſcorne to follow the faſhion.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: Can ſhe talk thus? ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A merry harmleſſe Girle.
Fear not, good Madam, ſhe will come about.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: A thouſand mile about rather then meet him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I much deſire ſhe would; for now my ſonne
Is ſet a marrying, I warrant it pure thing
It is in paine, till it be at it: ha!
Pray bring her on, Sir Swithen, let him kiſſe her.
Poor heart, he licks his lips; and look how arſeward ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Fie Blith, be courteous, Blith.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother,—ſhe has ſpit Amard juſt in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Amard, what's that? if you ſpeak French you wrong me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Gip, Mrs. Tripſhort. Is this the manners your Mother left you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Speak not you of Mothers, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l:
Sir
• w • then, will you ſ • e my childe abuſ'd ſo, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I can but grieve for't, Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: My mother is as good as your mother, ſo ſhe is, for all ſhe's dead.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I, well-ſaid Neh.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Yes, it appears in your good breeding
Your fine qualities expreſſe her vertues ſuſſiciently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How dare you Huſwife talk thus to my ſon, of me, and before my face too? ha! Sir Swithen, can you think well of me, and ſuffer this, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Alas, good Madam, I am down again I know not what to think of living woman now.

sp.speaker: La▪
sp.p: Do you bring your Neece to abuſe me?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I am ſo drown'd in teares, that I cannot • ee what to ſay to't.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, Amardla, the more I look on her, the better I like her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sayeſt ſo, my boy. Beſides, I have a conceit ſhe can out-ſcold you▪ and that's more then ever woman did, I think f'ſooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For thee, I do forbear her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: By your leave, my Lady Neſtlecock, I have brought a ſiſter of yours here to ſalute you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Though unworthy to be of your Counſel, or at the Ceremony, I heard you were married brother. And by a Siſters name you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Swithen Whimlby! and your pretty Neece! well met, what affairs have you in hand here? what do you cry for your old wife ſtill or for a new one? But heark, you Lady Siſter, where's my daughter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now for a tempeſt. Truly ſir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is ſhenot with you, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No truly, ſir.
She's ſlipt from me with her good Uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That Thief has ſold her then into ſome Bawdihouſe
Was this your project for her education,
To ſteal my childe to make a whore of her?
Are you turn'd Lady b • ud now for your Neece
Becauſe you have no daughter? O the devil!
If there be Law, I'll trounce your Lady Hagſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: VVhat, what? how now? do you taunt me, ſirrah, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou haſt made thy ſelf an example, and the ſcorne of thine own childe in marrying of thy drudge there; and thats the cauſe of her running away thou mayeſt think, becauſe ſhe hates to live where ſhe muſt call her mother that was thy droile.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Droile, I think, ſhe ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Speak to her, I charge thee, on thy obedience to ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The droile is now your brothers wife, Madam, and in that ſetting your Ladiſhips laviſh tongue aſide, as good a woman as your ſelfe, none diſpraiſ'd, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-ſaid Rachel, hold thine own Rachel. And ſo to you, ſir Sw then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, come away, mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By and by, my boy.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Do you preſume to call me drudge and droile, that am a Ladies Siſter every day in the week; and have been any time theſe three dayes, ha.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: That's not every day in a whole week yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not dare to call me ſiſter Huſwife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Cods ſo, and why troe? becauſe a Lady ſcornes to be a huſwife, ha. If you be no huswife, I ſc • rn to call
you Siſter, I; though my husband be your brother. From whence came you troe, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to the bold-face.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'ſooth come away, I am afear'd ſhe'l beat you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thanks, my good childe, but do not be afraid my Lamb.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Boldface, ha! Her brothers wife▪s a bold-face, but her face is not varniſh't over, yet like his Ladyſiſters face, but it may be in time when ſhe learnes the trick on't, and have as many flies upon't, though not ſo troubled with 'hem, as a bald mare at Midſummer, hah.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to her, ſhe has charm'd the vertue of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I never heard her ſpeak ſo much in all her life, Sir Swithin, nor half ſo loud. hank heaven, ſhe has a voice yet on a good occaſion. And ſo farre I'll maintain her in it. Nephew Nehemiah, when ſaw you your Couſin Joyce.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O Lud, O mother f'ſooth, look you, mine Uncle holds me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ah, naughty man, did a ſo gi▪me a ſtroke, and I'll beat it, • h—.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your wife has taught you to play the rude companion, has ſhe? Pray take her home ſir, and let her diſcipline your owne childe if you have one, and let mine alone. You know the way you came, ſir; or if you have a minde to ſtay here, Come Sir Swithen, come away children; I hope I ſhall finde ſome other room in mine own houſe, free from your aſſaults, if not, I'm ſure there's Law againſt Riots. Come Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Not yet good Madam Neſtlecock, you ſhall hear me.
You have entic'd away, then loſt my daughter.
And now y'are a jugling with your widow wit,
And your ſmall worme here, to catch up for Gudgeons.
Sir Swithen and his Neece, I know your plot..
She's not fit match for you Sir Swithen; and her ſon
Much leſſe for your faire Neece. Come dry your eyes,
And look upon him, and not only look,
But laugh at him, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: I could now for him heartily.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Mark how his mothers milk drops at his noſe, while I ſhew you the mother and the childe.
He was her youngeſt ſonne, and all that's left of ſeven, and dreaming that he needs muſt prove a Prophet, ſhe has bred him up a fool.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: F'ſooth mother he mocks me, oh.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O prophane wretch, worſe then thy brother Strigood.
sp.l: Do not cry, Nehemiah, peace, good boy, peace. So ſo.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A tender mother I muſt ſay ſhe has been.
For till he was fifteen, none but her ſelfe
Muſt look his head, or waſh his pretty face
For making of it cry. Laugh at her good Sir Swithen.
And before that, till he was twelve yeares old
She would dance him on her knee, and play with's Cock.

sp.speaker: Wh • m.
sp.l: Ah ah ah ah.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So well-ſaid, Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Juſt ſo efac my mother would ſerve me, ha, ha.
Is not this better then whining.
Yes, or perhaps then wiving either.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.l: Do you ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Well ſaid, Sir Swithen, laugh on. I hope I ha' done a cure on him, by ſhewing him a
more ridiculous object then himſelfe, to turne the tide of's tears.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Laugh ſtill, defie the fiends, women, and all their works.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, let the dead go, and the quick care for themſelves. You buri'd your wife, and cri'd, and I buried mine.
sp.l: And laugh; which is the manlier Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He knows not that he is married agen.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: You are the merrieſt Merchant, ha, ha, ha.
I think I ſhall not marry again in haſte, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-ſaid, hold there. And for your Neece
Let me alone. I'le fit her with a match.
I know a Lad that's worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He • ll laugh too much, I feare.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He may at you,
For your officiouſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: To thruſt your ſelf into unthankful offices.
In things concerne you not. Will you turne Matchmaker
For others un-intreated, 'tis enough.
For you, I hope, that you have match't your ſelfe, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hah! Do you hab, or talk to me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Who elſe
Should talk or give you counſel but your wife?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: VVell-ſaid Rachel, hold thine own Rachel.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am match't again.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pax, cry again, or burſt thy ſelf with laughing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: La. Ha, ha, ha. Laugh ſon Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What am I? what do you make of me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, what ha' you made your ſelf? beſt ask the Chimney piece that you have married there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Durſt thou advance a voice againſt me, ha?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You did commend it in me againſt your Siſter.
And I may better be familiar with you;
Hah, are you not my husband? I am ſure
'Tis not ſo long ſince we were married, that
You can forget it, or • epent ſo ſoon.
I am not now your ſlave, to have my face
Waſh't with your ſnuffes, nor to be kick't and trod on
VVithout reſiſtance, nor to make you anſwers
Meerly with ſilent court'ſies, run when you bid go
To fetch and carry like your Spaniel,
In which condition I liv • d long enough,
And was content until • ou freed me out on't.
Now free I am, and will be a free woman,
As you are a free-man, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O baſe-borne begger.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You wrong your wife in that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How ſhe holds up the wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I never beg'd
Nor mov'd a lip to be your wife, not I,
You held my ſervice portion good enough,
And for my blood 'tis no more baſe then yours,
Since both are mixt in marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come your way.
And let me hear you ſpeak ſo much at home.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I hope I may be bolder in mine own houſe.
So Madam, for the love I have found in yours,
You ſhall be welcome thither, when y' are ſent for.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What a bold piece of Kitchin-ſtuffe is this?
Brothery' are match't.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: And catch't ifacla, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He has not a word to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Follow me home and durſt.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I dare without more leave taking, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Was ever combe ſo cut.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: There's a new Aunt indeed! ſhe brought me nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: I have not laught ſo much I know not when,
H'has made me laugh until I cry agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Again, you are welcom, Sir, Mrs. Blith
Now the unwelcome gueſts are gone, lets in
And dine, then will we after meat

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Of Joinctures, Madam, and of Nuptials treat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Right ſir.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Love, as I ſhall adore thee for a deity.
Rid me of this ridiculous ſociety.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Matchil, Rachel, between Eraſmus and Valentine.

sp.speaker: Eraſ.
sp.p: GOod Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Myſtris, be not ſo violent.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll rather run my Countrey, Gentlemen, then endure her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You were beſt to kill her then, and then you'll have no other courſe to take, unleſſe you ſtay and behang'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'le make thee glad to flie firſt.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: From my houſe and husband ſhall I? from my poſſeſſions ſhall I? And leave you all to ſpend in riot ſhall I? No ſir, I'le ſtay and ſpend my ſhare if you go to that, that will I. And make all flie as well as you, and you go to that, that will I, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Whoop, whow.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Nay, fle be not ſo loud.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What didſt thou bring thou drudge thou.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That which you were content to drudge withal, I am too ſure o' that. The drudge you ſpeak of is no worſe then your own wife, I am too ſure o'that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Did you not fay for better, for worſe? And if 'twere worſe then 'tis, 'twere all too good for you. And that I hope I ſhall finde ſome good Friend to know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I like well, I'le be her firſt man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I truſt you have found the drudge to be a woman fit to content a man, and if you grant not that, ſome better man perhaps ſhall be a Judge, betwixt you and the drudge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She threatens hornes. I think.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hornes. I think, you ſaid. If 'twere ſo 'twere too good for you. Cannot your own wife content you, ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She holds up that point ſtoutly.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That ſhall be tri'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O for an expert Chyrurgion now to caſt her in a dead ſleep, and geld her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Introth you will be both ſorry, when your paſſion gives but leaſt way to your underſtandings. Mr. Matchil, let me perſwade with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Never unieſſe you bring her on her knees, to crave forgiveneſſe at my foot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you but yield an inch he treads upon your neck, I will not give an under ſpur-leather for you. But bear it out bravely, and I'll be your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mrs. Match-ill indeed, to be ſo match't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So match't▪ how match't? what from the hurden ſinock with lockram upper-bodies, and hempen ſheets, to weare and ſleep in Holland, and from the dripping-pan to eat in ſilver, • ha. Do you repine at your Match, ha. Is wealth contemptible to you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I was better content in my povertie. I have not been my ſelfe, Gentlemen, ſince he married me.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: You may be poor again as ſoon as you pleaſe, the door is open, depart at your pleaſure; you know the way to your old Aunt the Apple-woman, at Hockly-hole. Take your knitting Needles again, and live with her, go.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No ſir, I'll ſtay with you, and make you as poor before I have done wi' ye, as I was before you had me Gent. I ſhall not be my ſelf till then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The devil you ſhall. Was ever ſuch a crooked condition crept into a thing like woman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet this ſir, is the rare piece of obedience
You boaſted of, and ſaid you would defie
The devil to diſhoneſt her, I am ſorry
Your judgement led you into ſuch an errour,
Already ſhe's my Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l:
Yes, and I
• le call him ſervant, Gentlewomen uſe it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do ſo, Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If ſhe, ſir, be your Myſtreſſe, Then am I
Your Maſter-in-law, out of my houſe I charge you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Doeſt thou conſpire to grieve him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, ſir, I did but jeſt. You have my pity.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: All are not times for Jeſt, friend Valentine.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: O my affliction!

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Have a little patience, ſir.
sp.l: While I talk calmly with her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Leave me then
A while unto my thoughts. Go into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray ſervant help me here a little. Do ſo much
As winde up my Jack for me, my Watch I would ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her Jack▪ ſhe's in the Kitchin ſtill.
A pretty Watch this, Myſtreſſe, what did you pay for't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nothing, my husband ga't me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pity the Spring is broke, but I can get it mended.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good ſervant take it with you then to the Jack-makers, I would ſay, the Watch-makers. Come Gentlemen, ſhall we have a craſh at cards?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: With all my heart. What is your game?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can play a many old games. One and thirty bone-ace, Tickle me quicklie, and my Ladies hole, and ſichie. But you ſhall teach me new ones, though I loſe money for my learning, Gleek and Primero, Greſco ſaut, primofiſtula, I know all by hear-ſay. Come let us have a bout at ſomewhat. I have money enough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I'le make ſhift to eaſe you of ſome on't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Affliction on affliction hourely findes me,
And layes me on the Rack, tearing my heart
Like greedie vultures, O my heart, this heart
That I ſo long ſuppoſ'd impenetrable
By all the darts of ſorrow, is now transfixt,
Shot through and through with torments, and by this.
This laſt made ſenſible of all the reſt.
My ſons untimely death, my daughters loſſe.
My Siſters follies, and my Brothers vices.
My ſervants falſhood, and the jeers of ſtrangers
Now wound me all at once; and all through this
Predominant blow, pull'd on me by mine own
Impetuous raſhneſſe. Let me here conſider,
While my hearts torture keeps my ſoule awake,
The moving cauſe of all theſe ill effects.
Mine own unbridled wilde affections.
Scorne of example, and contempt of counſel.
I cannot but obſerve withal, how juſt,
A judgement follows mine own wilful acts,
In the ſame kinde of doing ills for ills.
For my loſt ſonne, I raſhly wrought revenge
Upon an innocent Girle; and with her
Have loſt mine own; and for th'unmanly joy
I took in one wives death, becauſe a Shrew.
(Though otherwiſe vertuous) I am in another
Trebly tormented; not alone with noiſe,
But with a feare of unchaſte purpoſes,
Which if they come to act, my purſe muſt pay for.
I ſee my faults, and feel the puniſhments.
And rather then ſtand out in my defence
T'enjoy ſome peace, I will endure ſome ſorrow
And beare it civilly. Within there.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Go call your Myſtreſſe, pray her to come alone.
My reſolution brings me yet ſome eaſe:
Men that are borne to ſerve, muſt ſeek to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.l: Your pleaſure quickly, I have left
My company, my ſervant, and my friend yond,
Sawing againſt one another at Corne the Caſter; till I come to 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And then all three to In and In, is't ſo?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My ſervant, and my friend and I are e'ne all one.
They are the goodeſt Gentlemen, the beſt company.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your ſervant and your friend.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, and my ſervant playes for me now in my abſence, as farre as ten pieces go that I left him. My plow goes there, though I am here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your plow makes vile baulkes of my money the while.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am not ſo ill a huswife as you imagine. And my friend, and my ſervant have promiſ'd to carry me abroad, to this town, and to that town, and tother town, and whow, I know not whither. And my ſervant will have me to Hide-Park he ſayes, to ſee and to ſhew all, as well as the brave Gallants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is gallant indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And my friend will carry me to a whatdeecall, a new Academy, where I ſhall ſee the rareſt muſick and dancing, he ſayes, and learn the fineſt Complements. and other courtly qualities that are to be had for money, and ſuch inſtructions for the neweſt faſhions

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She will flie to the devil for faſhions ſake. Pray ſtay a little, and let me talk calmely with you. You have almoſt broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But not altogether, I hope. I would not win ſo great a game, without ſome ſport in playing it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear me.
I know you put on this affected carriage,
But to try maſterie, and the diſeaſe
Being ſo general among all women,
Is in you therefore more excuſable.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O, are you coming?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear what I will ſay to you.
And finde in that a husbands good affection.
I love my peace, and would preſerve my honour,
Both which are in your breaſts to ſave or ſpoil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And can you think the way to purchaſe peace
Is by a war with me? hah, you are cozen'd.
Do you think your domineering looks, or noiſe,
Or blowes, can fright me into quietneſſe,
Or that you ſhall have honour by abaſing
Your wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You will not underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hah.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Though I love peace, and would preſerve my honour.
I'le yield in both to you, and can, (I have been
So uſ • d to thraldome) But the world, the world
Is ſuch a Talker.—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I have found the man.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There I would ſave a reputation.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He's loth to bring it out; I'le cloſe w'ye.
You'll be content ſo, I will ſuffer you
To bear a loud command o're me in publick,
That I ſhall carrie it in private. Is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Truly wife, yes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to beat you
In private then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, we'll bar blowes at all times.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But if I chance to give you a rap or two,
Or now and then a nip, and you ſtrike me
Again, I'le ſtrike you ſome way elſe, as you
Would not be ſtruck. And ſo obſerve my carriage.
The Gentlemen are coming.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O, here they are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And not by the eares: that's wonderful.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Sir, I perceive my errour, and repent it.
Promiſing you in all my after life,
To be a faithful and obedient wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has fetch't her about, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Grammercy Rachel, binde it with a kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And thus it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, have ye found us?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: With joy to ſee this reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thus ſhall ye ſee it ever, Gentlemen.
I knew ſhe would yield, or I ſhould make her heart ake.
What were a husband, if he were not Maſter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have wonne the ſield, it ſeems, yet I may hope
I have not loſt a Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor I a friend.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In a faire way, Gentlemen, I ſhall
Abridge her of no courtly priviledge.
But no more haytie twaytie tricks, I charge you.
She ſhall not jaunt to this nor that town with you.
(I thank you for your care) nor to Hide-Park.
Nor to the Academy you tell her of, without my leave.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And do you ſay ſo Myſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Truly yes.
I am no ſuch woman as you took me for,
With Mr. Matchils leave you may be welcome
Home to his houſe in good and ſeemly ſort.
Put pray expect no further entertainment
Then he ſhall well allow of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have loſt her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: This change is admirable.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why do you admire it.
Is ſhe not mine? how could you think ſhe durſt
Stand out in her rebellion? although the devil
Who ſoothes all Upſtarts diſpoſitions
Into an over-weening of themſelves.
Poſſeſt her for a time, had not I power
And vertue do you think to conjure him out?
What have I ſtudied for, think you, e're ſince
My laſt wife di'd, but how to rule the next?
Go get you in, there's ſomething in the houſe
Worth looking after.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I be ſworn, he frights her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Would I had you within to perform covenants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What do you grow rebellious again.
Why ſtir you not elſe, ha? prithee Sweetheart
Reſpect my dignity, or only ſeem to do it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, I will only ſeem to do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He makes her tremble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I muſt about my houſe- • ffaires.
So, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Good Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Aha.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And Mr. Matchil, at your own good pleaſure.
Having in private ſomething to impart to you,
I would entreat your preſence.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Your eare before I go good Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: H'has brought her to her ſervile old obedience.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O—oh.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: That is a private touch, ſir, of the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pox of your Lobſter claws. There waanip▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It will be worth conſideration, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, Ile come to you preſently.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Any ill newes that you change colour ſo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, nothing, nothing but a womaniſh feare.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, you are a happy man that have o' recom her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You know not me yet Gentlemen, I know a word in private would do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet ſhe deſires to have you again in private.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis her abundant love, and pure obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She comes again.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Since y'are not yet diſpoſ'd to cnter, ſir.
One word more, Mr. Matchil, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh,—I underſtand you. Go, I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Again, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I muſt weare Lantern-hornes upon mine arms,
If ſhe uſe this. Well, Gentlemen, at your own time
Lets ſee yee. My Rach. ſhall make you welcome,
And for me, you know me, I will ſtill be Maſter.—
I come, I come, I come. So, farewel Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha, do you run?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What doeſt thou think of this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le lay all the tricks I have againſt his brags.
She maſters him in private, and that all
This ſhew of her obedience is diſſembled.
My hope revives again; we muſt abroad with her.
But tell me, what new Academy's that
You told her of, I underſtand not that yet.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor have I ſeen it, but we both will ſhortlie.
'Tis but of two or three dayes ſtanding yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where is it? who are the Profeſſours,
And what the Arts?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I'le tell thee all know.
It carries a love-ſound; but I am told
It is but private lodgings kept by
Both men and women, as I am inform'd, after the French manner.
That profeſſe Muſick, Dancing, Faſhion, Complement.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And no drabbing?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: A little perhaps in private.
But gueſſe now in whoſe houſe all this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Even in your City-Myſtreſſes, that lends you
Money ſo freely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who Camelion?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I doubt, your borrowing of the wife
Has broke the husband, put'hem off their trade,
And now they ſeek new wayes to live by projects.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And could you keep this from me all this while,
Till I am there, each ſtep's a tedious mile.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But not without me, good Val. We'll finde a time.
Together, and our Mrs. Matchil with us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I proteſt Cock, I commend thy courſe
Thou haſt taken in brave Lodgers, gallant Gueſts,
Gueſts o'th' Game Cock; and my houſe is counted
A houſe of quality and recreation, Cock,
In civil ſort and gentle faſhion, Cock,
Sbobs Cock, I know thou wouldeſt not have it otherwiſe
For all the wealth i'th' Exchange.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But Rafe you care not
What people ſay, ſo I bring you in profit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, not I, my little Cockſie Nanſie,
Not I, piſh, Hony ſoit qui maly penſe.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Some do not ſtick to ſay, I know what's what,
And that our houſe is no better then it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh, Hony ſoit agen, i'th' very teeth of 'hem,
Let 'hem all ſay what they will. Dainty come thou to me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But I know what I know, and that our houſe is
Better then it ſhould be, if ſome of them
Had but the keeping of it, that ſpeak ſo ill on't.
And that the Gentlewomen in our houſe
Are well-condition'd, and as chaſte as courteous.
And if you ſaw, (as they deſire I ſhould
See all betwixt their great Reſorts and them)
You'd be in love with their ſweet way of living.
Then for their dancing, 'tis ſo neat and graceful.
See 'hem anon at practice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, Cock, I'le ſee nothing.
I will not leave one ducking pond, for ten dancing ſchooles.
Yet I can dance, and love it: you know that Cock.
And though you are a Gentlewoman borne,
You took me for my legs, not • or my armes.
Is not that a good Jeſt, Cock. Sbobs 'twas out before
I was aware. Here comes their father.
sp.stage: Enter Strigood, Caſh, diſguiz'd in bravery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It ſeems he has brought in ſome new ſcholar.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Where are my daughters, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Cloſe in their chamber, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Are none of our Academicks come yet?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not any, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I look for ſome anon
Pray bid the Girles come down
To practiſe.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sir, when I was a Batchelour, I practiſ'd,
Dauncing ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Indeed, good Landlord?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And maugre wedloek, I have ſomething left
Yet in theſe legs, that can expreſſe at leaſt
Love to the quality.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: That ſhall not be loſt,
If I can further it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I ſaw laſt night
Your new French daunce of three, what call you it?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think I could make one in't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: This Gentleman's another, call the Muſick.
I'le try what you can do.
Caſh, Thou art welcom, I am glad I met thee.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: But that you had foreknowledge of my habit,
And ſeen it in my out-leaps, as you call 'hem,
I might ha' paſt. But you in this diſguiſe,
None but the devil himſelf that is your Inmate,
And lodges with you in it, could have known you.
Sure he deviſ'd it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: No, you are ſhort.
I learn't it of a Jeſuite.
And 'twas but eaſie: ſhaving of my old
Gray haire and beard off; clapping on this perrule
After the faſhion; having but few wrinkles.
(For which I thank my Batchelourſhip, I paſſe
For a brisk youth. But for my Hannibal eye here. And by my brothers
Courteous advice I have ta'ne a courſe to live
Vpon my ſtock of wit, ſlight and activity,
With nimble braine, quick hands, and aery heels, as he told me, ha!

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: He could not think you would have ſtolne his daughter to ha' ſet up withal.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: But now I care not
What the wretch thinks, ſo he diſcovers nothing,
I dare truſt thee Caſh, partly on thy Oath
Which I have ta'ne you know: but more reſpectively
Upon your fourty pieces here, friend Caſh,
Which I have alſo ta'ne: but moſt of all
For that I know you dare not make diſcovery,
For feare of Little-eaſe. That were a priſon
Too fearful for ſuch bravery to ſtoop into.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: That keeps me ſtill in awe. 'Tis well you know it.
But it is better, he has no ſuſpition
That I am run away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Muſick's ready, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Play then,—the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Twas very well done, Landlord, I proteſt
I love your houſe the better for your quality.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But if you ſaw me at the ducking pond,
Me and my Trull.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Your Trull?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I mean, my bitch, ſir.
O ſhe would raviſh you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Some other time.
Here comes your wife. The newes good Landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Newes out of France, your fame is ſpread abroad.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: How out of France?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Two young French Gentlemen.
New come aſhore, the daintieſt ſweeteſt Gentlemen
That e're I ſaw (now you'll be jealous Rafe)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Are come to lodge here, having heard
It ſeems, that you profeſſe French qualities.
And inſtantly deſire to be acquainted
With you and your ſweet company.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can they ſpeak Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: One very well: and the tother can ſay
Tree Franſh crown for two Engliſh kiſſe already,
Now be jealous Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh, Hony ſoit qui maly penſe.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You can ſpeak French, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So much as you have heard, not one word more.
I aſſure you but this, Adieu Monſieur and ſo
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will you not ſee the Gallants Rafe?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, I wo'nt be jealous Cock, and ſo▪
By the Back-door to the ducking pond. I go.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enter then Landlady, where be theſe Girles?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here they are come.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stand aſide Caſh, and be not yet diſcovered.
Now Ladies, how do y'like your way of living?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I do not like it Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Troth, nor I ſir.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: We eat and lodge well; and we weare good cloathes.
And keep our credit in the houſe we live in,
But what we ſuffer in our reputation
Abroad, is dangerouſly doubtful.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Here we are view'd and review'd by all comers.
Courted and tempted too, and though w'are ſafe
In our chaſte thoughts, the impious world may ſay,
We are ſet out to common ſale.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And ſo you are to th' utmoſt of his power
I dare be ſworue;

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But Uncle, for the time that you intend
To ſtay, I pray admit no new acquaintance,
Nor any more, leſt I for my eſcape
Venture a leap two ſtories deep.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha! you ſaid?
You know I have diſcloſ'd you to no eye
That could take knowledge who or whence you are,
And for the forrein ſtrangers, and ſuch Townsfolks
As knew us not; what need we weigh their thoughts.
Their gold is weight; let that be all we look to.
While our deſerving arts and qualities
Require it from 'hem. If they think us wicked,
And hope to get Virginities for ſalary,
And pay for their deluded hopes before-hand.
What is our act bnt Juſtice on their follies,
In taking of their prodigal coine?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I hope,
You deal not that way for us.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Never fear it.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But Uncle, though you have taught us courtly
Gypſie tricks.
That ſomewhat trench upon our modeſties.
Pray let it not be thought we'll ſell our honeſties.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Truſt to my care.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And thats the way to do it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And in that care be confidently ſeen,
By a deſerving Gentleman, whom I
Preſent to kiſſe your hands.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I will ſee none.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You need not feare me, Lady; for I can
But tell your father, if you ſlight his ſervant.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Bleſſe us! what Metamorphoſis is this?
'Tis Caſh your fathers man.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Is this the habit of a Merchants Prentice?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Is this the lodging of a Merchants daughter?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Has his great marriage turn'd my fathers houſe
Into a ſumptuous Palace, that he keeps
Such coſtly men. Or doth the bravery
Of his late beauteous Bride require ſuch gorgeous
Attendants? Pray what office may you fill
About her perſon.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Will you home and ſee?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: We are betray'd?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Be not afraid of Caſh.
I know him, and he knows us. He is our friend
And we'll be his. As for his bravery
'Tis no new thing with him. I know him of old.
This ſute's his worſt of foure.
And he's one
Of the foure famous Prentices o'th' time.
None of the Cream and Cake-boyes, nor of thoſe,
That gall their hands with ſtool-balls, or their Catſticks,
For white-pots, pudding-pies, ſtew'd prunes, and Tanſies.
To feaſt their Titts at Iſlington or Hogſden.
But haunts the famous Ordinaries o'th' time,
Where the beſt chear, beſt game, beſt company are frequent.
Lords call him Couſin at the Bowling Green; And the great Tennis-Court.
Thy fathers money
Would ruſt elſe, Girle. Keep thou our Councel Caſh.
And we'll keep thine, though't be to the undoing
Of him and all the wretches of his brotherhood,
That love their money, and their baſe deſires,
Better then blood or name.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: But can you hold
It good in any ſervant ſo to hazard
His Maſters livelihood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can you hold your peace?
He's wiſe, and ſaves by't all this while: He knows
His friends are bound in full two thouſand pounds,
For's truth, and his true ſervice, and perhaps,
He is not out above one thouſand yet,
Where's your wit now?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Myſtreſſe, I'le do you ſervice, and be true to you.
I'd not have miſt of this diſcovery.—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You ſee ſhe hearkens to him. Talk aſide Caſh.
And touch her boldly.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I would not have miſt it.
For all the wealth your father has: and at
Convenient privacy. Ple give you reaſons,
That ſhall gaine your belief to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: The French Gallants.
I had almoſt forgot them. They are a paire
Of delicate young Monſieurs. If they have
But crownes enough, they are the likelicſt
Merchants for my new Mart that I can chooſe.
She ſaid they can ſpeak Engliſh, that's a help.
For devil of French have I to entertain 'hem.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: See mine own heart, here's more temptation ſtill.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I'le not endure the onſet.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I le defend you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Yet there are graces in their looks methinks,
That do invite my ſtay.

l.hi: N' entendes vous, la langue francois Monſieur dittez.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I would be glad to heare you ſpeak the language
I better underſtand, and that is Engliſh.
In which you are moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Your faire courteſie
Merits our greateſt thanks.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: I tanck you, ſir.
I have bid Fraunce adieu to come and learn
De Engliſh very well; I ſpeak a lietel,
But de Engliſh Meſtereſſe can teach de beſt.
I ſhall be glad to take my commencements,
Or my firſt Leſſons from theſe Ladies lips.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: A fine forward ſpark?

sp.speaker: Gali
sp.l: O ſweet, O delicate.
Ladies, if you will breath into me Engliſh,
I ſhall, if you pleaſe, put Franſh into you.
Ʋne pour l'antre, dat is one for anoder.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: So they might make a hot bargain on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Are theſe your Civil Gentlemen, Landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: He ſeems a little waggiſh: but the other
Is wondrous civil. He comes bluſhingly.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: You are before me in the Salutation
Of theſe faire Ladies, Monſieur Galiard:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Il E'vray Monſieur Papilion, I kiſſe before, then you moſe kiſſe behind.
But let me pray my tardineſſe be excuſ'd

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You pronounce Engliſh well ſir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I am glad
You like it Lady.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I like the others as well.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I have before ſpent many monethes in England:
And my great love unto the Nation,
Eſpecially to the beauties of your Sexe,
Retracts me hither, where my friend was never.
Till now that my perfwaſion wonne his company;
And happily, I ſuppoſe, we are arriv'd:
That, to the ſight and knowledge we have had
Of Muſick, Daunces, Courtſhips, and Behaviour.
Through all parts of our Countrey, France, with an
Addition of all Italy affords.
Where (by all beſt opinions) even the choiceſt
Of ſuch court qualities, and active graces,
Have had their Spring, we now, as Fame ſuggeſts,
Shall in this faire Society, diſcerne
More then by all our former obſervation.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Report, ſir, ſpeaks too loud on our behalfe,
And let me pray ye, that it not beget
Too great an expectation on our weakneſſe,
By your too gentle ſuffrage. What we can,
We'll do.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: O wee dats de beſt. Doe is de ting
De Franſh man loves: If all your both two daughters
Shew all; all makes but more deſire to do.
Speak I no good Engliſh, Madamoiſelle?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: You no underſtand me,
Becauſe you tinck I lie. But if you lie
With me, I make you underſtand me preſently.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: This hot-rein'd Mouſieur takes 'em for the ſame.
Strigood would have 'em be I came in time.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: At afternoon we'll have an exerciſe
Of courtſhip, Gentlemen. In the Interim,
If you will have to ſtir the appetite,
A dance before our Ordinary we are for you.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: And we for you Alloun al Egremant Alloun

l.hi: Monſieur Papillion pour l' honour de France.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: VVhat are your dances chiefly in requeſt.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Good Landlady, bid the Muſick be in r • adineſſe.
And then ſee dinner ſet upon the table.
We have Sir for Corants,—La Miniard,

l.hi: La Vemimde, Le Marqueſſe, Le Holland,
La Brittaine, Le Roy, Le Prince, Le Montague,

sp.l: The Saraband; the Canaries, La Reverree.
For Galliards, the Sellibrand, the Dolphine,
The new Galliard, the Valette Galliard and lepees,

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: 'Tis all very good Monſieur Papillica Eſſontes

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And heark you, Monſieur Strigood, you will be put to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I feare no French flaſhes. Beare up Caſh. If we cannot daunce 'hem of o' their legs, our wenches can,
I warrant thee. Muſick be ready.
Gallants, what are you pleaſed to daunce?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: tells what, &c.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Gentlemen, your dinner ſtays meat will be cold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And we are hot, 'tis better that take cold then we.
But come, one table for us all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stri. Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I ſay ſo too.
But to my ſelf reſerve what I will do.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: EPhraim, thou haſt made me a man, both without, witneſſe this ſword and within, witneſſe this precious book, which I have gotten almoſt by heart already.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: But ſir, beware you fall not back again Into your childiſh follies: but go forwards In manly actions: for non progredi eſt regredi.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I know the meaning of that too, Ephraim. That's once a man and twice a childe. But if I turne childe again, while I have teeth in my head, • 'le give Mrs. Blithe leave to dig 'hem out with Sugarplums, as ſhe almoſt did theſe two of 'hem yeſterday, with her knuckles. I would they ſtuck both in her bum for't, till I we • e married to her, and that ſhall be ſhortly, they ſay, I wo' not turne boy again for that trick.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p:
Thou mayeſt be ſure on't Ephraim: for if I would turne boy again, I ha' not wherewithal to ſet up again. Thou ſaweſt that, aſſoon as I had taſted the ſweetneſſe of this delic • ous book here, I tore and burnt all my ballats, as well the godly as the ungodly. In my conſcience as many as might have furniſh't three Bartholomew Faires, and then for love of this ſword, I broke and did away all my ſtorehouſe of tops, gigs, b • l • s, cat and catſticks, pot-guns, key-guns, trunks, tillers, and all; and will I turne boy again canſt think? ye • I am half ſorry, being towards a wife, that I did
not keep 'hem for my children: ſome money might have been ſav'd by't. And that is a manly and a good husbandly conſideration, I take it. But hang covetouſneſſe: There comes not a mouth into the world, but there's meat for t; and if I finde 'em not play games, their mother will finde friends, that ſhall, for them and her ſelfe too

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I'm glad to heare ſuch good things to come from you,
And hope that now your judgment's ſtrong enough
To manage my affair. You know my minde, ſir.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Amardla Ephraim, 'twill be hard to compaſſe. For the old Knight will never let me have his Neece, unleſſe he have my mother. He meanes to truck for her, though, I confeſſe, I had rather call thee father then any man, I know, yet I know not how to bring it about, unleſſe he marry her firſt; and then ſhe be weary of him, and take thee afterwards to mend her match. I think it muſt be ſo, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Now you flie out again, that's as impoſſible, as 'tis unlawful.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Peace, my mother comes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Where are you childe? Neh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I hear her neighing after me, I'le do all I can for thee, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Look you • onne, what kinde Sir Swithin has ſent you. A dancing frog, you would think it were alive, and a ballet of burning the falſe prophets before they be tried. And another fearful one of the new Antichriſt.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Hang bawbles, burn ballets, I am a man, and defie boyes tricks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A ſudden change, I pray it be good.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Tell me of toyes? I have a ſword: offer me ballets? I have a book. Speak to me of Sir Swithin, I'le talk to you of Ephraim that gave me theſe bleſſings; and is fitter to be my father, (ſo he is) then the fooliſheſt Knight of 'em all.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bleſſe my ſonne from too much learning. That book has done him no good, I doubt. He talks and looks ſo wildly o'the ſudden.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A ha!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What book is't. Let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I'le tell you firſt. It is a book all of Bulls, Jeſts and Lies Collected by an A. S. Gent. Mother f'ſooth, there be ſuch things in it! If you never reade it, it is the rareſt book that ever you read in your life. Open it where you will, and you ſhall learn ſomething. As here now. One refuſing to eat Cheeſecakes, was ask't his reaſon. He told them he lov'd the fleſh well, but was afeard of the bones. Then here's the next to't. One asking whence Lobſters were brought: his fellow repli'd, one might eaſily know their countrey by their coat. They are fetch't from the red ſea. Now would I might never eat more of 'hem, as well as I love 'hem, if I know what Cheeſe-cakes were made of, or from whence Lobſters came before.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is this your book-learning? In troth thou mak'ſt me laugh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Laugh on, good Mother. And while you are in the merry mood, let me ſpeak a good word for Ephraim. I have a minde f'ſooth, becauſe he has made me a man, to make him my father, f'ſooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! How now.
How durſt you firrah, move my ſonne in this? ha.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is it but ſo? ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'ſooth hear him ſpeak. He can ſpeak Poetry (he ſayes) as well as Knight Whimlbie. Speak Ephraim.

l.hi: Madam, Fa • re truth h • ve told
Keeper in wedlock. Theſe did wiſely know,
Inferiour men beſt could their work below.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother f'ſooth, Is it not fine?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, more then ſo, I'le further go

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But you ſhall not, Sirrah. What, what! how now! Is't but up and ride? ha! Out of my doors thou varlet.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I muſt out too then, mother I am afraid, oh.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Good Neh. be pacified, I'le give him a better anſwer.
sp.l: But not a word on't now, ſweet childe, I pray thee.
Here comes Sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I marry Sir Swithin. This is better then O Madam, O—, when you waſh't your handkerchiefs in the ſuds, and then to wring hem out in Poetry.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p:
My tears with the memory of the dead are all fallen into Lethe; and nothing but joy left in me, ſinc my hopes are confirm'd in your lap. And hang
Poetry: I ſtudy profit now. Therefore, look you, Madam, here is a draught of my marriage-inſtrument to your lap.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: His inſtrument being drawn, I muſt put up my pipe and be gone.

sp.speaker: VVhi.
sp.p: And here is another draught for ſweet Maſter Nehemiah, for my Neece Blithes Joincture.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O but ſhe ſayes ſhe will not have me.

sp.speaker: VVhi.
sp.p: When did ſhe ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Now, now, ſhe ſpat the word out of her mouth. And I ſay, if ſhe ha' not me, you ſhall whine both your eyes out before you have my mother; and ſee ne're the worſe, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A croſſe marriage, or no marriage, I ſay ſtill.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ſay ſo too, ſonne, Sweet boy, be content.

sp.speaker: Whi. Blithe.
sp.p: You ſpoke well of him behinde his back: and made me think you lov'd him, and would marry him.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Behinde his back, I may do much to pleaſe you. But when I look upon him, he turnes my ſtomack worſe then a fool made of ſoure wilk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Marry Gip, Mrs Queaſie, my ſonne's as ſweet as you, I hope, and as wiſe as you. And ſuck't as ſweet milk as ever the good Cow your mother gave.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Patience, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope the croſſe marriage is croſt. This is untoward wooing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Uds ſo! do you flirt out your unſavoury compariſons upon my ſonne?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Flirt not you at me, Madam, leſt I flirt your milk-ſop under the ſnotty noſe here.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Yes, and I have a ſword, and you ha' got ne're a one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You wo' not will you, ha! Do you flie at him, ha!

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Fear not, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ephraim, ſave my boy.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Whi
sp.p: She ſhall not hurt him. Leave her to me, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ever fear'd he was not long-liv'd he was ſo witty. And now I feare, ſhe will be the death of him. I would not he ſhould marry her for a million.

sp.speaker: Neh
sp.p: Say not ſo, mother. I love her better and better ſtill.
I never had play-fellow i my life, but we fell out and in agen.
And I muſt and will marry her, I take my death on't aforehand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O me! he is bewitch't to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Leave all to me, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: As I am to you, I think, Sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Let me alone with her: I'le win her, and he ſhall wear her▪ feare not. As • was ſaying, Madam, ſhe ſpeaks as well of him behinde his back, as your owne heart can wiſh. And told me ſhe was content to marry him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Behinde his back? did ſhe ſo?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes truly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Loe you there, mother, Let her marry me behind my back then: And when we are marri'd, I'le make her ſtick to't before my face, I warrant you; or if ſhe will make back-play. I'le play at nothing but backgammons with her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, Heaven bleſſe thee, thou art but too good for her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Speak gently, Neece, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Madam, I hope your Ladiſhip ſhall finde me too good for him. If e're he has me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ha! ſay you ſo?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She meanes in well-doing, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay then, I thank you Mrs. Blithe. Aſſuring you that you ſhall be no way ſo good to him, but I will be as good to you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Agreed again of all hands. But look how ſhe turnes and keeps cut like my Sparrow. She will be my back Sweet-heart ſtill I ſee, and love me behind.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She is yet raw, and has not much been abroad to ſee the manners of the time. In which my melancholy has been her main hinderance. But Madam, there is now that is worth all our ſight and obſervation; A new Academy, where they ſay, the neweſt and moſt courtly carriage and behaviour is taught and practiſed both for young Gentlemen and women. Have you not heard on t?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes Sir Swithin; and that the French tongue is taught there with great alacrity; and my ſonne is wiſh't thither, but ſoft I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: But let him ſee it: at leaſt in our company it will embolden him; I mean to carry my Neece thither. I have been a Lover of Arts and Exerciſes; and know ſomewhat ſince my youth. Pray let us ſpend one houre of this afternoon there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pardon me good ſir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: But he ſhall not mother if you love me: for I mean to perfect my dancing there; and to learn French there; For I mean when I am married to travel into France. But I will firſt be perfect in the tongue I ſhall learne it the ſooner when I am there you know. Pray let us go to th' Acomedy, what dee call it?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: The Academy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſonne? then come ſir Swithin. Come Mrs. Blithe, we will all go.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I'le wait upon you, though my heart ſayes no.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O mine own heart! how near were we both fallen
Into the Gulf of Ruine?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thanks for our delivery!
We were upon the brink of main deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch a Fr • end as this mine Vncle?
Pretending us his children too, and call'd us daughters
To thoſe he bargain'd with to ſe • l our Maide head?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Twas a moſt damnable practiſe ſie upon him.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And had the Monſieurs been as capable
Of our Virginities, as he was of.
Their moneys, how had we then reſiſted.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: By Venus (mine own heart) my Gentleman
Came up ſo cloſe to me, that if my voice
Had not been ſtronger then mine armes (O me!
I tremble fon it yet) I had been vanquiſh't,

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But did you note the vertue of the Gentlemen?
When they were ſenſible of our feares and tears,
How gently they deſiſted and with what humanity,
When they perceiv'd how we had heen betrayd,
They pitied our conditions; and woo'd homditly
Our loves in way of marriage. Provided that
Our births and fortunes might no way diſparage
Theirs, being free and generous

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I confeſſe
I love 'hem both ſo well, that if they prove
(As they pretend they are not) our inferiours
In blood and worth, I would take either of'em.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Troth (mine own heart) 'tis juſt the ſame with me.
I care not which I have. And mark a ſympathy,
How equally all our • ffections ſtrike.
We both love them, they both love us alike.
But peace. Caſh, though he has done us good ſervice,
Muſt not know all. How goes it within Caſh?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And why Caſh pray. Ha' not you chang'd your names
From Joyce and Gabriella to Jane and Frances.
And is not your Uncle Strigood now become
Your father, by the name of Mr. Lightfoot
The nimble dancing Maſter? And muſt I ſtill
Carry the name of Caſh? and having loſt
My nature too, in having no caſh left?
(Pox o'the dice) call me Mr. Outlaſh.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: My father will fetch you home with an Inlaſh,
One o'theſe dayes.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: But after you, faire Miſtris,
Now to your queſtion for the ſquares within.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I with the Frenchmen, and my Uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Your father Lightfoot, you forget agen.
There's a drawn match made: For the Monſieurs
Have ta'ne their money again: And you have ſtill
Your Maidenheads, I hope. But to have heard
And how the young Blades put the old one to't;
Would ha perplext you more then keeping of
Your Maidenheads from men you love.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: You cannot tell that.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: O how the old man chafes that you would offer
To make your mone to • hem to move their pity,
And not to make his bargain good; and then
How they put home his baſeneſſe to him; to make ſale
Of his own blood and honour in his children.
(They knew they ſaid ſome parents in their countrey,
After their children were turn'd whores, would ſhare
To live upon the profits, but to ſell
Their ſoules before they were damned, fie; fie, fie, fie).
Till he confeſt indeed you were none of his.
But children of ſome friends of his deceaſt,
Left to his care ſor breeding; which he had
Plenteouſly given, and thought it might ſeem reaſonable
To raiſe his money out of you agen.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: What an old devil is this?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Baſer and baſer ſtill.
The Monſieurs cri'd, and ſwore if they could ſinde
Your Parents were Gentle and vertuous,
Being their firſt Loves, they would marry you,
To free you from this miſerable thraldome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Brave honeſt Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Be adviſ'd though, Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Beware of Travellers, many paſſe abroad
For gallant fellowes that have run their countrey,
For picking pockets.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And ſome you know at home
For cozening their Maſters.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You are pleaſ'd.
But you have known my love; for Gabriella
Let'hem ſhare her betwixt 'hem. You and I
Made one, may ſoon make peace with the old man
At home.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O Rogue! I'le tell you more anon Caſh.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, Monſieur Papillion.
And Monſieur Galliard, all friends, all friends.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: A greed, agreed, ſir.
