sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: And agree for me.
Agree poor tout.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Chear up your faces Girles.
'Twas but my trial of your chaſtity.
And ſince you have ſtood firme, I am proud of you.
Truſt me, 'twas but to try you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Wee wee All, but for try. Trimount, trimount.
No more, but all for try: no man can tinck,
But'twas too very moſhe to take two hundred
Crowns for two puſillages, no, no was but
For try: but and ſhe had not ſqueek and ſcraſh too
Like to do leetel chat, I had Trimount
One, two, tree, five time, for all your try.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: VVhat's paſt let be forgot. According to
Agreement, Gentlemen, y'are now content
To joyne with us in Academick fellowſhip,
And for your paſtime profeſſe Art and Science,
As we do for our profit: y'are expert,
I finde; and ſhall winne wonder of our Nation,
To your own much delight out of their follies.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And then for Gameſters, Gentlemen. If you • ll play.
I'le bring ye thoſe ſhall venture money enough.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: VVe are planted to our wiſh.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: All very good.
All very good; but I would ſee thee firſt.
VVhat Ladies will come here to practiſe complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You are ſtill hot upon the female Monſieur Galliard
Monſieur Papillion here flies over • hem.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, the newes?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: The old will to't.
As well as the young I ſee.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: To what Landlady?
sp.stage: He takes her aſide. And that while the young men and maids court and confer at tother ſide.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: To faſhion following;
A Reverend Lady
Of fifty five; and a Knight of threeſcore
And upwards, are come hither to learn faſhion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Do you know their names?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, yes: and them; 'tis that
Begets my wonder.
'Tis the Lady Neſtlecock, and one Sir Swithin VVhimlby.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: VVit be merciful unto us.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: The Ladies man's without: who came to know if the houſe were ready to entertain 'hem; do you know 'em Mr. Lightfoot?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I have heard o'th' Lady. Caſh, ſee if it be Ephraim.
He cannot know thee. Let him not away,
By any meanes, his not return to them may keep 'hem back.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I ſee him hither.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, is your husband come from ducking.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, overjoy'd with the good ſport he has had.
He'll play th' good fellow then. Entreat him Caſh.
To help thee, put a cup or two upon
That fellow; and hear • ſt me, ſpice his cup,
I mean, grave Ephraims cup with this ſame powder,
'Twill lay him aſleep, and quickly.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I know the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And Landlady, when the Knight and Lady come,
Say we are ready for 'em.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: 'Tis then an abſolute contract. I am yours.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And I am yours as firme as faith can binde.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: To which we are de witneſſe. Be ſo for us,
I am her husband, And ſhe is my wife,
Speak you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Fore Heaven, I do acknowledge it,
But ſir, the Church muſt be obſerv'd,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: For that.
We'll ſend for one Miniſter that ſhall marry
Us all at once. One kiſſe till then ſhall ſerve.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well done Monſieurs, I no ſooner turn
My back, but you are on the Damoſels lips.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: A leetel in de honeſt way will ſerve,
But he ſhall know no-ting.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: On with your Maſques-Maids,
And take eſpecial heed you bluſh not through 'hem.
For here are ſome at hand will put us to't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: 'Tis not my father, nor my Lady Aunt?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I cannot promiſe you. Be bold and ſafe.
Beare it out bravely, or our ſchool breaks up
Immediately: and we are broke forever,
Beſides, there is no ſtartiug.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: That's enough
To make a coward fight, and mine own heart;
We muſt ſtand ſtoutly to't, we loſe our loves elſe.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Well, I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Fall into complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I muſe we loſt my man thus.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: By your leave, ſir.
Are you the Regent of this Academy?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I am ſir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: And are thoſe of your Aſſiſtants.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes ſir, and all Profeſſors of Court-diſcipline,
By the moſt accurate, yet more familiar
Rules, then have ever yet been taught by any,
For quick inſtruction both of young and old.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: You promiſe very fairly. For us old ones,
We know and could have done things in our youth,
Which ſtill we have a minde to: but we leave
The practice to our young ones: Here's a paire
Would faine be at it. We'll pay their admittance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But I'd be glad to ſee firſt by your leave,
Some probability of what they ſhall learn.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And reaſon good, good Madam. Pray obſerve there.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Fair ſtar of courtſhip, my unworthy humble ſelf, a Profeſt ſervant to the integrity of beauty, makes this
Clear teſtimony of your merits, that every eye that ſees you,
Owes you his heart for tribute, and that unjuſtly your beholders live, that live not in your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother f'ſooth, is not this French?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace ch • lde. Hear more on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: Noble ſir, you are ſo exactly deſerving in the opinion of all righteous judgements, that the leaſt ſyllable of your faire teſtimony, is able to re-edifie the ruines of a decayed commendation.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: The beſt that ever I heard, ſince I woo'd my Griſſel.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Was not that a ſweet bout, ſir?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, it puts me in minde of ſome ſweet bouts I had with one before I married her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: • as he married my Siſter troe?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: I am forc't to give you over, Madam, you have ſuch a preventing and preoccupying wit in all things.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: That goes like Engliſh Mrs. Blithe. I could learn ſome of that me thinks.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Beſt tell your mother ſo; ſhe may rejoyce at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: There, Lady, was a taſte of ſweet complement between perſons equally affected. May it pleaſe you now to let your ſonne paſſe upon this demoſel. Who being to her a ſtranger, and raw (as I imagine) in courtſhip, ſhall meet with reprehenſion, that may be for his inſtruction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do Neh. ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Put of your hat and ſay—.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What! and her masque on?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That was well-ſaid. Why are they mask'd, I pray ſir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We are commanded it by the policy of wiſe authority; for feare young heires might fall in love with 'em, and ſink their fortunes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have well ſatisfied me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What ſhould I ſay to one I never ſaw.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: When I was young and bold, I would have ſaid, Lady, you are moſt auſpiciouſly encountred. And ſpeak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Lady, you are moſt ſuſpiciouſly accoutred, I ſpeak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Auſpiciouſly encountred man.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Auſpicouſly encountred woman, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I commiſerate your encounter. 'Tis a moſt hungry, verminous, impoveriſh't word ſir. It ſeems you are a ſtranger by't, to the Innovation of courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What ſhould I ſay to that now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He's a weak ſcholar forſooth, and would be glad to learn.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: The acknowledgement of his weakneſſe is the firſt greece of gradation to perfection, and his gladneſſe the ſcaling-ladder of reſolution.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'ſooth, can you teach me a complement to offer you ſugar-plums, and eat 'hem my ſelfe: to ſave my manners and my plums too?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What a wag it is?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What walking dunghil is this? made of the duſt ſwept from the houſe of ignorance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! how now, ha? you are a Flapſe to terme my ſonne ſo, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O good Madam. This is but ſchool play.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I'le put her by her ſchool-tricks and no only • nmask, but unskin her face too, and ſhe come over my heire apparent with ſuch Billingsgate Complements.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, no harm was meant, and nothing ſaid in earneſt: 'Twas meerly but ſchool practice, but to ſhew the ſweet young Gentleman how he might be ſubject to the ſcorne of Court, before he be ſeen in Complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: 'Twas told your Ladiſhip before, that by reprehenſion he might finde inſtructiou.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Right Madam; For no Fencer learnes his Science before he receive ſome hits and knocks too: Oh, I have had many.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, I am ſatisfied, and pray, that my raſh errour may prove pardonable Lady

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Rather let me implore your mercy, Madam—.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
'Tis well, 'tis well Lets hear an Interchange or two now, of complemental acknowledgement of
courteſies paſt betwixt Ladies, for the edification of • his faire one, who ſeems not yet to have ta'ne notice of us, but looks o' the ground ſtill.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: 'Tis not to finde a feſcue, ſir, among the Ruſhes.
To pick out a leſſon in your criſſe-croſſe-row of complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sharp and ſudden. She has a good wit I ſee.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ob erve, good Blithe, obſerve.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Can your poor ſervant expreſſe acknowledgement enough, Lady, for favonrs ſo inceſſantly heap't upon her, beſides the accumulation of many ſecret benefits?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: I cannot but admire, Madam, your noble and illuſtrious Gratitude, that can give beauty to benefits of ſo low a birth and condition.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: O my Griſſel comes to my minde agen, ſhe was the gratefulleſt woman.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: If ſuch favours, Madam, ſhould paſſe under an humble name, Honour would grow idle, and a thankful Nature beguil'd of her emploiment.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You' • l make my zeale hereafter, too baſhful to ſerve your moſt curious acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Curious acknowledgement! There was a thrid drawn out.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am hound by many kindneſſes, Madam, to celebrate the faire memory of you; as the trouble of your Coach twice in one day, beſides thoſe ineſtimable Jewels, the Monkey and Dormouſe your Ladiſhip ſent me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I would you could lend me a ſight of 'hem forſooth, I love ſuch things devoutly.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You do but open a privie door to my thankful temembrance, Madam, for the bounty of your Squirrel and Paraquitoe.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Fagh, ſhut that privie-door.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And ſhut in the Squirrel and the Paraquitoe to be ſtifled, ſhall ſhe? O that I could ſee hem!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now Madam, and Sir Knight, Is not this neat and handſom?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Truly, truly, 'tis moſt admirable pretty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Nay, if you heard our Lectures, ſaw our
Daunces.
Reliſh't our Muſick and harmonious voices,
Obſerv'd our Rules for faſhion and attire,
Our many exact poſtures and dimenſions,
Fit to be uſ'd by way of Salutation,
Of courteſie, of honour, of obeiſance,
To all degrees of man or womankind,
From the low bent of vaſſalage, to the head
Of towring Majeſty, you ſhould admire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But do you reade and teach all theſe to your ſcholars?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Stand forth, Monfieur Galliard. Stay w'are interrupted.
sp.l: Up maids, and quickly; or 'tis not your Masques
Can keep you undiſcover'd. Go, be ready,
With Muſick and your voices, when I call to yee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why are we interrupted? pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, it is my naughty Aunt, ſo 'tis▪

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No matter, ſonne, we'll take no notice of her.
sp.l: I wonder at the boldneſſe of the drudge though.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can turne taile too, as well as the great Lady. Hab.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And do ſo, Myſtreſſe, give her a broadſide.
sp.l: Well-ſaid, we'll make our partie good, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sir, we have heard your Fame; and love your Arts.
〈◊〉 pray that our ambition be excuſ'd,
Which drew on our Intruſion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To me and to the place you are all welcom.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ſo to all I hope, chiefly to you,
Good Madam Dowager, hoping in good time
I may get good, by doing much good upon you
How likes your L • p • my complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you bring your rude companions to affront me? Are you ſo hot? you ſtir up your cinders before they be cak't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Still in the Kitchin-dialect.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No ruder then your ſelf, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I brought her, Madam,
sp.l: 〈◊〉 advance my ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Will you ſee me abuſ'd
• ir 〈◊〉 , look to your Neece, the t'other talks to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Kinde merry Gentlemen, Madam, when I was young I would have done the like. Their coming hither, was as ours was to note th' inſtructions
That are taught here. Pray ſir proceed. On with your exerciſe, that we may all be edified.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We ſhall do ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But ſir, your Gentlewomen,
sp.l: That paſt upon our entrance where are they?

sp.p: Sir, they were call'd in haſte to private practice
sp.l: With ſome great Ladies in an upper room.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Umh—private practice. Well, I ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And they being abſent, we ſhall for the preſent
sp.l: Only deliver by theſe Gentlemen,
•• me heads of Sciences.
A Song, a Daunce, and then
Entreat you take a taſte of a collation.
And all moſt fairly welcome.
The heads of our chief Arts. Your ſilence, pray you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: The firſt is the due carriage of the body,
The proper motion of the head, hand, leg,
To every ſeveral degree of perſon,
From the Peaſant unto the Potentate;
To your • nferiours how and when to uſe the Nod,
The Hum, the Ha, the Frown, the Smile,
Upon the fit occaſſion; and to your equals,
The exacteſt, neweſt, and familiar motions
Of eye, of hand, of knee, of arme and ſhoulder,
That are in Garbe, in Congee, Crindge, or Shrug,
In common Courteſie, or Complement,
Laſtly, for your Addreſſes to Superiours.
The Honours, Reverence, or Obeyſances,
Proper unto the quality or eſtate
Of perſon whatſoever. And ſo much
For carriage and behaviour. In the next place
You ſhall have rules for the more graceful wearing
Of your Apparel, with the natural Reaſons,
Why ſome mans hat does better in his hand
Then on his head, and why his coat hangs neater
Upon his elbow, then upon his back,
As alſo Reaſons for Tunes bringing up.
And marriages, together of the faſhions
Of man and woman, how his Caller, and her
Black-bag, came on together; how his pocket-comb
To ſpru • e his Perrule, and her Girdle-glaſſe,
To order her black paſhes, came together;
How his walking in the ſtreets without a cloak
And her, without a man came up together,
Of theſe, and of a hundred more the like.
We ſhall demonſtrate reaſons and inſtructions.
Shall render you moſt graceful in each faſhion.
The next are skills in inſtruments, ſong and dancing

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enough, thoſe ſhall be made familiar to you
By voice and action inſtantly. A Song there.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Admirable pretty ſtill.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Are theſe your Gentlewomens voices, ſir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What do you keep 'hem up like Nuns,
To ſing and not be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Not alwayes ſir.
But may it pleaſe yee Gentlemen and Ladies,
Now to obſerve the practice of our feet
In active dancing.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: That came I to learn,
And to ſpeak French, do you think ſir, you can bring
My mouth to handle the French tongue handſomly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He's apt to learn, ſir, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Yes. I ſhall bring his Mout to it. But his Mont is yet a leetel too wide. But he ſhall have ſome of de water datde woman uſe for anoderting, to bring it better together, and he ſhall ſpeak like de Franſh Lady.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray ſir, if you can like the Ladies daughter of Paris properlie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. thou knoweſt the way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder ſir, 'Mongſt all your Arts and Sciences
You have ſo little judgement in a face,
Does his mouth appear wide to you? what falſe glaſſe
Are your eyes made of?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What you mean?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, friend.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Pray ſir take no offence. Here was none meant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Slander is no offence then. He has injur'd,
By breathing an aſperſion on that face,
The life of beauty, and the ſoule of ſweetneſſe.
Wide mouth Y—.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Begar Monſieur, you ſhall no point out mouth,
No, nor out-face the Frenſh man with your great Bull-beef, and Muſtard Engliſh looks.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Val. forbear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le ſtop.
This mouth that knowingly ſayes he dares except
Againſt a tittle of his face or perſon.
But as he is an ignorant ſtranger, and
I muſt reſpect the company. I forbear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: However ſir, I can but thank your love in 't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now it works in her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pardon my plainneſſe, Madam.
I never was ſo ta'ne with Maſculine beauty.
And till I winne a woman that is like him,
Or has been like him, I can but languiſh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They told me I was like him, when I was younger.
And let me tell you y' are a comely Gentleman.
And be you but as honeſt as y' are handſom, you deſerve well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ʋmh, 'tis a hard matter to bring thoſe ends together.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother f'ſooth. Here's a man now for you to make my father!
Beyond the Knight or Ephraim!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Were I free from the old Knight, I could look well upon him.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Come ſervant, come away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By no meanes, Myſtreſſe, I do but ſooth her up to jeare her for vou.
If you out-ſtay her not, you loſe your honour.
She'll brag ſhe has out-look't you. If you ſtart.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Nay, and ſhe go to that, I hope I can,
Look as ill favouredly as her ſelfe, or a better
Woman then ſhe, and ſtay in ſpight of her, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, Myſtris, Madam ſhall I tell you.
But I would pray you not to ſtorme, but laugh at it.
She ſayes you are no match for me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And knowing I aim at none but ſome great widow.
Tells me ſhe knows her husband's but ſhort-liv'd.
I fear ſhe means to break his heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No words, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: • et more whiſpering.
Pray Madam let us go. Neece come away,
For I fear Madam, as you wiſely doubted,
This is no companie for us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, I hope.
I am not yet ſo tied, but I may ſafelie
Uſe my own • reedom, I'le go when I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: O Griſſel, Griſſel, when would'ſt thou have ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Loves power, I hope, hath wonne on deſtinie,
T' appoint this day for my delivery.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir Swithin,—Ladies—we have yet
Dauncing to come, and a Collation promiſ'd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes Gallants, now w' are readie, we but ſtayed for this fourth man here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Camelion.
Where is your wife? I hope your je louſie.
Locks her not up.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh Honi ſoit. I hate it.
No, ſhe has been preparing of a banquet,
Which now is ready for you, worthy Mr. Lightfoot,
And your faire company; jealouſie I defie
The ba • e horne A gue, Mr. Askal I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What does he call you? Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Askal Madam.
My name is Askal. But the R in Maſter
Runs in • o't ſo, that ſometimes it ſounds doubtful.
I muſt be Knighted, Euphoniae gratia.
Sir Valentine Askal will come fairly off.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now note me Mr. Askal, and tell me if ever jealous man came ſo lightly off.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Sir, your collation ſtayes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Gallants and Ladies
Wilt pleaſe you enter.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, of all ſides.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: INhoſpitable! 'tis inhumane, paſt
The cruelty of infidels.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt
But thine own barbarous cruelty, hollow Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Abominable hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cunning Villain.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fie Gentlemen, forbear this unknown language.
And either ſpeak to others underſtanding,
If you ſpeak Juſtice:

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Give me then my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Thou haſt thy ſonne, give me my ſonne and daughter.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, if you'll not hear each other, yet both hear me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I pray Captain ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You had his ſonne to foſter; he your daughter.
You faithfully affirme you ſent his ſonne
For England a moneth ſince.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: And mine own with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You have confeſt you put away his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And mine own with her, through her diſobeence.
But 'twas upon advertiſement by letter,
That he had firſt caſt off my ſonne to an
Untimely death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Some Villain forg'd that letter,
And let me tell you ſir, though in your houſe,
Lafoy's an honeſt and a temperate man.
You are raſh and unadviſ'd, what Lafoy ſpeaks
I will maintain for truth: what you have done
I wiſh you could make good; But I may fear
You are mark't out by your own wilfulneſſe,
The ſubject of much woe and ſad misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not what I am; but did you know
The number, and the weight of my afflictions,
You could not chide me thus without ſome pity.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Indeed I pity you, and now y'are calme,
Know that Lafoy ſent his ſonne over with yours,
And but for ſome affaires he had with me,
I'th Iſle of Wight he had embarqu'd himſelf
With them, and brought hem to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There's hope then yet
That my boy lives.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And is come over feare not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You comfort me, and now Lafoy y' are welcome.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: But to what comfort, having loſt my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Loſt or loſt not, mine's with her. And I
purpoſe now to be ſad no longer. For I think
I ha' loſt my wife too, there's a ſecond comfort.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Take an example here Monſieur Lafoy,
And ſhake of ſadneſſe; mirth may come unlook't for.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I ha' loſt a ſonne too, a wilde roaring Lad,
About this town. And if I finde not him,
I doubt not I ſhall finde, that he has ſpent me
A hundred pound ſince I laſt heard of him.
By the way ſir, I ſent you a bill of change
Laſt moneth, to pay a hundred pieces for me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Twas paid. I have your bill for my diſcharge.
How now?
Ha' you found your Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nor tidings of her, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She has found then ſome good exerciſe, I doubt not.
That holds her ſo.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, there's a Gentleman
Craves inſtant ſpeech with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Who? or whence comes he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He will be known to none before he ſees you.
And, when you ſee him, he ſayes he thinks you'll know him.
He's a brave gallant, one o'the Alamodes,
Nothing but French all over.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fetch him me quickly,
It is my ſonne. Grammercie mine own heart,
That waſt not light ſo ſuddenlie for nothing,
Pray Gentlemen, who e're you ſee, name no man
To me, unleſſe I ask you. He comes, he comes.
I'm grown a proper man. Heaven make me thankful.
Juſt ſuch a ſpark was I at two and twenty,
Set cloathes and faſhion by. He thinks to try
If I can know him now. But there I'le fit him.
With me ſir is your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I preſume
You do not know me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: As well as he that got him.
Pray Gentlemen keep your countenances. Not know you ſir?
'Tis like I may have known you here to fore,
But cannot readily collect; perhaps
You are much chang'd by Travel, Time, and Bravery,
Since I laſt ſaw you. There he may finde.
I partly gueſſe, but will not know him yet.
Good Geutlemen ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What ailes he troe.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: He knowes me, I feare, too ſoon. If now my plot faile, and he have a Counterplot upon me. I am laid up.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Do you not know me yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Know you, or know you not ſir, what's your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You ſometimes had a ſonne ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes to me.
I had ſir. But I hear he's ſlain in France.
And farewel he. Mark how I handle him.
And what ſir of my fonne?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: He's dead you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I mufe the Knave askes me not bleſſing though.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: But to ſupplie his loſſe you have a daughter
That may endear a ſonne, ſir, to your comfort.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whither now flies he trow! Sir, do you know her.
Or where to finde her?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Firſt upon my knees
Let me implore your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes home: And I can hold no longer.
My bleſſing boy, thou meaneſt. Take it, and welcome
To a glad father. Riſe, and let my teares,
If joy confirm thy welcom.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I may not riſe yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No? why? what haſt thou done? where's young Lafoy?
My true friends ſonne here? whom I now muſt lock
Up in theſe armes, amidſt a thouſand welcomes.
Where's the young man?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I know not who you mean ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Diſtract me not.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: I feare you are deſtraught.
I know not him. How ſhould he know my ſon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let me look nearer.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Sir, I am your Prentice.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whow—whow, whow, who—my Thieſe and Runaway.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Prav ſir afford me hearing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, your cauſe
Requires a Judges hearing.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I have put me
Into your hands, and not without much hope,
To gaine your pardon, and your daughters love.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis roundly ſpoken. Gentlemen, I'le tell you.
This gallant youth, has gallanted away
A thouſand pound of mine.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: For your advantage ſir: For
By this way
Of Gallantry, as you call it, I have travell'd
Through the Reſorts and Haunts publike and private
Of all the Gallants in the Town. In brief
I have found your daughter, where ſhe had been loſt
For evet in your brother Strigoods hands.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Canſt bring me thither?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Is my daughter with her?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Madam Gabriella, the French Damſel's there.
And others, men and women, whom you'll know when you come there.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Good ſir, lets haſten thither.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You'll aid me, ſirs?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, with our lives and fortune.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be fearleſſe Lady, and upon my life,
Honour, and faith; you are ſecure from danger.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Sir, I have put me in your hands you ſee
So liberally that I may feare to ſuffer,
If not a cenſure, yet a ſuppoſition
Of too much eaſineſſe, in being led
So ſuddenly ſo farre towards your deſire.
But my opinion of your nobleneſſe
Joyn'd with your Proteſtation, pleads my pardon
At leaſt it may, the wretchedneſſe conſidered,
To which I was enthrall'd.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: It is not more my love
Unto your vertue, and your faire endowments.
Then pity in me labours your releaſe.
Nor is it rather to enrich my ſelf.
Then to ſave you from ſo immenſe a danger,
As you had fallen into by yielding under
Your Uncles weakneſſe in ſo fond a match.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Bleſſe me from being fool-clog'd.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now you are free.
If you can think your ſelf ſo, and but yield
Unto my preſent Counſel.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do ſo Lady
Before you are miſt within. Here is the Cloſet,
And here's the Key in your own hands, And preſently I'le fetch a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You ſee
I ſtill deal fairlie w'ye; and give you power
To keep guard on your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: And yet I yield
My ſelf your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In: ſome body comes.
She will be yours. And let me tell you, ſir,
I wiſh you as much joy with her, as I
Have with my Cock.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You have befriended me
In this good enterpriſe: And one good turne
Requires another. And now for that I told you,
Touching your wife, your Cock you ſo rejoyce in.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas. alas, good Gentlemen, you would fain
Ha' me be jealous. Honi ſoit, y'are ſhort.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Stand by and obſerve.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you begin to boggle,
And when I ſend for twenty pieces, do you
Send me but ten?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay mark.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray,
What have I had in all by your account.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: At ſeveral times, you have had fifty pounds of my poor husbands money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What's that to the free pleaſure of my body
Which muſt afford you ſweet and luſtie payment?
You froward Monkey. But perhaps you ha' got
Some new-found Horn-maker, that you may think,
Deſerves your husbands money better, for
Doing his Journey-work, one o'the Monſieurs,
Or both perhaps i'th' houſe here under's Antlers,
It muſt be ſo, why elſe of all the town,
Muſt I be one o'th' laſt that muſt take notice
Of your new College here, your brazen face College
Of feates and fine fagaries? do you grow weary of me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Do you grow wilde? ſpeak lower, do you mean to undo me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will tother fifty pound undo thee, I have loſt
All that I had within among your Monſieurs.
And you muſt yield ſupply, or loſe a friend
Of me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What a way would ſo much money have gone
In betts at the ducking pond?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will no leſſe ſerve your turn then fifty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No leſſe. All makes (you know) but a juſt hundred.
And there I'le ſtick; and ſtick cloſe to thee too,
Elſe all flies open. What care I who knows
Your credits breach, when you reſpect not mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis too well known already; All • s too open.
My houſe, my purſe, my wife, and all's too open.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: O me, undone.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Was ever loving husband
So much abuſd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Enquire among your neighbours.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be patient man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O thou cloſe whore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heed, ſir, what you ſay.
Eene now you ſaid ſhe was too open, ſir.
Y'are in two tales already.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I feare he's mad
Or jealous, which is worſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, Honi ſoit.
He jealous, he defies it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do you deride me?
Sir, you can witneſſe with me, he confeſt
Receipt of fifty pounds my wife has lent him,
(Falſe woman that ſhe is) for Horn-making,
Job Journey-work.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I know.
(At leaſt I think) I am deceiv'd in both.
My money and thy honeſty, but the Lawes
In both ſhall do me right, or all ſhall flie for't.
I'le inſtantly to councel.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Hear me firſt.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: By all meanes hear her firſt. Pray grant her that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I dare not look on her, leſt I be tempted
To yield unto my ſhame and my undoing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you not heare your Cock, your Nanſie,
Nanny Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Time was you would not ha' denied me that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nor any thing, if my Cock had but ſtood upon't.
Such was my love, but now,

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But now y'are jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have I not cauſe?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here's tother fifty pieces, take 'hem ſir.
They are full weight, and truly told.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Brave wench.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: If you will law, ſir, you ſhall law for ſomething.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope ſhe'll humble him ſo,
That he ſhall keep our chamber-door for us,
While we get boyes for him. A dainty Rogue,
She tempts me ſtrongly now. Would ſhe would call me
About it preſently.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That money ſir
May ſerve to countenance you among the Gameſters
Within, that blew you up. The Lady widow
May think the better of your credit too,
Being ſo good i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le ſtreight amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Councel me not ſir. All my joyes are gone.
I cannot think now what a ducking pond
Can be good for, except to d • own me in't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Alas, poor man, I was in this too buſie.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Stay, you ſhall promiſe me before my husband,
That you will never more attempt my chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That bargaine's yet to make. Though before him
I may ſay much, I will not ſtand to that
For all the wealth he has.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You ſhall proteſt
Then, fairly, as you are a Gentleman
You never have enjoy'd me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I like that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, no, I cannot ſafely, for in that
I ſhall ſurrender up my intereſt
In's houſe; and he may warne me out on't. No,
Take heed o' that. 'Tis not his tother hundred
Shall make me ſlip that hold.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am loſt again.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What a bold thief is this! Pray heare me, ſir.
You may remember that I ask't you once
What Countreyman you were.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, when you firſt caſt your good liking on me, and I told you.
sp.l: O'th' Iſle of Wight: And what o' that?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you
Call Captain Hardyman, their father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You wrong me baſely, to ſay I call him any thing; for he gives me nothing.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You wrong him baſely. Look you, Can you reade.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had done ill to venter (as I ha' done)
On Salisbury plain elſe. Hah, what's here
sp.p: That daughter, I ſent you order to receive for me an hundred pounds. If you finde that your brother the Spendthrift Val. Askal, (Zookes that I) be in any want, furniſh him according to your own diſcretion.
sp.l: I am Val. Askal, where's the money? My hundred
pound, ha' you't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: It ſeems a Siſter of yours had it.
Ha' you a ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: He had a daughter by my mother, but
He plac • d her out a childe, I know not where
Where's that young whore trow? Hannah I think
her name was. Hang me if 〈◊〉 know directly.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My wives name's Hannah, ſir.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I am that ſiſter, brother, but no whore.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. your brags to make men think you lay with her.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You have your hundred pound ſir. Look you, husband.
This is my fathers letter which you wrote on.
That which you dar'd the devil and Clerks to counterfeit, reade your own hand.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I muſt admire this woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do'ſt think I did not know thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: No ſir, nor would I that you ſhould,
Till I had foil'd you in your courſe,
And had my will to make my husband jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Cock, my Cock again, my Nanny cock,
Cock-all my Cock-a-hoop, I am overjoy'd,
See, ſee thy father too.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the woman.
To whom I paid your money.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter—.
My bleſſing on you.—What are you here too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ask you bleſſing too. Your hundred pound Has bound me to't. Heaven bleſſe you, Here's halfe one ſtill, yes, and the better halfe, for tother's ſpent.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: O y'are a great good husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would be one. And here's a good rich widow
Now in the houſe, your countenance may help me,
My Siſter and my Brother both can tell you,
How orderly and civilly I live.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O wag.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis like ſir, I ſhall prove your Furtherer.
What is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That Merchants Siſter, and a Lady ſir.
I would not have him heare.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: Well talk aſide then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In that I'm partly ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I love you ſir,
And waited on your wife but as your Sp • e,
For feare he might have led her to more folly.

sp.speaker: Mat:
sp.l: But ſaw you not two ſuch Damſels here?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Here are
Some in the houſe that would not be ſeen by us.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Becauſe they thought you'd know 'hem.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And if that
Old fellow be your brother Strigood, tis moſt ſtrange

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You know not him here do you?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No not I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis my man Caſh.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Moſt wonderful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We ſhall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Pray haſte ſir, to diſcovery: I would f • ine
Once ſee my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would ſee a little
The faſhions o'the houſe firſt.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Pray obſcure
Your ſelves in that by room there, where you may
See and hear all that paſſes, nor can any
Paſſe out o'th' houſe without your notice.
The Gentlemen and I will mix again
With the Society, if they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Agreed.
Within Strigood. Where are you Gent'emen?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Come away Val.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is not that the Hell-hounds voice?

sp.speaker: Caſh
sp.l: Yes, 'tis your brother.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good Captain go with us upon diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I'le ſeat you to ſee all, and be unſeen.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do ſo good Cock. Do ſo now ſir, I'le fetch the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, you have loſt ſuch ſport, the
Lady
And Merchants wife have been by th' eares.

sp.speaker: Caſh
sp.l: Could not
The old Knight part 'hem?

sp.speaker: Stri
sp.l: He has done his beſt,
And almoſt loſt his eyes in the adventure
Betwixt the Furies tallons▪

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But are they friends agen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And deep in complement.
Our ſchool affords no ſuch in act or language.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Siſter, Indeed I am too much your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray Madam let me ſerve you truly truly.
I'le be your ſervant for a yeare and a day

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed you wrong your ſelf, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am your ſervants ſervant, and will ſerve
Under your Ladiſhips Cook to do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed you may not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If I may not be
Accepted for your houſhold ſervant, let me
Become your Chare-woman▪ in any office
From Cupboard to (loſe-ſtool, I can do all
To do your Ladiſhip ſervice.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: This now ſavours of Complement indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: In ſooth, 'tis ſooth, forſooth the tale I tell you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Well acted mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Y' are too obſequious
Good gentle Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am ſhort of good.
Gentle I grant I am, for I bite no body,
Command me then ſweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And very well acted Nant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O you ſhall pardon me▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am no Pope, for your ſake would I were.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your courteſie o'recomes me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O not ſo.
I wiſh it could forſooth, would it were better for you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Exceeding well acted o'both ſides.
Mother and Aunt f'ſooth, Amardla you have done't
Better then the two School-Myſtreſſes to d • y
Could do their Whatſhicomes, their Complements
I think you call 'hem. But I ha' loſt my Myſtreſſe
To complement withal. Mrs. Bli • he Tripſhort
Has out-ſtrip't me, Amardla that ſhe has.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where's he • wiſe Uncle ſhould ha' look't to her.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: He's crying all about the houſe for her,
But cannot finde her. How ſhall I have her now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not have her boy, ſhe's naught.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Then he's
Naught too. You ſha'nt have him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor will, I feare not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Think of the Gentleman, mother that out-fac'd
The Frenchman for me. I would you had a thouſand ſuch in France now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: God-a-mercy boy.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Peace, hear a little more.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir; come away.
I have found a careleſſe Curate, that has nothing but a bare Coat too looſe ſhall chopt't up preſently. And give him but a piece, he'll fear no Cannon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Whither goes he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No matter, let him go t'untruſſe perhaps.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I ſay ſhe is i'th houſe.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's gone, ſhe's gone.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's flowen out of a window, or chimney-top then.
I'm ſure I wrtch't the door with epen eyes
E're ſince you entred, as my Lady charg'd me,
Leſt her childe might ſlip out to play i th' ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And I am here you ſee. He cannot ſee
He has no more eyes then a ſucking pig,
And yet he weeps like a roaſted one.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I am abuſ'd,
And r • nder me my Neece,
You have ſtolne her for your ſonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My ſonne defies her,
As I do you, old whining wither'd fellow,
That has no moiſture in him but for teares.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That is my Cue. A young well govern'd man
Were fitter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Where have you been ſervant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſpeak to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lady, I think you ſaid.
Are you ſo ſtout ſir▪ hah?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I rather think he playes the cunning hypocrite
With his falſe teares, and packt her hence himſelf

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lady mindes you not, and I can learn
To give you a broad ſide too.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, that cannot be, for I have ſeen
All that went out, or came into the houſe▪
Since you. Here came a Church man in ere while.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A Churchman! then I feare ſhe's clbſely married unto her wo and mine.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Perhaps to me.
Behinde my back you ſaid ſhe would do ſo.
And before him came in your brother Matchil.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother, who her husband?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Yes, with others.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My husband, I think you • aid What a foule houſe theſe waſhing dayes make?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no Jeſt Now •• dies let me tell you,
And ſad Sir Swithin; pray lend all your eares.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l:
Caſh, we are betray ••
Caſh if we be not nimble.
I ſmell a Fox. Hy thee up quickly Caſh,
And hurry down the wenches We'll make bold with
My Ladies Coach to hurry us away.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But not too faſt, Go ſir, fetch down the wenches.
Thou ſhameleſſe Reprobate. Doeſt thou hang thy head now?
I'le take a courſe to hang the reſt o'thee.
Your Ladiſhips well met at the new ſchool.
So is your Chare-woman. Ha' you profited
By the devils doctrine here? you weep ſin Swithin
For the iniquity of the times.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: You mean
His Neece, pray Vncle did you meet her,
She's gone away too, after my Couſin Joyce,
And the French maid, I think, ſhe is here agen.
Amardla, wipe your eyes, and look Sir Swithin,
The tother honeſt Gentleman has found her.
And let him take her for his paines for me.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I thank your love. But ſir, 'tis your conſent
We only ſeek.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir Swithin, let 'em have it,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman I would have ſpoke for:
In birth, in meanes, in perſon every way
Deſerving her. Take him upon my word.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And Madam, ſince you ſtick but upon Joyncture,
Having heard lately well of his husbandry.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Thank a good ſiſter, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: I will ſecure you
Three hundred pounds a year, your brother knows me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: With make good his word. Agree by your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Upon theſe termes, 'tis like we ſhall agree.
Sir Swithin are you pleaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Pleaſ'd or diſpleaſ'd.
It ſeems they are married.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, I aſſure you,
I ſaw their hands joyn'd, and I heard 'hem both
Anſwer the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I will no longer whine.
Heaven give you joy, As y'are your owne, y' are mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There are more weddings i'th' houſe, your daughters,
Are linck't by this time to the two young Frenchmen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: His daughters? ours I fear? what French? where are they?
sp.stage: Enter Caſh, two ſonne's, Joy, Gab.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Here ſir, undone I feare.

sp.speaker: Mat,
sp.l: What are you married.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Jun: Sir, ſhe is mine, I muſt and will maintain it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. And ſhe is mine.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: This is your ſonne. And this
Is mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is your daughter. And this mine. Each married to her brother.

l.hi: Jun. Mon Pere Je deſire veſtre Benediction Jour pour moy & ma fennue.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: You are loſt children all, was ever thread
By fate ſo croſſely ſp • n, ſo croſſely wed?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not how to Bleſſe you, or to look
On your inceſtuous eyes.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. What is dat Inceſt,
We have commit noting, we have no time,
Since we were marry for ſo much as kiſſe,
Begar no point ſo much as but one kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Be not diſmay'd. Theſe marriages are none.
The errour of the perſons nullifies
The verbal ceremony; and 'tis well
They paſt not unto further rites: I'le finde
A lawful way to clear all this. And then
As you and they conſent, they ſhall exchange
And marry in due order.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. Sir I tanck you.
You'ave ſpeak very well. And we ſhall make.
De exſhange preſently. A new exchange,
De new Exſhange indeed, for de husbands
To ſhange the wifes before they can be wearie.

l.hi: Prenez mon frere, la voici la' une pour lautre.

sp.l: Dere, is one for anoder:

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Is each party
Agreed, and ſo content?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: J. Gab. We are.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: And we.

sp.speaker: Laf. Ju.
sp.l: Wee wee, I enſuis tresbien contult.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ja.
sp.l: Provided that we have our fathers leaves and councels.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Can you ſeek fathers leaves or councels now,
That have run from 'hem in your diſobedience,
Into the ſnares of hell: too farre I fear
To be releaſt. O hell-bred Villain.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Your brother o' one ſide.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ju.
sp.l: Lend but a patient care.
And by my hopes of your deſired pardon
I'le quit you of your feare. 'Tis true, my duty
At my Arrival ſhould have wing'd me to you.
But hearing of your late, ill talk't on marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O that root of miſchief,
And of my Siſters flight as • oth to appear to you,
As to preſume a welcom; I was curious
Firſt to obſerve the Town, and taſte the newes;
When more by Providence then accident,
Here we made choice of lodging, ſaw and lik't
The practices of the Society,
Until this wicked man; (who ſtill preſumes
To call you brother,) finding us youthful ſtrangers,
And (as he might ſuppoſe) wanton—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He made
A bargain with you for their Maiden heads.

sp.speaker: Caſh
sp.l: told me that, and how that helliſh purpoſe
Was vertuouſly declin'd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O counterfeit Caſh.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But muſt you therefore, knowing whoſe ſons you were.
Marry you knew not whom.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ju.
sp.l: Pardon me, ſir.
Our loves were noble, and by due enquirie,
Fetch't from each others faithful breaſt, the knowledge
Of each other.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: VVhat! and marry then
Each his own Siſter? Riddle me not to death.

sp.speaker: Mat. Ju.
sp.l: Sir, I have done. And now that I have ſaid
The worſt that might have hapned by his practice,
To make his ſhame or his repentance greater,
VVho only was my aim. VVe are not married,
None of us all are married one to other.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No, I aſſure you ſir. Howere I li'd
At their requeſt, (ſmall matter for a friend)
I ſaw all the hurt the Prieſt did here to day.
That was upon them two there.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thank you ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You ſhall be then: And ſo take hands in earneſt.
Is't not a double Match Lafoy?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: VVithout
All manner of condition I conſent.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am full of joy.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: O can you pardon me ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good boy, good boy. I know not how a City
Could ſtand without ſuch Prentices. And hope
This wants few ſuch. But what canſt thou now ſay
Brother, o' one ſide for thy felfe. Speak quickly▪
VVhile the good humour holds me to be friends
VVith all the world: yet yonder's one lies heavy
Athwart my ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Y'are full of joy you ſay.
And I ſay had it been within my power,
To have broke your heart, I had don't. Therefore in me
Be comforted and love me; for I finde
I have no power to hurt you, and will therefore
Attempt no further.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Brotherly ſpoke in troth.
And worthily worth an hundred mark a month,
Shall ha't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Know then into the bargain, that
I forg'd the letter that ſuggeited to you
My Nephews death, in hope of means that way.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Honeſtly ſaid agaiu. Now what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I ſay that I am humbled on my knees.
I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: All's too well me thinks.
But heark, before you break up ſchool, lets have
Oue frisk, one fling now, one cariering dance,
And then pack up.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed, Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Play then Les tous enſembles.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: That's the French name on't, Uncle, 'tis in Dutch
call'd All-to-mall; and I call it in Engliſh.
Omnium Gatherum, 'tis the daintieſt daunce.
We had it here to day: I and my mother,
My Aunt and all can daunce in't, as well as the beſt.
With every one in their own footing. Now obſerve.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You have done well. Now pray lets break up ſchool.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: But yet not break up houſe. My ſonne and daughter.
Have given me power to call their Supper mine.
To which I'le give you welcome, Ale and VVine.
sp.stage: Deus dedit his quoque finem, laus Deo.

list.head: Theſe BOOKs following are ſold by Andrew Crook, at the Green Dragon in St. Pauls Church-yard.
In folio.
list.item: A Large and compleat Concordance to the Bible, by Samuel Newman.
The Bible of a large Engliſh, or black Letter, uſed in Churches.
The Bible of a faire London Print.
'The Bible in Welch.
Leviathan, or the Matter, Form and Power of a Common-wealth, Eccleſiaſtical and Civil, by Thomas Hobbs.
Ben. Johnſons Works, in two Volumes.
The Hiſtory of Don Quixote.
Doctor Kellet of the Sacrament of our Lords Supper.
All Homers Works tranſlated by George Chapman.
Orlando Furioſo, by Sir John Harrington.
Pſyche, or Loves Myſtery, by Jo. Beaumont.

list.head: In quarto.
list.item: Riders Dictionary.
Doctor Gauden, of the Miniſtry and Miniſters of the Church of England.
—His three Sermons upon ſeveral occaſions.
The Fables of Eſop, paraphraſed in verſe, and adorn'd with Scripture, by John Ogilby.
Doctor Lightfoot, his Harmony on the foure Evangeliſts.
—His Commentary on the Acts of the Apoſtles.
—His Deſcription of the Temple
—His Deſcription of the ſervice of the Temple.
Ten godly and faithful Sermons by John Gore, late Miniſter at St. Peters in Cornhil.
Doctor Day his Treatiſe of the Reſurrection, 1 Cor. 15. 16.
Burton of bowing at the Name of Jeſus.
Mr. Thomas Shepherd, of Liturgies, power of the Keyes, and of the Catholick viſible Church, in anſwer to Mr. John Ball.
Dr. Twiſſe of Predeſtination, in anſwer to Mr. Cotton.
The Swediſh Intelligencer, containing the principal paſſages and actions done in the beſt parts of Chriſtendome.
Virgil tranſlated Grammatically by John Brinſley.
A Phyloſophical and Chymical Treatiſe of Fire and Salt.
Clement, (the bleſſed Pauls fellow-labourer in the Goſpel) his Epiſtle to the Corinthians.
The Proteſtants Kalendar.

The Myſteries of Art and Nature in foure parts▪ the firſt of Waterworks, the ſecond of Fire-works, the third of Drawing, Limming, Painting, Engraving, and Etching, the fourth of ſundry experiments, by John Bate.
William Lithgow his Travels.
A Sermon preacbed at Newport in the Iſle of Wight, Octob. 1648. in the time of the Treaty, on Gal. 5. 22. 23. by Robert Saunderſon D. in D. and Chaplain to the late King.
An excellent Treatiſe of the intereſt of Princes and States of Chriſtendome.

A Path-way to Piety, containing
1. Chriſts Prayer expounded.
2. A Communicant inſtructed.
3. A Direction to live well.
4. A Direction to die well.

Doctor Swadlin his Manuel of devotions, ſuiting each day with prayers and meditations ſuitable to the works of the Day, as alſo each mans calling, she Nobleman, the Souldier, the Lawyer, the Tradeſman, the Sick man, the dying man.
A Brief of the Bibles Hiſtory.

div.p: BY RICHARD BROME.

q.l: Aſperius nihil eſt Humili cum ſurgit in Altum.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for A. Crook, and Hen. Brome, at the Gun in Ivy Lane. 1659.

list.item: Gonzago. King of Sicilie.
Gonzago. His Son the Prince.
Horatio. An old humorous Courtier.
Lodovico. Eulalia's faithful Counſellor.
Flavello. alias Alphonſo, Alinda's Sycophant.
Four Lords, two Biſhops.

row.cell: Three or four Countrey-men of Palermo.

list.item: The Scoene Sicilie.

div.head: The firſt Song, for pag. 88.
div.l: VVHat if a Day, or a moneth, or a year
Crown thy Delights
With a thouſand wiſh'd contentings?
May not the chance of a Night or an Hour
Croſs thy Delights
With as many ſad Tormentings?
Fortune, Honour, Beautie, Birth,
Are but bloſſomes dying.
Wanton Pleaſures, doating Mirth,
Are but Shadows flying.
All our Joys
Are but Toys,
Idle thoughts deceiving:
None hath power
Of an Hour
In our lifes bereaving.

div.head: The ſecond Song, for pag. 111.
div.l: HOw bleſs'd are they that waſt their wearied Hours
In ſolemn Groves, and ſolitarie Bowers,
Where neither eye nor Ear
Can ſee or hear
The frantique mirth
And falſe Delights of frolique earth:
Where they may ſit and pant,
And breath their purſy Souls;
Where neither grief conſumes, nor griping want
Afflicts; nor ſullen care controuls.
Away falſe Joys, ye Murther where ye kiſſe.
There is no Heaven to that, no Life to this.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: THe clouds of Doubts and Fears are now diſpers'd,
And Joy, like the reſplendent Sun, ſpreads forth
New life and ſpirit over all this Kingdom,
That lately gaſp'd with Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now the Court
Puts on her rich Attire, and like freſh Flora,
After the blaſts of winter, ſpreads her Mantle,
Deck'd with delightful Colours, to receive
The jocund Spring, that brings her this new life.

div.head: Scoen. II.
div.stage: Enter Flavello bare before the Prince, the Queen Eulalia, Alinda, Attendants, Hoboys,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Queen comes on, Joy in that face appears
That lately was overwhelmed in her tears,

sp.speaker: Lod. and Hor.
sp.l: Health and perpetual Joy unto the Queen,

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Thanks my good Lords, I am prepar'd to meet it.
How neer's the King?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: At hand, my Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Welcome that happy word that leads the way,
But yet he is not come, he is not here:
Never ſo ſweet an expectation
Appear'd ſo tedious: pray ſet on apace,
That I may live yet to an interview
With my lov'd honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That your delay
May ſeem leſs grievous, hear this by the way,
A brief relation of the Kings ſucceſs
In this his late well-won Battail.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Be it ſo.
But mention not his dangers, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That were to make his Conqueſt nothing worth:
It would make Victory upon his head,
As ſhe had flown into his Burgonet,
To ſhrowd her from a ſtorm, and not to ſit
Or rather ſtand triumphant on a foot,
With diſplay'd wings upon the utmoſt Sprigg
Of his high ſtouriſhing P • ume, vaunting her ſafety
So perch'd and ſo ſupported by his Valour.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Pray Mother hear the dangers too; the worſt
Will make the beſt the ſweeter: I could hear
Of dangers yet to come; and Women may
Diſcourſe of Perils paſt each Holy-day.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well ſaid, young Prince, right of the Kings own Metal:
And gracious Madam, let me tell you, though
You do not love to hear of blood and danger,
Y' have brought a Warrior forth, I do foreſee't:
I love to ſpeak my thoughts, I hope you truſt me,
A right old Courtier I, ſtill true to th' Crown.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: How this old fellow talkes! you ſaid, my Lord,
You would diſcourſe the Battail.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Excellent Prince,
I was i'th' way: but the Queen put me out on't.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Well, well my Lord, deliver't your own way.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then, humph, humh, humh, in my own way.
But by the way, no way to derogate
From the Kings matchleſs reſolution.
A word or two of the beſt Soldier
In all the world (under the King I mean,
I know my limits) that's our brave General,
Lord Sforza, Madam, your ſtout Country-man,
Though our Kings Subject now; that bore him ſo
At the great marriage-Triumph in Tourneament,
Tumbling down Peers and Princes, that e'er ſince,
He's cal'd your Champion, and the Queens old Souldier.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: But what of him now in the battail?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Marry but this, That as we have a King,
And as the King brings victory, nay life,
Home to his Queen, his Country and our comforts,
Next under Heaven we are to give the praiſe
To this old Souldier, to this man, the man
Indeed, another man is not to be
(Except the King) nam'd in this Victory.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You ſeem my Lord to honour Sforza yet
Before the King.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Excuſe me gracious Madam,
I know my limits: what? before the King?
I am an old Courtier I, ſtill true to th' Crown,
But thus it is declar'd, that in the battail,
When in the heat of fight the mingled bloods
Of either Army reek'd up to the Sun,
Dimming its glorious light with goryvapour,
When ſlaughter had rang'd round about the field,
Searching how by advantage to lay hold upon out King.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good mother.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: At laſt ſhe ſpied and circled him about
With Spears and ſwords ſo thickly pointed on him.
That nothing but his ſacred valour could
Give light for a ſupply to his relief,
Which ſhin'd ſo through and through his wals offoes,
As a rich Diamond 'mongſt an heap of Ruines,
And ſo was found by the quick eye of Sforza,
When like a Deitie arm'd with wrath and Thunder,
He cut a path of horror through the Battail
Raining down blood about him as he flew,
Like a prodigious Cloud of pitch and fire,
Until he pierc'd into the ſtraight, wherein
The Royal Perſon of our King was at
His laſt bare ſtake of one life to a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I dare not hear it, yet.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then in a word, old Sforza fetcht him off,
And with his ſword which never touch'd in vain,
Set him i'th' heart of's Army once again.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: That I like well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That did your Champion, Madam,
The Queens old Souldier, and your Father, Lady:
D'ye ſimple at it? ſuch a Souldier breaths not,
Only the King except: now note the Miracle,
The King receiv'd and gave new life at once
Of and unto his Army, which new life
Was ſtraight way multipli'd, as if the lives
Of all the ſlain on both ſides were transfus'd
In our remaining part, who with a preſent fury
Made on with that advantage on the Foe,
That the whole field was won as at one blow.
I am prevented.

div.head: Scoen. III.
div.stage: Enter Captain, Drum and Colours, King and Sforza, Souldiers.
The King embraces and kiſſes the Queen, the Prince and Alinda.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now ceaſe our Drums, and furle our Enſignes up:
Diſmiſs the Souldiers, hoſtile Armes ſurceaſe,
Whiles we rejoyce, ſafe in theſe Armes of Peace.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Go Souldiers, better never ſtood the ſhock
Of danger, or made good their Countreys cauſe.
Drink this to the Kings health and victory.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs the King, and our good General Sforza.

sp.speaker: Again.
sp.l: Long live the King and Sforza, Sforza and the King,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: The King and Sforza, Sforza and the King,
Equal at leaſt, and ſometimes three notes higher,
Sound Sforza's name then doth the Kings: the voyce
Of the wild People as I paſs'd along
Threw up his praiſes neerer unto Heaven
Ever methought then mine: but be it ſo,
He has deſerv'd well, now let me again
Embrace the happie comforts of my life.
Through deadly dangers, yea through death it ſelf,
I am reſtor'd unto my Heaven on Earth,
My wife and Son: a thouſand bleſſings on thee.
Say, deareſt life, whoſe prayers I know have been
Succeſsful to me in this doubtful War,
How welcome am I?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: That's more than I can ſpeak:
For ſhould I bring compariſons of the Spring,
After a Froſty winter to the Birds,
Or rich returns of ventures to the Merchant,
After the twentieth currant news of Shipwrack,
Redemption from captivity, or the Joyes
Women conceive after moſt painful Childbirths,
All were but Fabulous nothings to the Bliſs
Your preſence brings in anſwer to my Prayers:
Heaven heard me at the full: when I forget
To ſend due praiſes thither, let me die
Moſt wretched, though my gratitude ſhall never
Sleep to th' inferior means, e'en to the meaneſt
Souldier aſſiſtant to your ſafe return,
Eſpecially to you good Sforza, Noble Souldier,
I heard of your fidelitie.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: My duty Madam.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are you one of his great Admirers too?
The world will make an Idol of his Valour,
While I am but his ſhadow: Ile but think on't,
Indeed he's worth your favour, he has done wonders.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Let me now ſpeak, I may not hear theſe wonders bounc'd,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You do forget your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What ſays my Lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay I have done.
Gonzago, you and I have chang'd no words yet;
I have brought Victory home, which may perhaps
Be checkt at when my heat ſhall fall to aſhes.
How will you maintain your Fathers quarrels ore his Grave?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I do not hope t' outlive you Sir, but if I muſt,
I ſure ſhall hope to keep your name and right
Alive whilſt I live, though I cannot hope
To have ſo good a Souldier at my Standard
As Warlike Sforza.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is more and worſe
Then all the reſt: the childe has ſpoken plainly,
I had been nothing without Warlike Sforza:
Ile make him nothing, and no longer ſtand
His Cypher that in number makes him ten.
My Lords, my thanks to you for your due care
In my late abſence.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: All was Loyal Dutie,
As we are old Courtiers Sir, ſtill true to th' Crown.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have found you faithful.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It befits true Stateſmen
Watchful to be at home 'gainſt civil harms,
When Kings expoſe themſelves to hoſtile Arms.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There's a State-Rime now: but Horatio,
Has not Petruccio viſited the Court
Since our departure?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Pox on Petruccio.
Bleſs me, and be good to me: how thinks your
Grace of my Allegiance, and can ask
Me that Queſtion?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now he is in his Fit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Hangman take him. Petruccio King?
Peugh, peugh; I hate to name him.
How can you think your State had been ſecur'd
If he had breath'd amongſt us? That vile wretch,
Whom in your Kingly wiſdom you did baniſh
The Court for a moſt dangerous Male-content,
After his juſt repulſe from being your General,
When he durſt ſtand in Competition
VVith brave deſerving Sforza here, the beſt
Moſt abſolute Souldier of the world.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Still Sforza!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Except your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is an Exception wrung out,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He come at Court by my permiſſion?
I ſhould as ſoon be won to ſet your Court
On fire, as ſee him here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Send for him ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: [Starts] Your Majeſty is pleas'd to have it ſo.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And upon your Allegiance
Which you ſo boaſt of, let me have him here,
And very ſpeedily; Ile have your head elſe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay ſince it is your Highneſs pleaſure, and
So ſeriouſly commanded, I will ſend
My own head off my ſhoulders, but wee'l have him:
In what you can command, I dare be Loyal.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Look to it,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo, this is one of his un-to-be-examin'd haſtie Humours, one of his ſtarts: theſe and a devilliſh gift
sp.l: He has in Venerie, are all his faults.
Well, I muſt go, and ſtill be true to th' Crown.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Petruccio ſent for! who for braving of
Brave Sforza here, ſo lately was confin'd.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I cannot think the Court muſt hold 'm both
At once, leſs they were reconcil'd, which is
As much unlikely: what do you think my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She Sforza's Daughter, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: She's a right handſome one: I never knew he had a Daughter.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: He brought her o'er a Childe with me, when happily I came your Bride, bred her at home, ſhe never ſaw the Court, till now I ſent for her to be ſome comfort in your long abſence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sforza's abſence, I fear you mean.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: And truſt me Sir, Her ſimple Countrey Innocence at firſt
Bred ſuch delight in me, with ſuch affection,
That I have call'd her Daughter, to embolden her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O did you ſo?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: And now ſhe has got ſome ſpirit,
A prettie lively ſpirit, which becomes her
Methinks ſo like her Fathers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Very good.
I like her ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What was that ſhe ſaid
To you Conzago?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: That Heaven might ha' pleaſed
T' have faſhion'd her out to have been a Queen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Comely Ambition.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Reconcile all quickly,
Or you had better never have been born,
Then diſobey my laſt command, which was
Neve • to ſee the Court till I induc'd you.
Do you ſtare at me?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I but obey'd the Queen.
I hope ſhee'l anſwer't.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: No more, Ile talk with you anon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Sforza, Welcome to Court, ſo is your
Daughter too, I have tane notice of her: O f • ireſt, welcome.
Come you both with me this night, weel Feaſt:
Pray bid us welcome all, as but one Gueſt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I ſhall in all obey you.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: And for this,
Leſs then a King I ſhall abhor to kiſs.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Repuls'd? diſgrac'd? and made the ſcorn o'th' Court?
Is the advancement of an upſtart ſtranger,
Becauſe he is the Queens dear Countrey-man?
Have I for all my many Services,
Found the reward of being made an outcaſt?
Could not the King be pleas'd, though he advanc'd
Sforza unto the Honour I deſerv'd,
To truſt me in his ſervice? could he think
My ſword could be an hinderance in the Battail,
Or have delay'd the winning of the Field!
And muſt his Court and preſence which I have
VVith my obſervance dignifi'd, reject me
Now, as a dangerous and infectious perſon!
Tis a new way to gratifie old Souldiers.
So ſoon return'd? I do commend thy ſpeed.
The news at Court.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The King's come bravely home,
And every ear is fill'd with Victory,
But chiefly with the Fame of Sforza's Valour.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Sforza? Ser. Lord Sforza Sir, I cry him mercy,
The new Lord General.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Thou com'ſt too faſt

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: So me thinks too, leſs 'twere to better purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The Fame of Sforza's Valour, good if it laſt.
VVhat other news?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I have told you all the beſt.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: If thou haſt worſe, let's have it quickly.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: You ſhall, That you may flie the danger.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: VVhat is't, without your Preface?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here are Meſſengers ſent from the King to you; pray Heaven all be well. Ther's the old tutchie teſtie Lord, that rails, and never could abide you, ſince the King look'd from your Honour.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Th' haſt made me amends, ther's for thy news.
Is this bad news?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Truely my Lord, I think ſo:
For if the King had ſent to you for good,
I think he would have ſent one lov'd you better.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: VVhat? then the old Courtier? thou knowſt him not.
Ile ſhew him thee. He is the onely man
That does the King that ſervice, juſt to love
Or hate as the King does, ſo much and ſo long,
Juſt to a ſcruple or a minute, and then he has an
ignorant Loyaltie, to do as the King bids him, though
he fear immediate death by it.
Call him in.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: They come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: My maſters, come along, and cloſe up to me: my Loyaltie defend me, I ſhall not dare to truſt me in this devilliſh fellows reach elſe. And thus it is Sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis thus Sir, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good friends look well to me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You come with ſtrength of armed men, to bear me
From mine own Houſe which was my appointed Priſon,
Unto a ſtronger Hold.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look every way.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The King it ſeems now that his Nignion
General is Landed, cannot think him ſafe, and I not
Faſter: which though I can prevent, I will not.
Come, what Gaol will you remove me to?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would thou wert in Hell for me:
No Sir, I come to call you to the King.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What? with a Guard?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's for my Self. I know thou loveſt not me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nor you me, do you?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nor cannot, leſs the King could love thee.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Why perhaps he does, you ſee he ſends for me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Why if he does, I do, but 'tis more then I know, or can collect yet by his Majeſties affection.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Here's an Humour now.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I know my Loyalty, and I know the King has ſent for you; But to what end I know not: and if it be to hang thee I cannot help it. Look to me now my maſters. Nor do I care, that's the plain troth on't, while the King is pleas'd, and thou wert my Brother. I am an old Courtier I, ſtill true to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I commend your Loyaltie: Come, we are Friends.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look to me for all that.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Were you afraid, you came ſo arm'd and guarded?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's becauſe I would not be afraid: look to me ſtill.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, as much as I look for.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: VVhat ſhould the King intend by this? I fear no ill,
For I have done none; therefore I may go.
Perhaps he thinks to make me honour Sforza
Now in his time of Jollitie, and be friends:
I need not go for that; he cannot do't,
Yet I will go to tell him ſo: my Lord,
My joy to ſee the King will poſt me faſter
Than your grave Loyaltie, or Maſſie Bill-men.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, prethie keep afore with thy back towards me, and ſo long I dare truſt thee.
Have an eye though.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Her Father hath ſurpriz'd her then?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Yes, and means to hurry her away from
Court this night: I heard him threaten it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But he muſt not do't, ſhe is too ſweet Flavello, and too fit for my embraces, to be ſnatch'd away.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Now that ſhee's ripe and ready for your uſe,
Like fruit that cryes, Come eat me. Ile not boaſt
The pains I took to fit her to your Appetite, before ſhe ſaw you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How, my carefull Agent?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: At firſt ſight of her Feature, I foreſaw
She was compliable to your affection.
Then by diſcourſe I found ſhe was ambitious,
I ply'd her then with Pills that puff'd her up
To an high longing, till ſhe ſaw the hopes
She had to grow by. Pray ſtand cloſe, they come.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Has the air of Court infected you already?
Has the Kings kiſſes mov'd by adulterate heat,
Swoln you into aſtubborn loathſomneſs
Of wholſom Counſel? Come your wayes; Ile try
If Countrey-Air and Diet can reſtore you
To your forgotten modeſtie and Duty.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: VVhat have I done amiſs?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Do you capitulate?
But ſo much ſatisfaction as may make
Thee ſenſible of ſhame, I will afford thee:
Didſt thou not after Banquet, when the King
Heated with wine, and luſt rais'd in his eyes,
Had kiſs'd thee once, twice, thrice, though I look'd on,
And all the Preſence whiſpered their cold fears
Of the Kings wantonneſs and the Queens abuſe;
Didſt thou not then ſtill gaze upon his Face,
As thou hadſt long'd for more? O impudence!

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Impudence? Sir, pray give it the right name,
Courtſhip, 'twas Courtſhip Sir, if I have learn'd
Any ſince I came here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Brave metal'd wench!

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Beſides Sir, the Kings kiſſes
Are great ineſtimable Honours, and
VVhat Lady would not think her ſelf the more
Honour'd, by how much the King did kiſs her?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: And ſhould he more then kiſs, ſtill more Honour'd?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: It might be thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Durſt thou argue thus?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I know he dares not beat me here. Pray Sir
Let me but ask you this, then uſe your pleaſure:
(Cauſe you ſtile Impudence, that which I call Courtſhip)
VVhat Courtier ſits down ſatisfied with the firſt
Office or Honour is confer'd upon him?
If he does ſo, he leaves to be a Courtier.
And not the thing we treat of. Did your ſelf
After the King had grac'd you once, twice, thrice,
(As he kiſs'd me) expect no further from him?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: She's wonderouſly well read in Court alreadie:
VVho i'th' Devils name has been her Lecturer?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Do but your Majeſty obſerve that, and think
VVhat pains I took with her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: How many Offices
Did you run through before you were made General?
And as the more the King confers upon us,
Is more our Honour, ſo 'tis more the Kings,
VVhen moſt his Favours ſhine upon Deſert.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I like her better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Inſufferable Baggage.!
Dar'ſt thou call any thing in thee Deſert?
Or mention thoſe baſe Favours which the King
Maintains his Luſt by, with thoſe real Honours
Confer'd on me, who have preſerv'd his life?
Is it ſuch Dignity to be a VVhore?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Pray Sir, take heed: Kings Miſtriſſes muſt not
Be call'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Dar'ſt thou talk thus to me?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Yes, Sir;
If you dare think me worth the Kings embraces,
In that neer kind, howe 'er you pleaſe to ſtile it:
Sure I ſhall dare, and be allow'd to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That word makes thee a Queen.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: The King dares not
Maintain it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that coſts you your Head.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Dear Sir, take heed; Proteſt I dare not hear you:
Suppoſe I were advanc'd ſo far above you
To be your Queen, would you be therefore deſperate,
And fall from what you are to nothing? Pray
Utter no more ſuch words, I'd have you live.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: She vexes him handſomelie.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: As I live ſhe's mad. Do you dream of being a Queen?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: VVhy if I ſhould, I hope that were no Treaſon:
Nor if I were a Queen, were that ſufficient
VVarrant for you, to utter Treaſon by,
Becauſe you were my Father; No dear Sir,
Let not your Paſſion be Maſter of your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: How ſhe flies up with the conceit? d'yee hear?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Becauſe you were my Father.
Soveraignty you know, admits no Parentage.
Honour, poor petty Honour forgets Deſcent.
Let but a ſilly Daughter of a City
Become a Counteſſe, and note how ſqueamiſhly
She takes the wind of her Progenitors.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: She has ſwallowed an Ambition
That will burſt her: I'll let the humour forth.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: You will not kill your Child?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Though all Poſterity ſhould periſh by it.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Not for the Jewel in your Ear.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Impudent Harlot! ſhe has heard me value
This Jewel, which I wear for her dead Mother,
I would not part with, whilſt I wore my Head;
And now ſhe threatens that: a Kingdom ſhall not ſave thy life.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Know where you are, Sir, at Court, the Kings Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Were it a Church, and this unhallowed Room
Sanctum Sanctorum, I will bring you to your knees,
And make me ſuch a Recantation
As never follow'd Diſobedience;
I'll take thy life elſe, and immediately.

sp.speaker: King. Flav.
sp.l: Treaſon! a Guard! Treaſon! &c.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Heaven ſave the King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lay hold on Sforza, the dangerous Traytor.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: 'Tis Sforza is betray'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away with him, ſee he be kept cloſe Priſoner.
Flavello, ſee that his daughter have convenient Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Let me but ſpeak; I hope your Majeſty—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let not a word come from him: hence, away.
VVhat a moſt dangerous eſtate even Kings do live in?
VVhen thoſe that we do lodge ſo neer our Breaſt
Study our Death, when we expect our Reſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Be comforted good Queen, and I beſeech
Your Grace to pardon me in this command
The King has laid upon me.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I do, and muſt no leſs ſubmit my ſelf
To the Kings ſoveraign will then you: and though
I am committed to your houſe and cuſtody,
I am his Highneſs Priſoner: and more,
Though I know not my crime, unleſs it be
My due Obedience, I am ſtill ſo far
From grudging at his pleaſure, as I fear
To ask you what it is ſuppoſ'd to be;
But rather wait th' Event, which though it bring
My Death, 'tis welcom from my Lord and King.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVas ever Vertue more abus'd then hers?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yet thus much, good my Lord, vvithout offence;
Let me demand, Is Sforza ſtill cloſe Priſoner?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, and Petruccio his Adverſarie
Governs his Place, and high in the Kings Favour.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I will not ask his Treſpaſs neither, it
Sufficeth it is the Kings high pleaſure. But Alinda •
Sforza's fair Daughter, what becomes of her?
Poor vertuous Maid, is ſhe thrown out of Favour
Becauſe I lov'd her too?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Alas good Queen!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What do you weep? nay then all is not well
With her, I fear.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Queen, I fear ſo too;
And that all ill proceeds from her to you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I may not underſtand thee, Lodovico:
I'll ſtill retain the duty of a wife,
