Which though it be rejected, ſhall not throw
Me from the path a Subject ought to go.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Two ſuch wives more might ſave a Nation.
But ſee Petruccio the now-powerful man, under tho King.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Horatio with him too, are they ſuch Friends?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: None greater ſince the King was pleas'd to grace Petruccio.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Madam, howe'er my Perſon, no leſs then my Authority, I know is moſt unwelcom to you; I muſt appear, and lay the Kings Command upon you, which you muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I muſt? ſee, Lodovico, here's a plain-
Dealing Lord, that knows, my Love and my
Obedience to the King, and warnes me
Faithfully to obſerve it: good my Lord,
I will obey the Kings Command in you:
Lay't on me. What muſt I do?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You muſt go to the Bar, to anſwer to
Thoſe Accuſations that will be brought
Againſt your Life and Honour, as touching
Your foul Diſloyaltie unto the King.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: He is a Traytor to the King and Me,
That dares accuſe me of Diſloyaltie.
Patience aſſiſt me, and controul my Paſſion.
The greateſt Crime that ever I committed
Againſt my Soveraign, was, To be ſo neer
The Vice of Anger in the preſence of
One that he lov'd ſo well; but pray your Pardon,
Though truly thoſe ſharp-pointed words drew Blood
From my oppreſſed heart: and though you love me not,
I hope you think me innocent.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Would I could.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You do.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I would I durſt ſpeak what I think.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: My Lord, you ever lov'd me, can you think?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, what I think, I think; my love to you
Was the Kings love, if it were love at all:
If he will ſay, he ever lov'd you, I can ſay ſo too.
But to ſpeak truth, I know not if I did,
Or I did not; but now you're hateful to me;
That I dare ſpeak, becauſe he hates you ſoundly.
And your old Ruſſian Sforza, that fell Traytor,
That would have kill'd the King: do you look up at it?
You may look down with ſorrow enough:
Your Country-man, your brave old Champion,
He has Champion'd you ſweetly it ſeems.
Is there no honeſt VVoman?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVhat means this unknown Language?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVomen are alwayes ignorant of Reproof:
I'll tell you what it means, for that loves ſake
You thought I lov'd you once. Or do you know
VVhat Mars and Venus meant, when injur'd Vulcan
Had e'm in's Net? Good King, how wert thou abus'd?
And this good honeſt, faithful, loyal Lord,
Full to the brim, of Merit, and true Valour,
By that Blade-brandiſhing Sforza, that meer Fencer▪
To this great Martialiſt: but he is faſt enough,
And all's come out, howe'er you'l anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVhat muſt I anſwer? I know not yet your meaning.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nor ever ſhall, for me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You'll know too much
I fear, anon. Come, Madam, vvill you go?
The High-Court ſtayes your coming.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I muſt ſubmit me to it, and its Laws;
But to a higher Judge refer my Cauſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Good Queen, thy wrongs are manifeſt, though none
Muſt dare to utter them, but in our Mone.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Mount, mount, my thoughts, above the earthy
Of Vaſſal minds, whilſt ſtrength of womans wit (pitch
Props my Ambition up, and lifts my hope
Above the flight of Envy. Let the baſe
And abject mindes be pleas'd with ſervile Bondage▪
My Breaſt breeds not a thought that ſhall not flie
The lofty height of towring Majeſty.
My power upon the weakneſs of the King
(Whoſe raging Dotage to obtain my Love,
Like a devouring flame, ſeeks to conſume
All interpoſed Lets) hath laid a Ground-vvork
So ſure upon thoſe Ruines, that the power
Of Fate ſhall not controul, or ſtop my building
Up to the top of Soveraignty, vvhere I'll ſtand
And dare the VVorld to diſ-commend my Act:
It ſhall but ſay, when I the Crown have won,
The vvork was harſh in doing, but well done.
Flavello, welcom!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Hail, my Soveraign Queen.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave ſound, and that vvhich my Soul thirſts for;
But do not mock mine Ears.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Believe it Madam,
Joyn your attention but vvith one hours patience,
And you ſhall hear the gen'ral Voice o'th' Kingdom
Give you that ſtile, vvith large and loud allowance.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Stile thy ſelf happy then, in vvhat Reward
A Subject can receive, or a Queen give.
How moves our great proceedings?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Fairly, thus:
Eulalia, for now I muſt no more
Give her the Title that belongs unto
Your Execellence, of Queen.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Advance that Harmonie.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Eulalia is brought unto the Bar, accus'd,
Convicted of that high offence, that inſtantlie
Shall pull that Judgement on her, that ſhall cruſh
Her into nothing.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Appear the proofs manifeſt?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: That vvas my care, it behoov'd me to work the VVitneſſes, vvho ſwore (in brief) moſt bravely, that they heard Lord Sforza, vvhom you alſo may forget now to call Father.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: That vvithout your inſtruction.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: They ſwore, I ſay, they heard that Sforza boaſt
The knovvledge of the Queen in carnal Luſt.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: VVas that enough?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: No, but it ſerv'd to put
The queſtion to her, Was it true or not?
No, cries the Queen, nor can I think that Sforza
Would lay that ſcandal on himſelf and me.
Thoſe Witneſſes were two caſhier'd Lieutenants
That Sforza ſhould have hang'd for Mutinies
In the late war, but threw 'em by, it ſeems,
To ſerve him in this Office: me they coſt
Five hundred Crowns apiece, and well they got it.
But where I left: the Queen denies their Oath.
And though it had been true that Sforza had
Affirm'd as much, that had not found her guilty.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What Witneſſes were next?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Two dainty devils
Birds, a Doctor and a Midwife, who accus'd
Themſelves for Bawds i'th' Action, and depos'd
I know not how many, how many, how many times,
They ſaw 'em link'd in their unlawful pleaſures.
Theſe were the Queens own people, and deſerv'd
A thouſand Crowns apiece, and had it inſtantly,
Afore-hand too.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: What could the Queen ſay then?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: She denied all, but in ſuch a patient way,
After her fooliſh faſhion, that it gave ſtrength
To th' Evidence againſt her; then ſhe wept
For their iniquity, and gave them a God forgive ye.
And ſo attends the cenſure of the Court,
VVhich ſtraightway will be given: they'l be ſet
Before my coming.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Haſt, Flavello, haſt,
And let thy next news be to this a Crown,
That ſhe is not a Queen, and I am one.
This Father and this Queen I now could pity,
For being hew'd out and ſquar'd thus to my uſe,
But that they make thoſe neceſſary ſteps
By which I muſt aſcend to my Ambition.
They that will riſe unto a ſupream Head,
Should not regard upon whoſe Necks they tread.

div.head: Scoen. I.
div.stage: Enter four Lords, two Biſhops, King, Prince: they ſit; Eulalia in black, Crowned; a golden Wand in her hand, led between two Friers; ſhe kneels to the King, he rejects her with his hand. Enter at the other door, a Doctor of Phyſick, a Midwife, two Souldiers; the King points them to the Biſhops, they each deliver Papers, kiſs the Biſhops Books, and are diſmiſs'd. The Papers given to the King, He with his Finger menaces Eulalia, and ſends her the Papers: ſhe looks meekly. The Biſhops take her Crown and Wand, give her a Wreath of Cypreſs, and a white Wand. All the Lords peruſe the Papers. They ſhew various countenances: Some ſeem to applaud the King, ſome pity Eulalia. Muſick ceaſes. King ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: MY Lords and loyal Peers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A new diſtinction
Between Spiritual and Temporal.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good Lodovico, peace.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: This is a Cauſe, the which, but for fair Order,
By which I am conſtrain'd to be a Judge,
Would rather drive me to a mourning Cloſet
Then to this Seat; to ſhew my equal grief
Againſt the Crime and Shame of the Delinquent.
I ſee y'are all amaz'd, and cannot marveil
At your Aſtoniſhment, who do ſuffer with you
In the great Change Honour compels me to,
Together with Religion, fairly urging
To an high point of Juſtice, which to utter
Draws faintneſs from my words, chilling my Blood
Like the departing Breath that ſeparates Life.
For ſuch I held her, and ſo many yeers
Retain'd her in the Cloſet of my Heart,
Its ſelf-Companion: that till theſe proofs,
VVhich now like daggers by compulſive wounds
Have made their paſſage, ſhe could ne'er have parted.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Royal Hypocriſie!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Proofs you ſee are plain,
That ſhe was found—Pray ſpeak it for me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: In Adultery.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that ſhe ſought the Life of fair Alinda
By Sword and Poyſon both: and of that Cup
'Tis like my ſelf had taſted,
For my ſuppoſed love to that wrong'd Lady.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You have given her the Bed-right that belong'd to your wrong'd Queen, theſe twelve months.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our Laws of Sicilie are ſo well rebated
VVith Clemencie, and Mercie, that in this Caſe
They cut not Life from one of Royal Blood,
Onely take off (as is on her perform'd)
All Dignities, all Titles, all Poſſeſſions,
All means to live, even to her naked hands.
And ſuch, Eulalia, now is your condition.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: To work for her living? if ſhe were as young, and no honeſter then ſhe for vvhoſe ſake this is inflicted on her, ſhe might find ſomething elſe about her, then naked hands, to help at a living ſhift-

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now to this Cenſure, for due Orders ſake,
And for vvhich end this Parliament vvas call'd;
Your Voyces are requir'd: do ye all approve it?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: VVe do.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: We muſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: VVhat ſay you, Lodovico?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVe do; Heaven knows againſt my heart.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: My thanks unto you all, that do obey
So vvell vvith one conſent your Soveraign Lord.
And ſacred Sir, thus low, as it becomes me,
Let your poor Hand-maid beg, that you incline
A patient Ear to this my laſt Petition:
That as you caſt me off, as an offence,
You will be pleas'd to think me not offended,
But pleas'd in all I ſuffer: for, Heaven knows,
I am as free from any Paſſion
Of Anger, Hate, Repining or Diſtaſte,
Nay, as inſenſible of Grief or Sorrow,
Or whatſoever Anguiſh of the Minde,
As I was capable, for ought I know,
Of Joy or Bliſs the firſt hour I was born.
Never made happy till I was your Bride,
In which bleſt ſtate I cannot but remain,
While you are pleas'd, and I obey your will,
Though unto Death, to Baniſhment or Priſon.
Poverty is Bleſſedneſs, in vvhich I'll pray
For pardon of the Sins of my Accuſers,
And thoſe that have ſuborn'd them.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O poor Woman!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: So in the bleſt continuance of your Dayes,
I ſhall pray Heaven to ſmile on all your VVayes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay, ſtay Eulalia, I have yet a Buſineſs
I would have paſs the general Conſent
Of this Aſſemblie, in which your Voice is uſeful.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Upon my life, his Marriage with that Start-up,
That Snake this good Queen cocker'd in her Boſom,
Is not this Royal cruelty?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You wrong your Princely Dignity:
Turn to the King your Father, kneel to him.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And are not you my Mother?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I muſt and can forget what I have been;
So muſt not you: your Mother was a Queen.
My preſent fortune claims no Title in you.
Hurt not your own, by looking down on me.
This I will do as warranted by ſafetie,
Not as a Mother, but Beadſwoman, pray
For all that bliſs on you a Mother may,
Good Sir, obſerve the King before his wrath.
Take hold upon you for regarding me.

div.head: Scoen. II.
div.stage: Enter Favello uſhering Alinda like a Bride, two Virgins.
The King deſcends, takes her up: the Lords riſe, all amazed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let your amazement ceaſe, and now perceive
My Lords in general, that I your King
Am Subject to this all-deſerving Lady,
And do require you not alone to hear
What I can ſay, but without all denial
That you approve, confirm what I will ſay.
I am by law no leſs then your conſent
Divorc'd, and free from all impediment
To make my ſecond choice in Marriage,
And therefore crave Alinda for my wife,
And that immediately we ſolemnize
Our Marriage, and her Coronation.
I hope none rates our will or his own life
So meanly, as to give leaſt contradiction.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O let me lead your voyces. Long live
Gonzago and Alinda, King and Queen of Sicily.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: O groſs Hyocriſie!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: My Lord the Prince, pray let your voyce be next;
The reſt will follow. Why ſpeak you not, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: She would fain ſeem to voyce in your behalf,
But in a way that much perſwades againſt you.
Do but your Highneſs note it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You Sir, come from that Woman.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: She was my mother when ſhe was your wife;
And that's ſo late, I cannot yet forget it.
But I fear to offend.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: O ſhew it in your Duty then, young Prince:
'Tis true, the Law of Nature-wills a Son
To be a partner in his Mothers woe;
But Laws above that lay a ſtrong command
On Sons to obey the Edicts of their Fathers.
A Fathers frownes are Comets threatning ruine.
Let all your thoughts be free from his offence:
The moſt Heaven ſeeks, is our obedience.
In all obey the King; think not of me:
I am no more, nay not ſo much to you
As is the Begger whom you may relieve,
Since of all theſe comforts I am depos'd.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faith thou hadſt not mine, good woman:
I muſt not call thee Queen now.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Or if you needs will think I am your mother,
Let it be onely in the charge I give you,
That ſince Alinda bleſs'd by providence
Muſt be inveſted with the Regal Crown,
You ſhew her that obedience befits a Queen,
And your dread Fathers Wife.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I fear ſhee'l turn him
Traytor, if he give more ear to her inchantments.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ile ſhew him a way to give her thanks.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My Royal and dread Father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Put forth that woman:
Do it without grudge, out of the Court,
I mean to ſeek her way. Do you refuſe?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: He does not, ſhall not, Royal Sir.
Onely I beg that I may take my leave.
The wiſhes a true Subject ought to ſend
From the moſt humble heart up to the Throne
Of ſacred Majeſty, I equally divide
To you my King and Queen,
Profeſſing by the Powers you preſent,
I part as well content with my condition,
Since it is your command, as ere I was to ſit in that Promotion.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Sir, I may not ſit to be taunted and upbraided thus.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Pardon me, mighty Lady, I am as far
From daring to do ſo, as from a Queen.
And whilſt you love the King, and he is pleas'd,
I ſhall no leſs obey you, then I lov'd you
VVhen I ſent for you to the Court, and there into
this heart received you.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: I am plainly jeer'd: hence that woman.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away with her.
And let it be proclaim'd according to th' extremitie of Law our Cenſure be obſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Alas, how can ſhe live one night?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now to your conſent: have I it yet
For Marriage with Alinda? If you are pleas'd,
Then call us King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Long live the King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I mean Eulalia

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis well: on to the ceremonies then. Kings were
But common men, did not their Power get fear.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: It is oppreſſion, Tyrannie indeed.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Speak lower, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: For fear of whom? of what?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You would not that the King ſhould hear you, would you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faith if he did.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Faith then as ſure as your tongue's your own now, your whole head would be his then.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If it might ſo excuſe the Queen, I car'd not.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: It will do the Queen as much good, as the money it might be ſold for in the Market; That and the Appurtenances to it, would yield little at the Shambles. Come my Lord, ſpeak privately, and purpoſely keep your head on your ſhoulders: it becomes the place as well as 't had been made for it. If the King have a mind to turn away his Wife, Ile give him leave to turn mine after her, to wait upon her, rather than to have my head bowl'd at her, though I were ſure it ſhould kiſſe the Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Oh but the enſuing danger, my Horatio! The miſchiefes that of neceſſary courſe muſt follow, even to the ruine of the State, by the Kings dotage on his ſecond choice, draws blood from Subject hearts: Oh that lewd Woman!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
She is a Woman of middle earth yet. But what ſhall we dare to ſay two hours hence? Come, think upon Law and Regal Authoritie. The Kings Power Warrants his Acts: I know as well as you the Queen Eulalia (Heaven bleſs her, I hope 'tis yet no Treaſon to pray for her) is as vertuous a Lady as ever
beautified a Court, or made a Kings Bed happy, For all the Articles fram'd againſt her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The perfect Pattern of Meekneſs, Patience, Obedience.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Of all that's good, or ſhould be wiſh'd in VVoman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So obſequious a lover of her Husband, that ſhe gave way unto his looſe affections, even to this now-ſhe-ſtart-up that ſupplants her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: She conſider'd ſhe grows old: ſhe reads in her Sons face nigh twenty years of the Kings love to her: and gives him leave to place it now elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And is ſo far from limiting his Choice,
That ſhe poſſeſſes it that ſeeks her blood.
My ſoul tels me the witneſſes againſt
The Queen, are by this Concubine ſuborn'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I will not ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You cannot chuſe but think ſo.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: My thoughts are warranted by the Proverb. But come, make up your Face, temper your voyce and looks with the reſt of the moſt Honourable Aſſembly: ſhake off this diſcontent, 'tis a diſeaſe by which you'l periſh elſe:now all the Court's in height; you to profeſſe diſtaſte! Come, be a looker on at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Upon a Court on Fire? O Horatio,
Bright Burning Troy gave not a dearer cauſe
Of willingneſs to thoſe affrighted ſouls
She forc'd to leave her ſinking in her aſhes,
To flie for refuge to another Region;
Nor in their flight could they by looks reverted,
See danger in more horrible aſpect,
Than I upon the ruines of this Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your ſtay, my Lord, may prevent danger.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Yes, if it could remove the Fatal cauſe,
The pride, the crueltie, the Ambition
Of that wild Fury, the outragious Queen,
VVho treads and tramples down the Covernment.
Conſider this Horatio, and the means
To work this great effect: and I am yours,
To ſtay till it be done.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Alinda's Death.
VVho's there?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Is it not neceſſary? no body: what d' ye fear?
Or can you find how to preſerve the State
At a leſs rate? you know too well the King,
How apt his Nature is to fell oppreſſion.
The burden of whoſe crueltie long ſince,
If by the vertuous Clemencie of his Wife
It had not been alay'd and mitigated,
Had been a general ſubverſion.
And now that Peerleſs Princeſſe being depos'd,
Whoſe vertue made her famous, and us happy;
And he re-married to this ſhame of women,
Whoſe vileneſs breeds her envie and our miſchief,
What can we look for but deſtruction?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I dare me thinks a little hear you now,
(The Court being ſurfeited too with wine and noiſe)
And could almoſt talk to the point it ſelf,
To your own ear.
'Tis fit ſomewhat were done:
I cannot ſay what: but if the wronged Queen
Be not reſtor'd, we ſhew ingratitude,
How much, I may not ſay: enough to damn us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I, now you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And though I will not ſpeak it: if the Strumpet:
Be not conveniently and ſpeedily deſtroy'd,
Though death dance with us in the enterprize,
We ſhall ſeem born more for our ſelves than Countrey.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Brave noble reſolution!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay more, now I will ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: This way, good Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: That way, or any way; If Poyſon, Sword,
sp.l: Policy or Strength may do it—

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Speak lower, good Horatio: ſee the Mignion.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What for him? my Ladies Game-keeper, that underſtands nothing but Monkeyes, Parrots, ſhort-nos'd Dogs and Starlings; Maſter of her Majeſties Foiſting-hounds.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So, he hears you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Let him; he has no Soul to underſtand, nor Language to anſwer a Man: he knows how to dyet, diſple and perfume the ſmall Cattle he has charge of; for which rare Art, and catching Spiders for principal Pug, he is rais'd prime man in his great Miſtreſſes favour.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How the Petitioners flock to him!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Swarm rather, for they are Bees in his head; Oh! he engroſſes all the Suits, and commends them to the White Hand, whoſe diſpoſing will make the whole Kingdom black in Mourning, if Fate by us prevent not. See how he carries it! We might talk what we would, for him. His well-ordered head is ſo taken up with Particular Affaires, he mindes no General talk.
sp.l: But my good Lord, ▪fore others Ears and Eyes,
Purſue we our Deſign as all were Spies:
You and the Common Good have won me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O I embrace you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p:
Oh—Oh—and Oh-ho—O and alas! O and alack for O—O—O—that ever a true Neapolitan born,
ſhould live to ſee this day in Sicily! there O-again, • Queen—O me—what wilt thou do? O—O—what ſhall I do? O—thou maiſt work and ſtarve; O—and I may beg and live: O—but from thee I cannot live: O—I cannot, nor I wonnot, ſo I wonnot.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.p: See, here's poore Andrea mourning as well as we,
And all the reſt of the poor Queens caſt-awayes.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: But I can tell him comfort.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Oh—I will hear no comfort.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Yes, and be glad on't too.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Is my Queen Countrey-woman call'd back again?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: No, but the Queen Alinda has enquired for thee, to entertain thee into her ſervice, whilſt we and all the reſt of our late Queens ſervants are turn'd out o'th'Court, and now at this high dinner time too.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: She would eat me, would ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.p: That would make it a Feaſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: But Ile not truſt her on a faſting-night: Fools are meat then.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Well ſaid Andrea, witty in thy ſorrow: I know thou wilt back again for a new Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: No, no, take you your courſe, and ſerve her if you pleaſe,
I have play'd the Fool too long, to play the Knave now.
Ile after my old Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Thou maiſt not ſerve her: that will be brought within compaſs of Relief, and then thou maiſt be hang'd for her.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: If I be hang'd for doing good, pray let it not grieve you: and as I am an Innocent, Ile never grieve for you though you be hang'd never ſo juſtly.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We thank you good Andrea.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Take you your ſwinge, let me take mine I pray.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.p: Hark, the King drinks now to his new Queen.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: So, having turn'd his old Wife out of door,
A man may drink and frolique with his who—
VVould have thought it? did you think to catch me?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Not I Andrea.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Catch me if you can: when it ſhall be Treaſon to ſay there is an honeſt woman, Ile ſay my Countrey-woman was juſtly condemn'd of Adultery: and till then, I know what to ſay: Catch me if ye can.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: There again: now the Queen drinks.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Poore woman, at what River?

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: I mean the Queen Alinda.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: O the new thing at home here; I will not call her Queen, not I: my Countrey-woman is my Queen.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.p: Why is not ſhe thy Countrey-woman?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: She was when ſhe was Sforza's Daughter:
But ſhe has turn'd a Father out of him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: As here come ſome to turn us out o'th' Court.

div.head: Scoen. V.
div.stage: Enter Horatio, Flavello, Guard, two or three Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Away with them: out of the gates, away.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: See, here are more of them: more of that hated womans Retinue: away with all.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Beſeech you, good my Lord: I hope we are true men.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: As I am true to the Crown, not one of you peſters the Court a minute longer: go, you are traſh and trumpery: and Ile ſweep the Court of all of ye: follow your Miſtreſſe: go.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: The Fool my Lord ſhall ſtay: the Queen ask'd for him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yes yes, the Fool my Lord, ſhall ſtay.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: The Fool my Lord will not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Will not? how dar'ſt thou ſay ſo? ha, Fool, ha?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: The Fool dare ſay more than the wiſeſt Lord dares do amongſt ye: you will not take my own proper goods from me, will ye?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: See what he caries: I heard of Plate and Jewels loſt to day.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Let's ſee, Sir, I will ſee.
sp.stage: [Opens the Box: Coxcomb, Bable, Bells, and Coat.]

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Heyday, here's ſtuff indeed!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Your VVardrope cannot matcht it: pray give me all again; or if you will be the Kings and Queens Takers with that extremitie to force my goods from me, then preſent this to his Highneſs, and this to Hers; and tell them, 'tis all the poor diſcarded Fool could ſpare them.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: No Sir, you ſhall take them with you, and a whip for advantage, unleſs you'l ſtay and ſerve the Queen.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No Sir, to you with an excuſee moy,
If you be your Queens Fool-taker, you may
In Countrey, Court and City quickly find
Fools upon Fools that I ſhall leave behind.
New Lords (you know the Proverb) make new Laws,
New Lawyers of an old make a new cauſe.
New workmen are delighted with new Tooles,
And her new Majeſty muſt have new Fools.
New fools ſhe wants, not having you about her,
VVhile the old Fool makes ſhift to live without her.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Let the Fool go my Lord, 'tis but a Fool the leſs,
For he'll get wit by it, to wiſh himſelf here again.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p:
If I get but enough to keep me from Court,
I care not.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Farewell Fool, take your Trinkets with you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Farewell fine Lords, adieu old Courtier.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Court unclouded of this Factious crew,
VVill ſhine on us that to the Crown are true.

div.head: Scoen. VI.
div.stage: Enter Sforza and Keeper, as in Priſon.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: VVas ever man ſo hurried into thraldom,
And lock'd up in the ignorance of the cauſe,
Stronger and darker than his Priſon walls?
But I muſt not be Sepulchr'd alive,
And therefore Keeper, though thy office be
More Devilliſh than thy viſage, yet thy heart
May be humane: let me then conjure thee
To vent the ſecret forth but in a whiſper;
Or ſhouldſt thou utter't in a Tempeſts voyce,
As loud as are my injuries, thou art ſafe:
I can be here no carry-Tale: I am faſt
In thine own cuſtody, thou ſeeſt:
I pray thee tell me, what's laid unto my charge?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: All I can ſay, 'Tis the Kings pleaſure, and you muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: Do you barke Sentences, Hell-hound?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: My Lord, y'are off your Command, and under mine,
You much miſtake your ſelf and me.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Lions may rage in toyles: but whilſt they do,
They more enthral themſelves: will you ſit down,
And promiſe on your Honour not to force
My counſels from me? Ile deal fairly with you,
(My meaning is, to give him never a word)

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I will not lift a finger up againſt thee,
As I am a Souldier: now prithee tell me,
VVhat ſay they is my crime? [ſhakes his head] nay ſpeak it freely.
I can give it hearing:
Or tell me firſt if thou wilt, how fares the Queen?
VVhat? art thou dumb to that too? Anſwer me,
Is my Antagoniſt Petruccio
Repeal'd to Court yet? thence may ſpring my miſchief.
VVhy doſt not ſpeak? this is dogged ſilence,
In ſcorn of me, to mock my miſery.
I may not wrong the Honour of a Souldier
In my Revenge, or I would thrattle thee.
You're very civil, Hell take your courteſie.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I pitie him: but muſt not dare to ſhew it.
It adds to ſome mens miſery, not to know it.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: It is decreed of me, that I muſt ſuffer
This Barbarous crueltie; and Ile bravely bear it:
I ha' not force theſe double walls to part,
Or mollifie the Jaylors harder heart.
May ſpirit then aſſiſt me to deſpiſe
And bear my ſcorn above my injuries.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Revenge has caſt her ſelf into my hands,
Strangling the Life of Sforza in theſe Lines:
His Head is in this graſp, but where is Honour?
Muſt that forſake this Breſt? muſt the pure heat
Of heavenly Honour, yeeld unto the ſcorch
Of Hell-bred baſe Revenge? it muſt not, cannot:
For as the Sun puts out all baſer Fires,
Where Honour ſhines, thought of Revenge expires.
Beſides, he is below my Anger now;
And has no Life but forfeited to Law,
Or the Kings Fury, I'll not queſtion which;
Nor was it juſtlie, he gave me th' Affront,
In being made Lord General, when I ſtood for't.
But the Kings ſelfe, in his Election,
He wrong'd not me no more then I did him,
When th' Honour was transfer'd from him to me.
That's anſwer'd cleerly, I acquit thee, Sforza.
But now my Loyaltie, how ſhall I diſcharge
That ſpecial Duty I am here commanded,
(Stand back I ſay) to ſee the Execution,
And bring the Head of Sforza to the King?
What an addition here is of Advanceme • t?
To make me firſt a General, then a Hangman:
I'll do him better Service: Loyal Horatio
Would think himſelf now damn'd, to leave a tittle
Of the Kings powerful pleaſure unfulfil'd.
Call the Keeper.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I am to ſee and ſpeak with Sforza.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Then I doubt not but your Honour has brought VVarrant.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Honour be your VVarrant: will not that ſerve?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I will not loſe the Kings Grace for all the
Honours in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Do'ſt know me, or my place?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes, I both know and honour you, as far as my own place gives me leave: but in this I muſt crave pardon; you may not ſee him my Lord, by a leſs VVarrant then the Kings own Signet, and that fetches him out, and it pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: But have you been ſo ſtrict to all men elſe?
Has no man chang'd a vvord vvith him?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Not ſince
Theſe Keys commanded him, I can aſſure you,
Not even the Prince himſelf, who much deſir'd it.
I look'd as black on him, as upon you now.
I am no white Priſon-Keeper, I, to venture
Mine own Neck for a Priſoner's, at a price,
And give condemn'd men leave to run away:
No, I am the black Jaylor, I, and 'tis thought,
Lineally deſcended from Cerberus.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I muſt commend thy Care; ſee, there's the Signet.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I'll fetch the Priſoner.
May it pleaſe you to come forth, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Have I then liv'd to hear Mans voice again?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Here's the Lord Marſhal, and chief General
Of the Kings Forces, come to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Thoſe Titles once were mine, but now I muſt
Attend his pleaſure that is Maſter of them.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: All leave the Room, but be at hand.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: VVe ſhall.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: My firſt object from my long obſcurity,
The man that hates me moſt of all the world?
It is: his news cannot be good. not good?
The better: 'tis beſt to know the worſt; he cannot deceive me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Lord, I do preſume I am unwelcom,
Becauſe you are poſſeſs'd I never lov'd you:

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: The Court yields me ſuch Complement; this has
No ampler Comforts in't. But y'are deceiv'd,
For you are welcom, ſowre captious Lord, y'are welcom.
Becauſe (love me or love me not) you ſpeak.
I have been here theſe two and twenty dayes,
And never heard the voice of Man till now:
Meat I have found, and Lodging; but for Language,
In what part of the world I am, I know not.
Proceed; I value your words well, you ſee,
That give you ſix for one; why do you not ſpeak?
I have been us'd to talk with men that love me not,
And more with Enemies, I dare beſworn,
Then Friends: come, ſpeak, I pray, what is't you come for?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Alas! I pity him: his too too much vexation
Has over-tam'd him.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Will you not ſpeak and tell me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Pray let me ask you firſt; Have you been kept
So ſtrictly from the Speech of all men?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: E'er ſince I was committed, and from the knowledge
Of vvhy I vvas committed too; nay, he that keeps me,
'Till now he call'd me forth, never ſpake a vvord:
If I ask'd him, what News? here he vvas vvith me:
Or when he heard from Cuurt? then there again:
Or, why I vvas committed? ſtill the ſame anſwer.
So that I could inform my ſelf of nothing.
Come, if thou bee'ſt an honeſt Enemy,
Tell me ſomething:
As thou doſt wiſh my throat cut, tell me ſomething.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You ſeem to take no notice of the cauſe of your commitment.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Further than this I cannot: 'Twas the Kings pleaſure to command it.
Treaſon was cry'd; a Guard: away with him:
But for what cauſe, unleſs it were for drawing
My ſword upon (O that Rebellions Girle!)
To ſave her from the danger of his luſt,
(VVhich I tell you I was doubtful of) and ſo Sir,
Let me ask you, is ſhe ſtill about the Queen? (Queen.
My daughter Sir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Yes, much about the

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: And the Queen loves her?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: As dearly as her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Nay if you be a Souldier, now ſpeak truely.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The Queen and ſhee's all one.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Then there's ſome hope,
The King yet keepes fair quarter with her.
VVomen are quickly jealous.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: He knows nothing,
I'm confident, of all theſe great proceedings.
Poor man! I pity him: but Ile put him to it.
VVill you now anſwer me as y' are a Souldier
To ſome few Articles?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: You have engag'd me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'T were ſhame he ſhould die ignorant of at leaſt
The Accuſations are laid againſt him.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Come Sir, your Articles?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You are accus'd
Of an intended Treaſon 'gainſt the King.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Who's my Accuſer?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Even the King himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Umh, umh, umh: he ſhould not be my Judge then.
It is ſome Devilliſh dream of his, or elſe
That Policie that Princes purchaſe Hell by,
With ſtrong aſſurance without all exception;
That is, when Souldiers men of beſt deſert
Have merited more then they have means to give,
To cut their lives by whom they onely live.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You flie now from the queſtion: y' are engag'd by the Honour of a Souldier
Unto that Accuſation: guiltie or not guiltie?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I am not guiltie, as I am a Souldier;
And in that Oath I would not be forſworn,
To ſave as many lives, were they within me,
As periſh'd by my Sword to ſave his One.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: In that I am ſatisfied: now to the next,
If you will hear it; you ſhall promiſe me
To anſwer without paſſion I or no.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I will do what I can.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You're next accus'd
Of fowl Adulterie with the Queen Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Hah!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Guiltie or no?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: No Sir, nor dares there be
Such a ſuggeſtion in the heart of Hell.
And were he there, that thought, or could but dream
Of ſuch a Scandal, I'ld ſqueeze it out on's Brains.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Then I muſt hold you to your promiſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: A wreſtling towards; away weſt, away.
Nay then I am betray'd.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Forbear I pray.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: He comes but to inſult and to torment me.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Lord you much forget, is not this Paſſion?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Paſſion of heart! he hopes not for Salvation
That hears with patience but the repetition
Of ſuch a Blaſphemie. I muſt not die,
Until the world be vindicated from
The redamnation ſuch an error threatens.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You ſee I could oppreſs you; but all forbear the roome.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Do you come to mad me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: If you will be calm, Ile tell you what I come for.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: As ſetled as a Rock beneath a mountain
Here will I ſit, and hear thy loudeſt malice.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: If this man be not innocent, vertue lives not.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Now tell me what you come for; and be ſure
You ask no more abominable queſtions,
VVhilſt calmly I clear theſe, thus: By the Honour
And faith of a true Souldier, I am clear
Of theſe ſuggeſted crimes, which before Heaven
(Which knows my Innocencie) I do not urge
To ſave my life from the Kings violent Fury,
Nor any way to cloſe with thee in Friendſhip,
Now that my fortune is at worſt. So, ſpeak:
'Tis long a coming: I begin to think
It is ſome good, you are ſo loath to utter 't.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: It is, if you can apprehend it ſo.
My Lord, I take you for my friend, and come
To make my moan to you; inſomuch as now
I do conceive you Noble, Vertuous, Honeſt.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Foh! this is worſe than all the reſt, this ſtinks
Of the Court-putrefaction, Flatterie, groſsly.
But on I prithee: talk is ſuch a noveltie,
I will hear any thing.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I could not ſee your vertue, when it ſhin'd
Thorow the radiant favours of the King:
It dazled me with envie then: but now,
Like the red Sun through cold and myſtie vapours,
I can behold it at the full.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: So, ſo: umh, whu: ſo much for my vertues:
What's your buſineſs now?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I ſay I come to make my moan to you,
Groaning beneath a weightie Injury
The King has thrown upon me.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Has denyed him
Something I warrant, that he would have begg'd;
The making of a Knight, or ſome ſuch foolerie:
What was 't?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: In putting a baſe office on me.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Is the great Marſhals and chief Generals
Office, become ſo baſe?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: No Sir, the Hangmans Office. Read that—
I am commanded there, and warranted
VVith preſent ſpeed to bring your Head to him.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: A prayer or two, by his great leave and yours,
And you ſhall have it inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Lord, you ſhall not undervalue't ſo:
That Honour which has won me to you, ſhall
Work better for your preſervation.
I have much more to tell you, and ſtrong Reaſons
Why you ſhould live: of the Queens infinite wrongs
And yours, wrought by your Daughters cruel Ambition.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: This is a nobleneſs beyond Example:
Sure now you are honeſt.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: There you ſee my ſtrength:
If now for truth and Honours cauſe I ſtrain
A point of Loyaltie, you will engage
Your Honour to ſecure me?

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I hold my Honour equal to the beſt,
And prize it ſtill ſo far above my life,
That to ſave Kingdoms Ile not forfeit it.
Here in the ſight of Heaven I do engage it,
For your ſecuritie.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I ask no better. Keeper!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Diſmiſs that Guard, and give us way.

sp.speaker: Keep
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Now come my Lord, vertue may be caſt by;
But never overcome by Tyrannie.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: VVars Sword, Laws Axe, or Tyrannies fell Knife,
May overcome my Perſon, not my life.
For that is yours Petruccio.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: TUrn'd out of all, and caſt into the world;
And that forbidden too to pitie me?
No ſucour, no relief to be afforded?
Heaven ſtill is where it was, and cannot loſe
The Providence it ever had: let thoſe
That think me wretched now, conſider that,
And be with me converted to a Faith
That will proclaim us happy. What's my loſs?
VVhat was the State and glory of a Court,
But ſteps and lights through dangerous Ambition,
To ends beyond our ſelves, in whoſe atchievements,
VVe make our ſelves but nothing to ourſelves.
And all that we are then, is to the world,
VVhich renders us great Titles: which tane off,
VVe then return unto our ſelves again,
And all the world is ours: I was not great
Till now; nor could I confidently ſay
Any thing was mine own, till I had nothing.
They do but ſleep, that live in higheſt Pompe;
And all their happineſs is but a dream,
VVhen mine is reall: nay, nay, I can prove it.
Their coſtly fare breeds riot, mine content:
Their rich Attire is but mere Pageantry,
Made to pleaſe their eyes: mine keeps me warm,
And healthful, when a cold becomes their ſickneſs.
They boaſt of Honour and Gentilitie,
For their Attendants then, when the chief Honour
Of the beſt woman, meek obedience,
Is my own handmaid; and my Patience
A ſweeter ſervant than Gentilitie,
Continually my other: for Councel and defence, what have I now?
They have the helps of worldly wiſe mens brains,
And I the comforts of my fruitfull Prayers.
They have tall big-bon'd ſervants for defence:
I the ſtrongſt guard of all, mine innocence.
What Muſick had the Court compar'd to this,
Or what compariſon can all their ſports
And Revells hold with thoſe of Kids and Fawnes,
And frisking Lambs upon the countrey lawnes?
VVhich are my hourly pleaſant entertainments
In all my wanderings: in which I have not
Hunger'd at any time, but I have found
Meat which I duely earn'd: nor ever thirſted,
But I have found a Spring that has refreſh'd me.
And am no ſooner weary, then I finde
A ſhelter or a ſhade to reſt me in:
As now, in which a ſlumber 'gins to creep
Over mine Eyes, more ſoft then any ſleep,
Could theſe my Senſes when I lay of late
On Down, beneath the Canopy of State.

div.head: Scoen. II.
div.l: Sleep in thy Sainted Innocence,
Whilſt Angels watch in thy defence.
Sleep whilſt I charm theſe bubling Streams
With Muſick, to make ſweet thy Dreams;
Thy Dreams which truly ſhall relate
The Paſſages of thy Eſtate.
div.stage: Dumb ſhew. Enter Alinda, Flavello, two Lieutenants, Doctor, Midwife. Exeunt Lieutenants, Doctor, Midwife. Enter Sforza at the other end raging, and the Jaylor, with mute action. Enter King, Petruccio: Alinda whiſpers the King: he gives a Warrant and Signet to Petruccio: Exit Petruccio. King. kiſſes Alinda, graces Flavello. Exeunt. All this as the Genius ſpeaks.
div.l: Note, firſt thy Foes in Court conſpire
Againſt thy Life, and Villains hire
To act thy Tragedy.
Loe thoſe the perjur'd Evidence
That ſuggeſted thine offence,
Are hir'd the ſecond time to be
Co-actors in thy Tragedie.
They have their Fee, and now are ſent
Towards thee with a vile intent.
Ill thrive their purpoſes. Now note
The wrongs that are 'gainſt Sforza wrought,
Who lives from Speech of all men ſtill,
Pent by the Kings abuſed will;
Not knowing of the Treacherie
That was conſpir'd 'gainſt him and thee.
Nothing of all that's paſt knows he,
More then he muſt a Priſoner be;
Which doth him much impatience bring:
But the bad Queen inſtructs the King
How his vexation he may end,
Who ſtrictly for his Head doth ſend.
What from theſe black intents ſhall grow,
Is not as yet for thee know.
Now, holy Soul, I muſt thee ſet
A courſe that muſt thy living get.
Thou muſt not beg, nor take for need
More then thy Merits proper meed.
Firſt therefore, I thy Brain inſpire
With a Divine Prophetick Fire;
Thou ſhalt be able to Fore-doom
The ends of many things to come.
Into thy Breaſt I next infuſe
The Skill of Med'cine how to uſe:
Learn'd Aeſculapius never knew
The uſe of Simples more then you.
Many diſeas'd by Grief and Pain,
Of thee ſhall Health and Strength obtain.
Next Handy-Works and Literature,
With Education good and pure,
Thou ſhalt be able to beſtow
Upon the Country's Youth, and ſhow
The Elder ſort how to improve
Their Wealths by Neighbour-hood and Love:
Now when thou from this Trance doſt wake,
See that thou preſent Practice make
Of theſe thy Gifts, and fear not then
The Practices of Fiends or Men.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What ſoft? what ſweet? what heavenly Trance was this?
I feel my ſelf inſpir'd with holy Flame
Above the heat of Mortals: ſure I have
The Spirit of Prophecie, the Gift of Healing,
And Art of teaching hidden Myſteries.
Thanks Heaven, that firſt didſt ſend me Patience
To ſweeten my Afflictions, and now
Plentiful means to live, for others Good.
Who live but for themſelves, are but for ſhow,
And ſtand like barren Trees, where good might grow.

div.head: Scoen. III.
div.stage: Enter to her, Lodovico and Andrea.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Farewel, thou fooliſh Pomp, and Pride of Court,
Whoſe ſhine is but an Ignis fatuus
That leads fond Mortals from the path of Vertue,
And Tracts of real Comforts: thus I ſhake
Thy wanton Duſt from off my Feet, to tread
The wayes of Truth and Innocence: this Air
Breaths Health upon me, Peace, and perfect Pleaſure.
VVhere the ſwoln Courts ſophiſticated Breath
Did but diſeaſe my Blood, and taint my Senſes.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: It is good Lodovico, though diſguis'd,
I can no leſs then know him: and the poor Fool
That was my Servant: they come to relieve me
In theſe diſguiſes, that I might not know
From whom I receiv'd Comfort.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: To this way
The moſt unfortunate Queen enclin'd her courſe:
And ſee, already, how her VVants and VVoes
Have worne her to the bone: Alas, ſhe's pin'd!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And look you new Maſter, yonder's my old Miſtreſs;
VVhat Fools were we; that could not find her ſooner!
Alas! I can ſee through her: there is not
So thin a Queen in the Cards.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hold thee, good Woman, pray thee take it quickly.
I came now from a Feaſt where we had plenty,
And brought theſe Dainties, meant unto another;
But my dear Charity tells me thou doſt want it.
I pray thee eat it; do not look, but eat it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What Traytor art thou, that preſents me Poyſon?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: By all the truth and honeſty in Man,
'Tis wholeſome Food: ſee, I will be thy Taſter,
Though in good ſooth, it grievs mee to beguile thee
Of the leaſt Morſel: ſure thou haſt need of 't▪
Good VVoman eat, and let not Famine be
Fearful of Poyſon, or falſe Treacherie.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Is it not Poyſon to a loyal heart,
To eat contrary to the Kings Command?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: No, if it were, what a many would have been poyſon'd the laſt Lent, that may live to be very good Subjects, very good Subjects all the yeer after, except a few Fiſh-Dayes?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Las, we are plain poor Country Folke, and hear no ſuch news.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVhy will ye urge ſo much againſt your conſcience?
Have you not heard of my baniſhment, and the Kings Edict,
Proclaiming all men Traytors that relieve me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: VVe heard indeed the King had put away his old good VVife, and tane a new one: but can we think you are ſhe that was the Queen?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes good Diſſembler, you do know't, and you;
As ſure as I know you for Lodovico,
And you, Sir, for Andrea: Can it be,
That you that have been loyal Subjects, ſhould
Now go about to forfeit thus your Lives?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Pray leave this fooling, Miſtriſs: eat your meat;
And here's good Drink to waſh it down: and then
If you have a minde to hang us, let the
Gallows take his due; for my own part, I had
Rather hang like a man, while I am good
For ſomething, then you ſhould pine away to nothing.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Fear not you me, pray Sir, nor neglect the care
That's due unto your ſelves, to injure me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O deareſt Heaven! do you think we'ld injure you,
That venture lives for you? no, gentle Queen.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Lo, there again, that's Treaſon too, to call her Queen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No body hears nor ſees; pray eat a little.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Do not I hear and ſee you? I am not ſafe
In my obedience unto the King,
To hold ſuch conference with you that would
So violate his Laws: but let it warn ye
Off of this courſe; for I'll appeal to Juſtice
If you perſiſt in this Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Any woman but ſhe, now in her Caſe, would eat ſuch an Husbands Brains without Butter, rather then forſake good meat; and but for this wilfulneſs in her, I ſhould not think her a woman, I. But as ſhe is, new Maſter, we ſhall never do good upon her: and therefore ſince your Grace has not the grace to eat this meat, mark with what a grace or without Grace, I will eat it my ſelf: do you fear Poyſon? [Eats] Now Bottle let me play a part with thee; can you think this Poyſon, that goes down ſo merrily?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Much good may it do thee.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Stay, now perhaps ſhe'l eat.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: 'Tis like enough; I did but eat to get her an Appetite, therefore I'll e'en eat on, till all be done, to get her the better ſtomack: now Bottle, to thee again.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: See, here come poor Folks, that perhaps do want
That which ſuperfluouſly thou haſt devour'd.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p:
I'll eat again, for that: I am as poor as
they; and you never knew Charity in Beggers towards one another. Bottle again for that.

div.head: Scoen. IV.
div.stage: Enter to them, Pedro, Poggio and Lollio.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O Miſery! O Deſolation!

sp.speaker: Pogg. Loll.
sp.l: Diſeaſes, Sickneſſes, O Calamity!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What Saints are thoſe that they invoke ſo?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What is the Cauſe of theſe ſad Cries, good People?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Go back, if you reſpect your ſafety, go;
And look not this way where the Air diſperſeth
Nothing but foul Infection, Pain and Sorrow.
Return, I ſay, for here you appear ſtrangers,
And run not to the Ruine of your ſelves:
This way is fil'd with Cries: you can meet nothing
But Lamentations of a thouſand Souls:
Some Lame, ſome Blind, ſome Deaf, ſome Lunatick,
Some ſtruck with Palſie, ſome with Leproſie;
All ſighing, groaning, crying, underneath
The painful weight of Sorrow and Affliction.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What is that woful part o'th' Country call'd,
That ſuffers this Calamitie? and how
Did the Inhabitants there ſtand affected
To Goodneſs or Religion?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: We are all ſinful▪
Yet no way to extenuate our fault,
Or murmure at the Judgement faln upon us;
We have been held obedient to the Church,
True Subjects to the King, and friendlieſt Neighbours
Among our ſelves, all Sicily could boaſt of:
This part of it, or Province, being call'd,
The fair Talermian Fields, and is the ſame
Our Kings have cuſtomarily laid out
For their Queens Dowry: and has therefore been
Vulgarly call'd The Paradice of Love.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Stay there, old man: I have heard there is
Neither Lawyer nor Phyſician in all the Province.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: None could e'er get a living amongſt 'um in all their Practiſe.
It ſeems they liv'd then civilly and temperately.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Nor Gentleman nor Begger in their Confines.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then ſure their Wealth was all communicable.
There could not but be excellent Neighbour-hood.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And, which was worth all the reſt, their Prieſts
Were ever the beſt good-Fellows in all the Country.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Y'are now upon the Confines of that Country,
And cannot ſcape ſome dangerous ill,
If you dare taſt the Aire of it.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: That ſhall be try'd; I'll have a whiff on't:
If I get a miſchief by it, let the Fools harm be a warning to the VViſe.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: See more of thoſe diſtreſſed Souls that flie
The foul Contagion,
Yet charitable to each others wants:
For here the Deaf conducts the Blind: the Blind
Supports the Lame: the Dumb removes the ſick and feeble.
All that can make leaſt ſhift for't, flie the Place,
Then do not you preſs torward it.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: There will I.
Take up my Habitation.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Y'are not deſperate?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Mark me, good Lodovico, note my Reaſons:
This poor afflicted Province was my Dowry:
And the o'er-haſty judging world will ſay,
According to the Cenſure paſs'd on me,
My Treſpaſs drew this Evil on the Land.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Tis better that the world ſhould judge ſo, and periſh
For it in it's Ignorance, then you ſo wilfully
Be caſt away: you hear that none eſcape.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: None, Old nor Young, Man, Woman Child, all
In one kinde or other, do feel Affliction.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Do any die?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: None, though the moſt do wiſh
They might, in lieu of their ſad ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: And whither now do you intend your travail with your griefs?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: VVe hope a better Air will cure us. But
VVe are advis'd by our Divines and Augurs,
By the beſt means we can, to make our Journey
Towards the Court, to ſend our ſad complaint
Unto the King.

sp.speaker: (Eul.
sp.l: Hear now what he will ſay)

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: They find by Divination, that this puniſhment
Is falne upon this Province by the Sin
Of the Adulterous Queen, whoſe Dowrie 'twas.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: And that until
His juſtice take away Her loathed life,
This evil will not ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What, the Queen Eulalia's life?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Yes Sir; we hear ſhee's baniſh'd, and forbid relief:
But nothing ſave her polluted blood muſt quench this flame,
In expiation of her Sin and ſhame.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Dare you ſtay longer here? pray let us flie.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Why then you think me guiltie, Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I know not what to think, but that I will not.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Was that your Prieſts opinion and advice?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Yes, and thus grounded, that our pains began
Juſt at the hour, the Kings Indulgencie
Releas'd her forfeit Life.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: 'Twas everſo; Prieſts are but Apes to Kings,
And proſtitute Religion to their ends.
sp.p: Might you not judge as well, it was th' injuſtice and the wrongs the innocent Queen hath ſuffer'd, that has brought ſenſe of her injuries upon her Province? And that if ſhe had died, her Dowrie here with her had alſo ſuffered Death? to make it nothing to the King, as he made her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I, mark ye that: and that your falſe ſurmiſe
Againſt the Queen has brought this evil on you.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: O now my pain increaſes. 1. O mine Eyes. 2. My Brain. 3. My Bones. 4. My limbs are on the Rack.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis plain, your fowl miſtruſt is the infection that rages in you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Lodovico, peace: where is thy pain good man?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: Here in this Arm ſhrunk up as it were ſear'd with fiery Irons.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Bleſs'd Providence aſſiſt me whilſt with Prayers I uſe the gift thou gav'ſt me for the cure of theſe afflicted People. Give me thine hand: what feelſt thou now?

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: A precious cooling Balm that has extinguiſhed
The ſcorching heat I felt, and has reduc'd
My Fleſh, my Sinews, and my Arteries,
Into their natural temper and true uſe.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Joyn that hand to thy other, and thank Heaven then
sp.l: That made thee whole.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Miraculous!

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O ſure you are ſome Heavenly Saint or Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Beware Idolatry, and onely ſend
All praiſe to th' power whoſe mercy hath no end.
Onely do this for me: inform the reſt
How you have ſped, and win them back again,
To the next village: bid them be of chear,
Whilſt I make Holy Prayers for their help.
Ile come and live among you for my hire,
Which ſhall be cheap, believe me.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: All we have
VVill be too ſlight reward: firſt take my ſtore.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: I will but take my next competent meal.
I hope this will be thought but valuable.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I pray take more.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Go back I ſay with your ſad company,
And comfort them with news of your ſucceſs,
And a full hope of cure to every one
That's Partner in this ſad Affliction.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: With happy feet I ſhall ſpread it through the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O happy woman, now no more a Queen,
But Holy Saint: I ſee how Providence
Means to advance thy injur'd innocence.
Ile dwell here now my ſelf, and without fear:
For perfect health I think dwells only where
Good Eulalia remains: I have enough
To buy a Farm for me and poor Andrea.
But what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Ile tell you, Lodovico: the poor Fellow
Is gone to taſte the Countrey Air for me,
Leſt I might be infected: you ſhall ſee
Straight how he ſpeeds.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And that was honeſt love.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: A Surgeon, a Surgeon! Oh a Surgeon!

sp.speaker: Eul,
sp.l: How now, Andrea?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: A Surgeon: Oh twentie Surgeons, boneſetting Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: What's the matter man?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I am out of joynt. Ile taſte no more of ſuch contagious Aires, To ſave as many Queens as I have hairs. Oh Surgeons and Bone-ſetters, Bone-ſetters and Surgeons, all my Bones, all my Bones for a penny.
sp.l: I have not a finger nor a toe in joynt: my Leggs,
my Thighs, my Arms, my neck.
My back and Crupperbone is out of joynt.
Oh for a Sowgelder, a Surgeon I would ſay.
Out a joynt, out a joynt, I am all out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Thy tongue's not out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No, nor a Thing
I have that has no Bone in't: All elſe is out a joynt.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: This came of tempting Providence: were not you
Told the danger by the many that ſmarted of it?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I met them all dancing and frisking home.
The blind man made the way: the dumb man ſung,
The deaf kept time to his Notes: the lame led on
The Dance to all the reſt: whilſt I can go
No further. [lies down] 'Twas for you I ventured.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: And now you repent you meant me ſo much good.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: And now again I do repent that ever I did repent. Oh for a Stone-cutter, a Bone-ſetter I would ſay.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: VVell Sir, give me your hands: ſtand up.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: VVith as good a will as ever I ſtood to woman.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Now, how do you feel your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: In very pretty plight, I feel I am ſufficient.
sp.p: Haugh, heigh— [Capers and turns] 'twill do again: and if I durſt venture into that unluckie Countrey again, I would now teach the Clowns how to Dance for joy.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Yes you ſhall venter Sir; and by the way,
Ile teach you to teach them to work and pray.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: To work and play I pray you,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: If there be Heaven on earth, it is this woman.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Then if there be a Purgatorie on earth,
Ile venter through it for her, heigh, o, ho.

div.head: Scoen. V.
div.l: 1. Health and Joy: Health and Joy.
2. O happy woman that ever ſhe came hither!
1. Nay happy we that ere ſhe came among us.
2. VVhat ſhall we render her in recompence?
All that we have is too little for this woman,
This good woman, this holy woman, this ſhe-Saint,
If there be one above ground.
3. O do not make an If at her, neighbour, leſt the ground ſwallow thee quick in thy Infidelitie.
2. Now doubtleſs, and without all adventure, ſhe is an unknown woman.
3. And therefore a good woman: for 'tis too true,
All thoſe that are well known are e'en bad enough:
And known ſhe will not be for all our entreats,
No not ſo much as from whence ſhe came, we ſee.
2. And that counſel ſhe may keep ſtill for me:
For doubtleſs, and without all peradventure
If we had need of another ſuch, 'it were in yain to ſeek her.
1. Sure 'twas from Heaven ſhe came,
Where the whole ſtock of good women vvere plac'd long ago.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe I'm confident.

sp.speaker: Stroz.
sp.l: Our work lies fairly then before us.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Theſe look like miſchievous Robbers.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: What can they take from us?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your Life, I fear.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: I have e'en din'd, let 'em take away when they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Their looks are murderous.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: Fear not, Lodovico: why look ye Friends, ſo amazedly? ha'ye loſt your way? or what do ye ſeek?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: No, we ha' found our way, 'tis to you we ſeek: we dare come roundly to you, for all your
sp.l: Guard, your old Fool, and your young here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O my unhappy Fears!

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: You will not murder me?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: 'Tis all the Office we are bound to doe you.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Juſt Heaven protect me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Call upon Heaven as you go thitherward:
VVe may not ſtay long Invocations.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Pray take me in your way, and run me through her, if you be honeſt Murderers. Help: Murder, Murder!

div.head: Scoen. VII.
div.stage: Enter to them, Curate, Crier, Pedro, Lollio, Poggio.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: O yes! O yes! O yes!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Silence Crier, ſuſpend the Proclamation, to preventa bomination.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Heaven has ſent us ayd.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O we are prevented!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
On, on; ſa, ſa; down with their VVeapons, up with their heels, till we inſect and rip up the intrails of the Cauſe: what an Aſſaſſinate was here attempted?
O infauſta D • es! two ſwords againſt the naked vvomb of a VVoman! and none but weaponleſs men to aſſiſt her!

sp.speaker: viz.
sp.l: Senex & Ineptus.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: That is to ſay, Give me their Swords under my Fools Coat, I'll hurt no body.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Upon my facundity, an elegant conſtruction by the Fool. So, I am cedunt arma Togae.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: For our attempt Sir, we vvill anſwer it: vve are for the King.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then vve are for the King, Sir; & in nomine
Majeſtatis, we command you to attend our preſent
Office, and then we will examine yours.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: And then if you deſerve the Gallows, you ſhall be ſure on't: a ſhort breathing-vvhile ſhall be no hinderance to you. So Crier lift up your Voice, and proceed.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.p: O yes, O yes, O yes: By the Kings moſt Excellent Majeſty, a Proclamation, prohibiting upon pain of Death, any Relief to be given unto the baniſh'd Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Now ſay, VVhereas upon juſt and lawful Tryal.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.l: VVhereas, &c.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The ſaid Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Crier.
sp.l: The ſaid Eulalia.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: I am that hapleſs ſhe, that for relief will not beg, nor borrow, nor take of yee.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe, and at the price of Life I vvill relieve her.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: How? vvhat have vve done? In relieving her from killing, we are all become Traytors.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: That's an idle fear: vve knew her not,
VVhich now vve do, vve may again reliver her
Into their hands, for them to kill her yet:
And then there's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: So let us give them their ſwords again; and
vvhen they have done their vvork, to make all ſure,
vve'll hang them for their pains, and ſo keep the Law
in our own hands vvhile vve have it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The woman muſt be ſav'd á manubus istis.
They are Catilinarian Traytors.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You Sir, have reaſon; you have found her Life
The King has pardon'd: and although her Doom
In this her Baniſhment were heavy, and
A puniſhment even unto Death, but that
Good ſoul ſhe works and labours for her food,
You find not yet 'tis lawful any kill her.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Recte dixiſti Domine: therefore Sir,
You that are for the King, as you pretend,
Shew us th' Imperative mood or warrant for her death,
Or we ſhall put you into the Optativa mood,
By puniſhment to wiſh your ſelves dead oftner
Or more times than bona fide there be Tenſes
In all the Moods of all my Accidences.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: For my part Ile forgive them, if they will
Deliver truely who corrupted them,
To rid the world of this weary burden; that I may pray for them.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: Can ſuch a goodneſs deſerve ſo fowl a Cenſure?

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.p: But firſt tell me: Are not you two the men that gave falſe evidence at my Arraignment touching injur'd Sforza?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: We gave no evidence, nor falſe nor true.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: No countrey-woman, they had no ſuch Beards. But I will try if I can make'm like'em: O rare! what a nimble Barber am I? Lod. They are the ſelf-ſame men, the two caſhier'd Lieutenants that Sforza ſhould have hang'd for mutinies in the late Wars.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: What hinders now their execution?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Digito compeſce labellum: ſilence good Pedro.
I do commend your zeal: but Periculum eſt in via,
We will walk ſafely: for this time therefore wee'l do onely thus,
Double our guards upon 'em, and away to priſon with them,

l.hi: Eſt locus in carcere quod Tullianum appellatur.

sp.l: We will preſume to know who 'twas that ſet you awork, before you go,

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: You will be made to anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: A word more, wee'l hang you preſently, and anſwer that too: Abite hinc in malam Rem: away with 'm.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: Ah Rogues, wee'l hamper ye.

sp.speaker: Pogg.
sp.l: Kill a woman 'cauſe ſhe was a Queen?

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.p: Wee'l hamper ye, and halter ye, and do ye hear? hang ye.
sp.stage: Exeunt Lollio and Poggio, with Fabio and Strozza.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Abi hinc & malam rem, away with'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: As I am Erudite, idoneus Adoleſcens,

A very towardly Juvenis. Cupis at
que doceri?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Wilt thou be a Scholar?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: After you is manners.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Now by mine intellect, diſcreetly ſpoken.
Be but my Pupil, I will make thee one,
And dip thy Caput in pure Helicon.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Pray what's my Caput? and what's your Helicon?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Still a deſire to learn: this is no Fool.
And by the company hee's in, I do ſuſpect,
Simile non eſt Idem: hee's too wiſe,
To be the thing he ſeems but in diſguiſe:
Some Lord of Court, his outſide non obſtante.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It is confeſs'd Sir, I am Lodovico,
Somtimes a Lord of Court when this was Queen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: O Oedipus! I meant this Juvenal.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No truely Sir, your Simile non eſt Idem.
I am no Lord, what ere you like me to.
What I may paſs for in the Country I know not,
At Court I was a Fool when ſhe was Queen.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVe dare not call her Queen now: but while we
Relieve her not, though we aſſociate her,
VVe are the Kings true Subjects: and with your leave,
Diſclaiming of all Honourable Titles,
VVe'll live amongſt ye.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: O gracious woman, ſo I may ſafely call you,
VVho once preſerv'd my life.

sp.speaker: Eul.
sp.l: Mention not that.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: I ought not to conceal it: therefore know
That ſome years paſt being imploy'd to Court
To render the Kings Rents for this Province:
VVhich though I duely did, there was a Lord,
A ſtrange officious one, that charg'd me deeply,
And all our Province, with deteſted breach
Of our Allegiance: at which my rage
Baniſh'd my reaſon, and confounded ſo
My ſenſes, that without reſpect of Perſon,
Or Place, which was the Danger of the Law,
I ſtruck him there in Court: and was adjudg'd
To ſuffer death for't, till you won my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: VVere you that man?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And 'twas my
Cozen Lord'I warrant that you box'd.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: 'Tis he that braggs ſo much his truth unto the Crown; I need not name him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Sed nunc quid ſequitur? Pray mark the iſſue of this Court quarrell. By the way,'tis well you have renounc'd all qualitie of Court.
sp.l: Here were no living for you elſe; for know,
Since this mans trouble, not a Gentleman,
Much leſs a Courtier dares breath amongſt us,
But be as you pretend and write, but Yeoman:
You ſhall live Jovially with us and welcome,
At your own charge, your own Viaticum.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: We have laid up
The murderous minded men in dungeon deep,
Clogg'd them with Ploughchains, Fetters and Horſelocks.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: VVe'l teach 'm to kill Queens:

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: VVe mean this woman, this diſcarded Queen.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: For all the Feaſts, the Triumphs and the Glories
That have been ſpent, at price of great Eſtates,
In celebration of my high Advancement;
For all the King has in his preſent being,
His Love to boot, aſſur'd in higheſt meaſure;
Me-thinks there is yet wanting an Addition
To crown my Happineſs: all's not ſafe hereafter;
I cannot ſafely ſay I am his Wife,
While th'other ſeems contented with a Life. Flavello!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Moſt Mighty Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: O moſt Coeleſtial ſound!
Here's all your buſineſs granted.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Greateſt and beſt of Queens! All?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: See the Kings hand to all: do you miſtruſt me?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I onely look for the poor womans Pardon
That kill'd her Husband for his gelding the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.p: If you but manage the Profits of my Favours with a diſcreet Hand now, you may ſoon finde the difference between a Mignion, and the Son of a Diſh-Maker.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: I finde it in your Gifts, my bounteous Goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Oh Divine!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: And would preſume that
I my ſelf were worthy
A place i'th' Kalendar, might I do you Service,
That merited the ſmalleſt of your Graces.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Do you know the village where that woman lives?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Who, ſacred Deitie?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: I'm very ſick to name her or her Son.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: O Eulalia; yes, the very Houſe: 'tis in your Majeſties way now, as you paſs to Nicoſia: the King is ready, Madam, and calls away; he longs to be at the end of his journey, to perform his Duty in the three Grants belong to you.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: O but that Woman, and that hated Boy.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: Eulalia▪ Madam?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: Thou art a baſe
Ingrateful Villain to name her to me;
Thou hear'ſt me ſay, I dare not ſpeak her name,
Yet thou dar'ſt ſtab mine Ears again, with it.
Had ſome receiv'd the Favours thou haſt done,
Or could but dream of half▪thou'rt like to have,
I ſhould not fear her Ghoſt; but thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.l: O let me take new ſpirit from your hand,
And ſay unto your ſelf, She is ſure dead.
But the King comes. I am enough inſpir'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will not onely have you guiltleſs, Sir,
But free from leaſt ſuſpect; let but a ſpark
Of Diſcontent appear upon your Look,
I'll rip the hollow cave that holds the fire,
And with Death quench it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: I beſeech your Highneſs,
If any alteration in my looks
Be found, or read, let it as well be conſtrued,
It grows but from a filial fear t'offend.
I have forgot I had another Mother:
And humbly at the Feet of this I honour,
I beg her Ayd, to win your Favour towards me.
Moſt gracious Madam, if you knew the Truth,
The fair ſincerity I bear in Duty
Towards your Highneſs—

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: For what reſpect, young Prince?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: The principal i'th' World: For that you have
My Fathers Love; and but to Wrong or Grieve you,
Were Stripes or Wounds to his Affection.
So much of my late Mother I remember,
To yield a Reverence to his Contentment, and ſhall for ever.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: My Lord, my Love, what pretty meaning have you?
Do you bring your Son to mock me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ha! my Alinda, he's no Son of mine,
That with leſſe Adoration dares look up
On thy Divinity, then the Aegyptians
Gave to the Sun it ſelf: but an out-caſt Baſtard,
And of the daring Giants ignorant Nature,
That war'd againſt the Gods.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.p: I would not move your Anger: pray let this win your Reconcilement.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O thou art gentle, and the life of Sweetneſs:
Come, my Alinda, I was calling you
To our intended Journey to Nicoſta,
Where ſolemnly I will perform my Vow,
To grant the three demands I promis'd you,
In the full view of our Nobility.
Which by the Cuſtome of my Predeceſſors
Have ratified and confirm'd the Power
Of Queens, and made them abſolute: have you thought
To ask things worthy of your Dignity,
Wherein I fully may declare my Bounty?

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: I, Sir, ſhall be ſo reaſonable, that
I doubt not upon the way, or there at very inſtant,
To crave paſt my Deſert.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O you are modeſt: but ask home, Alinda.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: And by the way, Sir, let it be my Suit,
We give a Viſit to diſtreſt Eulalia;
Wherein we may do Charity fitting Princes;
(We may perhaps give Order for her Burial)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art all Goodneſs: Come, all Friends, Gonzago:
But thank her Clemency.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: An Earldome be thou ſure of, wiſe Flavello,
To add to thy improvements: Though it be
No full Diſcovery, I'll make it ſerve,
As I will faſhion it, to excellent uſe.
Poyſon or Sword thou heardſt him ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Elav.
sp.l: And in a menacing way: Now what may be
Conjectur'd by ſuch words, from men whoſe looks
Shew diſcontent againſt your Mightineſs,
Reſts moſt conſiderable.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: VVrite, Flavello, write,
VVrite by that Copy in a States-Man's hand.
Alas, good men! I dare even ſwear for them,
How ere thoſe words might fall in their diſcourſe,
They had no thought of me: yet this ſurmiſe
Gives me an hint to try her Loyaltie,
Or make her once more guiltie: for my State
Stands by the King, as unto her his hate.
Read it Flavello.

q.p: Moſt Royal and moſt wronged Soveraign Miſtreſs, be happily aſſured that the time of your Reſtoration is at hand: and thatby no loſs means then the death of that ſhe-monſter that uſurps your Dignitie. All ſhall be determin'd at Nicoſia, by
Your devoted Servant unto death. Nameleſs.

sp.speaker: Alind.
sp.l: 'Tis well.
It needs no ſuperſcription: only ſeal it,
And think of your directions and diſguiſe.
'Tis but your half days journey: and be ſure
VVe are not far behind you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I flie, my Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Now to the King,
Of whoſe deſpight I ſtill muſt ſharp the ſting.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No news of Lodovico yet, Horatio?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: None ſince he ſtole from Court upon the Baniſhment
Of that falſe wicked woman, whom I cannot
Name to your face or forehead, but I tremble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Becauſe you fear all horned Beaſts.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Loyalty forbid,
And my infallible Truth unto the Crown,
But I were ſenſible of the injury.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I know thy Loyalty: but as for Lodovico,
How was my Judgement wrong'd in him!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I thought my ſelf as ſafe in that mans Counſel—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And ſo did I,
By my lov'd Loyalty, think my ſelf ſafe
In his Advices—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet methought he had
A kinde of ſlyneſs in his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, he had ever a kind of a ſlie look.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That ſtill methought I had a Genius
That check'd my forward love, and did inform me
That he would prove diſloyal: and for that cauſe,
To ſpeak plain truth, I never lov'd him truely.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVill your Majeſty believe me? I would I might never riſe
Into your Favour (and that I would not ſay
For all the Traytors Lands in your Kingdom,
VVhich were no ſmall reward) if that were not
Mine very own conceit of Lodovico
That Traytor; hang him: what ſhould I call him leſs?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet 'twas given out you lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: So 'twas thought your Highneſs did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And that he was your yoak-fellow in the State.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, when he's hang'd he ſhall be King. How Horatio?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your Majeſty knows my thoughts: nay I thank my creation, I was ever
Juſt of your Majeſties mind from my Nativitie,
And in that faith Ile die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here's a true Stateſman now!
Go, ſend Gonzago to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My ſweet yong Prince?
I ſhall: but ere I go,
Let me inform your Highneſs in my thoughts
Of the ſweet Prince Gonzago: if ever King
VVas happy in a Son, you are in him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go, call him to me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Cheriſh him, good my Lord:
Hee'l be a ſure ſtaff to you in your Age,
And prove a Stateſman quickly: I cannot think,
Except in him and your undoubted Queen,
Petruccio and my ſelf, True Loyalty lives.
And here he comes: obedience in his Face
Moſt brightly ſhining.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wait without Horatio.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My dread Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Did you attempt
Againſt my ſtrict command to viſit Sforza?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: It is moſt true, I did.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You are a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Gracious Heaven forbid it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What was your purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: Firſt on my knees let me implore your Royal Pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: My end was noble: as I thought, well ſuiting
The Honour of a Prince: I would have ſearch'd
Into the ſecrets of his heart by queſtions,
VVhether he had intended or conceived
Treaſon againſt your Highneſs, as it is
Preſum'd he did: for which he was committed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My ſelf for that was his Accuſer;
How durſt you then make a ſcruple at it?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Still relying on your Pardon, I had thought
T'have won confeſſion of it from himſelf.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Suppoſe he had confeſs'd it?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: I had then
Concluded there had been a Probabilitie
Of my poor mothers falſehood: yet I would have put
That Queſtion to him next.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And ſay
He had confeſs'd that too?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Then had I ſav'd
Your Laws a needleſs labour in his death;
And with the ſame hand made that mother childleſs,
That by her folly forfeited her Husband.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: VVas that your reſolution? but ſuppoſe
He had denied all?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: All had then been nothing
But a Scandal to my mother and himſelf:
So good a Souldier would not be a lyer
To ſave an abject life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirrah, you are
His Baſtard, not my ſon, in doing this.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: You are my King, would I could ſay, my Father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Within there!
Horatio, would you think it? this young ſtripling
Takes part againſt me with that Traytor Sforza.

sp.speaker: Hor.
